answer: Certain materials should not be removed from libraries, such as books, music, movies, and magazines. These forms of media provide valuable insights into the real world and can help individuals understand different perspectives and experiences. For example, books and music can offer lessons on overcoming challenges and embracing diversity. Movies can teach viewers about empathy and social interactions, while magazines can provide valuable information on important issues and potential consequences of certain actions. By keeping these materials accessible in libraries, people have the opportunity to learn from the experiences of others and make informed decisions in their own lives. Removing such materials would limit the ability of individuals to broaden their horizons and gain valuable knowledge, ultimately hindering personal growth and understanding of the world around them. Therefore, it is important to preserve a diverse range of materials in libraries to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to learn and grow from the stories and perspectives shared through books, music, movies, and magazines.

Censorship in libraries is a controversial topic that has sparked debates for years. Some argue that certain materials should be removed from libraries to protect children and uphold moral values. However, I firmly believe that censorship in libraries should not be allowed.  Libraries serve as a place for individuals to access a wide range of information and ideas. By censoring materials, we limit the diversity of thought and hinder intellectual freedom. It is essential for individuals to have the opportunity to explore different perspectives and form their own opinions.  Furthermore, censorship in libraries sets a dangerous precedent. It gives the power to a select few to determine what is appropriate for the general public to access. This can lead to the suppression of important information and ideas that may challenge the status quo.  In a democratic society, freedom of expression is a fundamental right. Libraries should be a reflection of this principle, providing access to a variety of materials without fear of censorship. It is up to individuals to make informed choices about what they read or view, rather than having those choices made for them.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries undermines intellectual freedom and restricts access to diverse ideas. It is essential that libraries remain open spaces for individuals to explore, learn, and grow. Let us uphold the principles of democracy and resist censorship in all its forms.

Do you think that libraries should remove certain materials off the shelves? People have different opinions on what is good and what is bad. I have read and seen a lot of books in my lifetime. I hear people telling me, "oh, don't read that book, it's a bad book." But I ask myself, do I know it's a bad book when I haven't even given it a chance? There are some books, music, movies, and magazines out there that are offensive. Yet we still want to read, listen, watch, and look at them. If we tried to remove all the offensive books from the libraries, we wouldn't have anything left on the shelves. Katherine Paterson said, "If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf that work I abhor, then you also have exactly the same right, and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us." Katherine Paterson makes a great point with her quote. Why should we have to remove a book if just some people think it's offensive? Ask yourself the question again, do you know it's a bad book when you haven't even given it a chance? Don't judge a book by what you hear. Find out what your own opinion is.

In @DATE1's world, there are many things found offensive. Everyone has their own opinion on what is offensive and what is not. Many parents are becoming upset because they think their children are viewing things that they should not. Other people are upset because they think the libraries are offending their culture or way of life. This is even taken to the extreme where people want censorship on libraries to avoid this, which is wrong.  Some people are becoming concerned about the materials in libraries. They find these things to be offensive. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but there really is nothing anyone can do if someone is offended. The world is a public place and everywhere we go, something might be found offensive. The library is a place for study. It is never intended to offend someone, or bring bad to the world. It is simply a place to inform, and if someone is offended by what they see, they should stay away from the library.  I have been to the library many times, none of which have I ever seen anything offensive. Everything I have ever witnessed at the library is for learning and research. There are certain sections in the library. If a parent does not want their child seeing something, they should keep their child in the children's section. I can assure you, there is nothing offensive in the children's section, or else the library would not have it in that section. The owners of these libraries know what is going to upset people and what will not. If there was truly offensive materials in the library, those materials would be taken out.  Also, if a person complains, and the materials are removed, it could lessen someone else's chance getting the materials they need. One person could think the material is offensive, but someone else might want to learn more about it. If one is offended by a certain material, all they simply must do, is not look at it. The library can be compared to a big computer. One can basically find anything there. Asking the library to censor their materials is like asking the internet to censor theirs. It is a way of learning and researching and it would be almost impossible to censor everything there.  Everyone is going to be offended some point in their life. If the libraries removed everything that could offend someone, they would have no materials left. People need to stop being so easily offended and realize the library is not trying to harm anyone. There does not need to be any censorship in libraries. It is simply trying to teach people about the world and let them enjoy books, music, movies, or whatever else one might go to the library to find.

In life, there are always things that may offend us, such as books, movies, music, and other forms of media. While it may be difficult to get over these offensive things, they can ultimately make us stronger. It's important to remember that the content that offends us may reflect someone else's truth or life, and it's not the author's intention to harm us.   Libraries are filled with a variety of materials, and it's not fair to remove something just because it offends us. Others may find value in the material that we dislike, and removing it could hurt the authors and publishers who worked hard to create it. Additionally, offensive material can open our eyes to different perspectives and help us see the world in a new light.  Personally, I have experienced being offended by a book only to realize later that it helped me gain a new understanding and change my views. It's important to push ourselves out of our comfort zones and be open to different ideas and viewpoints. Life is too short to be constantly worried about feeling offended.  Every book, magazine, movie, and piece of music has its place and can be valuable to someone. Instead of removing offensive material, we should embrace the opportunity to learn and grow from it. By being open to different perspectives, we can enrich our lives and become more understanding individuals. Let's not be quick to judge or remove things that offend us, but rather seek to learn and expand our horizons.

A lot of content today is censored because of the material found in books, music, movies, and magazines. This censorship can be addressed by implementing specific sections for different audiences, such as adults and children. By creating designated areas for potentially offensive content, individuals can choose whether or not to engage with it. Additionally, age restrictions can be put in place to ensure that young children are not exposed to inappropriate material. Ultimately, this approach can help cater to varying preferences and sensitivities while still allowing individuals to access a wide range of content. Hopefully, libraries will consider implementing these measures to effectively manage censorship concerns in the future.

How would you feel if your favorite book was removed from the shelves of your school or public library? Many students, like myself, would find this discouraging and disastrous, as it could lead to a diminished love of reading, crushed individuality, and a divided population. Censorship should not dictate which books are available in libraries, as it can have detrimental effects on society.  Popular series like the beloved Harry Potter books by J.K. Rowling have faced calls for censorship due to their portrayal of witchcraft, which goes against some religious beliefs. However, banning books like these can prevent students from exploring new worlds and developing a passion for reading. All books have the potential to ignite a love for literature, and restricting access to certain titles can hinder the intellectual growth of individuals and communities.  If censorship is allowed to prevail, it raises questions about who gets to decide which books are banned and on what grounds. This power struggle can lead to division and conflicts within society, as people become entrenched in their beliefs and refuse to consider opposing viewpoints. Limiting access to diverse opinions and ideas stifles creativity and undermines the value of individual thought.  Each person has a unique perspective on what is considered offensive, and censoring books would be akin to suppressing individuality and personal beliefs. Embracing diversity of thought and allowing for a variety of perspectives enriches society and fosters a culture of open-mindedness. Free thought is a fundamental right that should be protected, and censorship threatens to erode this essential aspect of human expression.  In conclusion, censorship poses a threat to individuality, personal beliefs, and the joy of reading. Rather than imposing restrictions on what books are available, it is important to respect the diversity of opinions and allow individuals the freedom to explore different ideas. Removing books from libraries based on subjective criteria only serves to limit intellectual growth and diminish the richness of our cultural landscape. So, imagine if your favorite book disappeared from all libraries - it would be a disservice to you and to society as a whole.

Taking certain materials off the shelves of a library because someone finds them offensive is a contentious issue. While some may argue for the removal of offensive materials to create a more inclusive environment, others believe that censorship goes against the principles of intellectual freedom.   In my opinion, books, movies, music, magazines, or computer access should generally remain on the shelves of a library. Just because something is deemed offensive by one person does not mean it should be unavailable to others who may find value in it. Moreover, what is considered offensive is subjective and can vary greatly from person to person.   However, there are instances where materials should be removed, such as if they are severely damaged or promote dangerous behavior like drug use without consequences. In such cases, it is reasonable to consider removing them to maintain the integrity of the library's collection.   Ultimately, libraries serve as repositories of knowledge and information, and it is essential to uphold the principles of intellectual freedom and access to diverse perspectives. While some materials may be deemed offensive by some, they should generally be available to those who seek them out. It is important to strike a balance between protecting intellectual freedom and ensuring the quality and appropriateness of the library's collection.

The idea of the removal of 'offensive' material from libraries is understandable. Some believe that this material is not appropriate for anyone to view. However, because we all have different opinions on what is offensive, I believe that books found to be offensive should not be removed from the shelves of the library.  First, I believe that if this policy were to be in effect in libraries, there would not be many books left on the shelf. Offensive is a relative word. What @MONTH1 be offensive to one person @MONTH1 not be to another. Every has a different opinion on different matters based on their beliefs and life experiences. Many books have things people disagree with, but expressing this is a part of freedom of speech. Therefore, if everyone complained that they found a certain book or movie to be offensive, there would hardly be anything left, as Katherine Paterson said.  The purpose of a library is to provide the people who go to the library a resource. If the sources were censored in such a way, it would be hard to get information. Sometimes, it is beneficial, even, to read an opposing view or side to have more knowledge on a certain topic and see things from a different perspective.  However, some books @MONTH1 not be entirely appropriate to certain people. For example, some material in the library @MONTH1 not be best for small children to read or view. In this case, I do not necessarily feel that they should be removed from the shelves rather than placed in an area these children do not have access to.  Having books, music, movies, or magazines removed from the shelves if they are found to be offensive is in my opinion, a ridiculous notion. It hinders expression. People have different opinions about what is offensive to them and it would be very boring if everyone thought the same. If someone finds something particularly offensive, I believe they just should not view it.

All authors write for a purpose, whether it be to teach, entertain, or persuade an audience. No author writes something and says, 'I hope no one picks this off of the shelf!' So, if every author wants to express something through their writing, then why should we not let them be heard. We all have the freedom of speech, right? So, why not the freedom of writing? Libraries should not remove a book, music, movie, or magazine from the shelf just because they found it offensive.  Everyone will read a book that they don't like, its natural, but that doesn't mean that no one will like it. Authors write for an audience, but maybe you are not in that audience; so, it doesn't appeal to you and might even seem offensive. Not everyone believes in the same ideas. You could think about an issue one way and your neighbor think about it a totally different way.  Like for instance, you're reading a book about a young girl that is going through many problems in her life. She has gotten into some really horrible situations. Some of these situations you read about are so awful that you wouldn't want anyone else to read it. But, did you ever think that maybe there's another girl that is or has gone through some of these same situations. Maybe this girl comes to a library and finds this book; suddenly she finds guidance in it. She finds something she can depend on in her life that she's never had before. She feels like she has a friend in this book that can handle the situations with her. So, would you really want to take that book off of the shelf and not let that girl ever find her guidance?  Situations happen like this all of the time. People find something special in what they read that other people might not find. When a librarian takes a book off of that shelf, an opportunity is forever gone. No one will ever be able to learn of what was to become of that writing and of those ideas. We all have a right to learn, to explore new ideas, and to expand our minds. No one should have the right to take that away. In conclusion, the freedom of writing should be upheld, and all voices should be allowed to be heard, even if they may be deemed offensive by some.

I have noticed that some movies are offensive to certain people, such as movies that are about supernatural beings that some individuals do not believe in. However, some movies are appropriate for certain age groups, like those rated 'R' which are not suitable for children. Magazines can also be offensive, with sections that may talk negatively about public figures. In these cases, I believe some magazines should be removed from shelves.   When it comes to books, I do not see a reason to have them removed from shelves. While some books may contain graphic content, they are not necessarily offensive. However, there may be books that some individuals find offensive, such as those that depict poverty in a negative light. Ultimately, I believe that whether or not a book, magazine, or movie should be removed depends on its content and the impact it has on society. It is important to consider the perspectives of different individuals when making decisions about what should be available to the public.

Personally, I don't think libraries, movie stores, etc., should be selling any of the items just mentioned if they are found offensive to the public. I believe that it offends many people, especially senior citizens and children who shouldn't have to be exposed to inappropriate material. In my opinion, individuals should be at least eighteen years old in order to buy or rent certain books, music, movies, or magazines. The economy is already struggling, and the younger generation being raised should not have memories of offensive content from their childhood.   I strongly feel that music has the most influence on a person, as constantly listening to foul language can have a lasting impact on an individual. Similarly, movies can also greatly influence people's thoughts and behaviors. For example, exposure to violence in movies can lead a child to believe that harming others is acceptable since they saw a character get away with it without consequences.  In conclusion, while I believe in the freedom for individuals to choose what they read, watch, or listen to, I think there should be age restrictions on certain content. Additionally, anything deemed offensive by citizens should be placed in a separate area within stores or libraries to ensure that those who wish to access such material can do so without exposing others to offensive content.

A library is a place you can go to read, write, and relax. Nowadays, many people take for granted the knowledge that can be obtained there. Even more of the knowledge to be learned is being stripped away and cut down by censorship. Censorship can eliminate many varieties of reading materials that people can learn from and enjoy.   First of all, removing classics from the shelves of libraries because they offend certain people is completely unwarranted. If they offend you then do not read them. It is as simple as that. Many books offend people because they are not in agreement with their morals or beliefs. A great example of this is the Harry Potter series. Harry Potter is a bestselling series with over a million copies that have been sold worldwide; however, it does not correlate with many people's beliefs. Therefore those people boycott the series.   I remember several years ago I attended a Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire party at the local library to celebrate the next book in the series being released. While I was at the library there was a gigantic storm brewing. Now most people would think that it was only a storm, but the people in town who did not like the Harry Potter books blamed it on the party. They said that we were worshipping the devil and God brought the storm to tell us that what we were doing was wrong. I know many people do not like the Harry Potter series because there is witchcraft and wizardry in it, but that does not mean that they should blame natural occurrences on a book!  Even great novels like the Catcher in the Rye should not be banned because of their content. For a while, Catcher in the Rye was reading material for school, but then the 'morality police' banned it because it was about a crazy person. Books should not be required to meet everyone's personal standards.   Consequently, what Katherine Paterson states is true. If we ban books because we do not agree with them or find them suitable, eventually there will not be any left to check out at the library. Although there could be a way to compromise. If the books with questionable content had a sticker on them telling the reader that, then it could benefit both sides.   In conclusion, eliminating books is not a good idea because of how beneficial they are to us all, especially children. When I was young I would always want to be read to and when I continued to age I would always read. While I was in middle school every day I would have a book with me to read. Books allow the reader to travel to far off places or see what it would be like to walk in someone else's shoes. Books are a gateway to another world. Why take that magic away from children?

Yes and no, some materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc, should be voted upon by citizens to be removed from shelves. Some materials in these categories should be removed if they are offensive to me and others, but it will take time to get them removed if others enjoy them. Music with violent themes can influence teenagers negatively, leading them to engage in harmful activities like selling drugs. While it may be challenging to stop the production of such music, collective efforts can help prevent the spread of harmful content. For instance, if an artist produces offensive material, individuals should voice their concerns and work towards removing it from circulation. It is important to stand up against content that promotes destructive behavior to safeguard communities and create better opportunities for individuals. Ultimately, addressing offensive content requires collaboration and a commitment to upholding values that prioritize the well-being of society.

When discussing censorship in libraries, it is important to consider the role of the community in determining what materials are available. While library staff play a significant role in managing the collection, the input of the community members who actually utilize the library is crucial. It is essential to respect diverse opinions and preferences when curating library materials.  While everyone is entitled to their own opinions, there are certain instances where censorship may be necessary. For example, offensive music that could potentially harm or disturb library patrons should be carefully evaluated and potentially removed from the collection. This does not mean that all music should be banned, but rather that materials with the potential to cause harm should be considered for removal.  In conclusion, community involvement is essential in determining library materials, and censorship should be approached with sensitivity and consideration for the well-being of library patrons. Offensive materials should be carefully evaluated and potentially removed to ensure a safe and inclusive library environment for all.

Dear Newspaper,  How would you feel if someone wrote a book about how bad newspapers are, tearing you down so much that no one wanted to touch another newspaper? Should offensive materials be available for thousands of people to read? I believe that certain offensive materials such as books, music, movies, etc., should not be allowed on library shelves, let alone be available for public consumption.  Imagine if a sexist book ended up in the hands of an innocent child who could be influenced by its harmful content. That child could end up living a life that the book portrays. As a parent, I would never want my children exposed to such harmful reading materials until they have a clear understanding of right and wrong.  Now, consider if a book promoting racist ideologies fell into the hands of someone who already harbors such beliefs. That book could fuel their discriminatory thoughts and lead to harmful actions towards others. This could result in violence, discrimination, and perpetuate harmful stereotypes.  All it takes is one book to cause significant harm and perpetuate negative beliefs. That is why it is crucial to reconsider the availability of offensive materials in libraries. These materials have the potential to influence individuals in detrimental ways, leading to real-life consequences that can be devastating.  In conclusion, the impact of offensive materials on individuals and society as a whole cannot be underestimated. It is essential to take proactive measures to prevent the spread of harmful ideologies and protect vulnerable individuals from the negative influence of such materials. Let us strive to create a safe and inclusive environment where everyone can access materials that promote understanding, empathy, and respect.  Sincerely, [Your Name]

A lot of people in school may come across books or magazines that contain offensive content, such as profanity or racial slurs. While some may find it humorous, others may be deeply offended. It is important for libraries and schools to consider the impact of such material on their students. Parents have the right to object to their children being exposed to inappropriate content and should be able to have such material removed from school libraries. Additionally, movies and music that contain offensive content should be reviewed and potentially altered or removed if they are found to be offensive to a significant number of people. It is crucial to prioritize the comfort and well-being of students and ensure that they are not subjected to content that makes them uncomfortable or goes against their values. Ultimately, if a book, song, movie, or any form of entertainment offends a considerable portion of the audience, it should be addressed promptly and removed to uphold respect and sensitivity towards all individuals.

I believe that certain books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves simply because someone finds them offensive. People choose what they want to read, listen to, watch, or purchase, so if something appears offensive, they can simply choose not to engage with it. Additionally, when visiting the library or a store, individuals are typically seeking something that aligns with their interests, so they are likely to avoid materials that seem offensive to them. Ultimately, censorship based on individual sensitivities should not dictate what is available for others to access. Everyone has the right to choose their own entertainment without interference from others' opinions on what is offensive.

If the people that are publishing and writing these articles in these magazines then yes, they can feel offensive about the things inside the magazine or books. These people are going to always find something or some rumor to start a big fight about these things, those people are called 'haters'. They can find an easy way to get something started just like that, That's why before I buy a magazine, I take a look inside first and see if I'm interested in buying that specific certain book or magazine. If I don't like the things that I see inside of it, then I will not buy it, it's as simple as that. If they are offensive, they should immediately be removed from the newsstands on the streets of various locations.

I think that all the bad books, music, magazines, and movies should be removed from libraries. Children can easily access these materials without understanding the harmful content they contain. Parents do not want their children exposed to inappropriate themes such as sex, explicit language, or violence. It is essential for libraries to be mindful of the materials they offer to ensure the protection of young minds. In addition to books, music, and movies, magazines also play a role in exposing children to inappropriate content, such as pornography. Overall, it is crucial to eliminate such materials from libraries to safeguard the well-being of children and promote a safe and healthy learning environment.

Dear news people,  I believe that individuals should have the freedom to write whatever they want in books without facing unnecessary criticism. In a free country, people should have the liberty to express themselves through their writing, regardless of the content. Readers have the choice to pick up a book or not based on their personal preferences, so there is no need to create a fuss over books that do not align with one's beliefs. It is simply a matter of choosing to read something else that resonates more with them instead of making a big deal out of a book that they do not agree with. Ultimately, it is a waste of time and energy to complain about something that can easily be avoided by choosing a different book to read.  In conclusion, rather than causing unnecessary conflict over the content of books, individuals should simply set aside ones that they do not appreciate and opt for literature that they find more suitable. It is important to respect the freedom of expression and choice when it comes to reading material, and not dwell on books that do not align with personal beliefs.  Thank you.

I think that books, magazines, papers, etc. should not be removed from libraries because some people like to read them. Some individuals feel that reading a book about their problems will help them get through whatever difficulties they are facing. Many people often express feelings of stress and depression, and having access to these resources can provide valuable support. If certain materials are deemed offensive, individuals who find them objectionable can simply choose not to read them. People have the right to access a wide range of books and other materials, and those who feel uncomfortable with certain content can easily avoid it. Ultimately, it is important to respect the diverse preferences and needs of library users and allow them to make their own choices about what to read. Libraries serve as valuable resources for individuals seeking knowledge, understanding, and personal growth, and it is essential to uphold the principles of intellectual freedom and access to information for all.

Hello, my name is @CAPS1. I feel that there should be any genre of media in libraries. If they call it a 'media center,' then why censor any media. People know to read the back of a book to see if they want it, so if they see something they don't like, they are able to put it back on the shelf. People say The @CAPS2 and the @CAPS3 inspired @CAPS4 @PERSON2 to kill @PERSON1; that is completely speculated. It's all a matter of 'he said she said.' I feel there should be sections for different age groups, but to censor literature is just un-@CAPS5. There should be a parent supervising children @NUM1 and younger because, ultimately, it comes down to the children not being exposed to something they're not ready for. There are some magazines and movies that I feel shouldn't be in libraries, including pornography, non-educational movies, @CAPS6 @CAPS7, and social networks. I'm not saying to let kids listen to murderous music and jump off of the terrace, but shouldn't some leeway on books. This is an approved message. Thank you for your time. Goodbye.

Books should not be removed from shelves simply because some individuals may find their content inappropriate. Instead, these materials should be placed in a separate section where only adults can access them. Children often imitate what they see in books, movies, and other media, so it is crucial to shield them from harmful influences. By keeping explicit content out of reach, we can protect young minds from being exposed to inappropriate material and prevent them from engaging in risky behaviors. Parents can also play a role in monitoring what their children read and watch, ensuring that they are exposed to age-appropriate content. Ultimately, while freedom of expression is important, it is equally essential to safeguard the innocence and well-being of our youth by carefully regulating the content they consume.

I think almost every movie might offend someone in some way. So if you want to take every movie off the shelf, then go ahead. Everyone has different tastes in movies, music, books, etc. If the music offends you, don't listen to it. If a book does, don't read it. It's as simple as that. I don't think they should remove books, music, movies, etc. that could offend someone. If you were to remove all the things that might interest people nowadays, then there wouldn't be anything to entertain kids, potentially leading them to get into trouble.   Everyone has the right to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to. If something offends them, they can simply avoid it. Children should also have the freedom to choose what they read, listen to, or watch. Exposure to different materials can broaden their perspectives and help them understand that life isn't always easy. People have different tastes, and as long as something doesn't offend them, they should be able to enjoy it without judgment.   In conclusion, people should be able to consume what they want, even if some find it offensive. Exposure to potentially offensive material can help individuals navigate life's challenges and understand different perspectives. It's essential to respect everyone's right to choose their entertainment without imposing restrictions based on personal preferences.

The world is filled with offensive material, but it is essential to preserve a wide range of knowledge in libraries, even if some content may be deemed inappropriate by certain individuals. Exposure to diverse information is crucial for individuals to make informed decisions and understand the world around them. While some materials may be controversial or potentially harmful, they still have value in providing a comprehensive view of society. It is important to strike a balance between necessary knowledge and purely entertainment-based content, removing only those items that serve no purpose. Ultimately, each person's perception and values will determine what is considered acceptable, highlighting the ongoing challenge of navigating the complexities of censorship and information access in our society.

People are entitled to their own opinions about things, and what one person finds offensive, another may not. Libraries should have the freedom to stock materials that may interest and educate individuals, regardless of potential offense. If we catered to every individual's sensitivities, libraries would have very limited content. It is natural for people to find fault with almost anything that is put out into the world.  I have come across nonfiction books and movies based on true events that use language some may find offensive. However, how can we effectively express emotions and educate others without possibly causing offense? Teaching history, especially events as dark as slavery and the Holocaust, requires a full and honest narrative, even if it may upset some individuals.  I firmly believe that such materials should be available in libraries for those who wish to learn and understand history and human experiences. If someone finds them objectionable, they have the option to avoid those specific resources. Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, and it is essential to have a diverse range of perspectives and information available for those who seek it.

If people find books offensive, they should simply choose not to read them. Removing offensive books from shelves would leave bookstores barren, depriving readers of valuable literary works. Many esteemed authors incorporate offensive language or themes in their writing, but censoring these works would eliminate some of the greatest material available. For instance, in the book "American Psycho," which contains offensive content towards gays, removing it from shelves would mean losing a significant piece of literature. It is essential to respect the diversity of perspectives in literature and allow individuals to make their own choices about what they read. Freedom of expression and the availability of diverse viewpoints are crucial in fostering a vibrant literary landscape.

A book is more than words or happenings; they're adventures and stories that travel from one person to another. I find it amazing how someone from one country could write a book, then someone from another country could read it. Inspiring stories reach from one person to another in books, music, and movies; I believe things like that help shape us into who we are today.  There are many problems with entertainment today in my opinion. They include things now that show a lot of violence and intimacy; which may not be fit for some people. I don't think they should take them off the shelves, but simply rate them so everyone knows what to expect. Movies are rated because some people don't want or need to see what will happen in them. While some of it is not appropriate, other parts of it guide us. It's almost like they are preparing us for the worst, but are hoping for the best. We see what happens to one person in these articles of entertainment, and it helps us to make sure we don't make the same mistake.  I also believe that many stories and movies inspire us to be better people and to reach for our dreams. If we see that one person can do it, we think, why can't I? Where would we be in the world if no one encouraged or pushed someone else to do what they wanted? Entertainment pushes that concept, but adds everything in it to show the reality of it. Whether these things have offense or harsh contents to them, they still prepare and help us to battle through everyday life. Ultimately, entertainment serves as a source of inspiration, guidance, and motivation for individuals to strive for their goals and become the best version of themselves.

I don't believe that certain books, music, magazines, or movies should be removed just because they are found offensive. If something offends me, that is my own issue to deal with. Society will always rediscover and bring back items that were once deemed offensive. Everything has educational value, even if it may be offensive to some. Whether something should be removed from shelves depends on personal beliefs and views. It's important to remember that what is offensive to one person may not be offensive to another. It's easier to live with the fact that not everyone will agree on what is offensive. Maybe the creator intended for their work to be offensive, or maybe they didn't. It all comes down to how individuals interpret the content. In the end, nothing should be removed from shelves, as removing one thing may lead to removing everything. It's important to respect diverse perspectives and opinions on what is considered offensive.

I absolutely do not think that any book, movie, magazine, music, etc., should be removed from the shelf because they find it offensive. If we do that, then all the books would be off the shelf. Sometimes the really good books are when they are offensive, because they are actually telling you what they really believe in.  I remember when I was twelve, the news was saying that a school was taking books off the shelf because it offended one person in the school. The shocking part was that almost the whole school was reading that book. Even teachers were reading it. The school board did not even care though. I think that was completely handled the wrong way. They should have talked to the girl and said it was unfair to ask that when everybody reads it. If it offended her, then she should not read it.  Music is an outlet for many people. They can express their feelings in a way that is amazing. Without music, there would not be any fun in the world. People are always listening to music. When they are sad, mad, upset, confused, etc. If people think some kind of music is offensive, then they should not listen to it.  Movies are going to be offensive to at least one thing all the time. That is what makes a movie: a hero and a villain. We want the good guys to win. The movie makes fun of the bad guys. Somebody is always going to get hurt.  When I read, watch, or listen to something, I do not think of how offensive it is to me or somebody else. I think of how the artist feels. Why they wrote it that certain way. If I am listening to music, I listen to the beat and the words at first. Then if I like it, I start singing it. If I do not like it, then I just change the song.  I hope people do not end up just taking things off the shelf when someone is offended. We need the different opinions in life. If we all had the same opinions, we would not be ourselves in any way. I do not want to be the same as everybody else. I love my personality. I am different and kind of an outcast. But I am true to myself. And I respect other people's opinions. I wish everyone would do the same. Or at least try to do the same. Thank you for listening to what I had to say.

Books, music, movies, magazines, etc. should not be removed from certain library shelves because people have enough sense on what they are interested in and what they are not interested in. There will always be people that find specific thoughts or ideas offensive no matter what the subject is, so censorship does not really make a difference to the individual. Censorship is not necessary because people know what they are interested in without anyone helping them find what they are looking for.  Censorship is not entirely necessary because people will always find something that they are not exactly looking for or interested in. People's interests are their own business without the censorship of others in the surrounding community. I've read a couple books that have cussing in them, but the book is still as good as it would be without the cussing in it. People like things no matter what, because there will always be flaws with some objects such as books, music, and movies.  Books, music, and movies all have much interest from the common person, and each individual is capable of making their own decisions based on what they are interested in. The individual does not need edited objects, or music to listen to the music or other objects without being offended. There is something offensive to people in every work that has been published, and the buyer is fully aware of that fact before they go and buy something.  Censorship is not necessary because individuals are aware of what they are interested without anything telling them what to look for. People will almost always get offended about what they are watching or listening to no matter what it is, so why is censorship such a big deal? Censorship is not needed in today's society because each specific individual is capable of making their own decision in what's best for themselves. Books, music, movies, magazines, etc. should not be taken away from the library shelves because there will always be some offensive objects that some individuals will find offensive no matter what the object is.

Many people believe that magazines, books, movies, music, posters, and other forms of media can contain content that parents may not want their children to see. This could include books discussing different races or cultures, which may contain sensitive or inappropriate material for young readers. It is important for individuals to approach these materials with an open mind and consider whether the content aligns with their values before making a decision to engage with it. Ultimately, it is up to each person to make informed choices about what they consume and to be respectful of different perspectives and experiences.

Would you want your children reading about things that only adults know? When you go to a library, you expect to learn about history, science, literature, and more. Libraries are places for expanding knowledge and gaining valuable insights. Upon entering a library, you anticipate seeing people checking out various books or finding ones that pique their interest. If a book is deemed inappropriate or detrimental to a child's development, it is crucial to advocate for their mental growth.  We must also consider what children desire to read. They should have the freedom to explore topics that interest them, as long as they are engaging and educational. Some books provide valuable lessons about the world they inhabit. While there may be books we hesitate to let our children read, they may offer valuable insights that we cannot provide. These are what I refer to as "eye-openers," books that may initially seem controversial but ultimately prepare them for the future. Not every book is filled with positivity; children must learn about the complexities of life and the importance of distinguishing right from wrong.  Do you remember the first book you read independently? I recall mine was "Of Mice and Men" at a young age. Despite my mother's concerns about its content, that book taught me valuable lessons about the world. Some books are meant to be read, while others may not be suitable for children. If you feel a book is unsuitable for your child, read it first and then explain your reasoning to them. It is essential to guide children towards appropriate reading materials that align with their age and maturity level. Ultimately, fostering a love for reading and learning will enrich their lives and contribute to their overall development.

Libraries should not remove materials from their shelves just because some people find them offensive. When individuals visit a library, they are seeking knowledge or entertainment, and removing materials could limit their access to information. It is important to respect diverse beliefs and opinions, as everyone has the right to choose what they want to read or view. If someone finds a particular item offensive, they can simply choose not to engage with it and find something else that suits their preferences. Libraries offer a wide range of materials across various genres and subjects, catering to different interests and age groups. It is crucial to uphold the principles of intellectual freedom and allow individuals to make their own decisions about the materials they want to explore. By maintaining a diverse collection, libraries can continue to serve as valuable resources for education, research, and personal enrichment.

Censoring books goes against freedom of speech and the right to access information. While some may find certain topics offensive, it is important to understand historical events and learn from them to prevent their repetition. Censorship limits the exchange of ideas and can be just as offensive as the material being censored. Instead of censoring books, individuals can choose not to read them if they find them offensive. It is important to respect different viewpoints and allow readers to make their own decisions about what they choose to read. Ultimately, censorship restricts knowledge and inhibits intellectual growth, which is detrimental to society as a whole.

There are many types of materials in the library to entertain you. Some of these materials may be books, magazines, movies, and music. Each person has their own type of information and genres that they like. For example, most teenage girls love to read young romance stories, and about young peoples' lives; some people like informational books. Everyone is different in their own way. The material they choose to read is their own choice.  How would you feel if one of your favorite books or magazine were taken off the shelves of all the libraries? You would probably wonder why such a thing would happen. Well, some people would like to argue about how some of the information that is contained in such materials are offensive or inappropriate. They want these types of things to be taken off the shelves. But is it their decision to say that some things offend people?  Everyone has their own opinion and can make their own choice on what they want to read or what they do not want to read. In my opinion, these types of materials should stay on the shelves. It is simple, if you do not like a certain genre of magazines or books, do not read them. If you hear someone's music, and it sounds completely awful to you, then just walk away or listen to your own music. There's a new movie out about how the world is going to end, and you disbelieve in the fact that the world will not end that way, do not go and see it.  Some parents do not want their children to know about some of the things that are out there in the world, which is completely understandable. But, everyone has rights to what they want to know and what they do not want to know. If everyone had a right to take away some books that they think are not appropriate, do you think there would be any books left? The thing is, is that in today's society, people want to do what they want and think what they want. Some people do not agree with most things, but that is something they will have to face, because not everyone can be happy.  In conclusion, it is important to respect individual choices and preferences when it comes to reading materials. Everyone has the right to access information and entertainment that aligns with their interests, and censorship should not dictate what is available to the public. Let people make their own decisions about what they want to read, watch, or listen to, without imposing restrictions on content.

Should certain materials be removed from the shelves of the library that are found offensive? @PERSON1 states that we will have no books left of the shelf to read if everyone removes a book they do not approve of. What some people think is the most innocent book, could offend another individual. Different people find different topics offensive. No two people think the same.     Though certain books or magazines @MONTH1 have offensive subjects or materials in them, if they were to be removed, how would we learn? For example, say there was a historical fiction book about racism. The book might show different perspectives of how people lived when racism flourished. Readers could learn from the books how racism affects people, and why it is wrong. Learning about dislikes can make someone more knowledgable on why some people think the way they do. The readers can learn from mistakes made in the past. Books or movies depict how life was years or even centuries ago; morals were different a while ago from what they are now.     If many people were to agree that a certain material is very offensive or not appropriate for adolescents or young children, one option that could be available is only allowing adults to check it out. The library could also put a warning on it if they think the content of the material is too harsh. Another idea could be setting up reviews on a website with a list of each book in the library. Consumers can read the review first and then decide whether to check it out or not.     People have their own opinions and views on materials. A person should learn to be tolerant of materials; others might truely enjoy it. This article might be offensive to those who read it, because they might think things should be more sensored rather than tolerated.  If someone does not like the material, they are not forced to check it out of the library so why cause a fuss over it? One person might find a topic very offensive while that same topic sparks interest in another individual. Each person has different morals so who is to say what should and should not be in a library?

One essential right that every man, woman, or child should have is the freedom of speech. Without this right no one would be able to express their views. When libraries pull books, magazines, movies, and music off of their shelves it takes away that right. Even if the matter of the subject is offensive to some people, the books or other items should be left on the shelves.  What one person finds offensive another could find miraculous. If one person does not find the content of a book attractive then simply do not read the book. Libraries should not censor the material that they put on the shelves just because someone does not like it. I do think however, that books should be placed in the section that they belong. Sections for children's books, young adult books, adult books, and many more can all be found in a library. An example would be that a book about the anatomy of the human body does not belong in the children's section. beyond this, the library should leave the rest of the decisions to the reader. If someone wanted to read a book on the @LOCATION1, then that person should be able to go to a library and check the book out. The problem with censorship is that a @CAPS1 could find the book offensive and want it removed from the shelves. Then the person interested in the @LOCATION1 would not be able to withdraw the book.  The choice of what material you read should be left up to you, not restricted by what someone else finds offensive. Libraries should not remove items from their shelves if someone else finds it offensive to their own beliefs. The person should just not read the book. Everyone is going to have a different opinion on most things and therefore, there should not be censorship in libraries. In conclusion, the freedom of speech should be upheld in libraries, allowing individuals to choose their reading material without interference from others' personal beliefs.

Writing is a form of expression that allows individuals to share their thoughts and ideas freely. In this country, authors have the freedom to write about any topic without fear of repercussions. While some works may be enjoyable to read, others may be disturbing. However, just because a piece of literature is offensive does not mean it should be censored or removed from shelves.  For example, "The Jungle" by Upton Sinclair shed light on the appalling practices of the meat packing industry, sparking outrage and leading to much-needed reforms. Despite its controversial content, the book remains a significant part of literary history. If authors were not allowed to address issues like those depicted in "The Jungle," important societal changes may never have occurred.  In education, students should be exposed to a variety of literature that not only enriches their minds but also reflects the world around them. While classics like Shakespeare and Dickens are important, students should also read works that address contemporary issues and offer insights into success and personal growth.  It is crucial for individuals to cultivate a love for reading in a world dominated by technology. If every book that offended someone was removed, we would be left with a limited and censored literary landscape. Therefore, it is essential to uphold the freedom of expression and keep all books accessible to those who wish to read them. Censorship should not dictate what individuals can or cannot read, as every book has the potential to educate, inspire, and provoke thought.

Dear Newspaper,   I believe that no book should be taken off the shelves for any reason. People may not be mature enough for some books, music, magazines, etc., and so if libraries have a problem with certain materials, they should consider putting an age limit on checking out those items. Libraries cater to a diverse range of tastes and preferences, so there should not be a reason to remove any material from their shelves.  If libraries start removing materials that some people don't like, then it would be unfair to those who enjoy them. For example, taking off a popular series like '@CAPS1' would upset many fans. Different people have different interests, and libraries should be able to provide a variety of reading options for everyone.  While some parents may not want their children to read certain books, it is ultimately their responsibility to monitor what their kids are exposed to. They could request age restrictions on certain materials or simply guide their children in their reading choices. However, removing books altogether just because some individuals object to them is not a fair solution.  In my opinion, all books should remain accessible in libraries because diversity in reading materials is important. If someone has an issue with a book, they can simply choose not to read it. It is essential to respect the varied preferences and opinions of readers.   Sincerely, @PERSON1

From many arguments, people disagree with school libraries due to the presence of disturbing content like violence, drugs, and nudity in books, magazines, articles, and the internet. Parents are concerned about their children having access to such uncensored material, fearing it may influence them negatively. Libraries need to be more responsible in curating their collection to ensure children are not exposed to inappropriate content. Parents also play a vital role in monitoring and guiding their children's exposure to such materials. Both parents and libraries need to work together to create a safe and educational environment for children to thrive in without being exposed to offensive or uncensored content. Ultimately, the well-being and development of children should be the top priority for both parents and libraries.

Parents should have control over what their children read and watch, especially when it comes to inappropriate content like sexual relationships or violence. Libraries should also be mindful of the materials they provide to young readers, ensuring that they are age-appropriate. Parents need to take responsibility for disciplining their children and not allow them to be influenced by negative behaviors seen in movies or books. Education should focus on preparing students for the real world and teaching them valuable lessons about life and society. It is essential to prioritize educational and informative content over material that may have a negative impact on young minds.

In this millennium, censorship should not be a major concern, as people often say and do worse things in public than what may be found in books, music, or movies. Parents should take responsibility for monitoring what their children have access to, whether it be in a library or a store. If a child is exposed to adult content, it is ultimately the parent's responsibility for not supervising them properly. However, if the material contains racist content, it should be censored to prevent negative influences on young minds. While some materials may not be suitable for children, it is essential for research purposes or personal interest. Implementing age restrictions or creating separate sections for sensitive material could be a solution. Overall, censorship in libraries should be limited to ensure a wide variety of resources are available for all individuals without restricting access.

Libraries, to myself, are a gateway to another world; where I can be who I want to be, and let my imagination wander where ever it pleases. Libraries should not have the ability to take a book off the shelves depending on its content. We are all different people, we all don't enjoy the same kind of books. Also, some books may be needed for research. Censorship in a library should not be allowed.   First, there are so many different people in the world. Some people learn more about people from books. Imagine yourself a white, 10-year-old boy, growing up in an all white town. Never in your life have you seen an African American. You go to the library and pick up 'The Diary of Anne Frank.' This young boy has never been introduced to such racism. Books are history. Books are learning. Books can not be taken off the shelf just for their content. That content might be a whole other world for a young child.  Next, libraries are used so often by college students to writer papers for school. Books are needed for research. For an example, you're a college student writing a research paper on abuse--including sexual, physical, and mental. A young author writes a non-fiction novel about her childhood ranging from being raped by her father at six years old to being bullied in school. After hours of searching, you find all local libraries have removed this book for its explicit content. College students need books no matter what they're about.  Libraries are open to people of all ages. It is understandable that a twelve-year-old could easily get a hold of a book inappropriate for their age level, but that's why libraries are split into sections. If you find a book that is considered to be taken off the shelves, don't remove it, just move it to a more secure and mature area. Censorship in libraries limits access to information and hinders intellectual freedom. Let books remain on the shelves for those who seek knowledge and inspiration from them.

When it comes to the idea of removing certain materials like books, music, movies, and magazines, it should ultimately be a personal choice. It is a fundamental right protected by our constitution. I personally enjoy reading urban books as they resonate with my experiences and where I may be headed in life. While these may not be suitable for my grandchildren, they may develop a liking for them later on. Everyone has different preferences, and just because something is not to your taste doesn't mean it should be banned.   Libraries and bookstores offer a wide range of materials, catering to diverse interests. If certain books are not suitable for children, they can be placed in a separate section labeled "For Adults." Ultimately, it is up to us as parents and individuals to monitor what our children read and watch. Banning materials may not solve the underlying issues as determined individuals will find a way to access them. It is important to respect differing tastes and preferences, as what may seem inappropriate to one person may hold value for another. Let's embrace diversity and individual choice when it comes to selecting reading materials.

Libraries are essential repositories of knowledge, providing us with insights into the past through both factual information and fictional stories. Censoring books in libraries, whether due to perceived vulgarity or controversial content, hinders our ability to learn from diverse perspectives and experiences. History, despite its sensitive nature, should not be whitewashed or hidden, as understanding past mistakes is crucial for building a better future. In a society inundated with adult content in media, libraries serve as a valuable source of educational material for all ages. Limiting access to books restricts the opportunities for individuals, especially children, to explore different ideas and perspectives. As technology increasingly dominates our entertainment choices, it is important to preserve the tradition of reading and the valuable lessons it imparts. Books with complex themes such as substance abuse, family dynamics, and social issues play a vital role in shaping our understanding of the world and our interactions with others. Encouraging reading, especially of diverse and challenging material, is essential for fostering critical thinking and empathy. The richness of literature lies in its ability to provoke thought, evoke emotions, and inspire growth. By safeguarding the availability of a wide range of books in libraries, we ensure that future generations have the opportunity to expand their horizons and learn valuable life lessons from the written word.

I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should never be removed from libraries because people have the right to access information, regardless of whether it is offensive. Our country was founded on principles of freedom of speech and equality, and removing materials from libraries based on offensiveness sets a dangerous precedent. If we start censoring for offensiveness, where do we draw the line? What one person finds offensive, another may not. Libraries are meant for learning and teaching, and the information within them should be helpful and constructive. Removing materials would only limit access to knowledge and ultimately harm the purpose of libraries. It is important to uphold the principles of free speech and access to information, even if some may find certain materials offensive.

Have you ever been offended? Did you lash out, or did you keep an open mind and try to understand? People are offended by many things every day in life. So, we should broaden our minds and see these 'offenses' as a normality.  You're at a party with a bowl full of candy stationed right beside the front door. You walk in and take a piece. Wait, you don't want that piece? What are you going to do with it? Do you take all of the same pieces that you don't like out of the bowl and throw them away, or do you simply drop it back into the bowl and choose a new one? If you throw the candy away, what does that mean for the other party guests? You have narrowed their choices down because of your own selfish opinion. That candy could have been the guest favorite. But, since YOU don't like it, you take away the other guests' privilege to eat that candy. They didn't deserve that, now did they?  If you're searching through books in a library and you come across a book that doesn't interest you or offends you, then put it back and look for a new one. If you're having trouble finding the right book, ask the librarian for suggestions on other topics or books to check out. Go to a new library, even, but don't mess with something that isn't yours. Especially, something as small as a book.  The point of the matter is, if you don't like something then disregard it. The moment the book, and the book alone, starts causing problems is the moment anyone should intervene. But, come on, do you really think a book could cause a problem? If your child is having problems, don't you think you ought to check what's going on with him instead of looking to see if he/she checked out the 'book that we hope none of our children' took off the shelf. This is quite possibly one of the last things I would think of causing a problem, if I even thought of this at all. Opinions can cause a lot of problems. Sometimes, people just need to keep their opinions to themselves, agreed?

The libraries can contain books that are offensive to humans and animals. These offensive books may include negative comments just for entertainment purposes. However, it is important to consider the impact of such offensive content on readers, especially when it involves sensitive issues such as race.  I believe that all materials in libraries should be reviewed, and any content found to be offensive or derogatory towards any individual or group should be removed. Libraries should be a place that promotes positivity and knowledge, not one that contains harmful and hurtful material. Children, in particular, should be able to access books without encountering offensive or inappropriate content.  I recall a time when my little brother brought home a book from the library that depicted discriminatory behavior towards a dark-colored dog, which made him feel uncomfortable and upset. This experience highlights the importance of ensuring that libraries maintain a safe and inclusive environment for all readers.  In conclusion, while libraries are valuable sources of information and entertainment, it is crucial to be mindful of the content they offer. Offensive material can have a detrimental effect on readers and should not be tolerated in such spaces. It is essential to promote a culture of respect and understanding in libraries to create a welcoming and enriching experience for all individuals.

Censorship, whether in libraries, schools, or on television, restricts the free flow of ideas and information, leading to a society of conformists. While some may argue that censorship is necessary to protect the youth or maintain societal norms, it ultimately hinders individual thought and creativity. By censoring books, movies, and other forms of media, we limit our ability to explore different perspectives and learn from diverse viewpoints. Instead of promoting conformity, we should embrace the diversity of ideas and encourage critical thinking. In a world without censorship, we have the opportunity to expand our minds and enrich our lives through the exploration of all kinds of literature and media. Let us not stifle creativity and individuality but instead celebrate the uniqueness of each person's thoughts and opinions.

Wow, that's racist. As I said when I saw the movie "White Men Can't Jump," yes, that movie could have offended me a lot, but it didn't. Personally, I thought it was funny, and I enjoyed it because it's true that statistics show black people can jump higher than white people. It's all about how you look at it  you have to have a sense of humor when it comes to stuff like that. Everyone remembers a time when someone said something offensive to them, but it's your choice to take it to heart or just laugh about it. Life is so much easier when you don't cry over every little thing that someone said to you. See, now I have a sense of humor. When I was in that movie, I was laughing so hard I almost peed myself. I didn't care that it singled out white people  so what, it's funny.  "To Kill a Mockingbird" was also a book that many people found offensive, and I can see why. It had the n-word in there a lot. But back then, it was a different time, and the people in the book weren't saying it to you, so why would you be offended by it? They weren't offending you. If you take little things like that to heart, you'll have a tough time going through life. Some things you just have to let go and roll off your body.  In conclusion, yes, we've all had a lot of offensive things said to us, but you can't let it get you down so much that you have to move on. And if you move on, you'll be a better person in the long run.

Books, music, movies, and other forms of media are valuable tools for learning, but it is important to exercise discretion in choosing what to consume. While some material can be educational and enriching, others may be harmful or inappropriate. It is essential to consider the content and quality of what we read, watch, and listen to. By being selective and mindful of the media we engage with, we can ensure a positive and enriching learning experience. Remember, not all books, music, and movies are created equal, so choose wisely.

Every library has tons of information on just about everything. There are tons of books, music, movies, magazines and more that contain this information. There is even some information that some people might take offence to. On the other hand, somebody else could be perfectly fine with it. I think that all libraries should keep all their books on the shelfs, no matter what kind of content they contain, because not everybody takes offence to some contents in books, and it is the same way vice versa.  The subject race might come into play in some books in libraries. Books have information about people doing things to other people just because of their race. Some people want books took out of their libraries because of the content that they contain, but really it could be a n important part of history that people need to be educated about. Some books have words that are very offencive to people because of their skin color, relgion, or ethnic race. This information that people need to know because thats how people were treated back then and some stuff like that still occurs today.  Libraries have all kinds of information. I think that all the books at libraries should stay there no matter what they contain. Even if some content is offensive some people it could still be a important part of history that people need to know. Ultimately, the diversity of content available in libraries allows for a broader understanding of different perspectives, histories, and experiences, making it essential to preserve all materials for educational and informational purposes.

In my opinion, books, movies, magazines, etc., should not be taken off the shelves if they are offensive to some people. Everyone has different views, and what one person finds offensive, another may not. Removing offensive material would result in empty shelves and hinder learning in schools. Authors and creators would be discouraged from producing new content if their work is constantly rejected. It is crucial to preserve diverse perspectives and allow individuals to choose what they want to read or watch. Overall, maintaining a variety of materials on the shelves, even if some find them offensive, is essential for education and freedom of expression.

Being careful about what we have in libraries is essential because it can have a significant impact on individuals, especially children. Books, magazines, and movies can influence behavior, mindset, and even family dynamics. While libraries are valuable sources of knowledge and entertainment, it is crucial to filter out materials that may have negative effects. By being selective about what we expose ourselves and our children to, we can promote healthy growth, positive behavior, and a more peaceful environment. It is important to strike a balance between enjoying media and ensuring it does not harm our mental and emotional well-being. Ultimately, being mindful of the content we consume can lead to a more positive and enriching experience for everyone.

Author Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.  But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else.  And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.'  This quote is reflecting people wanting to rid of some of the literature, books, magazines, music, and movies in libraries, because they think that the material is inappropriate.  If we got rid of all of the books from our world, we would have nothing left to learn from, and some of the main sources of entertainment would vanish. I believe that certain materials should not be replaced from the shelves, because the youth of today need to learn about the true past, people should learn about how cultures really are, authors and writers need to be able to express themselves, and parents should be able to control what they believe their children should and should not read.    If it were not for books and novels from the past, the current generations would have no clue of what history was about.  Children should be allowed to read books such as To Kill a Mockingbird, The Diary of Anne Frank, and Night in order to get a taste of how much times have changed.  Stories from grandparents only take a person back about 20 years; we need sources that can take us back thousands of years.  Some families, such as an African American family, might get offended if their children are reading books that say things like 'nigger,' but that is our history.  It is something we cannot change, and it is important for kids to know how things really were and how terrible people were treated.  We also do not want today's youth making some of the terrible mistakes generations in the past made, so they need to be taught about the real but sometimes horrendous situations.    Learning about different cultures would be another issue if books and movies were depleted.  Money is not available these days to just travel to different countries and experience their culture.  How is a young girl from a small town in Iowa supposed to find out how people in Japan live their life?  For all she knows, the people could be living in igloos.  I believe that it is important for people to understand different cultures and religions in order to accept them in society.  Movies can teach a lot about different countries, and books do a wonderful job as well.  If they are gone, cultures would be misunderstood and forgotten.    Also, authors and directors need to be able to express themselves.  Every since people are young, they are taught that it is important to be unique and express their own style.  Not every writer is going to want to write about butterflies and rainbows.  There are people that love writing about violence, gore, and segregation.  Those things are part of the world today and everyone needs to face that reality.  Getting rid of all of those books from library shelves will not solve the problems; it would only cause people to not expect what might happen to them or our world.    Now, some parents may have hard times when their young boy comes home from school with an offensive book, but parents should have control over their kids.  If they have a problem with what their children are reading, then they should deal with that personally.  They do not need to influence other people's lives by trying to get rid of the materials off of public libraries' shelves.    Why people would even consider getting rid of history and learning materials about cultures and different subjects in our world is beyond me.  It would be like asking someone to rewind time so that we would not have had slavery, depressions, world wars, and homicides.  It is impossible to undo history, but we can learn about the things from the past in order to not make the same mistakes and things of the current world in order to be accepting and understanding.  Books, magazines, movies, and music are wonderful.  They represent self-expression and freedom of speech, so people should let them be an entertainment and learning source.  Without them, we would be and have nothing.

Many people believe that offensive material should be removed from libraries to prevent children from accessing inappropriate content. However, I disagree with this viewpoint. Libraries already have designated children's sections, and it is the responsibility of parents and guardians to monitor what their children are reading. It would be unfair to inconvenience others by restricting access to certain materials just because of the possibility that a child might come across them. It is also important to consider the context in which a book, movie, or game is being used, as it may not necessarily be inappropriate. Ultimately, it is crucial to balance the need for access to information with the need to protect children, and removing offensive material may not be the most effective solution. In conclusion, I believe that censorship in libraries should be approached with caution and consideration for all perspectives involved.

Who cares about unsensored things anyway? Offensive materials have always been present in libraries, so why the sudden concern now? Removing these materials from shelves and censoring them won't solve anything. If someone is not mature enough to handle certain content, then they shouldn't be reading it in the first place. Blaming offensive materials for societal issues like bullying is misguided; the focus should be on parenting and personal responsibility. It is unnecessary to censor books simply because a few individuals find them offensive. Let's leave unsensored things alone and focus on more important issues at hand. Thank you for your time.

When you were a child, how much did you learn from books? Books are filled with great stories of far-away lands, accounts of real events, and poems with powerful meanings.
