Two of the many privileges that we have as individuals are freedom of speech and freedom of expression. Although some bodies of work may be perceived as offensive or inappropriate, I believe that they should still be available to the public. Some might agree with the topic being expressed, even if it is offensive or inappropriate, and others may not; but they should not be removed from libraries because of their negativity.  These offensive or harsh pieces of literature could even be used to show the public what is considered rude, offensive, or inappropriate, and should be thought of as learning tools instead of being banned. Every person has a right to an opinion, and others may or may not agree with what that person has to say, but it does not change the fact that they have the right to their beliefs.  Katherine Paterson says, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf'. I myself have read literature that is considered offensive, but as disturbing as the literature was, I am glad that I was educated on what people thought was acceptable behavior so that I know, and can teach others that despite what the book said, we now know that it was describing how people should not be living.  I believe that it would be a grave mistake to remove these materials from the public eye, because many are ignorant to the historical beliefs of others that have affected our nation and other countries across the globe. All of these books are educational, though some are harsh, and they should be used to show what is right and wrong. If they are taken off of shelves in the libraries then people, especially children could start to think that a certain idea, that may be incorrect or offensive, is completely appropriate and acceptable. As someone once said, 'Those who do not know their history are bound to repeat it'.  By removing the problem, we would be creating another issue. For example, many books have been written over history that convey hatred and discrimination towards other cultures, ethnicities, religions, and lifestyles. If these works of literature were banned and not available to the public, many people would not know that it is wrong to show hatred towards others just because they are different than you. This type of literature provides useful information: it allows people to see how a large amount of people thought life should have been years ago, and they taught the people of today that it actually was how people should not be living.  In conclusion, it is important to preserve all forms of literature, even if they are offensive or inappropriate, as they serve as valuable educational tools to showcase what is right and wrong in society. Banning such materials would only lead to ignorance and a lack of understanding of historical beliefs and behaviors that have shaped our world.

Libraries are known as places where a person can go to find material on almost any topic they could want to learn about, whether that material is a book, movie, or magazine. Anyone can use the library, and it is a valuable resource to many people. So why do some libraries insist on removing some of those valuable materials from their shelves? In past years, censorship in libraries has been the focus of many news reports. In almost all cases, library patrons have been angry that certain materials have been deemed unsuitable to be offered at the library. People have a right to choose what books they want to read, what movies they want to watch, and what music they want to listen to. People have opinions; people disagree. What one person loves, another person could hate. But just because one person dislikes or is offended by a material on a library shelf does not mean that the opportunity to use that material should be denied to all other patrons. I feel that if a resource is checked out by just one individual, and that one individual is able to learn from or enjoy the resource, then the library has achieved its purpose and helped the community by offering that material. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is limiting and wrong. It creates barriers for those who want to learn and it takes away people's freedom to make decisions for themselves. Everyone should be able to decide whether to pick up a library material, and censorship makes that impossible.

I believe that materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from libraries because they serve as valuable sources of information and learning. Different individuals learn in different ways, and these materials cater to various learning styles. Additionally, in today's digital age, these sources are essential tools that we rely on for everyday tasks. Therefore, it is important to retain these resources in libraries as they are not only beneficial but also indispensable in our lives.

The right to remove a book off of a shelf is not a good thing to do. If this practice begins, there will be empty shelves in libraries across the country. Instead, libraries could have a separate section for books that may not be suitable for all audiences. Another solution could be to have a national library service to decide which books should be removed or placed in a special section. Libraries could also implement a new labeling system to provide more information about the content of books. Books, music, and magazines should be available in libraries for people to enjoy and learn from. Let's preserve the diversity of literature and information in our libraries for everyone to access and benefit from.

I believe that there should be a right to remove offensive books, music, movies, or magazines from library shelves. As a parent, I am concerned about the impact of such material on my child. Libraries are funded by taxpayers, and it is important that the content available is suitable for all audiences. Children can be influenced by what they read, watch, and listen to, so it is crucial to be mindful of the materials they are exposed to. Inappropriate content can promote violence, drug use, and other negative behaviors. It is essential to ensure that libraries provide a safe and educational environment for everyone.

Going into a library, everyone has their own opinions on what should be on the shelves for all to see, including children. Some believe that only age-appropriate materials should be available, while others disagree. In my view, there should be a variety of books for all ages, with a designated children's section for parents who want to control what their kids see. When it comes to magazines, movies, and music, I believe there should be a range of options available, excluding any explicit material like pornography. Parents should take responsibility for monitoring their children's choices, but there should be limits on what is publicly accessible, especially in a library setting. Drawing a line at pornography is essential to maintain a suitable environment for all library users.

All libraries have their own advantages and disadvantages. While some people misuse library resources, such as using computers for inappropriate purposes, others utilize them for job applications and other productive activities. Despite these challenges, libraries remain valuable spaces for learning and research. People of all ages can benefit from the vast resources available, whether it's to learn about history, current events, or other cultures. Ultimately, the library serves as a place for self-improvement and personal growth, and it is up to individuals to make the most of these opportunities.

There are more than six billion people in the world, each with their own unique personalities and opinions. It is virtually impossible to remove all aspects of media that could be found offensive, as almost everyone is offended by something. With the accessibility of the internet, materials once limited to shelves are now online and can never be permanently removed. While some media aims to raise awareness, there is a fine line that can be crossed into offensiveness. Authors must consider the impact of their words and avoid stereotypes that can be hurtful. Censoring libraries may not effectively address the issue, as libraries are already losing relevance in today's technology-driven world. Authors and readers alike should be mindful of the impact of their words and actions, working towards raising awareness rather than causing offense. It is crucial to respect the feelings of others and think beyond oneself when creating and consuming media in a diverse world.

I, personally, do not think that books, music, movies, or magazines should be removed from the shelves because they are found offensive. However, I do believe that there should be a way to protect adolescent, still-developing children from reading books that may offend them or introduce them to new concepts or ideas that could hinder their educational growth. Some kids who have not been properly educated over a controversial topic (such as drugs or alcohol) may make a bad decision based on something they read in a book or on a webpage.  To help solve the problem of offending children or deterring their education, I propose that we implement a book 'rating' system. Similar to rating a movie or a video game, this system would provide readers with information about what age level the book is appropriate for, and what factors led to the book being rated in that way.  As a newspaper company, you are familiar with our rights of freedom of speech and press. One of these rights is freedom of speech, which includes the freedom of authors to express themselves through their work. Taking books labeled as 'inappropriate' off the shelves is not a reasonable solution to the issue. Authors, editors, photographers, and publishers put a lot of effort into creating these books, and removing them would be repressing their freedom of speech. It could potentially lead to protests and strikes from authors who feel their work is being unfairly censored.  However, I do believe that implementing a rating system for books is a good compromise. It allows authors to fully express themselves while also providing readers with information about the content of the book. This way, readers can make informed decisions about what they choose to read without being exposed to potentially harmful material.  In conclusion, a book rating system would be a fair and effective way to address the issue of offensive content in books without infringing on the rights of authors. It would benefit both authors and readers by promoting freedom of expression while also ensuring that readers are aware of the content they are consuming.

Libraries should not have to remove books that some people find offensive. Different people have different preferences, and it is not fair to restrict access to certain materials just because they may be disliked by some. Embracing diverse perspectives and allowing people to make their own choices when it comes to reading is essential for intellectual freedom and growth. Let's celebrate the richness of literature and respect individual preferences without imposing restrictions on what can be accessed in a library.

There are many books in the library that shouldn't be there. From books about racism, violence, or pornography, I wouldn't want my young children to be able to take those types of books out of the library. A library in a school is a great way to help students with projects, essays, or just to read. If my child was in elementary or middle school, I wouldn't want them to be able to check out a book about things they shouldn't even know about yet. However, for teenagers in high school, they are old enough to understand the realities of the world and could benefit from accessing a wider range of materials, including potentially controversial subjects. Libraries also offer a variety of music, movies, and magazines. While educational materials can be beneficial, it is important to monitor and restrict access to inappropriate content, especially for younger audiences. Ultimately, it is essential to consider the age and maturity level of the readers when deciding what materials to include in a library to ensure a safe and enriching environment for all.

Books can be valuable resources, providing knowledge, entertainment, and comfort. However, there are instances where books may contain inappropriate content that could offend certain individuals. In such cases, it is important for libraries to consider removing offensive books from their shelves to ensure a welcoming and respectful environment for all patrons.  Religious sensitivities, language, and imagery unsuitable for children are factors to consider when evaluating the appropriateness of books. While some may argue for creating separate sections for controversial material, it is essential to recognize that individual beliefs and values vary. Therefore, libraries may need to take steps such as censoring or ultimately removing offensive books to maintain a positive atmosphere.  Similarly, music and magazines can also present challenges regarding offensive content. Some may view certain music genres as inappropriate, while magazines may contain images or language that could be misinterpreted. Libraries should exercise caution and possibly provide warnings for materials that may not be suitable for all audiences.  In conclusion, while books are generally beneficial, there are circumstances where they may have negative implications. Libraries should carefully consider the content of their collection and take appropriate action to address offensive material, ensuring a respectful and inclusive environment for all patrons.

Just because I agree with something, does that mean you have to agree too? Your cousin believing in one thing does not mean you have to believe in it as well. People have different opinions, and that is what makes the world diverse and interesting. If something offends you, it does not necessarily offend others around you.   Offensive material exists in the world, and it will not disappear. We should not try to eliminate everything that we find offensive because what one person finds offensive, another may not. Everyone has the right to express themselves, and we should respect that.   If something offends someone, it does not make it less valuable or inappropriate. We all have different likes and dislikes, and that is what makes us unique. We should not try to erase things that do not align with our personal beliefs.   Removing items from shelves because they offend some people sets a dangerous precedent. If we start eliminating everything we do not like, we will have nothing left. We should learn to accept that people have different opinions and respect their right to express themselves.   Instead of trying to erase things we do not agree with, we should focus on fixing the broken things in the world. Acceptance and understanding are key to creating a more harmonious society. We should embrace the diversity around us and learn to love what we have, flaws and all. After all, without the world as it is, nothing would be anything.

Offensive materials in libraries should not be taken off of the shelves because of their content. Writing is an art form and censoring what an author writes could obscure their message. People live around offensiveness every day on the street and in public places so censoring it in libraries would not protect anyone. Removing the books from libraries entirely could also interfere with research or school projects children have to work on for class. Censorship of books in libraries based on content should not be allowed as it could hinder the understanding of important themes and messages, people are already exposed to offensive language in daily life, and it could disrupt academic and research endeavors.

Libraries are sometimes connotated as very boring, with people walking up and down aisles looking for interesting books. However, some books may contain inappropriate content like profanity and nudity. In such cases, it is important for parents to educate their children about what is suitable for them to read or view. Instead of relying on censorship by libraries and other media outlets, parents should take an active role in monitoring their children's exposure to such content. By explaining the reasons behind restrictions and being present when children have access to potentially inappropriate material, parents can help guide their children towards more suitable choices. Ultimately, the responsibility for ensuring children's exposure to appropriate content lies with parents, not external sources of media.

Brian believes that censorship in libraries should vary depending on the age group. In a school library, he argues that there should be no censorship for books, as they provide important information, including historical and educational content. However, in a public library, Brian suggests that there should be some level of censorship, especially when it comes to explicit topics like drugs or alcohol. Similarly, he recommends limiting the types of movies available in school libraries to educational films, while in public libraries, movies should be restricted to a certain age rating. When it comes to magazines, Brian believes that there should be more leniency in school libraries, focusing on learning and fun content, while stricter censorship should be applied in public libraries to protect younger readers from inappropriate material. Ultimately, Brian's stance on censorship in libraries is clear: it should be more relaxed in school libraries and stricter in public libraries to cater to the different needs and ages of library users.

Some people might think that it is a good idea to censor things in the library. People might think that some of the material might be offensive or bad for the youth who visit libraries. They might believe that removing such items would be beneficial. However, I disagree with this viewpoint. I believe that nothing should be censored in the library, whether it be books, movies, music, magazines, or any other form of information. Censoring materials would limit resources and prevent individuals from accessing valuable knowledge, including important historical events that may be uncomfortable but necessary to learn about. Removing offensive materials would also not solve the issue, as people would find a way to access them elsewhere. Ultimately, individuals have the right to choose what they read, watch, or listen to, and the opinions of a few should not dictate what is available in a public space like a library. Everyone should have the freedom to access information and form their own opinions.

Some books in libraries offend others, leading to debates about whether they should be removed. While graphic and gory books may disgust some readers, warnings can help individuals avoid content they find disturbing. However, offensive material related to race, religion, or other personal characteristics can incite strong reactions and should be carefully reviewed by authors to prevent controversy. Inaccurate statements in books can fuel public curiosity and conspiracy theories, potentially harming an author's reputation. Overall, authors should strive to create works that resonate positively with the public to avoid backlash and ensure a successful outcome.

These books provide detailed information on various drugs, their effects, and even where to purchase them. This kind of content can potentially influence young minds and lead them towards dangerous behaviors.  I recently encountered a book that contained explicit descriptions and images of sexual positions, resembling a pornographic magazine. Such content is not suitable for students, as it can have a negative impact on their understanding of relationships and sexuality.  It is concerning to think about the kind of material that younger siblings may come across in libraries. As responsible adults, we should ensure that children are not exposed to inappropriate content that could potentially harm their development.  In conclusion, it is crucial for schools and libraries to carefully monitor the content of books and magazines available to students. We must prioritize the well-being and education of our youth by removing explicit and harmful material from their reach. Let us create a safe and nurturing environment for our children to learn and grow without being exposed to inappropriate content.

Comics, romance, adventure books, and mystery books are just a few of the different types of books available in our local libraries, along with magazines and music. While some content may be deemed offensive to certain individuals, it is important to remember that libraries cater to a diverse range of interests and age groups, including young children.  It is unrealistic to shield children from all potentially offensive material, as they will inevitably encounter challenging or inappropriate content at some point in their lives. Instead of removing offensive material from libraries, parents and guardians can take proactive steps to guide their children's reading choices and supervise their library visits.  By familiarizing themselves with the library's layout and content, adults can ensure that children are exposed to age-appropriate material and avoid areas with content that may be unsuitable. Additionally, parents can actively engage with their children during library visits, encouraging them to select books that align with their values and beliefs.  As children grow older, they will develop a better understanding of what is appropriate for them to read and will be better equipped to make informed choices. Ultimately, by fostering a culture of open communication and guidance, parents can help children navigate the diverse range of material available in libraries while respecting their individual preferences and sensitivities.

To start, if any materials in the library such as books, music, movies, or magazines are found offensive, I believe that they should still remain on the shelves. This is because everyone is entitled to their own opinion, and people should have the freedom to choose what they read, listen to, or watch. While something may be offensive to one person, it may be of interest or importance to another.   For example, a book or music that touches on a sensitive topic like slavery in history may be disturbing to some, but it is essential to understanding our past and learning from it. Just because something is offensive to one person does not mean it should be censored for everyone else.   In conclusion, it is important to respect individual choices and allow people to decide for themselves what they want to engage with at the library. While some materials may be offensive to some, they should still be available for those who find value in them. Libraries should be inclusive spaces that cater to a diverse range of interests and perspectives.

Censorship is a tool used in the media to prevent people from being offended by what they see or hear. While censorship can be useful in some situations, it can also be overused. Different cultures and religions have varying views and morals, so what may be acceptable to one group could be offensive to another. In my opinion, instead of demanding censorship, individuals can choose not to engage with content that offends them. Freedom of speech is a fundamental right, and censoring material because it may offend some goes against this principle. It is important to exercise discretion and personal choice when it comes to consuming media. For instance, while I may find certain language offensive, I choose not to watch programs that I disagree with. Censorship should be reserved for situations where there is a clear and present danger, not simply to cater to personal preferences. In conclusion, while some censorship may be necessary, individuals should have the freedom to choose what they consume without imposing their beliefs on others.

Censorship in libraries is not necessary. No reading material should be taken off the shelf. Every book has a different experience that can help a child learn. If the guardian of a child believes that a certain book is bad or offensive, then the guardian can forbid the child to read it. If people begin to take away options on reading materials, some kids may refuse to read at all. Every person is different and likes an option to pick a book that they can get into. Censoring books at a library is pointless; it takes away options and the experience to learn from certain books. Every book has a different plot and a different moral, teaching the reader something unique. Removing books from libraries takes away the chance for a student to learn a certain moral from that book and can hide away reality. No book should ever be taken off the shelves of libraries. Every book removed from the shelves is another learning experience taken away. If there is a book that a child's guardian disapproves of, it should be up to them to forbid their child from reading it. A book is simply a way to learn and explore the different things in life. Censoring at the library can only keep kids away from books for so long. Every child deserves the chance to read any book they want unless a guardian forbids it. It is not up to libraries whether a book is offensive or bad; that is solely based on the reader's opinion, which varies for everyone. When libraries begin to censor books, they take away the option to pick books, potentially leading to fewer kids picking up books. Everyone enjoys a different kind of book, so leaving options open gives everyone the chance to find a book they like. All in all, libraries should not censor books or any kind of reading material. Everyone is different, even when it comes to reading a book. People like their options to be open and at a wide range. Each book tells a different story and teaches a different moral. Leave the options open to children and let them learn from the stories they choose. Some books help teach a moral or get a point across, while others prepare a person for the outside world. Taking away certain reading materials is taking away the chance for a child to learn about the things happening around them. In conclusion, censorship is a bad idea and should be left to the guardian of a child.

Should certain books be banned or shouldn't certain books be banned? In my own personal opinion, no, I don't think that any books should be banned from a public library. The authors of books have freedom of speech, so while some books may offend people, individuals can choose to avoid those books if they find them offensive. Banning books from libraries could lead to restrictions on what is available in stores as well. In my view, no book should be banned from the public library because judging a book by its cover is not fair. Only after reading a book can one truly know if it is offensive, and in that case, they can simply return it and choose another. Books that may offend people often provide valuable insights into history and should not be restricted from public access.

In my opinion, some books should be removed from shelves if they are found to be offensive. Certain movies and books can contain harmful language or content that may be upsetting to readers. Similarly, some music can also be offensive with explicit lyrics or themes. However, not all music is inappropriate, as there is a wide variety of genres available to suit different preferences. It is important to consider the impact of media on audiences and ensure that materials being consumed are respectful and inoffensive. Ultimately, the decision to remove offensive books, movies, or music should be based on promoting a positive and inclusive environment for all individuals.

I believe that there shouldn't be any censorship in libraries. The reason why I say that is because of our first amendment, which guarantees freedom of speech. We should be able to include anything in books, magazines, music, movies, and other materials without restriction. Another reason why censorship should be avoided is that individuals should have the ability to determine if a particular book is suitable for their age or aligns with their personal views.  The first amendment protects our right to freedom of speech, allowing us to express ourselves in various forms of media. If we begin censoring materials in libraries, it could set a dangerous precedent that may eventually lead to the erosion of our first amendment rights.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries should be avoided to uphold the principles of the first amendment. It is important to preserve the freedom to express ourselves and access a wide range of materials that reflect diverse perspectives and ideas.

You know when you find a book on the shelf and discover that the content in the book is not appropriate for children to read. The same goes for magazines, with some images and covers not suitable for young minds. It is better to have offensive items like books, music, movies, and magazines removed from shelves as they can poison the minds of children.  For example, music with explicit lyrics can influence children's behavior and language. Rap music, in particular, often contains offensive language that kids may imitate, leading to inappropriate behavior. Similarly, magazines with inappropriate images can have a negative impact on children. Coming across such content in a learning environment like a school can be disturbing for both students and parents.  In conclusion, removing offensive items from shelves is essential to protect children from harmful influences. It is important to create a safe and positive environment for young minds to thrive without being exposed to inappropriate content.

Freedom of press is a right not many countries have. America is the land of the free. To some, having this much freedom causes great things to happen. Without the freedom of press, many of the most classic modern literature would not exist and their messages would be unknown. To censorize the right to write freely about one's outlook on the world or government or anything means taking away imagination and in some cases statistics and events that relate to the past.   Before today's technology, books were one of the only ways to obtain knowledge, and the process to make and publish a book took so long that it was an honor to receive one of the few copies produced. People have a craving for information; they like to learn and advance. If all books that were found 'offensive' are stripped off the shelves, information is slowly taken away, and the enjoyment of reading would be gone.   In the brilliant novel, Fahrenheit 451, a man who lives in a dystopian society discovers the lack of literature. All books found in homes are immediately taken out and burned in the streets for all to see. Children found it entertaining, and adults did nothing. The man goes through the novel with a secret stash of books of his own. Once discovered, he is on the run to protect his precious knowledge the government tries so hard to keep from the public. Censorship would create nothing but chaos and destruction as in the novel.   Having the right to know about your country's history or what is going on in your current government is critical in schools and colleges. Parents often find offense in the authors schools choose to make students read, saying their ideas and ways of thinking are too single-minded and wrong. Students need books to grow and learn, and if every person chose one book to take off the shelf permanently, there would be no more books. Eventually, all information would come from what one would know before the books were banished and in time gone for good.   Books are a history in themselves; no one wants to hear the raw truth of certain topics such as slavery or the possibility of a complete government takeover. In order to avoid hearing of this, one could simply choose a more fiction novel in which to escape into a fantasy of their own. No one can change history; however, they can exaggerate certain events, and without the actual book or site it came from, one could completely alter the public's view and thoughts of the past. Should one take offense to a certain book, they have their own freedom to write a negative blog or report on it.   Writing is a gift few have naturally, and to be able to show off one's talent is a privilege. Books help people escape the harsh world we live in or help them gain more knowledge. Censorship is irrelevant, for having all forms of music, movies, and magazines stripped of the truth, what does that leave? People always stretch the truth or tell a 'white lie,' however, most information is factual. The freedom to write and make books and music and movies is not all about entertaining people. The messages behind said 'offensive' material could be quite strong, and though the author might be long gone, his or her message could live on for decades.   In conclusion, the freedom of press and the right to write and publish freely are essential components of a democratic society. Censorship not only limits creativity and imagination but also hinders the dissemination of important information and diverse perspectives. It is crucial to uphold and protect this fundamental right to ensure a vibrant and informed society.

The entertainment for children and adults consists of movies, music, sports, video games, and reading. Books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from any shelf at any time. Libraries censor some material because of violence or inappropriate material. Children should have the right to read, listen, or watch whatever they want to because it's their life. Some books found 'offensive' or 'inappropriate' and taken off the shelves could be another person's favorite book to read. Why take it off the shelf? People are being too much self-centered. They care about themselves and that is it. The material being taken off the shelves should be put back on the shelves for the readers who find the material entertaining. If a parent does not want their child reading a certain book then they have the authority to take the book away from that child, not the shelves. Freedom of the @CAPS1 states that anybody has the right to write whatever they want to write. If we keep taking books, magazines, music, or movies off of the shelves then we're going to get to the point where there are no books on any shelf. It is important to respect the freedom of expression and the right to access diverse material for individuals of all ages. Let's keep our shelves full of diverse content for everyone to enjoy.

I do not believe that books should be removed from the shelves due to something offensive. Libraries are crucial in providing access to information, especially for those who may not have resources like computers at home. In today's society, where many job applications and school assignments are online, libraries offer essential internet access. As a student, I rely on the library for research and projects that require old books on history and the city. Everyone has a right to read, listen, or watch what they want. Sometimes it's not always up to them. For example rated-R movies, most children under 18 cannot watch them. Either it's a law or the parents have made it a rule. Music I think is different. Some songs have a bad influence on children whether it has to do with violence or cussing, certain songs like that still give kids the wrong message. Libraries should not have those kinds of books, music, movies, magazines, etc. If people want to view those kinds of things that other people find 'offensive' they should buy them on their own time. Not everyone has a great sense of humor, so things that some people find funny, others get offended by. Even if libraries had anything that would offend someone else, it would be the reader's choice to pick a book they want to read. Sometimes it may be better if children read these articles by themselves so it'd save time from having parents explain it to them later. They might ask a lot of questions the parents might not even have the answer for.   For example, when my brother watched a rated-R movie. In my brother's younger years, he was always curious and asked a lot of questions all the time. Sometimes my mother didn't know how to respond so she'd change the subject. Well, everyone knows the same old question 'Where do babies come from?'. That's the kind of question my brother was curious about. My mom never bothered to answer that question, but if she did she would make up some story. My brother was smart enough to know that what he was being told wasn't accurate at all. Finally one day he got nosy and took one of my mom's movies without asking. It happened to have the answer to his question. He was shocked and disgusted at the same time, yet he was glad to know he finally found the answer my mom wouldn't give.  In this situation I am somewhat neutral. I don't object to having things that might offend other people be removed from bookshelves but on the other hand, it might not be a good thing to put 'offensive' things in certain libraries if children can get to them. Perhaps it's what makes things not boring and makes it more interesting to the reader. Not everyone has the same opinion on things. It just may be a good thing to have these types of books whether it's stating a fact or stating their own opinion. Everyone does have a right to say their opinion, and there is nothing wrong with giving informational facts in articles or movies either.  The bad thing about having any 'offensive' things in libraries may not be a smart idea if it's where most children get their books. Parents can always have a say in what kind of book their children read or what kind of movies they watch. Some parents might not want to go through all the questions the children ask and give something to them that will explain it better for their understanding, while other parents don't want their children to see or know of any sort of things that may be 'offensive' until they're old enough to understand it better and are mature about those things. So in some cases, it might be a bad idea for things that only an adult should know to be on bookshelves in a library if a child might get ahold of it.  The quotation 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' by Katherine Paterson has its own opinion. The quotation is basically saying that even if a parent doesn't want their child to read something 'offensive,' if that parent reads it, then sometimes their children have a right to know. If the child has taken anything like that off a shelf, then once they know, they will not ask any more questions.

Dear @ORGANIZATION1, I think that it is wrong to remove offensive and other non-offensive books from the shelves in the library just because one or two students do not like them or do not want to see others reading them. The censorship in libraries should align with the age group accessing the materials. Children aged from 8 to 12 should be exposed to books containing profanity, as they are mature enough to handle such content without finding it offensive. However, children under 8 should not have access to books with profanity, as they are too young to understand or process such language. It is essential for libraries to maintain a level of censorship that is appropriate for the age group using the facilities, ensuring that children are exposed to content that is suitable for their level of maturity.

I am a citizen of @LOCATION1 and I believe that while censorship in libraries is necessary, it could be improved by implementing age restrictions on certain materials. It is essential to protect younger children from inappropriate content that may not be suitable for their maturity level. I have personally experienced instances where children have been exposed to content that they should not have been exposed to at such a young age.  However, it is also important to consider the needs of individuals who require access to certain materials for research purposes or other legitimate reasons. As a young adult, I believe that older children should have the opportunity to explore a wider range of topics and learn to distinguish between right and wrong. Ultimately, the responsibility also lies with parents or guardians to guide their children on what is appropriate for them to read.  While some children may not have mature adults to provide guidance, it is crucial for libraries to establish age limits or designate certain materials for a more mature audience. By doing so, the library can strike a balance between protecting young readers and providing access to necessary resources. In conclusion, while censorship in libraries is necessary, there is room for improvement by implementing age restrictions on certain materials to ensure a safer and more appropriate environment for all library users.

If something is found offensive, it should be removed from the shelves of public libraries. Parents expect their children to be able to access appropriate materials when visiting a library, without worrying about them encountering offensive content. Young minds can be influenced by what they read, and exposure to inappropriate language or topics can lead to confusion or curiosity that parents may not be ready to address. Public libraries should carefully consider the materials they offer to ensure that all visitors, regardless of age, are not exposed to offensive content. No one should leave a library feeling offended, and parents should not have to be concerned about what their children may come across. Libraries should be places of learning and knowledge, not sources of worry or harm.

I feel that they shouldn't be removed due to the fact that somebody else may like that movie, book, music, or magazine. Just because we might not like it doesn't mean there isn't someone out there who does. The library should have a variety of materials to cater to different tastes and preferences. Everyone should have the right to access the materials they enjoy, even if it may not be to everyone's liking. It is important to respect diversity and individual preferences when it comes to the selection of materials in the library.

What is this world coming to? We have stooped to the level of installing offensive materials in libraries where anyone can check them out. Being a daughter and teenager myself, I personally have had the experience of reading some of these offensive books and magazines. The sex, drugs, and violence used to create a story have destroyed the minds of our youth. I strongly feel this disturbing and destructive material should be removed from the shelves of libraries.  I do not question whether children and teens should read, but rather what they read. I agree reading helps our youth learn and excel in schooling, but offensive books and magazines put nasty ideas into their minds and distort their way of thinking. The more our younger generation reads about these ugly things, the more curious they become. I feel they will eventually let curiosity get the better of them.  Many would say that experiencing activities such as sex and drugs is all part of growing up, but I disagree. Trying any one of these harmful activities portrayed in certain library materials could put you and your health in severe danger. It only takes one time to become pregnant or become addicted to drugs.  To better prove my point, think of your favorite book. Did you look up to any of the main characters? Did you want to be just like him/her? Well, it seems to me that this malicious material makes the main character and hero of the story a bad role model. They may save the world and be a hero by day, but authors and producers make sure they include their night life in the story as well. This tells our children that it is okay to do these things, when it is the exact opposite.  I stand by my opinion and believe offensive books, magazines, and movies should be removed from the shelves of libraries. This material plants a bad seed in the mind of our youth. It leads them to believe everyone, including their heroes in books and movies, does these things. Sex, violence, and drugs are not what this world was made for. Let us protect the innocence and well-being of our youth by removing such harmful materials from their reach.

People often debate whether graphic images or words in books, movies, and other media have a significant impact on children's outlook on various topics. Some argue that such content can shape children's perceptions and should be restricted, while others believe that children will inevitably come across such material and that there should be no limitations. The latter viewpoint suggests that censorship is unnecessary, as children will eventually learn about sensitive topics regardless.  Critics of explicit content in media often cite concerns about offensive language, inappropriate themes, or stereotypes that may be harmful to certain groups. However, proponents of freedom of expression argue that authors and creators use these elements for entertainment or to convey important messages, and that their work should not be censored based on subjective interpretations.  Ultimately, the idea that restricting mature content in books or media will protect children from exposure to certain topics is flawed. Children will inevitably encounter diverse perspectives and themes as they grow up, and it is essential for them to learn how to navigate and understand these complexities. Therefore, rather than censoring content, it is important to engage in open discussions with children about what they are exposed to and help them develop critical thinking skills to interpret and analyze information effectively.  In conclusion, while it is understandable that parents may have concerns about the content their children consume, complete censorship is not the solution. Instead, fostering an environment of open communication and critical thinking is crucial in helping children navigate the complexities of the world around them.

Every author has an intended audience when they are writing a book, and they write about what they think is appropriate for that certain audience. Unfortunately, sometimes other people that are not intended to read the book actually do read it even though it may not be something that they are supposed to be reading. When an author writes a children's book, it is meant for a child to read, not an adult. Also when an author writes a romance novel, it is meant for people who can comprehend what the author is talking about and can act maturely while reading it. Although some novels may not be appropriate for certain people, censorship in libraries is not the way to fix that, and it is a big mistake.  As humans we are given certain freedoms, and one of those freedoms is the freedom of press. Authors should be able to write about whatever they choose to write about. If they choose to write about subjects that are not appropriate for all age groups they still have the right to have their books in libraries. Even though everyone isn't supposed to read them, certain people are. If you take those books away because you're scared that a child might get a hold of one, then you're taking away what certain people enjoy reading.  Due to the fact that different books are intended for different age groups, libraries have different sections filled with a variety of authors. They have a children's section made primarily for children, an adult section with books that only adults are supposed to read, and a teen section for everyone in between. By having sections within them, libraries are trying to keep people reading what they were intended to read without censoring or taking away people's favorite books. Having sections in libraries is a happy medium between letting anyone read whatever book they would like no matter how inappropriate it may be, and cutting out certain books altogether.  If a person is an adult, they should be allowed to go to the library and get whatever type of book, magazine, music, or movie that they want. If a kid's parent is okay with them checking out or looking at certain things then it shouldn't matter to anyone else if they think that the material is offensive. Instead of censoring what movies, books, magazines, or music that libraries have, there should be a certain age when someone can come in without a parent and check out whatever they would like. If a person is under that age then their parents should be present while they check out so they can approve of what their child is checking out.  Censorship in libraries is ultimately pointless and shouldn't even be considered. Whether some people find certain material offensive or not, there are other ways to get that material so there really is no point to censoring anything in libraries.

I think that all offensive materials should be removed from libraries so everyone can enjoy books, music, and movies without being offended. These materials should have their own section, locked up to prevent children from accessing them. This way, everyone can have access to a wide range of content without being exposed to inappropriate material. By segregating offensive content, libraries can ensure a fair and inclusive environment for all patrons.

Picture this: you come home one day after work and before you even enter the house, you hear music blaring from your child's room. As you step closer, you begin to hear the lyrics that go with the banging bass and you realize that that isn't just any music, it's completely unedited, explicit versions of vulgar songs. Now, who would want their child listening to songs that make it seem like drinking, doing drugs, and other various risky activities are okay? I know I sure wouldn't.  Music isn't the only source of offensive material in today's society. It can be found nearly anywhere. In books, magazines, TV shows, movies, on the internet, you name it. All of these are easily accessible by children of all ages. That is why there should be censorship of certain materials, to a certain degree. By this, I mean that if there is a dirty book in a public library, it should only be able to be rented by people who are of a certain age. Just because it's bad doesn't mean that it has to completely vanish from the face of the world. There should just be a limitation on who can view it. That applies to everything that could contain offensive material.  Kids are kids. There are certain things that should be absolutely off-limits to them--such as explicit movies, books, music, etc.--as they do not need to know about drugs, sex, or alcohol at such a young age. Censorship should definitely be in effect in places like public libraries where young children are bound to be. But, as mentioned earlier, censorship should only be to a certain degree. Keeping children's minds clean for as long as possible would be a very positive thing to do for both them and our society in general. Therefore, it is crucial to implement appropriate censorship measures to protect young minds from harmful and inappropriate content.

'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This strong statement by Katherine Paterson highlights the issue of censorship in libraries. In today's society, we often hear about books and other resources being banned from libraries due to unpopular views. The classic novel, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, has been removed from many shelves because of its language deemed offensive. However, libraries should not remove materials based on offensiveness, as it goes against their purpose and limits access to diverse viewpoints. Libraries are meant to provide information, interest, and enlightenment to all individuals. When materials are censored due to differing opinions, the library fails to fulfill its role. What one person finds offensive, another may find valuable. Children should be handled differently, with parents or guardians having the right to restrict access to inappropriate content. Libraries should provide separate sections for different age groups to ensure appropriate access. Banning books removes a part of history and restricts knowledge for future generations. Censorship in libraries limits our rights and hinders intellectual freedom. It is crucial to preserve access to diverse materials to encourage learning and understanding in society.

Our founding fathers created amendments to protect the freedom of speech, one of the greatest being the right to express oneself without censorship. Censoring offensive materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, is unnecessary and limits the ability of individuals to share their thoughts and ideas. Book burning, a historical act of destroying written works deemed undesirable, is a harmful practice that stifles creativity and knowledge. Libraries should not censor books, as they are meant to provide access to a wide range of information and perspectives. Parents should engage with their children about the media they consume rather than simply restricting access. Censorship of offensive materials is not the solution; instead, we should strive to understand and address the complexities of life. Freedom of speech is a fundamental right that should be upheld, and censorship is not conducive to the intellectual growth and development of individuals.

Books, magazines, movies, and music should not be put in higher reaches or removed from shelves just because some individuals find them offensive. It is unfair to restrict access to certain materials based on personal opinions. People should have the freedom to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to. Removing these items can hinder individuals, such as students, from accessing important information for educational purposes. It is important to respect different perspectives and not impose restrictions on what others can access. Everyone should have the opportunity to explore a wide range of content without censorship.

Libraries are a great resource for learning, but it is important to be mindful of the content that is made available to the public. Offensive material, whether in the form of books, movies, or music, can be harmful and upsetting to certain individuals. While libraries may prioritize profit, it is crucial for them to consider the impact of what they choose to offer on their shelves. Offensive movies can be disrespectful to certain groups, offensive music can promote harmful messages, and offensive books can be disturbing to readers. It is essential for libraries to exercise caution and thoughtfulness in their selection process to ensure that they provide a safe and respectful environment for all patrons.

I have little cousins, and I've seen it happen many times where they cuss back at their parents, and when the parents ask them where they heard that, it's usually the same answer - TV or movies.  So, do you really think it's necessary to have all that inappropriate content around for anyone, of many ages, to see? It's not. Everything like that just needs to be taken off all shelves and destroyed because I shouldn't have to see it, and neither should anyone else. It's gross, nasty, and inappropriate for children. Libraries contain a wide range of materials, including books, music, and magazines. However, not all of these materials may be suitable for all visitors. Offensive, distracting, and inappropriate material should be removed from the shelves and placed in a separate section of the public library to ensure a comfortable and appropriate environment for all patrons.  For example, young children may inadvertently come across books on sensitive topics such as abortions, which are not age-appropriate for them. It is essential to protect children from potentially harmful content by segregating such materials in a designated section. Additionally, distracting elements like loud music can disrupt the peaceful atmosphere of a library, making it challenging for others to concentrate. By creating a separate area for music listening, individuals can enjoy their music without disturbing fellow visitors.  Furthermore, magazines with inappropriate content should be completely removed from the library. Ensuring that magazines cater to specific age groups can prevent exposure to unsuitable material, maintaining a safe and welcoming environment for all library users. Implementing these measures can help promote a positive library experience for everyone.  In conclusion, by segregating offensive, distracting, and inappropriate materials into their own sections within the library, we can create a more inclusive and respectful space for all visitors. It is essential to prioritize the comfort and well-being of library patrons by carefully curating the available materials. Let us strive to foster a welcoming environment where individuals of all ages can explore, learn, and enjoy the offerings of the library without encountering unsuitable content.

I do not believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. Censorship takes away from the author's freedom of expression and the reader's ability to experience a work in its original form. While some content may be deemed offensive to some, it is important to allow artists and creators to convey their messages without restriction. Removing offensive materials limits the artistic value and overall impact of the work. In conclusion, censorship should not be used to restrict access to books, music, movies, or other forms of media, as it hinders creative expression and the exchange of diverse ideas.

Sexual conduct, language, and criminal behavior are prevalent in schools and communities, with certain books, movies, music, and magazines focusing on these themes. While libraries provide access to these materials, there is a need for stricter censorship to protect young individuals from exposure to inappropriate content.   Movies, magazines like @ORGANIZATION1, and music often contain explicit content that may not be suitable for children under a certain age. By removing such materials from library shelves, educators and parents can prevent early exposure to mature themes and discourage premature interest in these subjects.   Music, in particular, is easily accessible in libraries and can introduce children to explicit language, sexual behavior, and criminal acts. By restricting access to music with adult-rated content, libraries can create a safer environment for young individuals to explore without being exposed to harmful influences.   While enjoying magazines, movies, and music is a common pastime, it is essential to prioritize content that does not promote inappropriate behavior. By involving parents in media consumption decisions and enforcing stricter censorship in libraries, we can help guide children towards more age-appropriate and positive influences. Censorship in libraries is crucial in shaping the development of young individuals and should be a priority in safeguarding their well-being.

The diversity of the world makes it rather difficult to please every person all of the time. What I find appropriate, another person finds obscene and vulgar. What I enjoy in terms of media consumption may bother someone else, but that does not justify removing it from public access.   While it is understandable that certain content may not be suitable for everyone, outright censorship is not the solution. Instead, materials that some may find inappropriate can be placed in designated sections or areas within a library, making them less accessible to those who may not wish to be exposed to them.  By allowing for the segregation of materials based on content, individuals can make informed choices about what they consume, while still preserving the freedom of expression and access to information for all. It is important to find a balance that respects differing perspectives and preferences without resorting to blanket censorship. Ultimately, the goal should be to provide a wide range of materials while also respecting the boundaries and values of diverse individuals and communities.

There are many different people in this world, each with their own opinions about books, music, movies, magazines, and more. Just because one person doesn't particularly like horror movies, it doesn't mean that movie stores should remove horror films from their shelves. There are many people who are fans of slasher films and enjoy scary movies. It's important to cater to a variety of tastes and preferences.   I, for one, enjoy a wide range of genres when it comes to books, music, and movies. Trying new things can help broaden your horizons and introduce you to new experiences. Imagine if a bookstore decided to remove a classic book like "The Tiger and the Pig" from their shelves because they believed a tiger and a pig could never be friends. This would limit the options available to customers and could ultimately harm their business.   In a diverse world like ours, it's essential to embrace different perspectives and preferences. Variety is what keeps things interesting and allows people to discover new things they may come to love. So, let's continue to celebrate diversity and encourage a wide range of choices in the media we consume.

What is considered offensive? If we took books, music, movies, and magazines that people found offensive off shelves, there would be nothing left. Everyone is different, which means they all get offended in different ways. By taking all this off shelves, we would be providing a smaller education for students around the world. Things we learn about in school, slavery, wars, and some politics could offend many people. But if we were to take them off the shelves at school and libraries, children will have no idea about history or what is going on in the current world. What about drugs and alcohol? Many parents do not talk to their children about the uses of controlled substances, so without these sources, they may never know the harm that they can do to someone's body. Everyone takes something offensive, but not everyone takes the same thing offensive. So who is to say what offends people and what does not? If that's the case, shouldn't we take all books, movies, music, and magazines away from children's schools and libraries? Adults get offended too, so should we take all of their resources away, including the newspaper? By taking away what one may call offensive, it could land us in the dark ages with no books, no local news, no movies, no nothing because not one person can say what the whole world considers offensive. Everyone has the right to read and write what they want. No one can say what offends everyone. Someone may get offended by talking about one's race, another may get offended by talking about religion, and someone may even get offended if you talk about their cute little kitty cat. Everyone looks at everything differently. So why try and control us all as one? All people think differently and they know what they want to read, hear, and watch all by themselves; they don't need someone to tell them.

Censorship should only be implemented in environments where young children are present, such as schools and children's television programs. However, censoring materials that are not intended for young audiences, such as books, movies, magazines, and music, is counterproductive. By censoring content meant for adults, we limit our ability to explore new ideas and advance as a society. Parents who advocate for censorship of adult content are neglecting the opportunity to engage in important discussions with their children and help them develop critical thinking skills. Personal experiences also play a significant role in shaping one's views on censorship, as exposure to uncensored materials during childhood can foster maturity and understanding. While censorship has its place in certain contexts, such as children's media, it should not be used to restrict the free exchange of ideas among adults. In a society that values freedom of speech, individuals have the right to express themselves without fear of censorship based on the opinions of a minority. Ultimately, censorship should be approached with caution and used judiciously to protect children while respecting the rights of adults to access a wide range of information and perspectives.

Book censorship is a national issue that sparks debate over what should be allowed on the shelves for children to read. While some parents may find certain content offensive, others may see it as a necessary lesson for their children. In my opinion, books should be censored on a national scale, similar to the movie industry's rating system. However, it is ultimately the responsibility of parents to regulate what their children read. Removing books from shelves based on individual preferences would leave little left for anyone to read. Therefore, parents should focus on controlling their own children's reading habits rather than imposing their beliefs on others. Ultimately, a balance between censorship and personal responsibility is key in addressing this complex issue.

No, it would not be right to remove a book from the library just because one person finds it offensive. Decisions like this should be made collectively, considering the opinions of many people. Just because one individual is offended by a book does not mean it should be discarded. There may be others who enjoy the book and would be deprived of the opportunity to read it. It is important to respect diverse opinions and preferences when it comes to literature. If a book is offensive to someone, they can simply choose not to read it rather than imposing their views on others. Everyone should have the opportunity to access a wide range of books in a library without fear of censorship based on individual preferences. It is essential to consider the diverse needs and interests of library users when making decisions about book selection.

The media plays a crucial role in shaping the minds of individuals, especially children. It is essential to ensure that the content being consumed is appropriate and positive to avoid any negative impact. Children are highly impressionable, and exposure to vulgar or offensive material can have lasting effects on their development.   I support the decision to remove inappropriate content from public access, whether it be in schools or other platforms. It is important to safeguard the innocence of children and promote a healthy mindset. Adults are also susceptible to the influence of media, and it is crucial to be vigilant in monitoring the content being consumed.   Overall, it is imperative to prioritize the well-being and positive growth of individuals by restricting access to harmful material. By taking a stand against negative content, we can ensure a more nurturing environment for children and adults alike.

I think that they should remove inappropriate books and content from children's reach, as the exposure to such material can have a negative impact on their development. With the increasing accessibility of information, it is essential to monitor what children are exposed to. Implementing age-appropriate sections in libraries can help in ensuring that kids are not exposed to content meant for adults. Furthermore, parents should be honest with their children about sensitive topics like sex and drugs, as being informed at a young age can help them make better decisions in the future. Education on these subjects should start early in schools to equip children with the knowledge to navigate the complexities of the world. By being proactive in controlling what children are exposed to, we can create a safer and more informed environment for the younger generation. It is important to address these issues now before they escalate further and create bigger challenges for society.

Books have been a part of every person's life since they learn to read. Initially, parents and teachers introduce books to children, and as individuals grow older, books become a part of their academic and professional lives. Authors write books to attract an audience, and while some may find certain books offensive, it does not justify removing them from shelves. People have the choice to stop reading a book if they find it offensive, but it should not be denied to others who may appreciate it. When it comes to children's books, parents should take on the responsibility of monitoring and censoring what their children read. However, for adults, the interpretation of a book is subjective, and different individuals may have varying opinions about the same book. Ultimately, the freedom to read and form opinions about books should be respected, and censorship should be left to individual discretion, particularly when it comes to children. Every book has its place on the shelf, waiting to be explored and discussed, allowing readers to gain unique perspectives and insights.

I believe that offensive books, music, movies, and magazines should not be pulled off the shelves of libraries. Everyone has different tastes and interests, and it is important to provide a variety of content for people to choose from. Restricting access to offensive material can limit people's freedom to choose what they want to read, listen to, or watch. Additionally, censoring offensive material in libraries may not prevent people from accessing it elsewhere. It is essential to uphold the principle of freedom of expression and allow individuals to make their own choices when it comes to the media they consume. Ultimately, keeping offensive material available in libraries ensures that people have the opportunity to explore diverse perspectives and engage with challenging content.

I agree with Katherine Paterson.

When I go to a library I may find some stuff that is offensive to me. But what is offensive to me may not be offensive to the person beside me. People have different opinions based on their history, making it difficult to set boundaries on what is considered offensive. What one person finds offensive, another may see as the best thing ever. Offensive content does not have a set definition that everyone can agree on. However, there should be limitations in place to keep certain things away from certain age groups, like not allowing a kindergartener to check out a mature movie. Censorship is necessary to protect people, but ultimately, it comes down to using common sense to navigate what is appropriate. While we may never all agree on what is offensive, utilizing common sense can help solve the problem.

Certain people believe that offensive books, magazines, or music should be taken off the shelves of libraries. I think that offensive media should not be removed because individuals have the right to choose what they want to see or hear. It is not up to others to dictate what can be accessed. Removing offensive material would limit people's knowledge and prevent them from forming their own opinions. For example, learning about historical events like the Holocaust, despite being disturbing, is crucial to prevent history from repeating itself. Society should not control what people are exposed to, as it is essential to understand both the good and bad aspects of the world. Offensive content should not be censored, but rather acknowledged and understood.

Katherine Paterson emphasizes the importance of considering different viewpoints when it comes to censoring books. She argues that just because a book may be offensive to some, it does not necessarily mean it should be removed from shelves. Paterson suggests that a fairer approach would be to take a vote to determine whether a book should be kept or removed based on the opinions of a larger group of people. By allowing for discussion and debate on the matter, a more balanced decision can be reached. It is crucial to consider the diverse perspectives that individuals may have on a particular book before deciding its fate. Ultimately, removing a book should not be based solely on the opinions of a few, but rather on a collective decision that takes into account a variety of viewpoints.

Library censorship is a controversial topic that revolves around the removal of offensive materials from shelves. While some may find certain books, music, or other forms of media offensive, it is important to remember that everyone has the right to freedom of speech. Denying authors, musicians, and artists the ability to express themselves would be a violation of their basic rights as American citizens.   It is crucial to understand that just because something may be offensive to one person, it does not mean it should be removed for everyone. Libraries are meant to be a resource for everyone, providing materials that cater to a diverse range of interests and preferences. While individuals have the right to avoid materials they find offensive, it is not fair to deprive others of the opportunity to access these resources.   In conclusion, while it is important to consider the feelings of those who may find certain materials offensive, it is equally important to respect the rights of creators and consumers of these materials. Libraries should strive to provide a wide array of resources, even if some may be deemed offensive by certain individuals. It is essential to maintain a balance between freedom of expression and the sensitivities of the community.

Censorship in books and music is a significant concern in our society, particularly in @LOCATION1. Personally, I believe that instead of removing books from shelves, we should address the issues within them and move past the controversy. One example is the novel 'The @CAPS2 of @ORGANIZATION1,' which has faced backlash for its use of the word 'nigger.' While some may find this offensive, I believe it is important to understand the context in which the word is used rather than simply removing the book altogether.  In terms of music, particularly rap music, there are concerns about the explicit lyrics promoting violence, drug use, and other criminal activities. On the topic of movies and magazines, I have witnessed instances where excessive nudity in films can be inappropriate for younger audiences. In these cases, I believe that certain materials should be restricted or banned to protect vulnerable individuals from negative influences.  In conclusion, while some forms of media may contain controversial or harmful content, it is crucial to approach censorship with caution and thoughtfulness. Rather than outright banning materials, we should focus on educating individuals and promoting critical thinking to navigate the complexities of modern media. By fostering a culture of understanding and discernment, we can better address the challenges posed by potentially harmful content in books, music, movies, and magazines.

I don't think censorship is right for our public libraries. In my opinion, it depends on what they are saying or showing, as well as the age of the audience. People have different preferences and interpretations, so censorship may not be suitable for everyone. Removing books, music, movies, and magazines from shelves because they are deemed offensive can limit access to diverse perspectives and information. People should have the opportunity to explore different topics and cultures through reading materials. Censorship can restrict the variety of content available for readers, ultimately hindering the learning and growth potential of individuals. Therefore, I believe that censorship in public libraries may not be beneficial as it could limit access to valuable resources and knowledge.

If the library is in a high school, then we are all old enough to have already seen or heard anything and everything offensive. In case we haven't, you can't shield your kids from offensive material. This hurts them in the long run. For example, when your boss gets to work and you or someone around you mess up an important assignment or task, he may use terms such as the 'F' word or other vulgar terms to describe how mad he is. If you were to just hear those for the first time being yelled at you, there is a chance you would have a breakdown or be ineffective at work. Now, I'm not saying we should all use vulgar language every day. I'm just saying that the real world doesn't have a 'clean' version. There is no mom or dad there to stand by and say, "Oh no, that's not acceptable speech, son." If you took a survey of the daily language of teens and young adults, almost half would say they use some form of vulgar language or inappropriate terms. We need to teach our kids and teens that it's not okay to say those things, and they need to know what is acceptable in society. But sheltering them in the library and then thrusting them into a world with daily inappropriate acts is not right. It's important to educate them on appropriate behavior and language to prepare them for the realities of the world they will face.

Do we have the right to take books? Author Katherine Paterson proves a point by saying 'if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' @CAPS1 is saying that if everyone is able to just remove books from the shelf because they have something against it then we would hardly have any books at our libraries. Everyone has their own opinions. There are so many things that affect our opinions. Our beliefs, lifestyles, ways of thinking, culture, and the list goes on. I'm sure I could think of certain books, movies, music, and magazines that I don't like and could just do without. Does that mean I want to totally rid the world of those certain materials? It sure wouldn't bother me but that would be extremely selfish. Even if something is totally inappropriate and offensive, it is still information.
