That saying Katherine Paterson said 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' I disagree with that statement. I think it is the government's choice if these items should be taken out of libraries or not. So we will need legitimate reasons to take some books off the shelf.  Some people think we should take books off the shelf that teach the kids our history. People don't have that right to take away from children. In the statement Katherine made, she is supporting that very idea; taking away our kids' right to learn US history. The kids have that right to learn our very own history and some people want to take that away. Then what will our future generation be like. Some kids might not even know who George Washington is or how we got here to this very continent.  Parents also don't want us to read anything in books that have foul language or anything to do with nudity. I see what these parents are trying to do. They are trying to protect their children, but the fact is people are going to have to go through this in life and if they aren't introduced at a younger age what will they do when they are older. Some kids that have that right taken away from will have no idea what to do when they get older and the foul language in the texts of these books put voice into the books. We don't want the upcoming generations to be blind to all of this because it is the real world.  When I was in fifth grade I liked to read a lot. I really liked the adventure books such as the Boxcar Children and books like that. One time I went into the library and I picked out a book about a haunted house. The librarian would not let me check the book out because there were some texts in the book not appropriate for me. That sort of crushed my reading spirit and I really never wanted to go and check out a book by myself anymore. So adults that want to take these books off the shelves you might be stopping our generation from learning and if we don't learn then our next generation isn't going to want to read anything or learn.  These are just a couple of reasons we should not take books, magazines, movies, and music away from us. There are more people out there that have reasons too, so if you want to take this right away from us then be prepared for an argument because we will fight for this right. So you adults who want to take that book off the shelf, you better have real good legitimate reasons to take it off.

Censorship is a complex issue that can lead to the removal of music, books, and movies from public consumption. However, banning offensive material can have detrimental effects on the artistic expression and freedom of speech. While some argue that removing offensive content protects sensitive audiences and prevents negative influences, I believe that censorship should be avoided for several reasons.  Firstly, suppressing offensive material silences the thoughts and emotions of the creators. Banning works like "To Kill a Mockingbird" deprives readers of the author's intended message and historical context. By censoring content, we limit our understanding of different perspectives and erode the richness of literature.  Furthermore, removing offensive material sets a dangerous precedent where any work can be deemed unacceptable. As Katherine Paterson pointed out, if we continue to ban books, soon there will be nothing left on the shelves for anyone to enjoy. What may be considered offensive today could become accepted in the future, highlighting the subjective nature of censorship.  In conclusion, censorship of offensive material stifles artistic expression, limits diverse viewpoints, and threatens the availability of creative works for future generations. It is essential to respect the freedom of speech and allow individuals to make their own choices about what they consume. If we continue to censor content based on personal opinions, we risk losing the beauty and diversity of the arts that enrich our lives.

Everyone is different and unique in the world and they have their own unique opinions. Which brings us to the arguement of censorship on anything, because what some people find offensive others may not. The censorship that I am discussing is specifically about censorship in libraries. There are three main reasons why libraries should not be censored. The first reason is the books were written so they could be viewed by the public. The next reason is people have the right to make their own decisions. The final reason is parents can limit what their own children read. The censorship of libraries is an absurd idea, because a few people shouldn't make the choice for everyone.    The first reason that libraries shouldn't be censored is the books were written so they would be read by the public. A library is a public place where people are supposed to get whatever books they choose. If a few people start censoring books then it will set off a chain reaction. After so many different books are censored there will be less books for peole to enjoy. All of the books that were censored were meant to be enjoyed. If books are censored some people may never even get a chance to see those books and they wont be able to learn from them. Books deserve the chance to be enjoyed like they were meant to be enjoyed and if they are censored that chance is gone.    The next reason is people have the right to make their own decisions. If someone doesn't like a book then they don't have to read it. They don't have the right to go censor that book, because they don't like it. Another person may enjoy that book and many others may like it as well. People should be able to choose what books they want and they shouldn't be told by others what they can and can't read. They need to let others make the decision when it comes to getting their books. People can't go around preventing other people from reading a book that they enjoyed. They need to let others think for themselves and let them read what they want to.    The last reason is parents can limit what their children read. If the parents don't want their children reading something then they can tell their children that they aren't allowed to read it. Other people shouldn't be able to censor a book, because it is innapropiate for children. The child's parents can protect them if they find the book offensive for their children. Everyone needs to worry about what they like and let the other people enjoy what they want to. Let the parents set the limit for their children and it makes life simpler. Also it allows everyone else to enjoy the books if they aren't censored just for children. Parents will worry about their children and adults can worry about themselves.    The censorship of libraries is absolutely wrong and it is also unjust. Somone shouldn't be able to say, 'I don't like this book so censor it.' I will remind you of the three reason why this is true. First the books were written so they would be enjoyed by the public. Also people people have the right to choose what they want. Finally parents can set limits on what their own children read. Books should be left uncensored so they can be enjoyed by whoever wants to read them. Everyone needs to let books be enjoyed by all and they shouldn't take away a books cahnce to be loved by censoring it.

Some people ask, 'Should books be censored from libraries?' It is often parents who believe that libraries contain inappropriate material for their children and advocate for censorship. However, the decision to censor or remove books from libraries should be based on the subject matter of the material. Parents also play a crucial role in monitoring what their children read, watch, and listen to, rather than solely relying on libraries to censor content. Author Katherine Paterson raises a valid point that if individuals have the right to remove books, then there may be a risk of losing access to a variety of perspectives. While some movies may warrant censorship due to extreme violence or gore, it is essential to consider the context in which censorship is being proposed. Magazines and music should also be evaluated based on their content, with inappropriate material being restricted to specific age groups. In conclusion, censorship of books, music, movies, and magazines should be approached cautiously, with a focus on the subject matter and its potential impact. Ultimately, the responsibility lies with parents to guide their children's media consumption choices.

Today I am going to talk about certain materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines. Should they be removed from the shelf if they are found offensive? In today's world, it is hard to please every living soul. Everyone is going to disagree about something in their lifetime. Life as we know it, everybody lives it in a different way, and in a different place, but everybody has read a book, listened to music, and even read a magazine at a time or two. People interpret it differently than others. Therefore, I personally don't think they should take articles out of the library that you can learn something from unless it's something like pornography, then they should definitely take it out. My conclusion is that you can't please everybody. I think that you shouldn't take things out of the library that can help a student learn.

At a local library, you can find a diverse range of books catering to various interests and preferences. While some individuals may find certain books disturbing or inappropriate, it is essential to recognize that everyone has different tastes and perspectives when it comes to reading material. It is not fair for one person's opinion to dictate what others can or cannot read.  While some may argue for the removal of certain books deemed inappropriate, it is crucial to consider that what one person finds offensive, another may find enlightening or engaging. It is essential to respect the diversity of opinions and allow individuals the freedom to choose their reading material based on their own interests and preferences.  While adult content such as pornographic material should be restricted to adult stores, books containing nudity for educational purposes, such as health-related topics, should be available for those seeking knowledge and awareness. It is important to strike a balance between protecting individuals, especially children, from explicit content while also promoting education and awareness on important issues.  In a society with varying viewpoints and preferences, it is important to uphold the principles of freedom of speech and expression. Every author deserves to have their voice heard, and every individual deserves the opportunity to explore different perspectives through reading. Let us embrace the diversity of literature and allow everyone to find joy and enrichment in the books they choose to read.

Dear @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3:  I am @PERSON1 and I have heard there has been a discussion about different things in libraries. And I would like to let you know what I think about the whole situation. There are many things like books, music, movies, magazines, etc. that people believe aren't appropriate. Many people have different opinions than other people. Everyone has a different point of view and sees things differently, especially when it comes to what is appropriate for kids.  I believe if a child comes home with a book, movie, etc. and their parent does not approve, the parent should go and tell the librarian about why she thinks it isn't appropriate. The librarian should listen to the parent and then take a look at it for herself to see what she thinks about it. If she finds it not appropriate, then she has the right to take it off the shelf.  If the parent talks to the librarian about why something is not appropriate and the librarian believes it is alright, then maybe she needs to just put the book, movie, etc. in a different area of the library. For example, if a little kid finds a book and the parent says it's inappropriate, the librarian could move that book out of the little kid section and put it in an older kid area.  I have actually had an experience with this. At my old school, adults were always complaining about books they didn't think were appropriate. The librarian at the time thought they were appropriate and really didn't want to take them out of the library. So she had a great idea. She took those books, the ones people were complaining about, and put them on their own special shelf behind her desk. If you wanted one of those books, you had to talk to your parent or bring a note in saying that you were allowed to read the book. It was a really good idea because if your parent wouldn't allow you to read them, you weren't tempted to get one, and wouldn't even see them. And the people who were allowed and wanted to read them still could with no problem at all.  Another idea I have is if you see a younger kid by older people's books, movies, etc., go talk to them about why they are over there and tell them that's not their age level material. Try to direct them over to their age level area and find them a book, movie, etc. they might be interested in.  I believe that everyone has different opinions, but just because one person complains, it doesn't mean it has to ruin it for everyone. Just because one person doesn't like it doesn't mean everyone else does too. I think censorship should somewhat be in libraries, but not to the extreme. There should be many different topics in libraries so everyone enjoys the stuff there. There should be action, adventure, humor, love, etc. Talk to people and see what they like. Just because one person complains, don't take it out right away because to another person, they might love it. Thank you for taking your time to read my opinion, and I hope I helped.

I think that libraries should not remove music, movies, or magazines from their shelves. These items provide a form of relaxation and entertainment for people who visit the library. Removing them would take away a valuable resource for those looking to unwind and escape from their daily lives. Additionally, keeping these materials available at the library can help attract more visitors and ultimately benefit the library financially. It is not fair to blame children for the removal of books from the shelves, as they are not responsible for such decisions. People, especially children, enjoy visiting the library to read, listen to music, and explore different types of media. It would be a shame to take away these opportunities for individuals seeking solace and enjoyment at the library. Ultimately, removing such items would not only upset library visitors but also potentially harm the library's reputation and services. It is important to consider the needs and preferences of library-goers when making decisions about the availability of books, music, and magazines.

Are you offended when you read a book and your eyes cross over a swear word? Does it bother you to hear them with your own ears? No matter how hard you try, you can not avoid the harsh language of today's society.   Have you ever walked into your library and started reading a book but decided to put it back on the shelf because of the language in the book? Many books in today's libraries have offensive language. Sometimes it gives the book character and makes the story more real to the reader, but in other cases the reader may be offended.   In my personal view, if you do not like the language of the book, put it back on the shelf. The author wrote the book the way he or she wanted it to be written, not the way you would like to see it. Some material may be inappropriate for younger readers. The maturity level of the reader definitely makes a difference when discussing censorship.   For example, I am sure many parents have a problem with the movie 'The Hangover' for its use of alcohol and drugs. Many people find this movie funny and entertaining. Should this movie be taken off the shelves because it does use alcohol and drugs?   These words and actions we try to censor are not going away. We see and hear them in everyday life, no matter where you may be. So if you don't like the language in the book, choose a different one. Ultimately, it is up to the individual to decide what material they are comfortable with and what they are not.

I think that if certain materials are offensive, they should be taken off the shelves, depending on the nature of the offensiveness. If the material promotes racism, prejudice, or offends women or men, it should not be available for consumption. People should have access to reading materials and media that do not offend or harm others.  Offensive content can perpetuate negative stereotypes and attitudes, especially among impressionable children. Removing offensive material can help prevent the spread of harmful beliefs and behaviors. It is important for libraries to provide a safe and inclusive environment for all patrons.  Additionally, offensive material can lead to a decline in library usage and support. People may avoid visiting libraries that house offensive content, leading to a loss of community engagement and support. It is crucial for libraries to consider the impact of the material they provide and ensure it aligns with promoting respect and understanding among all individuals.  In conclusion, offensive material should be removed from shelves to prevent harm, promote inclusivity, and maintain a positive library environment. Libraries play a crucial role in fostering learning and understanding, and it is important for them to provide materials that do not perpetuate harmful attitudes or beliefs.

There are people who believe that certain materials should be removed from shelves or not even created in the first place. However, it is ultimately up to individuals to decide whether they want to engage with offensive content or not. While some may find certain material offensive and advocate for its removal, others argue that it should remain available for those who are interested in exploring it. It is important to remember that everyone has the right to choose what they consume, and avoiding content that is deemed offensive is a simple solution. Instead of spending time and effort trying to ban material, individuals can simply opt not to engage with it. By allowing controversial material to remain accessible, we uphold the freedom of choice and avoid censorship. Ultimately, it is up to individuals to decide what they want to read or listen to, and taking responsibility for their own choices is key in navigating a world where offensive content may exist.

Censorship in libraries can be a contentious issue, especially when it comes to deciding what material should be made available to the public. While it is important to protect children and young people from content that may be inappropriate for their age, completely removing books and other media from the library may not be the best solution.   One possible approach to addressing this issue is to create an alternative section in the library for material that some people may find offensive. This way, individuals who wish to access such content can do so without it being readily available to everyone. For example, books with explicit content could be moved to this section, along with music albums containing offensive language or themes, and movies with higher ratings.  By implementing an alternative section for controversial material, libraries can strike a balance between providing access to a wide range of content while also respecting the concerns of parents and other patrons. This approach allows individuals to make informed choices about the material they consume while preserving the diversity of literature and media available in the library.

There are thousands of libraries throughout the world filled with a variety of materials for people of all ages. Some argue for censorship in libraries, but I believe that materials should not be removed or censored. If materials were to be censored, the variety available would decrease, limiting choices for individuals with different interests. Furthermore, people should have the freedom to choose what they want to look at in a library, as preferences vary widely among age groups and individuals. Additionally, every item in a library can serve a purpose for research, whether it be for academic projects or personal interests. In conclusion, the availability of uncensored materials in libraries is essential for providing diverse options, catering to individual preferences, and supporting research needs.

In my opinion, no items should be removed from the library because people have various interests that should be catered to. While some items may not be appropriate for children, there are ways to segregate materials to ensure age-appropriate access. Removing items could lead to dissatisfaction among library patrons and potentially decrease overall library attendance. It is important to respect the diverse interests of the community and provide access to a wide range of materials to maintain a vibrant and inclusive library environment.

Books mean a lot to people that love to read. Books have pictures, or they may even be poem books. Some books should not be on the shelves in libraries. They have offensive language and not so well of pictures. They may be learning books, but the little kids do not need to see that. I think books should be removed from the shelves if found offensive. Libraries need to up their standards of what should be in the library and what should not. The books, movies, music, etc. need to be in a certain section of the library where the little kids cannot go or reach. A library is a family place, not a fun zone for adults.  On a stormy day, I went to the library with my brother to pick out a book for him. He is only six, about to be seven. He had told me he wanted to get a book about dinosaurs, but I told him to get one on space and aliens. He was very into reading. We were walking down the street when a bolt of lightning struck through the trees. 'Ekkk!' said my brother as he ran around me. We walked into the library, and the old lady at the front desk said, 'there is a huge storm coming.' We sort of ignored her and went on about our business picking out books for my brother. We walked upstairs to the children's section. My brother was looking around, and he said, 'hey, what is this?' as he picked up a naughty magazine. I rushed over to snatch it out of his hands, and he got scared. He asked, 'but sissy, what is that?' I did not respond. I told him to pick a book and come on. He grabbed one, and we were on our way to get it checked out when the lights suddenly went off. It was completely dark. 'Stay calm,' a man said. The backup lights came on, and we all went to the lobby area. We sat there for twenty minutes, and the lights came back on. Everything was normal again, and we went to check out. We got up to the front, and I turned in the magazine that my brother had found. The lady asked why I was bringing it to her, and I had to tell her the bad news that it was up in the children's section. She said, 'oh my!' My brother laid his books up on the counter, and we checked out. We walked out the front doors and were on our way home.

Should public libraries have to censor some of the books, movies, and music they have on display? In my opinion they shouldn't have to. We as people have the right to learn, read, and expand our minds in whatever way we see right for us. There are three main reasons as to why I feel 'offensive' pieces of writing, movies, and music should be allowed in public libraries. One reason as to why they should not is that people have been writing and expressing themselves throughout history; therefor, there are far too many pieces that we would have to get rid of in order to eliminate them all. The second reason is that people have different opinions as to what is 'offensive' and what is not. The third reason that will be elaborated on is that people will be exposed to whatever it is you try to hide, if not throught the art of music, movies, or books, then through the real world we live in.   Throughout history, man kind has been writing things down to document experiences, events, and ideas that have happend throughout history. With those expierences come profanity, sexuality, death, and abundant amounts of situations that the public eye might consider 'offensice'.  If you were to try and delete these pieces, one you would be destroying a big part of history, and two there are far too many books, movies, and music pieces that you would have to get rid of. In almost every form of art there is some remark to something negative. If you were to take them out, you would be left with very few, if any books.  The second reason is that poeple have different opinions on what is bad, and what is not. For example, I was going on a band trip with all the other band students, and on the way there we put on a movie. We ended up having to turn off the movie, because one parent found it inappropriate. While that parent didn't like it, other parents were upset we turned it off, because they saw nothing wrong with it. The same rules apply with books and music. It all depends on personal views as to it being 'offensive' or not.  The third reason is that poeple will expierence all of the things you are trying to hide. If you take it out of the library, one will hear about it on the news, on the radio, in a restraunt, in schools, just about anywhere they are. Taking out the pieces in the library, will be useless in the long run. For example, people want to take out a book called, 'The @CAPS1 of @ORGANIZATION1' because it uses the word 'nigger' in the story quite a few times. There are a lot of people that feel it is not appropriate enough to be taught in school. On top of that, they want to get rid of all the books that say 'nigger' and replace them with books that say 'slave' instead. In my opinion that would be a stupid thing to do, because it takes away the authentisity and effectiveness out of the book. In the book when they use the word it is very powerful and makes you think. If you replace it with 'slave' that statement or passage loses its power on its readers.  In conclusion, I strongly feel that libraries should not have to take out the 'offensive' books, music, or movies. If it does happen, we would be deleting part of our history and knowledge. With that if we do it, how will we know what books to take out, if everyone has a different opinion on what is 'offensive' and what is not. Finally, should we do this, it will not solve anything. People in today's society will still be mean, still do sexual things, people will still use harsh language, and people will still expierence 'offensive' actions. That is the society we live in and poeple will have to accept that fact. That is why I feel that we need to keep all of the 'offensive' pieces we have, that way the people reading them might be ready for the real world once it hits them.

Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Katherine has a good view on the idea of censorship in libraries. Most books have ideas and topics that are offensive to one person or another. I believe that books that have something offensive in them should not be censored. An idea that is offensive to one person may not be offensive to the other, and vice versa. Someone who is pro life on the controversial issue of abortion may believe that a book about a teenage girl getting an abortion is offensive and against their beliefs. In truth, the author was just trying to convey how the teenage girl feels and what happens when you go through with something like that. Katherine Paterson said it well when she mentioned that no books would be left on the shelves. If every person felt threatened or was offended by just one book, libraries would have to close because no books would be left. Books on the topic of religion would definitely have to be censored as well because people of differing religions. The Bible may be offensive to someone of another religion, and because of that the Bible would not be able to be sold. If that happened there would be an ongoing battle about it. Books should not be censored because an idea that is offensive to one, may not be to another. If books were censored, literature would have an immediate downfall. When authors write books they are pouring their hearts out to us. If someone thinks their book is offensive and it gets censored, the author of the book would be even more offended. Their life's work could go into one book and just because a group of people do not like it, it gets taken off the shelves. I don't know about you but I would rather read a book with an interesting and maybe controversial topic than a book that seems to go nowhere. If censorship in libraries actually happened, many authors may say forget it and not even write anymore. It is very hard to write a book that pleases everyone. Also, attraction to literature would seize. People are not attracted to books that do not have a quality topic that gets them interested. Literature would have an immediate downfall if books were censored. If books were censored, the quality of learning would not be the same. Books are tools for learning and taking them away would be harmful to education. Some teenagers including me may find some of the material they read-even in school-to be offensive or have a touchy subject. I do admit that reading books for class is somewhat annoying at times, but it will help us in the future. These books have meaning, which is why they are picked by teachers for students to read. Something offensive like a cuss word is not going to keep someone from finding the meaning of the book. The quality of learning would not be the same if books were censored. A book can be offensive, yes, but one book is not going to ruin someone's life. An important thing to remember is that by taking a book off a shelf, or not playing music because of a few harmful words is like denying the creativity and compassion of an author or artist. One book that is offensive to one, may not be to another. If books were censored, literature would have an immediate downfall and the quality of learning would not be the same. For all of these reasons, censorship in libraries should not be allowed.

Recently, the growing issue of censorship in libraries came to my attention. This is unfortunate in the extreme. People have a right to unmolested knowledge and censoring libraries is a direct violation of that right. Libraries are meant to be a place of learning and they should be kept that way.  History is filled with moments both glorious and inglorious. We aren't always proud of what we do or what happens but those events remain, irrespective of whether or not we choose to acknowledge it. To think turning a blind eye to the less than clean will make it go away is not only unrealistic but also totally ignorant of facts.  I realize that there are some things children should not see or hear and I'm not suggesting we expose them to these things. I'm merely saying that trying to hide them from what we deem to be unclean is neither right nor a good idea in general. We can't shelter our children forever and sooner or later they will learn things we wish they didn't. This is inevitable. Life doesn't seek to hide its darker side from us at all and to hide it from our children will serve little more than to handicap them. Do children need to be protected from some things? Yes, for a time, they do but it is the role of the individual parent to protect their child. Protect the children but don't do so at the expense of everyone else.  Why should the views of some hinder all others? Those who would presume to know what people should see and what they should not are out of touch. Those prudish enough to believe that people need to be protected from natural, from history, or from their own desires have no more right, and perhaps even less than everyone else to interfere with individual decision-making. People have a right to make their own choices on what they believe but no right to force those opinions on others.  Censorship in libraries is a hindrance to the free flow of information and knowledge. It restricts access to diverse perspectives and limits intellectual freedom. It is essential to uphold the principles of intellectual freedom and resist any attempts to censor information in libraries. Let us preserve libraries as spaces for exploration, discovery, and learning without imposing unnecessary restrictions on the content available to the public.

I believe that if you hear or read something offensive they should stay for many reasons. I feel everyone should know the history of the world, which means racism or being offended. I feel if you are reading a book or listening to music and you hear something offensive to you, just turn it off. You aren't being forced to listen or read it, it's your choice.  Libraries should keep the materials because people of the world should know how it feels to be offended. There may be people out there that probably disagree with me, it's just my opinion. You may go to certain libraries in the world that don't allow certain people in because of their opinions on the selection of materials the library offers.  I once heard a woman at a library talking about how she went to the police about someone writing offensive things towards her religion on the internet. What happened to the person but, it's the fact that she went to the police. She could have handled the situation herself, by just confronting the person about it. I feel that the minute she started to read it, she should have turned away or got off the website. It was her decision to keep reading it. I don't see why she should go to the police, if it was just the person's opinion.  Libraries should keep the materials because maybe someone wants to know the meaning of being offensive or being offended. Libraries shouldn't have to hide this topic from anybody. People are offensive because they were raised or just born that way. Some people just have to deal with these people. They might not like it or do somethings towards them in their lifetime but, they have to live with them.  In the end, whether they want to or not libraries should keep certain materials out even if they are offensive towards people. Libraries shouldn't just change their ways for certain people that don't like the materials. There are plenty of people in the world who want to learn more on the topic. These people shouldn't be stopped by the ones who don't like the topic. It's just a part of life.

Should certain materials such as books, magazines, movies, etc., be taken off the shelf in a library if those items may be offensive towards others? There are many possible answers to this question, but I believe that if someone does not like a certain book or finds it offensive they should not have the right to take it off the shelf.  I believe that him/her should not be able to take it off the shelf because if that person finds it offensive, there are others who would not find it offensive. For example, a person might want to read a book about abortion, but another individual is against and offended by that book or subject. If that book is taken off the shelf, it is restricting other people who would like to learn or read about that specific subject.  Another reason why I think that certain books, magazines, music, or movies should not be taken off the shelf is because if one book is offensive to some people, then another book may be offensive to others as well. So, if there are people who find some books offensive, and they are then taken away; there will be fewer books for other individuals to read.  Even though certain books may offend people, I believe the book or magazine should not be removed from the library or shelf. I think that if someone does not like a certain book, magazine, movie, music, etc., that person should not have the right for that material to be taken away. Removing such materials would limit access for others who may want to read or learn from them, ultimately reducing the variety of content available for everyone.

Many people base their actions on their own views. What may appear justified in their minds, due to their beliefs, might cause an uproar from others. One instance of this: media censorship. It happens every day, every place. Someone can take it upon themselves to, in their mind, 'make the piece better for viewing'. In reality, though, they are really ruining the experience of the media for everyone else and even impeding on the rights granted to us by the Constitution: Freedom of Speech.  First up, books in the library. Every time I go to the library and pick up some books, there is always one book with the 'bad parts' marked out. Someone had found these words offensive and decided that no one should have to see or read them. To me, it was irritating. I don't always like those words either, but having them marked out is distracting from the page and, for me, ruins the author's voice and style of writing, hence impairing what I draw from the book. Some marked-out words aren't always offensive to others, either. Simply put, if you find the book offensive, don't read it. Others may enjoy it, whether they share your views or not.  People also take the liberty of simply removing whole pieces of media from shelves just because they find it offensive. If everyone removed anything they didn't like, or found offensive, there would be nothing left in the world for anyone to enjoy. We, as citizens, have the right to make our own choices, and our choices should not be limited by the views of certain individuals. That means that if I want to read or view something, it should be available to me, so I can learn and expand my views, even if it makes someone else uncomfortable.  With nearly every disputable form of media that comes out, people harangue the producers and say the piece should have never been made. Wrong. Producers and authors can publish whatever they would like. It's called Freedom of Speech, and it is a right guaranteed to us, as citizens, under the Constitution. Clearly, if pieces like that are being produced, people read it. Plain and simple. You might not, but maybe a neighbor, or even a relative, may be offended by it and might read it. Supply and demand. If everyone found it offensive, no one would buy or read it, and because of that, it would no longer be produced. You would get your way. But, no. Some people do read it and it is produced. Again, if you don't like it, don't read it.  People should not take it upon themselves to censor what others can and can't do, see, or read. If someone wants to read a story that has 'bad words' in it, so be it. Others should not ruin the experience by marking the words out. Not only is it rude and ruining the experience for the reader, but it is also destroying someone else's property. If someone wants to view something that is against a certain religion, so be it. They have the right and no one can take that right away from them. In my opinion, censorship in libraries, whether by government or other civilians, should not be allowed. We citizens are allowed the right to make our own choices and in libraries, the public should be allowed to read or watch whatever they want. Choice is one of the principles of the constitution, and it should be protected, not limited.  In conclusion, media censorship, whether in the form of marking out words in books or removing offensive material from shelves, impinges on our rights to freedom of speech and choice. It is essential to uphold these rights and allow individuals to make their own decisions about what they read or view. Censorship should not be imposed by individuals or authorities, as it restricts the diversity of opinions and experiences available to the public. Let us respect the freedoms granted to us and embrace the variety of perspectives present in media.

Many libraries contain books, movies, music, and magazines that can be considered offensive.  All of these libraries, however, have certain reasons to have these books.  Whether those reasons are for education or for recreation, the libraries have reasons for them.  So, the libraries that do have 'offensive' books, should be allowed to keep them because they are not offensive to everyone, and they could be beneficial to the reader.     These books that are considered offensive to some people may not be offensive to others.  For example, a person from a certain culture might find a book offensive while someone from a different background may find the same book enlightening.  It's important to acknowledge the diversity of readers and not remove books just because they offend a particular group.  Some of these books could actually be valuable to readers, providing important historical or cultural insights that would be lost if they were removed.  Overall, libraries should strive to offer a wide range of materials to cater to the diverse interests and perspectives of their patrons.

Censorship in libraries, in my opinion, is overrated. While some may find certain materials offensive or degrading, it does not warrant removing them from shelves. Future generations need access to a wide range of knowledge and perspectives, and censorship limits this. Everyone has different opinions on what is offensive, so it is not fair for one group to decide what others can or cannot read. Instead of outright banning materials, libraries could consider creating special sections for explicit content to accommodate varying preferences. Ultimately, people should have the freedom to choose what they read, with parents guiding children's choices. Censorship should not dictate what is available for public consumption, as diversity in perspectives is crucial for a well-rounded education.

I believe as a citizen of this city and as an avid library goer, that censorship in libraries is necessary. Some of the material in the libraries can be very graphic and offensive, which is not suitable for all audiences, especially children. For example, there are books and movies that depict racism and nudity, which can have a negative impact on young minds. It is important to consider the implications of allowing such content to be easily accessible to the public, as it can shape perceptions and behavior.  In our society, where technology and media play a significant role in shaping beliefs and values, it is crucial to regulate the content that is available in public spaces like libraries. Exposure to explicit language, nudity, and offensive themes can desensitize individuals and contribute to a culture of disrespect and insensitivity. Parents may not always be aware of the content their children are accessing, which makes it even more important for libraries to exercise caution in what materials they make available.  While censorship may seem restrictive at first, it ultimately serves to protect individuals, especially children, from harmful influences. By removing content that is inappropriate or offensive, libraries can create a safe and welcoming environment for all patrons. It is important to prioritize the well-being and development of individuals, and censorship in libraries plays a crucial role in achieving this goal. In the long run, we will appreciate the efforts made to ensure that libraries are spaces that promote positive values and healthy attitudes.

I'm writing this paper today to discuss the issue of censorship in various forms of media, including books, movies, and music. I firmly believe that there should be stricter regulations in place to control what children are exposed to. When children encounter inappropriate content at a young age, it can shape their beliefs and perceptions in a negative way.   Supermarkets and video stores are filled with a wide range of content, much of which is not suitable for children. It is crucial to limit the selection of media that children can access to ensure that they are not exposed to harmful or inappropriate material. Items that are deemed unsuitable should be removed from shelves or placed in areas that are not easily accessible to young audiences.  While there are censorship measures in place for music played on the radio, explicit content still finds its way into mainstream media. This exposure to inappropriate language and themes can have a lasting impact on individuals, especially impressionable children. It is essential to enforce strict rules to prevent underage individuals from being exposed to harmful content.  The prevalence of violence in media, such as in video games like "Call of Duty," can desensitize children to acts of violence and lead them to believe that such behavior is acceptable. By implementing tighter regulations on the content that children are exposed to, we can help reduce the glorification of violence and create a safer environment for young minds to develop.  In conclusion, it is imperative that we advocate for stricter censorship measures to protect children from harmful and inappropriate content in various forms of media. By being mindful of the content that is accessible to young audiences, we can promote healthier attitudes and behaviors among future generations.

Certain books should be allowed in libraries to provide a variety of reading options for individuals. While some content may not be suitable for certain places, there is a wide range of genres available, including history, poetry, drama, romance, and horror. It is important to have diverse literature choices to prevent readers from becoming bored with limited options.  Similarly, music preferences vary among individuals, with some enjoying rap while others prefer rock 'n' roll. While some may disapprove of certain genres, it is essential to respect differing tastes and preferences. As time passes, musical preferences evolve, and what was once considered controversial may become widely accepted.  In terms of movies, there are various genres and ratings available, catering to different audiences. While some parents may restrict their children from watching certain films due to content, there are also kid-friendly options like children's shows.  Magazines offer another form of entertainment, with a wide range of topics to suit different interests. While some may find themselves engrossed in buying everything featured in magazines, others may simply enjoy browsing through them for leisure.  Overall, diverse options in books, music, movies, and magazines cater to different preferences and interests, enriching the cultural landscape. It is important to have a variety of choices available to accommodate the diverse tastes of individuals.

If we were to take away everything that someone in the world finds offensive, there would be nothing left. Many people in different cultures find many different things offensive. It's not right to take away from others something because a select group of people take offense at it. Something being offensive isn't always a bad thing. There are many different reasons why, but removing something because of someone else's opinion isn't right.  First, whether you find something offensive or not is largely based on your culture. To most cultures, declining food is offensive. To others, eating or hurting cows in any way is a complete disgrace. If something is offensive to one person, it may be because they have a different background. You're never going to please everyone.  Second, one of the best things about the world is that you can have your own beliefs. If something was removed from the shelf at a library because someone found it offensive, I would be disturbed. I have my own beliefs that I'm sure not everyone agrees with. Some of my beliefs would be offensive to certain people. That doesn't mean I should have to stay silent about my beliefs, does it? No, of course not. I wouldn't want anyone else's beliefs forced on me. I'm sure no one wants my beliefs forced on them. By removing things from a shelf because someone took offense at it, you'd be removing freedom of speech from the shelf also. That's not only wrong, it's illegal.  Some people would be offended at a book with a cross on it. Some people would be offended by a cover with a pentagram. That doesn't mean they should be taken away. It's good to get offended sometimes. It often makes people stand up for what they believe. To me, it's a reminder of why I believe what I do. I may be angered by what I see. I'm sure the terrorist group is greatly offended when they see the flag. We wouldn't stop waving it, would we? That'd be absurd! Just because someone takes offense at something doesn't make it wrong. It never has. It just means they have different beliefs. We should have the maturity to look away instead of demanding that it be removed.  I personally believe that removing things from the public eye merely because they're offensive would be wrong for many reasons. So many people find so many things offensive. It'd take away everything if we removed each and every one. Removing offensive items would also be an intrusion of freedom of speech. Plus, many things that are offensive often remind us of who we are. We should be strong enough to look away and not fight about it. I don't think they should be removed. I want my library to be what it was made to be, a mixture of cultures and backgrounds. I don't think anything should be removed unless it directly causes harm to people.

During school one day, all of our teachers informed the class that most of the books in the library were going to be removed from the shelves. The reason behind this decision was that some parents had been complaining about the content their children were reading. However, the students in our class strongly opposed this idea. They believed that the books in the library were beneficial for their learning and exploration of different interests and potential career paths.  The students felt that the books available in the library allowed them to dream and aspire to be something in the future. They argued that by limiting their access to a variety of reading materials, their ability to explore different subjects and career options would be hindered. They believed that it was important for children to have the freedom to choose what they wanted to read and learn about, as it could shape their future goals and aspirations.  If the school decided to remove the books from the shelves, the students feared that they would lose motivation to learn and may not be able to discover their passions. On the other hand, if the books remained accessible, the students were confident that they would continue to be curious and enthusiastic about learning, leading them to have a clearer idea of what they wanted to pursue in the future.  In conclusion, the students believed that keeping the books on the shelves was crucial for their academic and personal development. They hoped that their voices would be heard, and the school would consider their opinions before making a final decision. Ultimately, the students' dreams and aspirations were at stake, and they were determined to fight for their right to access a diverse range of reading materials in the library.

If libraries censored what people can read, watch, listen to, not everyone would get to learn extra information that they wanted to. Libraries cannot censor their materials! If libraries choose to censor things, then not everyone would have equal opportunities. Parents can censor what their kids read if they want. I believe it is wrong to remove books from library shelves even if they are found offensive. I have three reasons to support this statement. These reasons are knowledge, different sections of the library, and freedom. If a book is removed from a shelf because someone finds it offensive then the next person who comes along looking for that book cannot access it. In life, there are many things that can offend people, but that's life, you have to learn to let those things go. Everyone has a right to form their own views and opinions on things, but they cannot if they do not read other people's opinions. Reading expands our vocabulary, at any age. Libraries are everywhere and have different sections. If you are concerned about your children finding books that you do not want them to see, then take them to a library with sections. All libraries are broken down into sections. We live in a society that values freedom, and people rely on public libraries for access to books. Censoring books limits people's ability to explore different perspectives and ideas. It is essential to allow everyone the freedom to read whatever they wish, to contribute to the wellness of society. Let's not pretend everything is perfect and instead embrace the diversity of thoughts and beliefs found in literature.

Cooling the Flames of Censorship in Public Libraries  Censorship in public libraries would be an insult to the institution. A library, a citadel of knowledge, should not be bound by a society as to what knowledge it can convey. One point of a library, the destination of researchers, is to offer information that must be sought: for those who cannot find the information in their homes without fear, for those who cannot ask their questions without retribution, the library stands as a pillar of safety. Books are incapable of judgment.  To censor the books held in a library is to chip away at human progress. A freedom of thought and a freedom of press, present within our nation and increasing in presence around the world, precludes the idea of this censorship.  If any book is subject to criticism or opposition, are not all books worthy of the same? To value one opinion or perspective less than another is to debase the entire culture from which libraries have arisen. Libraries are a communal institution, open to all views and writings. The point of bringing books together under one roof is to equate them, and give them all equal standing as literature or scholarly works.  From personal experience, censorship in the library has cost me precious time, and has stolen from me parts of my life. Growing up in a small town, where ideas of gender and sexuality were somewhat firmly set, any search for dissenting opinion was often fruitless. When I visited my school's library, as a child searching for answers about my sexuality, I found little aid. Around the library were a thousand stories of a man and woman falling in love, but never did I find a fairy tale of two princes. It was not until I left the school that I found that such books did exist in my old school library, but kept removed, off the shelves, restricted. More insulting than finding books of LGBTQ+ issues completely unrepresented was to find that they were treated so separately.  Here lies the problem. Some people believe that if minority opinions or values are unrepresented, they will disappear. Such is the point of censorship: ignoring an issue or a life-choice to the point of extinction. But books cannot shout their values. They cannot shove information down our throats. Books must be read, we must give our consent to their knowledge. Unlike an advertisement that might accost us unawares, we must pick up a book and open it to receive its guidance.  If my library had done its job and given me the guidance I sought, I would have grown so much more easily. I would have learned not only how to express and accept myself, but I might have grown to more easily accept others as well.  In the past few years, with the effects of global events reaching the newest generation, the world has searched for ways to pay homage to the victims of violence and tragedy. What the world finds, however, is that it cannot effectively memorialize the tragedies. In trying to construct a monument, society finds that they have little to build off of. The products of murder and book-burning have resulted in an emptiness, a void. Architects have created what may be called 'anti-monuments', commemorating a void to posterity to memorialize what was lost. One of the most powerful, to me at least, appears in the form of a negative bookshelf: a solid wall, with gaping holes in the form of book spines, ranging across the rows. Such is the knowledge lost from book-burning. We cannot even describe what is lost, for the knowledge has vanished. We must ask, what are we missing? What views, what prose, what beauty has been taken from us while we continue living, never having the chance to glimpse it?  This is the effect of library censorship. To remove a book from its natural and rightful place on a shelf is to set its words aflame. Once it is gone, it will be forgotten. To protect our posterity, to enlighten our descendants, we must work to preserve all books, any book that appears offensive, or disgusting, or brave, or new. Let the reader decide its value. Let the person in search of answers pick it up or leave it behind. Give the book a chance for it may have a power that is unrealized. Leave the libraries as they are, as the monuments to the preservation and progression of knowledge and wisdom.

Have you ever wondered how libraries select their books? The process of censorship in libraries is crucial for ensuring that children are not exposed to inappropriate material. Censorship plays a vital role in shaping the social environment and influencing the music of our generation.   Censorship in libraries is necessary to protect children from accessing books that contain explicit content. Without censorship, children may stumble upon books that are not suitable for their age, such as those containing violence or sexual content. Parents may not always be aware of the books their children are reading, which highlights the importance of librarians taking a stand and censoring harmful material.  The impact of uncensored books extends beyond children, affecting social conversations in schools and workplaces. Uncensored books can lead to discussions centered around topics like sex and violence, shaping the social interactions of individuals. By censoring books, libraries can help create a more positive and constructive social environment.  Furthermore, the presence of uncensored music in libraries can also contribute to a culture of violence and negativity. Music that promotes violence can influence individuals' attitudes and behaviors. Censoring music in libraries can help prevent the spread of harmful messages and contribute to a safer and more positive society.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries is essential for safeguarding children, shaping social interactions, and influencing cultural norms. By advocating for censored books and music in libraries, we can create a more wholesome and nurturing environment for all individuals. Let us strive for a world where libraries promote education, creativity, and positivity without the damaging influence of uncensored material.

Considering the information provided, it is crucial to reflect on the importance of censoring books and magazines in libraries to protect children from inappropriate content and to promote respect and responsible behavior. This approach not only safeguards children but also allows for better allocation of resources towards their education and development.

I believe that there should be a little censorship in libraries.
