Do you really want a child to check something out that has violence, horrible language, and sexual innuendo? What can you do about this problem? You could censorship the books and hide them from the public, but that would cause another problem. The idea of censorship might sound okay, but really it's not the right thing to do. Hiding things from the public just because it might have some bad things in it is a little over the top. If you are an adult and you're in the mood to read something with a little violence in it, you'd have to go somewhere else because someone just took that book away because it had some swear words that they don't find appropriate in books. Censorship would just make it harder for adults to find some books that they would want to read. So what do you do if there is an offensive book on the shelf? Do you just leave it there, or take it away so no one can read it? You could just put age restrictions on the books. If someone underage wanted to check out the book, they would have to get permission from their parent. That way the book can stay on the shelf and be read by anyone.

People all judge things differently. That's why I feel that libraries should keep those kinds of books. What may be found as an offensive book to one person might not to another one. If there are people saying that certain books are offensive, then they should take them out of the library. You shouldn't take one book out because one person thinks it is offensive.  What might be offensive to one person may interest another. The person that doesn't think it is should have the right to read the book. That would be taking the rights for people away because a person finds it offensive. The person might find the book useful because they want to learn about the topic more. They will never get to learn about it if they take the book out because one person finds it offensive or doesn't like it.  I personally like watching movies or reading books that are thrilling and may have some violence in them. If the library took these books or movies out because a mother saw her son or daughter reading or watching them, it would be wrong. The mother would be taking away what I like to read and watch. That's not fair at all. A way to solve this issue is to have certain areas for each type of age group; therefore, they would be watching or reading types of things acceptable for their age group.  I understand the fact that some people take things offensively and that they don't want their children to pick up a book or movie that isn't acceptable for their age group. They have to understand though that sometimes people like those types of things, and they are taking it away from the people who enjoy them. It is like taking rights away from people because they don't agree with what is happening. It wouldn't be right at all to take those books out of the library.  All people have different views about things. You can't change a thing if one person doesn't like it. People have the right to pick up a book if they want to or not. Not everyone is the same, so not all people are going to think the same way. I like things that some people might not like, that is just how human nature is.

Over time, libraries have been used as a big resource when doing reports, researching, renting movies and simply trying to find something new to read. They have been used as a gateway for an extensive world of reading and learning. All libraries should have the right to have the content they please to have on their shelves. No book, music, movie, magazine, etc., should ever be denied a place on the shelf because of its content.  Sex, drugs, violence. There are many books over these topics that many people may find offensive or just completely oblivious. Every mind is different when it comes down to what it likes to read, watch, or hear. No mind is the same, so no mind will ever like exactly the same thing. Whenever someone wants to go buy a book about safe sex, it should not be denied to them because the library does not allow it. It should be placed in a different section of the library.  Many books that people find as explicit content to them may not be to others. When I was in middle school, I heard a lot about sex and drugs. I never knew what it felt like or how it felt. What I did know was that I could get accessible information from my local library. What happens when a child wants to know more than she does? She looks and researches it. If I would have been denied access to books about sex or drugs, I would have probably never been warned about the outcomes or the seriousness of them both. When you walk into a library and observe, not everyone is reading a book about rainbows and unicorns. Many people read books about real life, books that they can relate to. Many of those books that many people read are those that others call explicit. The purpose of a library is to have access to books, magazines, music, and movies of all kinds of content, regardless of others' concerns.  Also, Libraries can do many things so that certain contents may not be near others. They can organize their topics and genres. Explicit, or eighteen or older books, movies, magazines or music can be placed in a back room or simply on another side of the library, far from the reach where kids and children are able to access.  In conclusion, I believe with my strongly supportive ideas that books, magazines, music, or movies should not be removed if found offensive because every book has a right on the shelf no matter what. No book should be removed because someone may find it offensive. If a person finds something offensive, they should take it up with the author or publishers, not the library, for they only let people borrow the content.

Censorship is a highly debated topic, with individuals often having strong opinions on what should or should not be accessible to the public. While one person may find certain content objectionable and believe it should be removed from public view, it is essential to consider the perspectives of others who may have a different opinion. In a diverse society, it is inevitable that not everyone will agree on what is acceptable or appropriate in terms of content.   Freedom of speech and expression are fundamental rights that must be upheld for all individuals, regardless of their personal views. It is important to recognize that while one person may find certain material offensive, there are likely others who appreciate and resonate with it. Implementing systems such as content warnings, ratings, and alternative versions can help individuals make informed choices about the media they consume, allowing for a balance between freedom of expression and individual sensitivities.  Ultimately, the key is to respect the differing opinions and beliefs of each person while also ensuring that a variety of perspectives and voices are represented in the public sphere. It is not fair or practical to censor content simply because it does not align with the views of a specific group. By maintaining an open and inclusive approach to diverse viewpoints, we can create a more equitable and understanding society where all individuals have the opportunity to express themselves freely.

In libraries, there are books that contain racism and explicit content, which may not be suitable for all viewers, especially young readers. Some books can promote racist ideologies or contain graphic descriptions of sex, which could negatively influence young minds. It is important for parents to monitor what their children are exposed to and for libraries to consider placing such books in separate sections for older audiences. While some argue for censorship of certain materials, others believe that these works serve as a reflection of societal change over time. Ultimately, it is crucial to strike a balance between freedom of expression and protecting young readers from harmful content.

New section in the library Have you ever seen a movie or read a book that you did not want your kids/family to read? I know I have, and sometimes there is no stopping them from seeing or reading those books/movies. I don't necessarily think the offensive books should be removed, but I think they should be relocated to a different part of the library. This section of the library should only be accessed by an adult, or with an adult's permission.  Little kids see stuff that their peers are doing and want to be just like them so they do the same stuff. What the kids don't realize is that most of it is fake, and the things that happen in movies aren't really true. By having this separated section of the library, it gives parents the chance to get the racist, drug/gang filled, and murder books away from the children. This will be good for every race too! If an African American family does not want their child to be reading books about slavery or gangs, they can keep them out of the section of books where slavery and gangs are. Some books are really emotional and can trigger a person's emotions. If someone is going through a really hard time and they read a book about suicide, they are more likely to think about killing themselves.  I think by separating the bad influencing books from the good influencing books it will help a lot. People under the age of 18 are not permitted to be in this section of the library without a parent, or parent signature. So come on down to the library council on Monday and vote for the new section of the library! Thank you for your time.

Censorship in libraries is akin to cutting off the world's air supply, stifling readers' imaginations and hindering their ability to express themselves. Libraries already do a good job of ensuring that books are appropriate for different age groups, so further censorship is unnecessary. By removing certain materials, it only draws attention to why they are being restricted, leading readers to demand more freedom in their reading choices. Books are meant to inspire curiosity, learning, and excitement, and limiting access to certain content only serves to restrict the mind. As a child, I experienced being redirected to age-appropriate books in the library, which was a reasonable approach to censorship. Ultimately, censorship in libraries is unnecessary and goes against the fundamental purpose of libraries in fostering exploration and intellectual growth. Readers should be allowed to explore a wide range of materials without unnecessary restrictions.

There is a certain amount of responsibility when it comes to censoring all the different types of media and literature. Deciding whose responsibility that is can be a difficult task. Children can be strongly influenced by all media out there and making that material has been made easily accessible. When someone comes of age to make decisions that affect their life then they should be able to. Shop owners should be able to sell whatever they want in order to make a living.  When children go to a library usually they will not do so alone. Parents can decide what their child is allowed to take home or not. When a child comes to their parent with a book, movie, or magazine that is offensive or inappropriate it comes to the parent to decide whether or not they want their child to be exposed to that material. If the parent allowed for their child to have access to offensive media then that can give the child the idea that what they are looking at or reading is alright.  If someone has come of age and has all the other freedoms that everyone else has they should be allowed to buy, read, and watch what they want. To prove to someone that you are of age to have access to offensive material you should have to show some sort of identification proving it.  A shop owner or businessman/woman should be able to sell whatever he or she wants to in order to make a living as long as it stays within the boundaries of the law. Having someone who does not work in the law or a person who is not a legal guardian or parent of someone who is not of age should not tell someone not to buy, read, or watch something just because it might be offensive or offend that one person.  I conclude that in order for a someone to tell another person not to buy or rent material that person would either have to be law enforcement or their legal guardian as long as they are not of age. There is no reason why people should not be able to access material that is not against the law. If someone is offended by some literature then they should try to make it against the law.

Censorship is a topic that sparks heated debates in today's society. Views on censorship vary greatly around the world, with some countries imposing strict censorship to control information and prevent their citizens from knowing what is happening globally. This creates a closed-off environment where people lack awareness of important events outside their borders. While censorship may not always be as extreme, it still plays a significant role in various aspects of society, from media content to classified military information.  The debate over censorship has been ongoing for years, with no clear resolution in sight. It is a highly subjective issue, with arguments for and against censorship based largely on personal opinions. Some argue for the necessity of censorship to protect individuals, especially children, from harmful content, while others believe in the importance of freedom of expression and access to information.  In my view, censorship should be minimal, if not completely abolished. Artists and creators use certain words and themes to evoke emotions and convey messages effectively, and censorship can hinder their creative expression. Instead of censoring content, individuals can make informed choices about what they consume and expose themselves to, especially when it comes to children. By exercising our freedom to choose, we can avoid content that we find objectionable without restricting others' access to it.  In a society that values freedom, we should extend that freedom to the realm of censorship. Rather than imposing restrictions on content, individuals can make conscious decisions about what they engage with. By embracing our right to choose, we can avoid unnecessary debates and conflicts over censorship. Ultimately, the power to say no and make informed choices lies in our hands, allowing us to navigate a world filled with diverse content and perspectives.

Dear @CAPS1 @PERSON1,  Should certain books be removed because some people @MONTH1 think they are inappropriate for their children to see or read? No, I do not think they should be removed. I honestly think all they all should be put in different sections of the library by age.  Like all the children books and magazines should be in one section. The young adult and or teen books and magazines should be in a section by itself. Then the adult books and magazines should be in their section. Even the autobiographies and documentaries should be in their section too.  It would make things easier to find the book you are wanting to read. For example, if you're a teenage girl looking for a book about a high school girl with a crush on a boy, it'd most likely be in the section for young adults.  So yes, the parents that are concerned about their children's viewing of certain books should be able to say something about it. But what if one teenager is looking for a book about a famous person's autobiography for a school project. Even though it includes how they used to be into drugs as a teenager. That person shouldn't have to fail if they can't find it in a library because some concerned parent didn't think it was appropriate.  Like I said the best thing to do is put all the books in subcategories by age. It would make things easier and faster to find the book of your selection.

It seems as though inappropriate materials are prevalent in today's society, appearing in various forms such as magazines, books, and music lyrics. However, the question arises as to whether libraries should censor these materials based on the morals and values of certain individuals. While it is understandable to separate offensive materials from areas accessible to children, complete censorship based on personal beliefs is unjust. Each person has their own set of morals and values, and it is not fair to restrict others from accessing information based on individual opinions. Libraries should aim to provide a diverse range of materials, with potentially offensive content clearly marked in a separate section. Ultimately, it is important to respect differing opinions and allow individuals the freedom to choose what they read without imposing personal beliefs on others. Let libraries be a place of knowledge and learning, where individuals can explore a variety of perspectives and ideas without censorship.

Libraries should have censorship to protect young children from being exposed to inappropriate content. This is necessary because such material can teach children negative things and lead them astray. Additionally, it can have a harmful influence on their behavior, as they may share what they have seen with others and encourage them to engage in inappropriate activities. Ultimately, there is no valid reason for children to have access to such material, and implementing censorship in libraries can help ensure that they are not exposed to harmful content. By restricting access to inappropriate material, libraries can create a safer environment for children and help guide them towards a positive and healthy future.

I think that censorship in libraries isn't needed. The grounds for censorship are often opinionated and biased. Two readers of the same book could view the material completely differently. Readers choose to read a book and are likely aware of the general plot before starting due to the summary on the back. People can make their own decisions about what they read. If certain books are deemed inappropriate or offensive, they are most likely in teen or adult literature. In such cases, readers should be mature enough to handle the content or decide not to continue reading.  Saying that material is unsuitable for a younger age group is valid, but children should be accompanied by an adult when checking out books. Content that some find unacceptable would likely be intended for a mature audience, so younger readers encountering it would be the issue. Teens and adults reading such material are likely capable of handling a few foul words or innuendos in the plot.  Offensive material can be viewed differently by different audiences. What one person finds offensive may not be the same for someone else. Difficult situations in literature can help prepare us for the challenges we may face in life and encourage empathy and action to make a difference.  Stories that depict tough realities should not be censored as they can educate and inspire change. Libraries should remain open to all who wish to explore these narratives. Books serve a purpose in shedding light on difficult topics and showing readers that they are not alone in their struggles. Our actions following exposure to such stories define who we are, and it is through understanding and confronting harsh realities that we can work towards a better future.

I believe that certain books should not be on library shelves, but ultimately it is up to the library to decide what to offer. If a book is deemed inappropriate for children, then it should be kept out of their reach. However, books on important historical topics like slavery and the Holocaust should not be censored just because they may be difficult or uncomfortable to read about. Parents should have the right to control what their children read, but they should not impose their beliefs on others. It is important to recognize that people have different perspectives and to respect the diversity of opinions. If someone strongly opposes certain books, they can take steps to have them relocated or removed, but they should not impose their views on others. Ultimately, it is important to uphold the freedom to access information and allow individuals to make their own choices about what they read.

Dear @PERSON1,  I wanted to discuss with you the issue of offensive books in libraries that are accessible to children. It is concerning that some books intended for adults are available for children to read without any restrictions. These books should be removed from the shelves to protect young readers from inappropriate content. Instead, libraries should focus on providing age-appropriate and educational material for children to enjoy.  Parents also play a crucial role in this matter. It is important for parents to voice their concerns and protest against the presence of offensive books in libraries. By advocating for the removal of such material, parents can ensure that their children are not exposed to content that is unsuitable for their age. Creating a list of offensive books and restricting access to adults with proper identification can be a step in the right direction.  Furthermore, libraries should carefully consider the books they make available for children to borrow. It is essential to promote reading materials that are beneficial for their development and growth. Parents need to be aware of what their children are reading and guide them towards age-appropriate content that will enhance their understanding of the world around them.  In conclusion, it is crucial for libraries to take action in ensuring that children are not exposed to offensive material. By providing suitable reading material and listening to the concerns of parents, libraries can create a safe and educational environment for young readers. Let us work together to protect our children from harmful content and promote a love for reading that will benefit them in the long run.  Sincerely, @CAPS1

In my opinion, censorship should not be allowed in libraries. People should have the freedom to choose what they want to read without restrictions. Censorship can lead to disobedience and a negative atmosphere in the library. It can also discourage people from visiting the library if they feel like their choices are being controlled. Libraries should be welcoming and quiet places for people to enjoy reading, studying, and completing tasks. Ultimately, individuals should have the autonomy to decide what they want to read, and censorship should not be imposed on them in libraries or any other public spaces.

I do believe that certain materials should be removed from libraries to protect children from inappropriate content. It is important to ensure that children are not exposed to explicit material such as adult magazines or books with explicit language and themes.   Parents and librarians should work together to create designated areas for adult materials that require identification to access. This will help prevent children from stumbling upon content that is not suitable for their age.   While adults may have the freedom to read about mature subjects like sex and drugs, it is crucial to shield children from such content. Exposing children to inappropriate material can lead to negative consequences at school and home, as they may mimic the behavior they see or face disciplinary actions.   Therefore, it is essential for library staff to be mindful of where they place materials to ensure that children are not inadvertently exposed to content meant for adults. By taking proactive measures, we can create a safe and age-appropriate environment for all library visitors.

Eventually, everyone sees or hears offensive things. However, the government has taken it upon themselves to try and keep youth from seeing it. They believe the parents should tell their children about everything while they try to make it one big secret for kids. But, if kids are introduced early, we would not have to keep it a secret anymore. Libraries and all types of media should not be censored.  Kids always ask questions like 'where do babies come from?' and adults, wanting to avoid an awkward conversation, make up stories or do not tell them the whole truth. Imagine a world where the government let the media say whatever they want. Yes, at first it would be vulgar but the government would then have the right to teach about sex and drugs in school. More kids would be educated, so less of them would be curious enough to do any of that stuff.  That is not to say that newscasters should curse everytime they are on television. It is merely suggesting that instead of having a metaphorical black curtain over half the news, they report the whole truth. They have freedom of speech, and we have a right to know.  At first, people would think it was a terrible world. But, eventually, with right leadership, it would help make a more truthful environment. Kids would learn about sex and drugs in school, and have a safe environment to answer their questions if they have any. Drug use and rape would go down. Then, talking about 'offensive' topics would be non-existent so kids would not be embarassed if they had questions. This would change the world for the better.

The library is a place where dreams and imagination come to life through books. However, the issue arises when books meant for one age group are accessible to all. This can lead to young children stumbling upon inappropriate content, offensive material being exposed to certain races, and events depicted in books that may not be suitable for all ages. It is crucial for libraries to consider the impact of the books they provide and ensure that they are appropriate for all audiences. By taking measures to segregate books based on age appropriateness, the library can create a more inclusive and safe environment for all visitors. It is essential to prioritize the well-being and comfort of all library users by being mindful of the content available to them.

I do not believe that certain materials should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. Children are exposed to such content outside of school, so removing them from libraries or stores would be pointless. Instead of censorship, individuals can choose to avoid offensive material and seek out content that aligns with their values. Furthermore, removing books or movies on controversial topics hinders academic research and limits access to diverse perspectives. It is essential to promote critical thinking and responsible consumption rather than banning materials based on subjective opinions. In conclusion, censorship is not the solution to dealing with offensive material, and individuals should have the freedom to make their own choices about what they read or watch.

Censorship in Libraries  I believe that censorship in libraries should be minimal. Just because something is deemed offensive by some individuals does not mean it should be removed from the shelves. Everyone has their own perspective and what one person finds offensive, another may find valuable.  Libraries are meant to provide a wide range of materials to cater to diverse interests and preferences. Restricting certain content would limit the variety of books available, ultimately alienating potential readers. A library should aim to be inclusive and offer something for everyone, even if it means including materials that may be considered controversial.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries should be approached with caution. It is important to consider the diverse needs and preferences of library patrons and provide a wide selection of materials to cater to them. By allowing for a variety of viewpoints and content, libraries can truly fulfill their role as sources of knowledge and information for all individuals.

Have you ever been in a library and thought to yourself, 'hey, this book looks pretty good.' But once you read it, you deemed it as inappropriate for younger people? I have, but unlike some people, I don't blame it on the libraries. I blame myself for picking it up in the first place. Some people do not want to take responsibility for their actions, and so they blame it on the library for carrying a certain author's books, a band's songs, or a magazine's articles.  This brings me to say that books, music, magazines, newspapers, etc. should not be taken off the shelves of libraries. Just because some people do not like the content that they hold, doesn't mean that it can't be helpful or entertaining to others. I think it should be a matter of choice, like choosing which outfit you want to wear in the morning. There are too many options, like when it comes to books, movies, music, and magazines. If something strikes you as inappropriate, then simply take it back and exchange it for something better.  One experience I can think of that is a good example of this is when I was 10 years old. My mother took me into the library and I found a book, 'A Child Called It.' I showed it to her just like any other time we had gone to the library. Only this time, she did not want me to check it out. She saw it as too harsh of a book for me to read at the time, she wanted me to wait until I was older. It was about child abuse and she saw it as a very inappropriate book for my age, at the time. But she didn't blame it on the libraries, asking why they would carry such books where children could reach them.  Other mothers and fathers are the same way, as I found out. My best friend's parents had been the same way with her. Only instead of a book, it was a music CD that she had wanted to listen to. They thought that she should not listen to it because the lyrics in the songs were too 'sad' for her to hear. They agreed that if she were just a little older then she could have borrowed it. They did not blame the library. If someone else wanted to listen to it, or have their children listen to it, then it was their own personal choice.  I do not believe that libraries should have censorship. They can have different sections, such as adult, children, and young adult. But I believe that they should not have to take books, music, magazines, etc. off the shelves just because of certain people. It should be a person's personal choice. If they do not like the item that they picked up, they should take responsibility for their actions, and not blame others for their mistakes.

I think books, movies, music, and magazines that are offensive should not be pulled from the shelves. If you find something offensive, then don't pick it up; it's that simple. It is all according to your own personal opinion. Sure, there are some things that are very offensive to certain people, and those people will try to put a stop to it. But I think that is wrong because it may be offensive to you, but it might not be to someone else. It could be helpful to many people, and at the same time, it can be offensive to a lot of people. If you are one of those people who find something offensive, then don't pay any attention to it and find another subject or topic. For someone to take another person's right to read a book or watch a movie is wrong; everyone has their own opinions and rights.

There are some books that should not be removed from libraries due to censorship. Past experiences with censorship have shown that it can lead to a book being toned down. In the book "Fahrenheit 451," for example, books are being burnt, causing society to fall apart. Censorship often stems from individuals with a more conservative background who do not want children exposed to inappropriate language.  One recent example of censorship involves the book "Huckleberry Finn." The main word being targeted for removal is "nigger" because some people find this word offensive to their race. Committees are attempting to remove the book from school shelves.  I believe that censorship should not be enforced simply because parents do not want their children exposed to certain words in school. Eventually, children will learn these words on their own or hear them elsewhere. They may even learn them from their own parents or from television. I personally feel that committees should cease attempting to censor everything, as they cannot control how adults speak around children and young adults. Ultimately, censorship can hinder a full understanding of the world and limit intellectual freedom.

Katherine Paterson, a well-known author, presents an idea with which I strongly agree. She states, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf left for any of us.' If everyone has the right to remove certain books that they find inappropriate, there may not be anything left for people to read. Although it is a good thing for parents to have a voice and stand up for what they believe, books should not be banned. Many people have different views on what is right and wrong. Some may suggest that a certain book is obscene, while others may be offended by a different book. If every parent had the right to get a book banned, there could come a time when no books meet the approval of the parent. Some of these books present great learning opportunities to students. Books often allow students to think in different, new ways. They can learn from a new point of view. Often times, a student can look at his or her own morals and values, which is a good thing. If a teacher finds a book which they think is appropriate, parents should respect the decision of this teacher. They may suggest another reading, or offer other ideas, but to go as far as getting the book completely removed is not right. While removing books for reading may be going too far, things such as movies could go the other direction. Personally, my parents would be horrified to see grotesque, inappropriate movies set out in broad daylight where everyone can look at them. I think that this difference between books and movies is a simple thing: Books do not normally have an inappropriate cover, while bad movies often do. Because of this, even the people who do not wish to view the movie are often forced to see images which they find disturbing. If one was to walk past a book they did not intend to read, they do not have to be appalled at the cover as they pass. Although parents care about the things their children read, books should not be banned. Although other things may have affects on youth, books are a different story. They allow one's self to dive deep into thought, to make observations, and to form opinions. They are a key to growing, learning, and discovering.

First off, I do like censorship laws to an extent. However, the government cannot ban everything that they deem inappropriate. I think it depends more on what the family deems inappropriate. I do not think they should have any completely inaccessible areas in libraries for children of younger ages. I believe that the viewer should have a family member's consent to view said content. I also believe that if the content is not relative to the viewers interests, then they should just not look at it. They are not required to look at it so if they do not like it, then they do not look at it.  However, if the library does not consent to holding the books, music, movies, magazines, etc., then they do not have to and the viewer can go somewhere else. And if they do have the books, music, etc., then they can put limits and ratings on them. But I do not think that an adult could go in and complain about inappropriate material. As I said before, if they do not like it, then they are not required to look at it.  I actually think that the government should not tolerate parents whining and complaining about the content of different materials. One parent should not have the ability to take away others' privileges to books, because they deem it inappropriate. Just because they do not like the content, does not exclude all others from enjoying it.  Also, if a library does have an age restriction on certain materials, then appropriate acts of discipline should be taken for the viewer of said materials. However, if the viewer has an adult family member with them and has their consent, then I think they should be able to view the material, regardless of ratings. In conclusion, censorship laws should be applied with consideration for individual and family preferences, rather than imposing blanket restrictions. Each person should have the freedom to choose what they consume, with parental guidance and library regulations serving as important factors in ensuring appropriate content access.

There are so many books and magazines, music, and movies to be discovered in this world. Some are funny, sad, weird, scary, etc. And then there are some that are questionable to others on whether it was even necessary to even put the material on the shelf of a library in the first place. I for one am not one of those people who would question a book, magazine, movie or music. I believe that everyone's voice needs to be heard somehow and if we all take a voice away that we do not like, then we will lose a lot of voices. We are all entitled to our own opinion. When it comes to some things some are more opinionated than others, but in the end we all have something that we feel strongly about. There are some people who want to express their feelings with the whole world with people that understand and agree with what they feel. If we take that away from people, then how will we all connect? Some things may come across as offensive to others, but who has the right to say that something should not be shared with the rest of the world. I have observed that when people have the same interests in things like music, books, or movies then it gives people a way to come together and talk about something. I have witnessed at concerts everybody seems to connect because we are all there for the same reason, to see the band or person that we all like to listen to. Everybody's different and likes to have their own personal preference on something. Like Katherine Paterson once said, 'But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I think she was trying to say that if we all take a book off the shelf that we do not think should be on there, then there is going to be nothing left for anybody to read. Then what will we do? There's such a variety of materials that are needed to be discovered whether it is a book, music, or movie everyone has their own special type that they enjoy. I do not think that censorship is a good idea for any sort of material on a shelf. These materials are what keep people connected with each other. I think it is very important to not censor anything because it does not just give the writer a voice, it give a voice for the people that agree with the material of the book, movie, or music. Every voice deserves to be heard, and every individual deserves the opportunity to connect with others through shared interests and perspectives. By embracing diversity in materials and allowing for a wide range of voices to be heard, we can foster a more inclusive and understanding society where everyone's opinions are valued. Let us continue to explore, discover, and appreciate the vast array of expressions and ideas that exist in the world, without imposing limitations or restrictions on what can be shared and enjoyed.

There are many books, movies, and music in libraries, catering to a wide range of tastes and interests. While some content may be deemed offensive by certain individuals, it is important to remember that libraries offer a diverse selection to accommodate the varied preferences of their patrons. It is crucial for parents and guardians to guide children towards age-appropriate material and set a positive example for them to follow. Ultimately, libraries are shaped by the demands and interests of the community they serve, reflecting the diverse perspectives and preferences of society. It is essential to promote understanding and respect for different viewpoints, even if they may not align with our own, in order to maintain libraries as inclusive and enriching spaces for all.

Libraries should have whatever they want in the library. Everyone has their own thoughts on things. If you don't like what they have on their shelves then don't go there anymore or pick up something you like. Everyone is different so you can't just take offensive stuff off the shelves, it might be offensive to one person, but not to someone else. Materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, provide facts and information. Removing items just because they are offensive to some individuals is not the solution. The diversity of materials in a library caters to the varied interests and needs of different people. It is important to have access to a wide range of content for research, education, and personal enrichment. Restricting or censoring materials based on personal preferences limits the freedom of choice and access to information. It is essential to respect the diversity of opinions and allow individuals to make their own decisions about what they read or view. Embracing this diversity enriches the library experience and promotes intellectual freedom for all.

Libraries provide us with knowledge, entertainment, and peace. You can go there to learn, do research, rent movies, music, and books, or simply find a quiet escape. However, some people may find certain materials offensive and question whether they should be removed from library shelves. In my opinion, these materials should not be removed as they offer different perspectives and can spark curiosity.  Books, movies, and music can contain content that some individuals may find offensive, such as explicit language, controversial topics, or sensitive themes. However, censoring these materials would limit access to diverse viewpoints and hinder intellectual freedom. History books, for instance, may depict harsh realities that some find disturbing, but they are essential for understanding the past and learning from it.  Moreover, what one person finds offensive, another may find thought-provoking or enlightening. Offensive content can evoke strong emotions and stimulate deeper discussions and reflections. By keeping these materials available, libraries can encourage critical thinking and open dialogue on complex issues.  Instead of removing offensive materials, libraries can consider categorizing them appropriately and providing clear information about their content. This way, individuals can make informed choices about what they want to explore. It is important to uphold the principles of intellectual freedom and respect the diversity of perspectives within society.  In conclusion, while some may find certain materials in libraries offensive, it is important to preserve intellectual freedom and the diversity of viewpoints. By maintaining a wide range of materials, libraries can continue to serve as valuable resources for learning, entertainment, and personal growth. Offense is subjective, and it is essential to recognize and respect the varied opinions and preferences of library users.

Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I adhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I believe that the books and other items should stay in the shelves of the library that censorship in libriaries is unnecessary. As Katherine Paterson stated there will be no books left on the shelves if you take every book off that someone in the community finds offensive. What is offensive to one person may not be considered offensive in another persons point of view. Children, teens, and adults have their own right to choose whatever book they want to read, movie they want to watch , or music they want to listen to. If it is a child or a young teen then I believe that the parents should have a say in what their children read or watch. In my case I am not allowed to listen to offensive music or watch rated R movies but that shouldn't mean that it should be taken off the shelves of the library. Just because that is what my family believes to be right does not mean it is the only way to live.   A person has their own rights to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to. They can make the choice by the way they have been raised or just because that is what they think is right or wrong. If they think that a book is offensive then they don't have to read it, they have the right to say no and put the book back on the self. If they think that the book is appropriate then they can read it and there is no law stating that they have to share the book with anyone else. If there is a book out there that is offensive in your view and you read it there is no reason you have to agree with it. Every person is free to disagree with anything they want to disagree with.   If you are a parent to a child and you are uncomfortable with them reading, listening, or watching something that is offensive you should set the rules early in life with them. Parents should make sure that their children are not reading inappropriate things or listening to offensive music or watching inappropriate movies. Therefore, if you are comfortable with your children seeing and hearing offensive things then you don't have to worry about what is out there in the community. The things that your children are watching, reading, listening to isn't a problem and if it becomes a problem in the parents eyes then they have the right to stop the children from reading the offensive books or watching the bad movies and listening to the music that the view as offensive. Every parent and family is different, as long as your child knows the rules and what you believe in then there is no need for censorship in libraries.   In my family I am not allowed to listen to offensive music. Offensive music in my house is considered music with curse words in the lyrics. The words that my family considers offensive may be different than what other families consider offensive. I know that I don't want to and can't listen to those certain songs but that does not mean that I can't be friends or be around people that listen to that kind of music. Just because that is what my family believes in does not mean that it should be taken of the shelves of the library or any other place. What my family believes in may not be the right thing in another family's view. Every person has their own right and if they want to listen to that music then they should be able to. My family also believes that at my age right now I should not watch rated R movies. If you took all the rated R movies off the shelves, then half the movies would be gone and that is not fair to the people who enjoy rated R movies. What my family believes may not be what other families believe in. I know what I stand for and I will do what I think is right and I won't listen to offensive music or watch rated R movies. In no way though does that mean that other children, teens, adults shouldn't enjoy that kind of music and those movies.   In conclusion, I believe that censorship should not be used in libraries. It is every person's own right and they are capable of making decisions that they think are the right thing to do. Parents also have a say in what they want their children to watch, read, or listen to. They can monitor what their children are reading, watching, or listening to and if they find it offensive they can stop their children. It is not necessary to take the items off the shelf. Offensive media is pervasive in our society, impacting both children and adults. Children exposed to inappropriate content may mimic the behavior they see, leading to social difficulties and a distorted sense of what is acceptable. Similarly, adults can also be influenced by offensive media, potentially adopting harmful habits or beliefs. This can result in emotional distress and even violent tendencies. Removing offensive media from libraries would help create a more positive and healthy environment for individuals of all ages. By eliminating access to inappropriate content, we can promote a society that is free from the negative influences that such media perpetuates. Ultimately, the removal of offensive media from libraries would contribute to a safer and more enriching world for everyone.

All of us have the right to express our thoughts, beliefs, and feelings. Freedom is a precious gift that belongs to each of us, and no one can take it away. However, it can be challenging to understand and accept the opinions of others, especially when they differ from our own.   Libraries are valuable resources where we can find a wide range of material to answer our questions. While some content may be offensive or uncomfortable for some, it is essential to consider the potential value it may have for others. If we had the power to remove any material we found objectionable, the library shelves would be empty.   Music is another form of expression that can be divisive. Some may consider certain genres to be rude or inappropriate for children. However, it is unfair to judge people based on their musical preferences or other forms of media consumption.   It is crucial to remember that no one is superior to anyone else, and we must respect each other's feelings and perspectives. By working on understanding and empathy, we can create a more inclusive and harmonious society.

Should books, magazines, or movies that are found offensive be removed from the shelves? I think that the book, magazine, or movie should stay on the shelf even if it is found offensive. If it is offensive to one person, it doesn't mean that it is to every person. Everyone has their own view on the subject of offensive or not.     I don't think the person that wrote the book or magazine meant for it to be offensive. They were just writing what they thought went along with the story and some people took offense from the book or magazine. But, they shouldn't argue over it because, like I said before, the author probably didn't mean for it to be offensive.     In conclusion, the books should stay on the shelves. Everyone has different point of view. The author probably didnt mean for the book or magazine to be offensive.

Censorship in the world is a contentious issue, with many arguing that certain material is unsuitable for public consumption. However, I believe that individuals should have the right to read, watch, or listen to whatever they choose, as long as it does not violate any laws. While some may access material that is illegal or harmful, it is not fair to punish everyone for the actions of a few. The freedom of expression is a fundamental right enshrined in the constitution, allowing people to explore a wide range of ideas and opinions. While the government may have the authority to regulate certain content, this should not extend to limiting individuals' access to information. People should have the autonomy to decide for themselves what they find offensive or objectionable, without fear of censorship. Ultimately, the right to freedom of expression should be protected, allowing individuals to engage with diverse perspectives and ideas without unnecessary restrictions.

I think that books, movies, music, and magazines should be removed from the shelves of libraries if they have anything to do with drugs, sexuality, and violence. There are many reasons why I think that those materials should be removed. One reason is because young children can easily access them and learn inappropriate behaviors. Another reason is that libraries should be safe spaces for families, free from explicit content. Furthermore, such materials should be kept in restricted areas for limited access. From personal experience, I have seen how inappropriate content can be harmful. In conclusion, it is essential to consider the impact of these materials on individuals and society as a whole.

There are tons of books in the library that people today find offensive to young readers. However, these materials should not be removed from the shelves. People have the right to read what they choose, and censoring books would limit access to diverse perspectives and stories. Removing offensive books would be a slippery slope, as many works could be deemed offensive to someone. It is essential to respect individuals' right to choose what they want to read, listen to, or watch. Censorship limits access to valuable and thought-provoking content, ultimately hindering intellectual growth and exploration. Therefore, it is crucial to maintain a wide range of materials in libraries to cater to diverse tastes and preferences.

I don't think that they should be removed from the shelves. Everyone has a right to read it at some point in time. To where no little kids can rent the book. If they are complaining about how it's vulgar or sexual, then you shouldn't take it away. Try something else such as an adult section. One person may love a book that has some violence in it, and on the other hand, you may have a person who is really religious and can't stand to see it.  There are many viewpoints on this topic. The parents who don't want their kids to be exposed to this type of lifestyle may have valid concerns. However, some people don't think about it being as bad as the next person. If it's a book you dislike on a bookshelf and you don't like it put out in plain sight, should you really be the one to make the decision on who takes it down?  Some people don't know what their kids like to read. If they have the final thought on what gets taken down, it may affect the kids' reading habits. What if your kid wants to read a horror book, and you choose not to let those kinds of books on the shelf anymore? Then they may not want to read the books that are left up on the shelf. I'd rather read a book that interests me than a book that I dislike.  My point of view on this topic is simple. I don't think the parents should be in control of what we read as long as it's appropriate. I think the decision should be left for the government to say which book should and shouldn't be taken away.

When it comes to censorship, I believe that very few things should be removed. Just because something is offensive to some does not mean it is offensive to all. Material should only be removed if it offends an overwhelming majority of people. If something offends you, you can simply choose to ignore it rather than demanding its removal. When it comes to books, music, movies, or magazines, almost anything should be allowed, except for material that depicts nudity or drugs and alcohol. A little cursing or violence is acceptable, but it should be kept away from young children. Parents should take responsibility for monitoring what their children are exposed to, rather than demanding censorship. Everyone should have the freedom to express themselves without fear of being censored. In a free society, people should be able to read and write what they want without facing ridicule or censorship. Freedom of speech and creativity should be protected, even if some may find the content offensive. Let's respect each other's rights and allow for diverse viewpoints and expressions to coexist in a tolerant and open society.

Yes, inappropriate content in books, music, and other media should be removed to protect children from exposure to harmful material. Children should be exposed to educational and age-appropriate content that aligns with their learning and development. Parents should monitor and regulate what their children are exposed to, ensuring that they are not reading, listening to, or watching anything that is inappropriate for their age. It is crucial to create a safe and healthy environment for children to thrive and grow without being negatively influenced by inappropriate content.

My thoughts on censorship in libraries is yes some books, music, movies, magazines, and etc., should be taken off of the shelves if they are offensive. If they are left on the shelves some very small child or teens could come up and reach for a book and find that it has bad things in it that are meant for adults. The child will ask the caregiver that they are with what does this picture mean, and they will most likely not know what to say at that moment. Parents and caregivers are not always up to explaining or want to explain as soon as they have to about things sometimes. Everyone goes through life with different things they have to learn at different rates. Some things should be taught when we are young like how to brush our teeth, but some things should be left until we are older like having babies or drinking. When parents going through the explanation of something like making babies you do not want it to be when they are only five years old. With books in a library with pictures of men and women questions like that do get asked to young. Libraries are public places and should be safe for any age no matter whether they are young babies or adults. Public schools have libraries in them also, and I would not want a child reading a book with bad or offensive things in it. It does not just have to be a book with bad things in it, but it could also be something to do with religions. Everyone has their thoughts and comments on at least one religion. If you have grown up a certain way your whole life, and a kid picks up a book dealing with another religion they will ask someone about it. Young kids and teens can always find things that they should not at certain ages, but why not make it less by not letting a library be censored? When you were younger your parent did not want to take you to the library and be asked an offensive question because of a book, music, movie, or magazine. It has worked for so many years, so we should not have to change it now.

I dont believe that it should matter what books are in a library. If you think a book would be offensive to you, dont read it. If you were to read a book with opinions about a cirtian race or religion, just keep your opinion to yourself. Most people make a big deal about cirtian things to get attention.      If a library was split up into sections about topics and such, it would help a lot, and it would be a quicker way to get your books and get out to make room for others. I honestly have not seen a @CAPS1 in a school library, but its probly because I did not spend much time lookin for it. And if there isnt one, its probly because someone complained about it.     If you are religious, you should have the right to be able to read what you want. Theres all kinds of weird books in the library, and a lot of people just look at them for the fun of it. I dont know why some people have so many problems with certian things. Like I said before, if you dont like it, dont read it.

I don't believe any of those materials are offensive if found in a library. But if the children look somewhere else to find those things, then they will find them anytime. The offensive materials are out there to be picked up by some people, including children. The books aren't offensive if found in the adult area, as children would not be interested in reading them due to their length and lack of pictures. Music may be offensive but is typically found in the adult area as well. Children are not usually interested in music at that age, so they would not be exposed to it. Movies and magazines with offensive content can be found anywhere, but they are less likely to be found in a library. One may come across offensive materials like magazines in a library, as they cover a wide range of topics. While some books may be offensive, they can serve as a learning experience by showcasing the consequences of certain actions. It is important to consider the purpose of these materials and the lessons they may provide, even if they may be deemed offensive by some.

Is the censorship in libraries really necessary? In my opinion, it is, but only to a certain extent. I believe that most people who frequent libraries know what types of materials are more suitable for adults versus teenagers or children. Censorship helps to protect youth from being exposed to inappropriate content that could influence their behavior. However, if censorship were to be relaxed, a system of age-appropriate ratings could be implemented to guide parents and children in making informed choices. By introducing ratings like those used for movies, children could be steered towards materials that are suitable for their age group. This approach could help parents and children make better decisions about the content they consume and prevent negative influences. Overall, a balanced approach to censorship in libraries is essential to protect the well-being of young readers and ensure a positive learning environment.

Books, movies, music, and even social media are all essential forms of learning and entertainment in our society. They provide valuable insights into the past, present, and future, allowing individuals to broaden their knowledge and perspectives. While some content may be uncomfortable or offensive to certain individuals, it is important not to censor or restrict access to these materials.  For example, the book "Huckleberry Finn" contains language and themes that may be considered offensive, but it is a crucial piece of literature that sheds light on the historical context of slavery and societal attitudes of the time. Attempts to ban or censor such works only serve to limit our understanding of the past and hinder our ability to learn from it.  Similarly, movies and music that may contain controversial or provocative content should not be censored. It is up to individuals to make informed choices about what they consume and engage with. By allowing access to a diverse range of content, we enable people to make their own decisions and form their own opinions.  Ultimately, censorship limits our freedom to explore different perspectives and ideas. It is important to embrace diversity in media and literature, even if it means confronting discomfort or offense. By promoting open dialogue and critical thinking, we can continue to learn and grow as individuals and as a society.

People see libraries as a valuable source of knowledge and information, but some may find certain content offensive. While libraries should strive to provide a wide range of materials, including those that may be controversial, it is important to consider the potential impact on the community. If there are items that are widely deemed offensive, it may be necessary to address these concerns with library staff. Ultimately, the goal should be to ensure that the library remains a welcoming and inclusive space for all members of the community.

I think that if you feel like they are saying bad things, you should not read the books or magazines, listen to the music, or watch the movies. If something offends you, just avoid it because what may be offensive to you might not be offensive to someone else. It's a part of life to come across things that we may not agree with, so why dwell on it? Taking things off the shelves just because they are offensive to some people is not the solution. People have different tastes and preferences, and we should respect that. Instead of trying to censor everything, we should focus on what we enjoy and let others do the same. It's important to remember that we can always choose what we expose ourselves to and not let negative comments affect our beliefs.

Libraries should not be able to remove books, movies, and magazines from their shelves just because some children might be offended. Doing so could alienate the children who enjoy those materials and deter them from returning to the library. For instance, if a library removes popular books, movies, or magazines that many children love, it could lead to a decrease in library usage.  Instead of removing materials, libraries should implement a policy where parents must sign a permission slip for their children to check out certain books, magazines, or movies. This way, parents can have control over what their children are exposed to, and libraries can continue to offer a wide range of materials for all ages. By having age restrictions and parental permission in place, libraries can ensure that children have access to appropriate materials while still offering a variety of choices.  In conclusion, libraries should not censor their materials based on potential offense. By implementing a permission slip policy and age restrictions, libraries can continue to provide a diverse selection of books, movies, and magazines for all patrons to enjoy.

Some people think that certain books, movies, magazines, or music should be removed from libraries because they may be found offensive. I believe that libraries should not rid their shelves of 'offensive' material.  What really makes something offensive? If someone were to tell me that it looked as if I've lost weight, I would find that offensive. The person wouldn't have meant it that way, though. Although I would have found it slightly rude, another person may have found it to be a nice compliment. With this logic, can one really conclude that anything is truly offensive? By saying something is offensive, you're stating your own opinion. Even if they aren't the same as everyone else's, everyone is entitled to their own opinions; equality is something most people find very important. Because of this, one person's definition of offensive shouldn't be held higher than another's. If we rid libraries of 'offensive' material, that is exactly what you would be doing; you'd be making one person's definition of offensive superior to another person's.  I also believe libraries should not get rid of 'offensive' material because by doing so, they would probably be getting rid of a lot of interesting material. Let's use my religious beliefs for an example. I am a Christian. Basically, I do not believe in 'Buddhism'. If someone were to write a book about my religion, I would find it interesting. Some may find it to be offensive, though. So if a library got rid of that book because someone found it offensive, I wouldn't want to go there as often. When I go to a library, I want to find a book that I'd enjoy reading. If all the material that is found offensive was taken out of the library, would there really be anything left? If so, I doubt many people would find it interesting.  I also believe this because by taking a book off the shelf because you find it offensive, wouldn't you be offending the author? As I said before, everyone is entitled to their own opinions. Because of this, libraries should allow authors to speak their minds. By taking their books off the shelves, you'd be offending them. They took their time and effort to think about and write that book, and for you to offend them by taking it off the shelf, you'd be contradicting the entire purpose of removing it from the shelf.  In conclusion, I believe that nothing can truly be defined as offensive. Also, people should be able to speak their minds. Therefore, libraries should not attempt to rid their shelves of 'offensive' material.

In my own personal experiences, I have come across magazines, books, and music that are offensive. I believe that these materials should not be found in libraries. There are many people who may still want access to these materials, so my suggestion is that there should be a separate room designated for offensive materials. By having a separate area, we can keep these materials away from young children. When I become a parent, I want the library to be a kid-friendly place. In order to make that happen, we need to find a solution for these materials or not have them at all. Libraries should be welcoming to everyone: from college students studying for exams, to young children exploring the world of literature, to elderly individuals seeking peace and quiet. The presence of offensive materials can be a distraction and hinder the inclusive environment that libraries should strive to maintain.   Libraries serve as places for learning and exploration, where individuals can discover the wealth of resources available to them. For young children, libraries are like fairy tale lands where anything is possible and the impossible can become reality. If there are materials that parents do not want their children exposed to, they may feel uncomfortable bringing their child to the library. It is crucial for libraries to be kid-friendly environments so that individuals of all ages can fully enjoy what they have to offer.   In conclusion, offensive materials should not have a place in libraries. All individuals should be able to enjoy the offerings of a library without being exposed to content that may be inappropriate. I urge you to consider these points.   Kind regards,   @PERSON2

They need to remove the bookstores from the library because students want a wide variety of books available, including Spanish books and books from different cultures. This allows students to learn new languages and explore different perspectives. Additionally, the library should consider removing music and movies, as some DVDs may be damaged or missing.   Many people believe that libraries should be free for everyone to access. Libraries around the world should consider lending books to those in need without any cost. It is essential for libraries to reach out to the community and showcase the resources available, including books, DVDs, and magazines.   To attract more readers, libraries should offer a diverse collection of materials and create a welcoming environment. By providing unique and interesting DVDs for rent, libraries can cater to a wider audience and encourage more people to read. Overall, libraries should continue to evolve and adapt to meet the needs of their patrons.

Censorship is important when it comes to the media that people consume, such as books, movies, and music. However, completely removing offensive material from library shelves is not the solution. People have different opinions and what may be offensive to one person may not be to another. If everything deemed offensive is removed, there would be very little left for anyone to read, watch, or listen to.   Currently, there are measures in place such as ratings for movies and video games, as well as censoring of explicit language in music played on the radio. These actions allow individuals to make informed decisions about what media they consume. While some may argue that this is not enough, complete censorship would limit people's choices and potentially make others upset for not having access to the content they desire.  In conclusion, censorship can be effective without completely removing all media from shelves or the public sphere. It is important to strike a balance between protecting individuals from offensive material and allowing freedom of choice in what media they engage with. By maintaining a level of censorship that is mindful of diverse opinions, we can ensure that a variety of content is available for all to enjoy.

Censorship in libraries is a topic of debate, with some arguing for restrictions on certain materials while others advocate for unrestricted access. Libraries are known for their diverse collection of books, magazines, movies, and music, catering to a wide range of interests and age groups. While some may argue that certain content is inappropriate for certain age groups, others believe that all materials should be available to the public.  It is important to have a variety of materials in libraries to cater to the diverse needs of the community. While the internet provides access to a vast amount of information, books are seen as more reliable sources as they have to go through a publication process. However, concerns may arise about children accessing inappropriate materials in libraries.  To address this issue, some suggest segregating materials based on age appropriateness and placing adult content in designated sections that are not accessible to children. This way, parents can feel more comfortable knowing that their children are not exposed to content that they deem inappropriate. Ultimately, it is up to individuals to monitor and guide their own and their children's reading choices.  In conclusion, while censorship in libraries is a complex issue, it is essential to strike a balance between providing access to a wide range of materials and ensuring that content is age-appropriate. By implementing measures to segregate materials and educate the public on responsible reading habits, libraries can continue to be valuable resources for all members of the community.

Should certain materials be removed from library shelves just because they contain uncensored content? No, they should not be removed. While not everyone may appreciate such materials, it is important to respect individual preferences and allow people to make their own choices. In today's society, where people are exposed to all kinds of content, it is crucial for teenagers to learn to make their own decisions and navigate through different viewpoints. Censoring materials limits access to information and hinders intellectual growth. Ultimately, it is up to individuals to decide what they want to read and explore. Let us embrace diversity and freedom of expression in our libraries.

The censorship of certain media is a highly debated topic, often boiling down to individual opinions rather than solid arguments. What one person finds offensive, another may not, making it challenging to determine when censorship is justified. Some content may intentionally provoke controversy, while others may inadvertently go against societal norms. Ultimately, the decision to censor material lies with the general public, influenced by current trends, ethics, and societal issues. If something goes against too many of these factors and upsets a significant portion of the population, it is likely to be removed from public access. In the end, censorship in libraries and other platforms is shaped by the collective opinions of society, reflecting the values and beliefs of the time.

It is concerning to find inappropriate content in books, music, movies, and magazines in the children's section of libraries. Material containing profanity, sexual content, or offensive language should not be easily accessible to young readers. Parents should be able to trust that the items in the children's section are age-appropriate and suitable for their children. It is essential for libraries to be mindful of the content they offer to ensure a safe and positive environment for young readers.

All kids have their own style of books, whether they like scary, funny, or romance books, but can we really take that as an offense? Removing certain books from the shelves can impact more than one person, as some individuals may be mature enough to read more "grown-up" books or magazines. Libraries cater to different tastes and age groups, so finding the right book may require a bit of searching. It's important to consider how peer pressure can influence reading choices, as individuals may feel the need to conform to what their friends are reading. Books with offensive content should not automatically be banned, as everyone has the right to choose what they want to read. Instead of removing books, individuals can simply ignore those that they find offensive and seek out titles that align with their preferences. Libraries offer a diverse range of books to suit everyone's tastes, so it's important not to judge a book by its cover and to explore different genres to find what resonates with you.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' - @PERSON1     If one thinks about it books are such a magical escape from everyday life. They can take one anywhere they want to go at any time. Imagine a world where books are a luxury or where they are simply not present at all. I feel as if this would become an all too real reality if we censor books.      Where would the line be drawn saying a book is unfit to be read or placed into circulation. The popular book To Kill A Mockingbird was banned at one time in the United States simply for using the 'n-word'. If anything is to be banned, I believe it is censorship.

When one person is given the right to do something, then everyone else should have the same right. However, there are instances where individuals may abuse their rights. I believe that all forms of media, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, have a place on library shelves and should not be removed simply because they may be found offensive. Even if something is considered offensive, there may still be a valuable message within it that is worth sharing. While I have come across media that I personally found offensive, I have also recognized the underlying good message that it aimed to deliver.  In my opinion, no one should have the authority to remove any form of media from library shelves. Everything has a purpose and a message that can be meaningful to different individuals. It is essential to allow people the opportunity to explore and interpret various forms of media for themselves. By keeping a diverse range of content available in libraries, we can promote open-mindedness and critical thinking in our society.

Yes, I think they should be removed from the shelves. Some books, music, movies, magazines, etc. are overrated and young children visit the library. I honestly believe that everything should be allowed in libraries. The freedom of speech should be upheld, and individuals can choose not to engage with material they find offensive. Libraries should strive to provide a diverse range of materials while also considering the needs and sensitivities of their patrons.

Have you ever found a book offensive? Many people can say they have. They might not agree on the point of the book or certain viewpoints in the text. I think libraries should not remove offensive material from their shelves. While some people may find certain content offensive, others may still want to learn about that topic. I do not believe that certain materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, and etc. should be removed from libraries, unless they contain explicit content like nudity or excessive profanity. Overall, libraries should aim to offer a wide range of materials while implementing appropriate measures to regulate access to potentially sensitive content.

People believe that censorship is important in libraries to prevent children from being exposed to bad language and inappropriate content. However, I disagree with this viewpoint.
