Another book that should be removed from circulation is written by the notorious @PERSON1, responsible for sending countless individuals to their deaths in gas chambers and camps during a dark period in history. This book is rife with messages of hate, targeting specific groups and advocating for their extermination. While the removal of such books may be seen as censorship, it is necessary to prevent the spread of harmful ideologies and prevent history from repeating itself.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries should be implemented to remove books that promote hate, violence, and discrimination. By removing such toxic literature, we can prevent the perpetuation of harmful ideologies and ensure a more inclusive and peaceful society for future generations.

The library is a public space that should cater to the diverse interests of its patrons, providing a wide range of books, movies, and magazines. It is not fair to remove offensive materials simply because a few individuals find them disturbing. Everyone has different tastes and preferences, and it is impossible to please everyone all the time.  If the library were to start removing items based on individual complaints, it would set a dangerous precedent. It would be impossible to keep everyone satisfied, and the library would risk alienating a significant portion of its user base. It is important for the library to maintain a diverse collection to serve the needs of all its patrons.  Ultimately, it is up to each individual to decide what they want to read or watch. If someone comes across something they find offensive, they have the option to simply choose something else. It is not fair to impose one person's preferences on everyone else. By keeping a wide range of materials available, the library can ensure that it remains a valuable resource for all members of the community.

In all honesty, let people read and listen to whatever they find interesting. Everyone should have the freedom to choose what they want to read or listen to, regardless of the content. While some may argue that certain books should not be shared with certain people, the power of freedom allows individuals to make their own choices. It is important to consider a person's ability to comprehend the content of a book or song before deciding whether or not they should have access to it. While movies are rated for specific age groups, books and music can be valuable learning tools and forms of self-expression. Ultimately, everyone should have the freedom to explore different topics and express themselves through literature and music.

I enjoy reading very much and have read several books during my high school career. Three of the best books I have read covered topics such as drugs, rape, and partying, with inappropriate language. While some parents may find these books offensive and request their removal from school libraries, I believe it is important to uphold freedom of speech and press. Everyone has different opinions, and what one person finds offensive, another may not. Children often have differing views from their parents and will read what they want regardless.  It is crucial to respect individual opinions and allow access to a variety of materials in libraries. Books are categorized by age appropriateness, so children can access materials suitable for their age group, while teenagers should be mature enough to handle more challenging content. Restricting access to certain books limits the choices of those who enjoy reading them.   As an adult, I will encourage my children to make their own choices and provide guidance on what I expect from them. Ultimately, the decision to read a book with explicit content should be left to the individual, as reading a book does not equate to condoning the actions depicted. Overall, censoring books based on subjective opinions of offensiveness is unjust and limits the freedom of readers to explore diverse perspectives and experiences.

I do believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelf. They are certain books, music, movies, magazines that people find quite offensive. There could be a few books that have some awful material in it. The pictures in magazines, on CD cases or on movie/DVD cases would have stuff that people find really offensive. I have never actually seen anything like that before, but it does happen in schools all around the world. People might not get what certain materials want you to do, but they get offended and tell someone about it. They would most likely tell people to not get it and tell the school that they were offended by the material. Certain materials should be removed from the shelves.

Librarys have the right to decide how censored they want their material on their shelves to be. Much of this material may be considered offensive to certain people. However, some materials may be as offensive to one person, it may not be offensive to another. Americans have freedom of speech, and writing, and many other rights. A library should have the right to put whatever materials it would like on their shelves. There will always be offensive songs, books, movies, and magazines. However, some materials may be found offensive to someone, it may not be found offensive to others. A library may not be able to please everyone.  "But if they have the right to remove that book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then they also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And we have no books on the shelf for any of us" (Paterson). Paterson is simply explaining that if someone finds something offensive and wants it removed from a shelf then soon all books will be removed, and there will be nothing left at all on the shelves.  A library is a place for everyone to come and find what they are looking for without any disturbances. A person probably isn't looking for something offensive. Therefore, coming across something that is offensive may be disturbing; however, they should be able to try to ignore it. It is that person's choice to choose that library to attend to. So they will choose to maybe find offensive materials. If someone does not wish to come across offensive material they should choose not to go to the library.  Americans have the right to be free, so does a library. If a person comes across an offensive piece of material it should be ignored. A library cannot please everyone by taking out all of its merchandise that may be considered offensive. There simply would be nothing left. People should be aware that they may come across some offensive materials when going into a library, so it will always be the people's choice of attending that library. In conclusion, libraries should have the freedom to choose what materials they want on their shelves, and individuals have the choice to ignore offensive material or choose not to visit the library if they find it objectionable.

I believe that some material should be removed if it is very offensive. However, I also think that if it is helping someone learn, it should stay on the shelves. Everyone has different opinions on what is offensive or appropriate, so it is important to read the cover of a book or other materials to see if it is suitable for you. Libraries should consider putting warning stickers on items with graphic or vulgar language to inform people beforehand. This can help reduce the need to remove books from the shelves. In my opinion, warning signs can help prevent incidents like the one I experienced when I was younger, where I unknowingly read a book with inappropriate language. I believe this approach can benefit not only my own family but also other library visitors. It is essential to ensure that materials are age-appropriate and respectful of different audiences.

In today's world, being a child is not easy. With thoughts and ideas constantly racing through their minds, children face the stresses of school and daily life. However, the last thing on a child's mind is whether the literature they are reading is offensive. While some may argue for increased censorship, I believe that it would only serve to make our future generations more sheltered and closed-minded.  Currently, censorship is prevalent in music and movies, yet children still find ways to access inappropriate content. Censoring media does not prevent children from being exposed to unsuitable material; rather, it often leaves them unaware of the true meaning behind the content they consume. Additionally, with the internet providing easy access to a plethora of information, censorship becomes even more challenging to enforce effectively.  Instead of relying on censorship, parents should engage in open discussions with their children to help them navigate the complexities of the world. By fostering communication and providing guidance, parents can empower their children to make informed decisions and understand the implications of the media they consume.  In conclusion, censorship may shape the future to some extent, but it is not the solution to raising well-rounded and informed individuals. Encouraging open dialogue and critical thinking skills in children is key to helping them navigate a world filled with diverse perspectives and content. Ultimately, censorship may offer a temporary solution, but true empowerment comes from education and open communication.

Hello! My name is @PERSON1. I am writing to you @DATE1 because there is much conflict on the issue of whether materials in the library that are deemed offensive should be removed from their shelves. I believe that these materials should remain where they are.  People often get worked up over small things in life, but it is important to realize that there will always be things we don't like, and that is inevitable. In the case of offensive materials in the library, instead of demanding their removal, people should simply choose not to engage with them and move on. It is crucial to understand that not everyone will share the same opinions and preferences.  I advocate for leaving these materials in the library because individuals have the ability to overlook them if they choose to do so. We must learn to accept that we will not always agree with everything we encounter, but that should not lead to unnecessary conflict or demands for censorship. It is essential to learn to let go and move forward, recognizing that differences in opinions will always exist.  Ultimately, it is important for people to understand that they will not always get their way in life, and it is crucial to learn how to navigate through situations where our preferences may not align with others. Therefore, I urge individuals to refrain from making a big deal out of minor issues like offensive materials in the library and instead focus on moving past them without unnecessary confrontation. Let's learn to coexist peacefully, respecting differing perspectives and leaving room for diverse opinions to exist harmoniously.

I do not believe that books should be censored. If a book is on the shelf in a library, then anyone should be able to pick it up and read it. I have never come across an offensive book in all my experiences at libraries, and I believe that if a book is deemed offensive, it wouldn't be displayed for everyone to see. Reading is important for sharpening the mind, and individuals should have the freedom to choose what they read without censorship. If someone doesn't like the selection at a library, they can simply go elsewhere or order books online. Libraries have more important issues to focus on than individual preferences, and censorship limits intellectual freedom. In conclusion, books, magazines, movies, and other materials should not be censored, and individuals should have the freedom to choose what they read and view.

As many would agree, censorship is a growing topic of concern throughout the world. I personally feel that censorship is necessary to a certain extent. If one feels the content of music, a movie, or a book is questionable, he or she has the option of reading, listening, or watching.  Among many debated materials, movies have ratings, just as music has 'bleeps'. Movies are rated 'G' for all audiences, 'PG' standing for parental guidance, 'PG-13' for parental guidance for ages 13 and older, and lastly 'R' meaning that anyone under the age of 17 is either suggested or required to have an adult present during the viewing of the film. At home, the ratings are all based on the parent's preference. At the movie theatre, the restrictions become a sort of law. Anyone below the age of thirteen is not permitted to see a movie that is 'PG-13' or 'R' unless accompanied by an adult (anyone 18 or older). Depending on where you are, the restrictions may be more or less harsh. Ultimately, the rating system is intended to force parents to choose what is and isn't appropriate for their child.  As for music on the radio, all 'curse words' are 'bleeped' out. If a person wants to buy their own music, artists are required to make two of the same album, one with censors and one without. Thus creating a decision usually for the parents, assuming they are the ones to buy the album or the music for their child.  When it comes to books, there are no ratings, just genres letting the reader know who the author's intended audience is. Types of genres include 'adult', 'young adult' and 'children' sections in libraries and book stores. Just like music and television, the final choice in the purchase is all dependent on the parents.  Even though many restrictions are put in place, there are still some faults to the system. Obviously if you are 17 or younger, you most likely won't have identification. This leaves the person working at the movie theatre the option to let in who they believe to be of age. Looks can be deceiving. Buying music from the internet doesn't require any type of identification either. How can they prove your age? When purchasing a book, not many cashiers would stop a child and say, 'that's inappropriate for you'. Maybe kids of all ages should have identification. Although these are all underlying problems in the censorship system, it seems to all lead back to the parents.  Censorship is a huge topic of discussion for the parents of today's young and growing society, but in reality, if they have an issue with the content, they themselves will either rid of the material or prohibit the use and or purchase of it. All in all, it's about the parents and their personal preference.

No books should be taken off the shelf. Everyone has different tastes when it comes to books, magazines, movies, or poetry. If someone finds something offensive, they can simply choose to ignore it and find something else that suits their preferences. Variety in tastes is what makes each person unique. Personally, I enjoy horror novels for the excitement they bring with their themes of killing and suspense. While I'm not an avid reader, I do appreciate the thrill that horror novels offer. Transitioning to different genres can be challenging, as each type of literature has its own unique appeal. For example, poetry can be complex to understand due to its use of elaborate language and metaphors. Renowned poets like @PERSON1, who gained fame posthumously, have left a lasting impact with their work. In essence, individual preferences vary, and diversity in reading choices enriches our world.

How often do you find a book or a magazine that you don't want children or someone to read?
