Who is to label a book offensive? What one might find appalling, others may find a novel or passage to be rather interesting. All books and other arts were created to be read and enjoyed by people. Libraries banning books, music, movies, or magazines seems unreasonable since there is such a wide variety of people and their interests.  Books such as The Catcher in the Rye, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, and To Kill a Mockingbird have been removed from many library shelves. Though some people may find these books offensive, many others find them either enlightening or think they should be readily available. I have read a decent amount of each of the above readings, and have found the books to be full of remarkable things which have taught me a lot. If books are banned from libraries, it almost seems as if they're limiting our education.  Why would a book be published, or written for that matter, if we were not intended to read it? Any book could be offensive to any one person. Any article, song, or film could be offensive. But, there will always be a crowd it appeals to. And that crowd deserves to enjoy every last word. Censorship in libraries has gone on too long, it is time for the world to freely take part in the literature that interests them.  The solution to library censorship is the division of books into categories and sub-categories. First by subject, down to the author. Therefore, books that may be offensive are listed as such, but are still available to those who want to read them.  Censorship in libraries takes away from individual freedom every day. People should be able to read what they enjoy and not be ridiculed for it. All books are written to be read, and with the division of such books, everyone can agree upon this: books help us grow. Growth is not meant to be limited, nor is freedom.

People have a choice on the types of literature they want to read whether it offends them or not the choose to read it. Books should not be removed from the shelves of libraries. They need to try to avoid the books that may be offensive to them. Now if they can't, then that's not the library's fault. Books should not be removed for many reasons.  One of the many reasons books should not be removed is because individuals know the risk they take when entering a library, and that's their decision that they are making and sometimes decisions have consequences. When and if they are offended, they will know the types of books that offended them, so they would just have to do a little better job of avoiding those books.  Another reason would be the libraries don't know what offends people; it can be one little thing in a book but that doesn't mean that book should be removed from the shelves. Also, just because one person thinks it's offensive doesn't mean that others will. People aren't all offended by the same thing; some people are offended by little things, meaning they're offended easily, some aren't offended so easily, that means it may take more serious things than a book to offend a person.  Another reason books shouldn't be removed is because students need them for projects and school assignments. Some school assignments require you getting a little offended, especially if you're African American and you get an assignment on slavery or something during that time. But we need to learn about past experiences and our history, and we couldn't do that if some people are trying to remove some of those books from the shelf. You may get offended, but there is no reason to remove that book that others will need at some time. Find another way to solve that problem.  There are other ways to solve problems like these such as tagging the books with a yellow small sticker so it would warn people that the book offended someone. There is no need to completely remove the book. Another solution would be to maybe separate the books, meaning put the books in a different location of the library if they get more than a couple of complaints of being offensive. Also, when someone checks out a book, the librarian can warn them that the book has been tagged with a yellow sticker and it's possible that it may offend them. That's why removing books from shelves isn't the cause for concern.

Certain books, music, and magazines can be found offensive and harmful to children, influencing them in negative ways. It is important for parents to be vigilant and keep their children away from such content to ensure they grow up to be successful and well-rounded individuals. By limiting exposure to violence, drugs, and unrealistic beauty standards, we can help shape a better future for our children. Encouraging positive influences and steering clear of harmful media can lead to a more promising and fulfilling life for our youth.

There are plenty of books that people don't want their children reading. Books such as '@CAPS1 @CAPS2 @PERSON1' is a book I had read and it was very out there and straight forward. But I would have to disagree I think those books deserve to be read. It shows kids that not everything is perfect.  People complain about how they think books are bad or things people say on @CAPS3 or in music is bad but if you don't want to listen to them, don't let your kids listen to it. If parents are so worried about what kids are reading or learning because of the world we live in now, lock them up. But I do have to agree with one thing, there are a lot of bad things in music and magazines but I think it can be avoided and not be caused to corrupt a kid.  I'm very into music and some music I don't listen to because of the things in it but I don't let that music or magazines change my opinion on things. I don't think people should be able to take books off the shelves because it doesn't give other students or people to read them. Some people get inspired by books about drugs, not to use them but to know that there are people out there that have overcome situations just like them.  I like reading books about teenage problems and like to know all the different ways people have overcome them and see how they live. If people can get offended by a book or movie I don't think they have a right to take that away. I think people that feel offended by books, magazines, and movies should stay away from them if they are offensive to them because everyone has an opinion and not everyone thinks the same things.  With all the bad or good movies or books out there, I'm certain someone at least feels offended by one or two books or movies but that isn't a reason to want to take it down. Because once you do that someone will take a book you thought wasn't offensive and it will make you mad. I think if people stayed away from things that offended them and stayed close to books that they liked we wouldn't have much of a conflict unless you get that picky, always wanting to start a fight person to find something else to be picky about with the books or magazines or movies.

Do you think having inappropriate or offensive books, magazines, movies, or music should be found in a public library? Some books could be very offensive to people, and when they take their children or younger siblings to the library, they don't want them looking at that. Others prefer looking at it, which would anger them if they were taken away. Not all parents find some of the things in libraries offensive, even if they may be. Having music, magazines, movies, or books that aren't appropriate for children should just be put into a different section, not taken away from those who enjoy it.  Even though having children look at something they shouldn't could be bad, it's also bad and unfair to those who only come to the library to view those things. It shouldn't be taken away from them. If parents don't want their children seeing those things, they shouldn't take them to that section. Some adults don't enjoy seeing it, which can be understandable. No matter what, someone wouldn't be very happy about the decision.  In libraries, there is usually an adult section and kids section. If an adult doesn't want their child seeing something, they could simply take them to the children's section where it won't be seen. In the children's section, it's hard to find things that would be considered 'offensive' to adults. For the adults or teenagers who enjoy viewing these things, they could be in a section far away from the children. Taking things that people like away from someone is wrong, and it would be mean to take that away from those who enjoy it.  Recently, the world has been turning into something it shouldn't. Some of the most disgusting and cruel things happen every day, and you could probably find this news in a library. It's understandable if you wouldn't want your child around that, but it's wrong to take away those things from the people that love that stuff. For example, scary movies could be very disturbing and too violent for a young child, but they could be an adult's favorite thing to watch. That's why, if you put the more offensive things in a different section, the kids wouldn't notice it was even there.  If children were put into a different section, they wouldn't even notice the offensive things adults find. Taking away the things some adults may find offensive is like taking away the children's section, unfair. It wouldn't be fair to take away something that some adults or teenagers only come to the library for. Not all adults would understand both sides, but I can see where both sides are coming from. If I had children, I wouldn't want them seeing things that are offensive, but I would keep them away from it instead of promoting against it. Having music, magazines, movies, or books that aren't appropriate for children should just be put into a different section, not taken away from those who enjoy it.

There are millions of books and other media in libraries all across the world. Millions of people read and listen to those materials every day. Some people like certain books or media and dislike others. Many people dislike certain materials because of their content. Everyone has the right to read and watch what they want and not everyone will read or watch the same materials. Although some materials may be offensive, they should not be removed from the libraries.  Books and other media should not be removed from library shelves because what some people find offensive does not offend other people. Everyone has a right to their own beliefs and opinions. If someone wants to read a book or watch a video, they should be able to. What is offensive and what is not is a personal choice and it all depends on that person's point of view. If someone thinks the content in a book, song, or movie is offensive, then they should not read or listen to it.  Materials should not be removed from libraries because they can be used to learn history and other things that people should know about. Take, for example, the Holocaust. There are thousands of books on the Holocaust and many movies as well. These materials should not be removed from library shelves because even though some people find them offensive, they can be used to teach people how horrible it was so that it does not happen again. People should inform themselves about something before they view it so that they are not offended by the content inside. Some content in history is very mature and should only be viewed by mature audiences.  The offensive content should not be removed from libraries because it is usually in a mature section and it has a right to be there. Most content that some people find offensive is for adult audiences. There are not children's books that talk about things that parents would find offensive to their children. The content has a right to be there. If the author or publisher took the time to create the work, then they should receive credit for making it. In the United States, there is freedom of speech and people should be able to say what they want to say. If the content is too offensive then it should be removed but only under special circumstances.  The content in libraries, offensive or not, should not be removed. People can read or watch whatever they want. Many people have many different opinions on what should and should not be in libraries. The libraries are public and they are shared. No one person has the right to dictate what should and should not be in libraries. If it was not for libraries, the people in society would not be as smart as they are. Ultimately, the diversity of opinions and materials in libraries enriches our society and should be preserved.

Censorship in libraries is essential to protect young children from accessing materials that may be inappropriate for their age and level of maturity. By withholding books, movies, music, and other media that contain explicit content, libraries can help ensure that children are not exposed to harmful material. Setting age limits for certain types of materials can also help parents make informed decisions about what their children are exposed to. Overall, censorship in libraries should be allowed and enforced to safeguard the well-being of young patrons.

One day, a concerned individual walked into a library and noticed that some books in the young adult section may not be age-appropriate due to their content. This observation raised the issue of censorship in libraries and the need for stricter categorization of reading material. Some books and magazines may contain inappropriate themes or language that could be harmful to children and young adults. Implementing a rating system for books, similar to movies, could help guide readers towards age-appropriate content and prevent access to material that may be unsuitable for certain age groups. Additionally, increased supervision by librarians could ensure that individuals are aware of the content they are checking out and prevent unintentional exposure to mature themes. By taking these measures, libraries can better protect the well-being of their patrons and provide a safer reading environment for all.

This essay is to describe my opinion on if certain materials that can be offensive should be removed from shelves in libraries. I think that overall, anything taken as offensive to anybody should be taken out of libraries. If they are very offensive, then they should be removed, but if they are just mildly offensive, then I think they should stay. The library welcomes people of all ages, and materials that can be offensive for children may not be taken as offensive to adults. Children have access to everything in the library, so if they come across something that their parents find offensive, the library could be at risk of being sued. Removing materials that are not suitable for all ages can help reduce this risk.  Libraries are meant to provide information, so having offensive materials that do not contribute to knowledge is unnecessary. Libraries should focus on containing encyclopedias, dictionaries, and books that provide useful information to people. In conclusion, materials that can be offensive to anyone of any age should be removed from libraries. Libraries should stick to their core purpose of providing information to the public.

Should books, music, movies, and magazines that are offensive to the public be removed? No, I strongly disagree. While some individuals may find certain content offensive, it is important to remember that everyone has different preferences and opinions. Removing materials based on the objections of a few would limit access for those who may benefit from or enjoy them. It is essential to respect diverse perspectives and allow for a range of content to be available to accommodate the varied interests and needs of the public. Ultimately, censorship should not dictate what is available for consumption as individuals should have the freedom to choose what they read, watch, or listen to based on their own preferences and beliefs.

No, I don't think that books or any other material should be taken off shelves in libraries just because some people might find them offensive. If a parent doesn't want their child reading a certain book, they can simply advise their child against it. Removing books altogether denies others the opportunity to learn and gain knowledge from them. Education is vital, and books offer valuable lessons, even if they contain content that some may find objectionable. It is important to preserve access to diverse perspectives and information in order to foster learning and growth. Letting individuals make their own choices about what they read is essential for promoting understanding and critical thinking. So, books should not be censored or removed from libraries based on individual sensitivities.

Censorship in libraries is crucial in both schools and public settings. Some media, such as movies, books, and magazines, can have a significant impact on children. Violent and inappropriate content can influence kids in negative ways, leading them to believe that such behavior is acceptable. For example, movies like "@LOCATION1" depict graphic violence and racism, which can distort a child's understanding of right and wrong.   Similarly, magazines promoting guns and hunting can give children the wrong impression that carrying weapons or hunting animals is normal. This can be dangerous if kids are not mature enough to comprehend the consequences of such actions. Books, too, can start innocently but escalate into disturbing and violent themes, potentially glamorizing harmful behavior.  Therefore, it is essential to restrict access to age-inappropriate content in libraries to protect children from being exposed to harmful influences. By implementing censorship or age restrictions, we can ensure that kids are exposed to appropriate material that promotes positive values and healthy development. Ultimately, safeguarding children from harmful media is a responsibility that cannot be overlooked.

I believe that offensive materials should not be removed from libraries. If someone finds something offensive, they can simply choose not to engage with it and find something else that interests them. Everyone has different opinions and sensitivities, so it's important to allow individuals the freedom to make their own choices about what they read or view. Removing offensive materials would limit access to a wide range of perspectives and ideas, which is essential for a diverse and inclusive society. It's crucial to respect varying viewpoints and allow people to decide for themselves what they want to engage with in a library setting.

Censorship in Libraries  Author Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' There are many books, magazines, and movies out there that contain content not necessarily appropriate for young children. Part of a parent's job is to ensure their children are safe and looking at materials appropriate for their age level. However, this does not mean taking materials off of library shelves for everyone. Censorship in libraries rids people of their freedom to choose. Also, content that is inappropriate for children may be fine for adults to read. It is the responsibility of the parent to censor what their child takes off the shelf.  All people have certain rights allowing them to express themselves and to be free. People have the freedom to choose, whether it is books, magazines, movies, or music. Everyone is different and this causes the interests of each person to be different, also. Libraries offer a variety of materials and this allows people to choose what they want based on their interests. Censoring the content on the shelves of libraries may be a good idea for children, however adults have the right to choose what they want to take from the shelf. Would you like to have a portion of your freedom taken away? Censorship would greatly lower the freedom of everyone and their individuality.  Furthermore, censoring what is on the shelves of libraries limits the range of materials that are available to patrons. There is content out there that children should not see; however adults have the right to choose what they want to read and come in contact with. Although certain materials are not meant for children to see, adults may find it enjoyable and interesting. Libraries offer a large range of materials and this allows people to express themselves and find entertainment. There are many different types of books and music out there and censoring these would greatly limit the variety.  In addition, parents have the responsibility to watch over their children. They choose what their child wears, where they live, and where they attend school. It is no different when it comes to books, movies, and music. Each parent has a different style of parenting and they choose what works best for their child. If one parent finds something to be offensive or inappropriate, they shelter their children from it. However, another parent may not have a problem with it. The content children choose from library shelves should be at the discretion of the parent. After all, you cannot shelter children from everything.  Censorship in libraries results in more problems than solutions. It rids patrons of their right to choose and their freedom. Censoring materials also greatly limits the variety of content available for people to choose from. It is not the responsibility of the law to choose what children can and cannot read, but rather the parent's job to watch over what they take off the shelf. As citizens of the world, we have rights and freedom allowing us to act as individuals. Censoring the materials on library shelves results in very little materials left. As Katherine Paterson said, 'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.'

Censorship in libraries is a topic of debate in today's society. While some argue that libraries should have the freedom to stock whatever materials they see fit, others believe that censorship is necessary to remove offensive or immoral content. I personally believe that censorship in libraries is important, but it should be done in a thoughtful and controlled manner. Libraries should establish clear standards for the type of material they want to offer, and adhere to those standards when selecting books and other resources. However, it is crucial that these standards are not set too strictly or too leniently, as finding the right balance is essential. Overall, while censorship in libraries is still relevant, it should be more regulated to ensure that the materials available align with the values and expectations of the community.

Author Katherine Paterson argues that censorship should not be allowed in libraries, as it can lead to the removal of books and other forms of entertainment that some may find objectionable. She emphasizes that everyone has the right to their own opinion, but if censorship continues, there may be no books left on library shelves for anyone to enjoy. Censorship limits the freedom of authors and artists to create as they choose, and it deprives individuals of the opportunity to make their own choices about what they read or view. Paterson warns that if censorship is not addressed properly, it could result in a loss of valuable knowledge and entertainment for future generations. It is crucial to protect the diversity of literature and allow individuals to access a wide range of perspectives and ideas. Ultimately, censorship in libraries should be abolished to preserve the richness and variety of books available for all to enjoy.

Censorship is a law that is often disregarded, particularly in libraries where certain books, movies, music, or magazines may be restricted. This not only impacts the freedom of expression for writers and creators but also limits the knowledge and exposure of individuals, especially within the school system. The right to express beliefs and feelings on various topics is a fundamental right in the US, and censorship can hinder this right. Libraries and schools should not restrict access to certain materials based on personal preferences, as it goes against the principles of respect and freedom of information. The government should take a more active role in enforcing laws against censorship to prevent discrimination and allow individuals to explore a wide range of ideas and perspectives. Ultimately, censorship should not be tolerated or ignored, as it infringes upon the rights of both creators and individuals seeking knowledge.

Do you think that books with vulgar content should be available in libraries? While some may argue that such books should be removed from shelves, it is important to consider the historical and moral significance behind them. The banned book list includes titles like @PERSON2, @PERSON1, @CAPS1 @CAPS2, and @CAPS3 @PERSON2's @CAPS4, which have been challenged for various reasons. However, the presence of offensive language or themes does not necessarily warrant censorship. It is ultimately up to the individual to decide whether or not to engage with such material. Just as movies are rated for content, books could also be labeled accordingly. Banning books with controversial elements limits intellectual freedom and deprives readers of diverse perspectives. In conclusion, the availability of books with offensive content should not be restricted, as readers have the autonomy to choose what they consume.

I think censorship in libraries is wrong. Books, movies, and magazines are meant to enlighten, inform, and entertain readers. Just because someone finds something offensive in a book, movie, or magazine doesn't mean that it should be censored for everyone else. People have the right to choose what they want to read or watch, and limiting access to certain materials because of personal preferences is unfair to others who may not have the same concerns. Everyone pays taxes to support libraries, so they should have the freedom to access a wide range of materials without restrictions. It is important for individuals to take responsibility for monitoring what their children read and watch, rather than imposing censorship on the entire community. Ultimately, censorship goes against the principles of freedom of expression and access to information, and should be avoided in libraries.

In Katherine Paterson's writing, she expresses her concern about children picking up books that may be offensive. While it is important to be mindful of the content children are exposed to, there could be sections in libraries designated for certain age groups that are not accessible to everyone. This way, children can explore books that are appropriate for their age without the risk of stumbling upon material that may not be suitable for them. By having more vigilant library staff members monitoring the shelves, we can ensure that children are guided towards age-appropriate reading materials. This approach can help prevent situations where children accidentally come across books that are not meant for their age group. Ultimately, creating separate sections in libraries for different age groups can help provide a more tailored and safe reading experience for children.

There are some movies, books, music, etc. that can be found offensive to certain individuals. If a person is of the appropriate age for a particular form of literature, they should have the freedom to engage with it. If something is deemed offensive upon reading or viewing, then perhaps it was not the right choice in the first place. Entertainment mediums such as books, music, and movies are created with the intention to entertain, and if that purpose is not fulfilled, then it may not be suitable for that individual.  Personal experiences of being offended by a movie, for example, can stem from various reasons. In my case, I watched a film that depicted the degradation of women, which deeply offended me as I realized these characters were someone's loved ones. It made me reflect on how I would feel if it were my own mother in that situation. While authors may not intend to offend their readers, there might be ways to present their ideas more thoughtfully.  It is important to remember that everyone has their own perspectives and ways of interpreting information. If a particular book or movie is offensive to one person, it may still be appreciated by another. Expressing why something is offensive can lead to constructive dialogue and potentially prevent similar instances in the future. Parents, in particular, should be mindful of the content their children are exposed to, as it can have a lasting impact on their development.  In conclusion, if something is found offensive, it is crucial to learn from that experience and communicate the reasons behind the offense. While it may not be necessary to remove offensive content from shelves, individuals can make informed choices about what they consume. Ultimately, entertainment should serve to entertain and uplift, rather than offend or harm.

I believe that censorship is a very debatable subject for many. However, I think that it is important to consider the impact of media on children and the influence it can have on their behavior and attitudes. While adults should have the right to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to, children need to be protected from content that may be harmful or inappropriate for their age. By implementing censorship, we can help safeguard children and promote a healthier environment for their development. Ultimately, censorship, when applied thoughtfully and appropriately, can play a significant role in shaping our society for the better.

To whom it may concern; As a student who enjoys reading, I believe that books, movies, and magazines containing explicit material should not be taken off the market. We have the right to free speech and the freedom to choose what we want to read or watch. While some may find explicit content disturbing, others may find it appealing. It is important to remember that we have the choice to avoid such material if it does not align with our personal preferences. Parents also have the authority to monitor what their children are exposed to and set guidelines accordingly. If we were to start removing books and other media containing explicit material, we would risk limiting our options and stifling our freedom of expression. It is essential to respect the diversity of opinions and allow individuals to make their own choices when it comes to reading and viewing material. In conclusion, the availability of books, movies, and magazines with explicit content should be preserved to uphold our right to freedom of expression and choice.

To who it may concern,  I believe that books, movies, and magazines should not be removed from the shelves of a library if they are found offensive. While some materials may be deemed offensive by certain individuals, others may have a different perspective. I think that if something is considered offensive, it should be placed in a special section where mature individuals can access it. Books are valuable to many people in the United States, and just because something is offensive to one person does not mean it should be banned for everyone.  Many people enjoy reading materials that others may find offensive, and it is not wrong for them to appreciate something that has been written. Just because a book or magazine contains content that someone finds objectionable does not mean it should be removed. I believe that there should be sections in libraries for different age groups, allowing parents to control what their children have access to.  Creating a specific section for offensive materials in libraries may require more work, but it would be a solution that accommodates everyone's preferences. Libraries are already organized, so it would not be difficult to designate a separate area for controversial materials. This approach would allow people to access what they want while respecting the views of others.  In conclusion, I strongly believe that offensive materials should not be removed from libraries. People have different tastes and interests, and it is important to provide access to a variety of materials for a diverse audience. By creating a designated section for controversial content, libraries can cater to the needs of all patrons without restricting access to valuable resources.  Thank you for considering my perspective on this matter.

I believe that all types of materials should be placed in libraries to satisfy the different styles of what people like. Censorship should not play a role because everyone has their own opinions on what is looked at as offensive and what is not. By giving everyone the freedom to enjoy what they like will make a lot of people happier. The wants and needs of people vary from one extreme to the other. What one person loves, another may hate. This should not play a role in whether or not materials should be removed from public places such as a library. Everyone has the right to express themselves through art in their own way. Taking away the art that some find offensive would not be fair to those who enjoy it. By doing this, not all people will be satisfied when not everyone gets what they want. Censorship should not take part in any library. Entertainment cannot always please everyone. It will be judged in many ways no matter what anyone has to say, so the problem should just be left alone. Arguments to remove material that some like will only cause tension to rise and make matters worse. Opinions will vary with what I have had to say. I strongly believe that people should be given the right to enjoy the materials they take an interest in. Censorship definitely has its positives and negatives, but for the most part, it is wrong and should not have a role in any library. Cutting down people's availability to their interests will only lead to frustration. You cannot please everyone, so in that case, censorship will just have to be looked beyond.

Libraries hold many books and movies with a wide range of genres and styles, including fiction, nonfiction, historical, fantasy, and adventure. While some of these materials may be perceived as offensive to certain groups, it does not necessarily warrant their removal from shelves. One such example is the book 'The Birth of a Nation', which portrays blacks as slaves and uses offensive language, reflecting a time when such attitudes were prevalent. Similarly, the movie 'Slumdog Millionaire' has faced criticism for its depiction of a boy from a slum being mistreated, potentially perpetuating negative stereotypes about intelligence based on socio-economic background. Despite these concerns, these works continue to be available in libraries and stores due to their historical significance and artistic value.  While some individuals may find certain books or movies offensive, it is important to consider the context in which they were created. For instance, the book 'Gone with the Wind' presents conflicting views on slavery during the Civil War era, which could be unsettling to some readers. However, these works provide valuable insights into the past and spark important discussions about societal values and progress. Rather than censoring materials based on potential offensiveness, it is essential to preserve diverse perspectives and encourage critical thinking among readers.  In conclusion, the presence of potentially offensive content in libraries should not automatically lead to censorship or removal. By allowing a variety of voices and viewpoints to coexist, libraries uphold the principles of intellectual freedom and promote a deeper understanding of complex issues. While it is crucial to acknowledge and address concerns about offensive portrayals, the value of preserving diverse literary works outweighs the discomfort they may cause to some individuals. Letting books and movies remain on shelves enables readers to engage with challenging topics and broaden their perspectives, contributing to a more informed and inclusive society.

Would you ever read a book about the @CAPS1 times if your @CAPS2? Are you going to read about how people of your religion and maybe even your family were tortured? Probably not. If you're a person of color, would you want to engage in a book that talks about slavery? Not likely. And if you're a mother, would you want to read a novel or magazine about abortion? Would you let your child read that book? Of course not. So why are these books on the shelves? They're there to drown us in the knowledge they hold.  Whether we are learning about criminals, racism, or wars, there will always be someone who is against it all. When we read, we look for books that spark ideas and images in our heads, that bring us enjoyment. Most of us don't quite understand why others refuse to read such books or even hold in their hands a book that challenges their beliefs. Beliefs are important to people, regardless of their age, gender, sexuality, or race. It's just a way of life.  Some stories are there for our entertainment, some evoke emotions, and some are there for our knowledge. Authors write based on events that have happened or what they predict could happen in the future. They try to help us understand the world around us, not to offend us. Books can affect people in many ways, both positively and sometimes negatively. It's something that authors can't always control, so we can't blame anyone for being offended.  I believe that libraries should have these books on their shelves. They are good for us. No, I don't mean we should literally consume books. We should take the time to read some of those so-called offensive books. Even if you may be hesitant, reading these books can help us understand how terrible times were in the past and how some things are still unjust. Take abortion, for example. Books about abortion shed light on the impact it has, not just on the women who undergo it, but on society as a whole. They appeal to our emotions in a way that makes us think twice about life's decisions.  Books should be kept on the shelves for our own well-being. When faced with a choice, we will know what to do. Books help us differentiate between right and wrong. They are placed on shelves not for profit, but to educate and inform. I trust that you can grasp the message I am trying to convey. So, head over to your library and pick up a book about something that intrigues you. Who knows, you might find a book that challenges your perspective and makes you reconsider the information it holds.

In my opinion, I do not believe that anyone has a choice in what children or any other age group chooses to read. It is not up to the general public to say what is right or wrong. When society says that every single child is not allowed to read a certain book, or listen to a certain song just because it is found offensive to some people. There are laws against restricting what a person can or can not view. There is a level of media that is not as appropriate as it should be but that does not mean it has to go away completely. Some of the reasons society can not sensor everything are because of the fact that not everone is offended by everything, it is up to the parent of the child to say what is right or wrong, and lastly individuality is comprimised if the choices we have are limited. When someone gets offeneded by the media that is out there, that does not neccessarily mean that another person is also offended. When I do not like a video, or a book, or any other type of content, someone else should not have that content censorded because my opinion is in the way of what they enjoy. I know that personally I would not want someone to take away my favorite book so my child could not read it. Content that is out in the public will always be unsafe to read by someone else's views. Just like I will not believe in what other people believe in, but, I will see that it is valued by others and should not remain a censored topic. Books that are considered inappropriate, should be decided to has censoreship by the parents of a young child. Decisions like that should not be left up to a group of people that has opposite views. Whe children are growing up and are taught the values that know today, it is their parents that teach them and not a society full of people which have different kinds of opinions. There is a saying by an author and it says 'all of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf' and all that means if we all would have the power to remove a book or any other content from the shelf that we do not like then their would not be any books left. I believ in that saying and I also believe that many others will as well. Individualaity is when one person has differnt traits of feelings than another human being. We all have choices of the books we read and the musice we listen to and that is why we all have individuality. When people start to thnk that they are allowed to remove a certain song or book because that is not what they want other people to see, then everyone will do the same and no one would have that song they enjoy or the traits that make them differnt because they are the only one that likes that song. If there were not any of us left on this earth that has something that they enjoyed and no one else that also enjoyed the same thing, then we would all be pretty boring. I have learned from experience that being the person that has something different about them is not a bad thing and is actually a good thing in some cases. Also from experience I have learned that a boom that is no longer on the shelf that someone has removed is not a good feeling. I would not want the same happen to all of the other books in the world. It is a very good thing to practice the art of understading, and to have an open mind when it comes to a certain material that another person happens to enjoy. In the future, when I find a book that may not be a book I would want my children to read, I will just let the topic go and remember that everyone has their own opinions. So in conclusion I just want to let everyone know that books that are seen as inappropriate or offensive to one person, may be seen as a good thing to another.

Take it @CAPS1? How do you take it when people come out with magazines, movies, or music that is extremely offensive to you? How can you stop your children or the younger generation from watching these things? The truth is we cannot stop them; there is so much pornography and inappropriate content out in this world that it is easily accessible. It is all over the internet, and controlling what children are exposed to can be challenging.  If you find something very offensive in a store or online, you should have the right to voice your opinion, and it should be taken seriously. Inappropriate content should not be displayed in public places where children can easily access it. It sets a terrible example for kids, and some people should be more mindful of the impact of their actions.  Every day, online advertisements for adult content can be seen on various websites. It is concerning how easily accessible this content is on public platforms. There should be regulations in place to prevent such explicit content from being displayed on websites that are accessible to all, especially young children.  While the media industry often prioritizes profit, there is still a demand for entertaining and humorous content that does not rely on explicit or offensive material. It is possible to make money without resorting to controversial themes, and there is an audience for lighthearted and humorous entertainment.  In conclusion, it may be challenging to completely eradicate offensive content from the media, but by voicing concerns and advocating for more appropriate and positive content, we can hope for a shift towards more responsible media representation. It is essential to continue protesting against offensive content and strive for a media environment that is more mindful of its impact on viewers, especially young audiences.

Libraries are valuable repositories of a wide range of materials, including books, music, movies, and magazines. They cater to diverse interests and preferences, providing something for everyone. It is important to respect the freedom of choice and not impose personal preferences on others. If certain materials are deemed offensive by some individuals, they can simply choose not to engage with those particular items. It is not fair to restrict access to materials based on individual sensitivities. Ultimately, libraries should have the autonomy to curate their collections based on the needs and interests of their patrons. It is essential to consider the greater good and the principle of intellectual freedom when addressing concerns about library materials. Let us embrace the diversity of content available in libraries and celebrate the richness it brings to our reading experiences.

Offensive materials should not be removed from library shelves. Individuals who find certain materials offensive can choose not to view or check them out. If someone is offended by specific content, they can request for it to be placed on higher shelves. It is essential to remember that offensive material can still be valuable sources of information for others. Removing such materials could deprive people of important resources for research or learning. Additionally, with the easy access to information on the internet, simply removing offensive materials from libraries may not prevent individuals, especially children, from encountering such content elsewhere. Therefore, it is important to maintain a diverse collection of materials in libraries, allowing individuals to make informed choices about what they wish to access.

If you saw a book on the shelf of your library that took offense to you in some way or another how would you react? Every individual person has their own opinion and not everyone else is going to agree with that person. So, say you stumbled across a book about the @ORGANIZATION1 in the library and you are a person from Negro descent. Would you get offended? History is important to everyone and if we didn't learn about it and they did toss those books out how would we prevent history from repeating itself?  When I was a young child my father used to hit my mother, so my mother takes offense to anything in the media that has to deal with abuse. I tried to have my mother watch a movie with me called '@CAPS1'. The movie is about a girl who is abused by her mother and has her father's babies and she finally gets out of it and betters her and her children's lives. The media does not look at you as a whole, just as a population of people. When one person doesn't like something it doesn't mean it should be taken out or erased from history, it should just be rewritten or refilmed. You cannot control what everyone else says or does in books or movies, you have to just be in control of how you look upon it as. That is what I choose to do and I would say it is working out great.

No, because people have different preferences when it comes to books, movies, music, and magazines. Removing certain materials from libraries could deter individuals from using those facilities. While some may advocate for the removal of certain content, others may value the diversity of options available. If there are concerns about children accessing inappropriate material, it is ultimately up to parents to monitor and regulate what their children read, watch, or listen to. It is important to respect the varying tastes and interests of library patrons to maintain a welcoming and inclusive environment for all.

I believe that there should be some censorship, but not too much censorship when it comes to libraries. Each person has their own interests and should be able to find something in their library to suit their interest. Certain materials may be too strong for libraries and can be found in stores instead. While some materials may push the line of content, they should still be available for those who enjoy them. Everyone is entitled to their own beliefs and forms of entertainment, and libraries should cater to a diverse range of interests. In conclusion, there should be a balance in library censorship to ensure that individuals can find materials that align with their preferences.

I believe that books, music, movies, or any other materials that may contain offensive content should not be removed from library shelves. Everyone has different preferences and opinions, so just because something may be offensive to one person does not mean that it will be offensive to everyone. It is important to respect the diverse interests and viewpoints of individuals. If a particular book or material is not to your liking, you always have the option to not read or consume it. By leaving these materials available, people have the freedom to choose what they want to read or listen to. Ultimately, censorship should not limit access to diverse perspectives and ideas. It is essential to recognize that what may be offensive to one person could be enlightening or thought-provoking to another. Let people make their own choices and form their own opinions when it comes to reading materials.

Censorship in books, music, movies, and magazines in libraries is a topic that sparks debate. While some content may be considered graphic or inappropriate by some, it is essential to recognize that everyone has different tastes and preferences. Books, for example, can cover a wide range of topics, from romance to crime, and it is important to respect the diversity of readers' interests. Similarly, music can vary greatly in content, with some genres focusing on explicit themes while others offer more wholesome messages. It is crucial for parents to guide their children in making appropriate choices regarding the media they consume. Movies, too, can range from family-friendly to adult-oriented, and it is up to individuals to decide what they feel comfortable watching. Magazines serve as a source of information and entertainment, but parents should be mindful of the content their children are exposed to. Ultimately, while there may be content that some find objectionable, it is important to remember that censorship should not be used to limit access to diverse perspectives and artistic expressions. It is essential to approach the issue of censorship with an open mind and a respect for individual preferences.

Offensive reading materials should not be taken off the shelves in libraries. While some content may be deemed inappropriate for certain age groups, it is important to allow individuals to make their own choices and exercise responsibility in their reading selections. It is essential for parents to be actively involved in guiding their children's reading choices and discussing sensitive topics with them. Removing books from libraries will not address the underlying issues of immaturity or inappropriate behavior. By providing guidance and support, individuals can navigate potentially offensive content in a responsible manner. It is crucial to promote maturity and accountability in handling challenging material rather than resorting to censorship. Ultimately, individuals who can handle such content should not be restricted due to the actions of a few immature individuals.

I do not believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from library shelves just because some individuals find them offensive. Everyone has their own personal opinions on what is acceptable, and what one person may deem offensive, another may find enjoyable. Instead of removing materials, libraries should provide a wide range of options for people to choose from. If multiple complaints arise about a specific item, then perhaps consideration should be given to its removal. However, having ratings and different sections in the library allows individuals to make informed choices about what they want to read or watch. Removing materials based on personal preferences limits access to diverse content and can disappoint those who enjoy them. Therefore, I believe that censorship in libraries should be approached with caution and only implemented in cases of widespread objection.

I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, magazines, etc., shouldn't be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. People have different views on what is offensive, and what may be offensive to one person may not be offensive to another. It is important to respect the diverse perspectives and tastes of individuals. If something is offensive to someone, they can choose to ignore it rather than trying to censor it for others. Libraries and other establishments typically screen materials for extreme offensiveness, so there is already a level of control in place. Instead of focusing on what is offensive, we should focus on understanding and respecting each other's differences. In a world with billions of people, it is impossible to please everyone, but we can strive to coexist peacefully by accepting and tolerating varying viewpoints and preferences.

According to Katherine Paterson, who wrote an article about censorship in the library, we should not have the right to freely take books, magazines, movies, or other materials off the shelf. Allowing individuals to remove items based on personal offense could lead to a lack of variety and options for others who may appreciate the content. Everyone has different preferences, and what may be offensive to one person could be enjoyable to another. Additionally, the impact on businesses, such as stores and libraries, would be detrimental if items were constantly being removed. It is essential for individuals to communicate their concerns about offensive material to library staff rather than taking matters into their own hands. Ultimately, the responsibility falls on parents to monitor the content their children are exposed to. Therefore, we should not have the unrestricted right to remove items from shelves as it would limit choices and potentially harm businesses.

There are a ton of books out in the world that have a deep meaning and a sense of compassion. But, other books can have mean or hateful effects on the person who is reading it. Censorship, taking books, movies, magazines, etc. off the shelves so a person cannot read or watch them, is a very positive thing.  In many cases, censorship is a great thing. It protects young readers from being exposed to hateful things at such a young age. In libraries, the librarian should censor the books for younger people so they do not read the awful and hurtful things the book is saying.  Like books, music, movies, and magazines should be censored, too. Some music has a very catchy beat to it and could get stuck in a young person's head. This could cause an effect on that child and they may start to act like that or want to become like the person the song is describing.  Movies should also be censored. When I was little, my parents did a good job of censoring things that were bad for me to watch at that age. I barely had any nightmares because I was never exposed to that kind of writing when I was a child. On the other hand, my friend's parents were not the best at censorship and allowed her to watch or read whatever she wanted. She had many nightmares from the movies or books that she read.  Now since I am older my parents are starting to let me watch and read more censored things. In my experiences with this type of material, I have had some nightmares and have personally been offended by some books. Although censored books may have a great story behind them, the material that supports it can cause a dispute between different people who have different beliefs.  Thousands of books are censored each year. Many of them have to do with different religions or races that people have different opinions on. Libraries need to censor books to protect the innocent minds of young children.

@ORGANIZATION1 @ORGANIZATION1 People have different preferences when it comes to books, music, movies, and other forms of entertainment. It is important to remember that you are not obligated to consume anything that you do not like. Therefore, there is no need to remove items from shelves just because someone finds them offensive. If a particular book or movie is not to your liking, simply choose not to engage with it. It is unfair to expect the company or the author to cater to every individual's preferences. Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, and it is essential to respect that diversity. Removing items from shelves based on personal offense is unnecessary and could potentially limit others' enjoyment. Instead, focus on selecting what aligns with your interests and leave the rest for those who appreciate them. Ultimately, it is crucial to consider the bigger picture and not let minor disagreements escalate into unnecessary conflicts. Let's embrace the variety of choices available and respect each other's differences in tastes.

Should offensive or graphic books be removed from the library? Well, in my point of view, I think books, music, movies, magazines, etc., are amazing, exciting, and fun to read or watch, and they should not be removed from the shelves in the local library. People have various tastes in books such as drama, romance, action, and many others, which also apply to movies, magazines, and more. The public should not be punished for one's interest in certain themes, and individuals should have the freedom to choose what they want to read or watch.  I personally enjoy reading scary books as they give me chills and provoke deep thoughts. Others in my community may have a similar interest in such books. Without access to a wide range of materials, people may become disinterested in libraries, leading to potential boredom and even an increase in crime rates. Everyone in the community has the right to explore different genres and forms of entertainment.  If some individuals find certain materials disturbing or offensive, they should simply avoid them and seek out content that aligns with their preferences. It is not fair to impose personal opinions on others who may enjoy such content. Books and other forms of media are meant to be enjoyed, and creators share their stories with the intention of sparking imagination and creativity in their audience.  In conclusion, people should be able to enjoy whatever material they prefer without censorship. If you are someone advocating for the removal of offensive or graphic content, I encourage you to explore different genres and see how it can broaden your perspective. Let's embrace the diversity of literature and entertainment available in libraries for the enrichment and enjoyment of all.

There are many types of reading materials available in libraries, catering to a wide range of interests and preferences. While some materials may be considered offensive by certain individuals, I believe that they should not be removed from the library altogether. Instead, age-appropriate sections should be designated to ensure that children are not exposed to content that is meant for adults. Additionally, clear signage can help individuals make informed decisions about the materials they choose to engage with. It is important to strike a balance between providing access to a variety of resources and ensuring that inappropriate content is not easily accessible to young audiences. Ultimately, libraries should strive to offer a diverse selection of reading materials while also taking measures to protect the well-being of their patrons, especially children.

I do not believe that censorship should be an option for people that find a book, magazine, or movie offensive. I believe that if a person decides to take a book off the shelf because he/she is offended, they are obviously paranoid. If a few cuss words are found in a book and a person doesn't want their children to read that book, then don't allow them to get it. Don't make all of the other people suffer. Censorship is an unnecessary solution to something that isn't even a problem. You know what they say, 'If it ain't broken, don't fix it.'  First of all, people have a variety of opinions. Some people think that violence is ok and some people don't think it's ok. If one person decides to put a book off the shelf because they find it offensive, what will the next person think? They may find violence perfectly acceptable and they might allow their kids to read the book. Then it would create a big conflict.  Lastly, parents need to allow their kids to grow up and mature. They also need their kids to know the difference between right and wrong. If they don't read books or movies with violence or cuss words when they're young, what will they do when they discover it when they're older? As a child, it is a time to learn life lessons and begin to form clear distinctions between right and wrong. Shielding your children from it will only hinder their progress in figuring things out and learning to think for themselves as adults.  Censorship is the same thing that Hitler did to prevent people from thinking for themselves and discovering that his tactics were a great evil to society. In other words, censorship is part of fascism and should not even be considered in a free society. The citizens of America have the responsibility of exposing the truth and teaching our children the differences between right and wrong. It's one of the ideals that help make this country great.

Censorship is a topic that sparks debate, with opinions varying on its necessity depending on the audience. While some argue that censorship is essential to protect young children from exposure to inappropriate content, others believe that adults should have the freedom to make their own choices. Teenagers often fall somewhere in between, craving the excitement of mature themes but still needing guidance. The internet poses a challenge to censorship efforts, as it offers unfiltered access to a wide range of content. Ultimately, the decision on what to censor often falls to parents or guardians, who must consider their own values and beliefs. In the end, censorship is a subjective matter, with individuals holding differing views on what is acceptable for consumption.

Each book in a library bears its own relation to each person that enters that library. Whether the books relate well or poorly to each person is not something for a mass of people to decide. Every person has a different outlook on what makes a story interesting. There will not ever be a book that every human being agrees to be both appropriate and vivacious. Designed with distinctly different minds, people want to read distinctly different books, written by distinctly different authors. People should maintain a right to choose which books he or she wants to read. Never, will one book bind the world. Minds of human beings are too complexly separated. For example; reading 'To Kill a Mockingbird' by Harper Lee in my English class last year was more than appropriate, though rather boring for the majority of the class. Books of racism, religion, and sexual content intrigue a person's mind, or otherwise disgust one's. Finding satisfactory books for everyone in a community to agree simply will not ever be done. There will always be that one person who declines to agree. It is a choice. It is a choice for each person to read what he or she wants to read. If you force something upon a society of readers, then what will they have left for their own minds' freedom? Face it, forcing an atheist to read an emotionally comprehensive novel of the Christian faith will not be stood for by the reader. Cursing, to some people, brings a book to a realistic point. To others, however, it draws them further and further away from the story. A choice should remain a person's right; especially to read a book written to be read. Finding an appropriate book is not the problem. That has yet to become the problem. The only problem is finding appropriate books that are both compelling and enthralling. I find 'Lolita' in the Library to be dangerously inappropriate. However, it captivates my mind beyond other dimensions. Others that I know choose not to read it because of the offensive content. Do I find it offensive to some? No, but I understand where others could find it offensive. There is no way to approve a book to not be offensive, because it is not offensive to every person who reads it. To reiterate, the mind of human is a unique one, that identifies with no other. To sum up the full idea of this position; every person should be given the choice to read what he or she desires. Give each person the choice, and the rebellion will settle down. Removing a book from a shelf just puts the craving in the hearts of certain people to read it; sometimes completely rebelliously. Katherine Paterson is extremely correct by saying that taking a book from a shelf every time someone wants one banned will not leave books for anyone. As a person, I am well associated with my mind, and it desires the freedom of choice. Every human mind desires the freedom to choose. Give people the choice. Remove no books from a shelf, and let the outcome draw in whoever is interested in whatever they may be interested in. Let readers have their freedom.

In society today, people take things in very many different ways. So things that might help one person, may offend another. In libraries, there are different kinds of books; fiction, non-fiction, etc. So if you don't like a particular book, maybe you should try looking in a different area. I do not think books should be removed from the shelf because the book has offended a few people.  We are blessed to live in a country where we have freedom of speech. Authors have the freedom to write what they would like to. They work long hard hours getting a book ready to be published, and then someone wants to take it off the shelf because it offended a few people? I do not think that is right.  "One man's junk is another man's treasure." I think this quote goes along with this topic very well because the book may not mean something to one person but it may mean the world to someone else.  You never know what people may need to hear. Maybe an alcoholic is at a point in his/her life and is ready to change, and someone has a book about a recovering alcoholic. Now, this kind of book may offend a few people, but it may save a family, a friendship, or maybe even a life.  Take Anne Frank for instance, her journal is now a book. Now this may offend a few people that might have been there or maybe don't like Anne Frank, but her story has the right to be told. Yes, there is violence in it, and I understand that maybe you don't want your ten-year-old to hear about how they used to treat Jewish women, but the story has the right to be told, and should be told.  I do not think that the librarian has the right to take a book off the shelf at the library just because it has offended a few. There are lots of different kinds of books, if the books you are reading offend you, look for a different type of book.

I think a lot of books are good to read because they can provide new knowledge and perspectives. Some books may have characters with contrasting views, adding depth to the story. Magazines often give insight into different lifestyles. It's important to choose books that are meaningful and positive. Books that teach about life and success can be particularly impactful. While action-packed books can be exciting, it's essential to also read books that offer valuable insights. Ultimately, the best book is one that enriches your understanding and helps you grow.

In our society today, there will always be things that some people disagree with or dislike. However, just because someone takes offense to something, it should not be removed from the shelves. Removing items based on personal opinions limits the selection available to everyone. History should not be erased from books and movies, as it teaches us valuable lessons from the past. People have the right to choose what they read, watch, or listen to, and should not be restricted based on someone else's opinion. It is important to have a wide selection of materials to choose from for enjoyment and knowledge. Therefore, items should not be removed from shelves just because someone finds them offensive.

Practice makes perfect. You can do it! The United States is considered one of the greatest countries in the world because it is a free country. In the 19th century, people migrated here to escape the control that their government had in their homeland. In America, we practice freedom of speech. If we censor materials like books, music, movies, etc., it would defeat the entire purpose of America and its democracy. Everyone has their own personality with likes and dislikes. Not everyone likes the same music or is interested in reading the same subject, that's why it's wonderful that there is a variety of everything. If you start banning or censoring certain things, then how will people learn? There is nothing wrong with learning about negative things because that teaches people lessons so they know what to do or not to do if in that situation. When you censor 'bad things,' it creates naive thinkers, which only leads to discrimination. I agree that for children, there should be warnings for material that parents may find offensive. For example, movies have ratings for different age groups, and books could do the same. Of course, it's up to the parents if they want to follow the recommendations, but banning something altogether is not necessary. I personally learned a lot of things from what I've seen on television. What's on television may be considered 'street smart' education, but that is good. Today we live in a scary and violent society, so being 'street smart' is an advantage. If television was censored, then people would not know what to do in a bad situation because they have never experienced or seen it before. If books, movies, magazines, music, etc., are removed from shelves, then America is not practicing what it preaches to the many people who come here in search of freedom. Practice makes perfect. You can do it!

Censorship should be a crucial factor in determining which materials are included in library collections. To ensure that children are not exposed to inappropriate content, books, movies, magazines, and CDs should be carefully reviewed for offensive material. If a particular item is found to be offensive to at least ten children, it should be removed from the shelves.  Librarians should have a designated section for potentially problematic materials, such as those containing explicit language or references to drugs and alcohol. This will help protect young readers from stumbling upon unsuitable content. Additionally, age categorization of materials can assist in guiding children towards age-appropriate content as they grow and develop.  While it may not be possible to catch every single item with objectionable material, taking proactive measures to remove the most explicit content can make a significant impact. Parents should also play a role in monitoring their children's access to media by checking ratings and content warnings before allowing them to engage with certain materials.  Overall, a balance between censorship and freedom of choice is necessary to create a safe and appropriate environment for young library users. By being vigilant and proactive in curating library collections, we can help protect children from exposure to harmful content.

I believe that some books should be taken off the shelves if they are found offensive, especially if they contain racist content that could incite violence or discrimination against certain groups. It is important to consider the impact of such materials on the community, and removing them can help prevent conflicts and promote a safe and inclusive environment for all individuals, regardless of their background. In the end, it is essential to prioritize respect and understanding among people to ensure a harmonious society.

Many people have many different thoughts and beliefs. Some people may believe that a movie or song needs to be removed, but others may disagree, and nobody wants the things they enjoy to be taken away. If there was a book on a shelf in a bookstore that you didn't agree with and thought should be removed, and you removed it, then you are taking away from someone who may enjoy that book. If everyone removed things from life that they didn't enjoy, then there would be very little to enjoy.  For example, I personally love horror movies. I love the thrill you get from a horror movie and how they can make you jump even though it's just a movie screen. I'm sure there are people in this world who think horror movies are wrong. If those people were allowed to just remove them forever, I, and many other people, would be sadly disappointed. I also love video games. Video games are a huge part of my life, and I know for a fact that there are people who highly disagree with some of the content of them. If people could take video games away because they didn't agree with them, I would be crushed.  I am also aware that people may just be worried about their children watching movies, listening to songs, or reading books that are not appropriate for them. I understand that the parents want their children to be supervised, but removing the books, movies, and songs is not exactly the answer. Movies and books can easily be censored. Many movies and songs have language filters and some movie programs now have parental options that allow the parents to decide what movies they want to allow their children to watch. Parents can also supervise their children when they download music onto an iPod or phone, and depending on where they are bought, books and magazines may require parental consent. Video games also require parental consent depending on the rating of the game.  We can't just go around removing everything we don't like because it is not fair to those who may like it. We live in a world with many different ideas, thoughts, and beliefs, and we all need equal rights to share them. It is important to respect diverse opinions and interests, even if they differ from our own. By promoting open-mindedness and understanding, we can create a more inclusive and harmonious society where everyone can enjoy the things they love.

Today in society, there are many different views on various topics such as religion, race, and upbringing. Libraries, as a reflection of society, contain a diverse range of books that cater to different perspectives. While some individuals may find certain books offensive or discriminatory, it is important to maintain the integrity of libraries and leave things as they are for several reasons.  Firstly, individual preferences differ, and what may be offensive to one person could be valuable and enlightening to another. It is essential to respect the diverse opinions and preferences of library patrons and allow them the freedom to choose what they wish to read or engage with.  Secondly, books that address sensitive topics such as discrimination play a crucial role in documenting history and showcasing the progress that has been made in society. Removing such materials would hinder the ability to learn from past mistakes and understand the changes that have taken place over time.  Lastly, a library is meant to be a comprehensive collection of knowledge and information, catering to a wide range of interests and perspectives. By censoring or removing materials deemed offensive, the essence of a library as a place for exploration, learning, and discovery would be compromised.  In conclusion, it is important to preserve the diversity and inclusivity of libraries by maintaining a wide range of materials, even if some may be considered controversial or offensive to certain individuals. By upholding these principles, libraries can continue to serve as valuable resources for education, understanding, and enlightenment for all members of society.

In our public libraries, we can find books that cover topics such as slavery, drugs, gangs, prostitution, and violence, all of which are important aspects of our history. Censoring these materials would mean erasing crucial parts of our past, which could lead to a dangerous cycle of repetition. Libraries serve as invaluable resources for educational purposes, research, and personal growth. They offer a diverse range of materials that can enrich our understanding of the world around us.  Books on slavery, for instance, remind us of the dark chapters in our history and the importance of learning from past mistakes. By censoring such materials, we risk forgetting the struggles and hardships faced by those who were enslaved. Similarly, stories about gangs and violence shed light on the realities of crime and its impact on society. Rather than shying away from these uncomfortable truths, we should confront them head-on to build a better future.  In addition to books, libraries also provide access to movies, documentaries, and music that offer valuable insights into various subjects. From documentaries on historical events to films highlighting societal issues, these resources play a crucial role in broadening our perspectives and fostering critical thinking. Music, too, serves as a form of expression and can be a source of inspiration for many individuals.  While it is essential to consider age-appropriate content for young readers, outright censorship is not the solution. Implementing age restrictions and parental guidance can help ensure that children are exposed to material that is suitable for their level of maturity. By preserving our history and allowing access to a wide range of materials, libraries contribute to the intellectual growth and cultural awareness of individuals in society. Embracing our past, no matter how challenging it may be, is key to shaping a more informed and enlightened future.
