I don't think that anything that gets checked out from the library should be censored. Some of the people that go to the library aren't looking for material with offensive language and/or themes. On the other hand, there are some people who go to the library who find that having offensive language spoken when it was meant to be is better than censoring it.   Take for example a book about @PERSON1. It could have some things in it that people could find offensive. But if someone has to write a report on @PERSON1, it would be best to have as much information on him as possible. I will make one compromise: if there is music being checked out with offensive language, they should provide it with both a clean and explicit version of the album.   There are ways that censorship can be good, and some ways that it could be bad. Some people find bad language and themes offensive, while others find that it gives freedom to the artist or author. I think that uncensoring things in the good and bad form is better than not uncensoring things at all. In the end, it is important to consider the diversity of opinions and preferences when it comes to accessing materials at the library, allowing individuals to make their own choices without imposing restrictions based on subjective criteria.

A kid walks into the library up town. He looks around and finds a movie one of his friends recommended to watch. He checks it out and goes home to watch the movie. Later on, his parents come home to see their son acting out of the ordinary. He starts to say rude comments, being violent, and using profanity. Who is to blame? The friend who recommended the movie, or the library for having this movie on the shelves and letting the young kid check it out?   Today, many libraries have a variety of books, movies, music, and magazines to choose from. Some libraries even have computers for kids, teenagers, and adults to use for certain things such as business, personal mail on websites, or games for kids to play.   But are all the libraries meeting their requirements? Some people find many books, movies, music, magazines, and even websites threatening. Libraries have movies that are rated G, PG, PG-13, or R. They also have music that has explicit lyrics on the shelves. Some libraries may not meet their requirements and that is why libraries do not have as much business as others.   In my opinion, I think that if a library has offensive material, such as books, music, movies, magazines, and websites, they should be removed from the shelves. If the librarians are letting young kids check out explicit music, and R-rated movies, they should possibly be fired. From my own experience, I have not had trouble with libraries and materials they have to choose from. I have not visited a library that has had explicit music to choose, all of the bad websites are blocked on the computers, and all of the magazines are appropriate for all ages.   In conclusion, libraries should have respect not only for people, but for the materials they have. They need to show respect for the books, movies, music, and magazines they provide for kids, teenagers, and parents. Censorship is required for every library and I think that all the libraries around do meet their requirements.

Censorship at the library is not always necessary, as it is ultimately the responsibility of parents to monitor what their children read. While there may be instances where censorship is warranted, such as for adult content, the library should not dictate what individuals can or cannot access. Classic literature should not be altered to cater to the sensitivities of a minority group, as it reflects the realities of the world. Limiting books based on a few offensive words undermines the purpose of literature and fails to prepare individuals for the complexities of life. The library should not act as a censor, but rather provide access to a diverse range of materials for individuals to make their own informed choices. Ultimately, censorship should be approached with caution, considering the balance between protecting individuals and promoting intellectual freedom.

The seven books which constitute the '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' series by @PERSON1 are books which are frequently censored in school libraries accross the country. The main reasoning behind this is that since these books portray witchcraft in a positive light, they must be harming our innocent children. Many books, from @PERSON2's 'The @CAPS3 in the @CAPS4' to the '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' series have been banned from school libraries due to their content being deemed inappropriate by a group of people who fail to take the larger meaning of these works into account. Works meant to be accessed by the public should not be removed from the shelves of libraries if they are deemed offensive. Under the @ORGANIZATION1 to the @CAPS7, every citizen has the freedom of speech, press and religion. By censoring the speech of authors, their rights have been denied. It is an author's right to say what he or she feels needs to be said, and it should not be up to a board of parents or directors to prohibit that right. By prohibiting books such as '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' or 'The @CAPS3 in the @CAPS4' to be read; the greater meaning of these works is being disregarded. Many conservative @CAPS12 groups have advocated that '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' be banned from schools because of its portrayl of witchcraft (and therefore satanism) and the nominal fact that @PERSON3 has stated that @PERSON4 (the @CAPS15 in the series) is homosexual. However the ultimate message of the series is that love triumphs over evil. Apparently that is not a message worth teaching the youth of @LOCATION1. However, even if every school in the country took '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' off the shelves; that would not, and should not, stop children from reading these books. Since 'The @CAPS3 in the @CAPS4' began to be part of many schools' curriculum in the @DATE1, it has been at the top of the most censored book list due to its vulgar language and a chapter involving a prostitute. That has not stopped millions of teenagers from reading this novel, which is considered to be a rite of passage for most young adults. Being one of the most continuously challenged books over the last fifty years only seems to add to its allure and its popularity amongst the very people that these censorship boards are trying to 'protect'. If a parent, however, does not want his or her child to read such a novel; it should be left to the parent to censor what his or her child reads. But just because one parent does not want their child to read '@CAPS1 @CAPS2', does not mean that every child should be denied the opportunity to read it. Censorship should be a matter of the private, not public sphere. Books and other works should not be censored in libraries. In doing so; an author's freedom of speech is violated and the greater meaning of the work is disregarded. And while certain groups @MONTH1 advocate to protect the children of @LOCATION1 from these offensive works; the children will still find a way to access them. Ultimately, censorship in school libraries limits access to diverse viewpoints and hinders intellectual growth.

I believe that the view on censorship in libraries is justified for several reasons. The primary purpose of libraries is to provide access to information for people to learn, regardless of whether they agree with or are offended by the content. Removing offensive material would limit the diversity of information available to the public.   Katherine Paterson's quote highlights the impossibility of pleasing everyone when it comes to censorship. What offends one person may be valuable information to another. Libraries serve as a resource for individuals to explore a wide range of topics, even those that may be uncomfortable or controversial.   In conclusion, while some may find certain materials in libraries offensive, it is essential to maintain access to a variety of information for the benefit of all individuals. Limiting censorship ensures that libraries remain valuable sources of knowledge and learning for everyone.

Censorship in Libraries  I believe that there should be censorship in libraries. In society, there are many kids who are exposed to harmful content that can influence their behavior in negative ways. Censorship in libraries can help steer kids in the right direction, alleviate parental concerns, and prevent exposure to offensive material.  Censorship in libraries can play a crucial role in guiding children towards making positive choices. When children see their role models engaging in harmful behaviors in movies or books, they may be tempted to imitate them. By censoring such content, libraries can protect children from being influenced in harmful ways and help them avoid making poor decisions.  Parents often worry about the content their children are exposed to, especially when it comes to illegal or inappropriate behavior depicted in movies or books. Censorship in libraries can ease some of this parental stress by ensuring that children are not exposed to content that may encourage them to engage in illegal activities or harmful behaviors.  Additionally, offensive movies can have a detrimental impact on children, their parents, and society as a whole. By censoring offensive material in libraries, unnecessary hate and negativity can be avoided. Children should not have to endure bullying or discrimination because of the content they are exposed to, and censorship can help prevent such situations.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries is essential to protect children, support parents, and promote a positive and safe environment for all. By implementing censorship measures, libraries can help guide children towards making better choices, alleviate parental worries, and prevent exposure to harmful and offensive content.

People from all over the world have many different opinions. If someone doesn't like something, they do have the choice of not looking at it. Therefore, I believe that when you find something offensive in a library, it should not be removed.  One main reason why I feel that offensive materials should not be taken out of libraries is because not everyone may find the book, movie, magazine, or music offensive. People have their own opinions on everything, and if someone removes a certain item because they find it objectionable, others may miss out on something they enjoy.  Additionally, some individuals may become upset if offensive materials are continually removed from the library. Many people appreciate having access to a variety of materials, even if they may be considered offensive by some. Removing these items could lead to frustration and limitations on what individuals can access.  In my opinion, a certain amount of offensiveness can add humor and interest to books and other media. Just because something may seem inappropriate or rude does not mean it lacks value. Sometimes, controversial or offensive content can add depth and complexity to a work.  While some offensive materials may seem inappropriate to some, if they are available in the library, it indicates that they have some merit and should not be removed just because one person finds them objectionable. Everyone has their own unique perspectives, and it is essential to respect the diversity of opinions present in society.  In conclusion, I believe that offensive materials should not be removed from libraries as they provide valuable insights, perspectives, and entertainment for a wide range of individuals. It is important to recognize and respect the differing opinions and preferences of others when it comes to accessing and engaging with various forms of media available in library collections.

There are numerous books and movies which are deemed not appropriate for younger audiences. By marking movies with a rating, and marking books with a specific age group, it helps categorize them. In our public libraries, all books and movies are settled into one place for everyone to have the ability to check out. There is the ongoing discussion on whether these should be available to everyone. If a child were to check out a book, and it happened to be rated @CAPS1, the parents would most likely become upset with the library for giving the right to the child to check out a rated @CAPS1 movie. There is also the instance where a parent would have the child check out a specific movie with a @CAPS1 rating. In which the library would be harassed for not letting the child check it out. Furthermore, should public libraries let certain age groups check out movies/books which are not appropriate? The logical answer concludes to no, they shouldn't. If a child can not see a rated @CAPS1 movie at the theatre, why should they be able to check them out freely at the library? Public libraries should invest in a way to keep underage kids from checking out inappropriate materials. By simply having their age on their library card, there would be a lot of misunderstandings taken care of. Our public libraries should take it into their own hands, by changing their censorship. It would give them a better name, and give our children a secure place to gain access to these materials.

Wouldn't it be nice to walk into a library and be able to find any sort of book possible? I believe that it would be very useful and helpful for many libraries to allow a varied censorship of books. In my opinion it would be beneficial to students, parents, or teachers to get information on different topics. As well as many students who need to write a paper about a certain topic that they may not be familiar with, and allowing all types of books would help anybody with any topic.  A library is a place where anyone can go to find information on something, find an interesting read, or just relax. If you're going to get information on a topic that you know nothing about, it would be nice to find a book telling all about the topic. This would help students with reports, along with any other person who is trying to find some extra information they might not know about a topic.  If a person does not want certain types of books in the library, then I think that person should just try to ignore the books. I think this because I don't believe books should be taken out that are beneficial to others just because they are offensive to someone who could simply ignore them.  Maybe the books are about drugs, sex, or violence, but they still are able to teach many people who are not already knowledgeable about inappropriate or offensive topics.  In conclusion, throwing books out and keeping a library censored would be a mistake. It is a mistake because it takes away from many people who want to become knowledgeable about different topics. It takes away from people who need to learn about topics for things such as school or work.

No, books should not be banned from libraries just because some people find them offensive. Banning books only limits access to information and restricts the freedom to read and explore different perspectives. Instead of banning books, individuals can choose not to read them if they find them objectionable. Additionally, banning books can often lead to unnecessary drama and conflicts. It is important to remember that what may be offensive to one person may not be offensive to another. Therefore, it is crucial to respect diverse opinions and allow individuals to make their own choices when it comes to reading materials. In conclusion, banning books is not the solution to addressing offensive content, and it is essential to uphold the principles of freedom of expression and intellectual freedom in libraries.

In libraries, there are certain materials on the shelves that may be offensive to some people. While some may find these materials offensive, others may not. It all depends on the individual's perspective. Libraries cannot cater to everyone's preferences, but that should not mean removing these materials from the shelves.  Taking offensive materials off the shelves deprives others who may enjoy or benefit from them. Instead, a possible solution could be to place these materials on taller shelves or in a separate room so that individuals who find them offensive can avoid them, while those who do not mind can access them freely. This way, both sides have a say in the matter, leading to a fair compromise.  If segregating the materials does not suffice, libraries could consider replacing the highly offensive materials with more suitable alternatives that cater to a wider audience. By finding a balance between accommodating different preferences, libraries can ensure that all patrons feel respected and considered.  In conclusion, libraries should not remove offensive materials from their shelves. By implementing solutions that consider the concerns of both those who find the materials offensive and those who do not, libraries can maintain a diverse collection that serves the needs and interests of a broad spectrum of individuals.

Yes, I do think that if material in a library is offensive, it should be removed from the shelves. A library is a place for people to learn and grow, and it should be a safe and welcoming environment for all individuals, especially children. If something is deemed inappropriate or offensive, it has the potential to hinder the educational experience and overall satisfaction of library visitors. Therefore, it is important to ensure that the library maintains a positive and enriching atmosphere by removing offensive material. In conclusion, the primary goal of a library should be to promote learning and development, and this can best be achieved by ensuring that its collection is suitable and respectful to all patrons.

Should materials in libraries be censored? No, I don't think that materials in libraries should be censored or taken off the shelf. People should have the right to access whatever they want from the library, and if something is offensive to someone, they can simply choose not to look at it. While it is important to consider the appropriateness of materials for children, libraries typically have policies in place to prevent minors from accessing inappropriate content. In general, libraries aim to provide a wide range of materials to cater to diverse interests and preferences. Removing items from the shelves based on individual complaints of offensiveness could limit access to valuable resources for others. Therefore, unless something is widely deemed as highly offensive, it should not be censored in libraries.

I believe that if there is a book in a library that a child is not allowed to read, the book should be stored in a section where children cannot access it. Similarly, in stores, magazines with inappropriate content should be placed in an area inaccessible to children. Music and movies with explicit material should also be kept separate from items suitable for younger audiences. It is important to restrict children's access to such content to prevent them from being exposed to inappropriate material and potentially imitating it. By implementing these measures, we can help ensure that children are only exposed to age-appropriate content.

We should not have the right to remove materials from shelves if we find them offensive. Doing so would limit access to important information and perspectives for future generations. Even if a book, movie, or magazine contains content that some may find offensive, it is crucial to preserve these materials as a reference for historical events and societal attitudes. Allowing individuals to remove materials based on personal preferences or sensitivities could lead to the censorship of valuable content. It is important to respect diverse viewpoints and preserve a wide range of materials for the benefit of society as a whole. Therefore, the right to remove materials from shelves based on individual offense should not be granted.

Removing certain materials from the shelves of libraries is not the way to go. No matter how offensive they might be, there are many other ways to solve this problem. I believe that certain materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not be removed from libraries for being too offensive.  First off, many people have different opinions about what is offensive and what is not. For example, many people have different interests than others. Some people like certain kinds of books and movies while others do not. Everyone is going to have their own preference on what they want to read, listen to, or watch. Why would you take things away that people actually enjoy? There are other ways to solve this problem.  I believe that we can solve this problem by just separating certain materials from others in the library. For example, if something is thought to be offensive, then it can be placed with others like it. These materials do not have to be removed completely. Mothers are often worried about their children picking up things in the library that they think are offensive. If these materials are separated from others, there will not be a problem. Certain materials do not have to be removed completely from a library.  All in all, there is no need to remove materials from a library because many people have different interests. In conclusion, I believe that materials should not be removed from libraries for being too offensive.

I'm really sick and my head really hurts at this moment while having to write this paper, so please take it easy on me. Any source of literature is someone's own creation of imagination, taken in whatever direction they so choose for it to be taken. The creation of that art form as writing would be nothing less than lonesome trash floating the winding streets if it were censored.  It is almost like when watching television; your kids are up and want to stay up late to watch the new horror movie but no way, that movie is way too scary for them, plus it shows some nudity. If the movie is not appropriate for your children then do not let them watch it. In a library though, your mother might not always be there to pre-read your books for you. So maybe you just have to assume responsibility and read the book if you choose to, or not read the book depending on how your mother would feel about it of course.  The thought of there being censorship in libraries is quite ridiculous. Of course I would not like to see explicit content in my children's section but that is all up to just having books in their right sections. Have the explicit books on one side of the library and the non on the other side. The main point is that most people that make use of the library are old enough to choose a book of their liking and if they are not they have their mother accompanying them.   In conclusion, censorship in libraries restricts the freedom of choice and access to diverse literary works. It is essential for individuals to have the autonomy to decide what they want to read, while also ensuring appropriate categorization of materials for different age groups. Censorship should not hinder the exploration of ideas and creativity within the realm of literature.

There are many different types of books, music, movies, magazines, etc., that fill the shelves of libraries and stores across the country. Consumers are constantly taking these items off the shelves without realizing what they are really buying. Some parents may not even realize what their teenagers or little children are actually buying. Some of the material may be offensive and have a bad influence on those who buy into them. But if parents were more careful about what their children buy, then there would not be a problem. That is why these materials should remain on the shelves.  One vital reason these items should not be taken away is because it is the consumer's choice on whether or not they want to buy or check out these items. People should be able to decide for themselves on what they will or will not buy. If they do not want to buy or check these materials out, then they should just go to another shelf or shop at another store. I have seen some parents who do not really care what their children buy, and I have also seen parents go the other way. If stores take away these items, then it is almost like taking away their right to make a choice.  It is the adult's responsibility if they do not want their children to watch movies that are for mature viewers. The parent should be able to prohibit certain things until their child is old enough to make its own decisions. If they trust their children with these materials, then that is their choice. These offensive items cannot just be taken off the shelves just because some people are bothered by them. With the way the media works, it would be difficult to remove all these items from libraries and stores. No matter what, there will probably always be a way for younger children to be exposed to these materials. On television, there are always commercials that will attract kids or teens and influence them to buy their stuff. I have also seen music videos and magazines with their favorite celebrities on the covers. It is almost impossible to control every aspect of society to make it appropriate for younger viewers.  If all the people were able to take all the items that they did not approve of off the shelves, then there would be many of these shelves left empty and bare. If everyone were to take a book they did not like off the shelf, then there would be a little selection at the libraries. By taking off one of these books, someone could be taking off another person's favorite book. People cannot just take books off the shelves because they have some bad language. There is a reason for separating the children's section from the adult's section, and it is because some books might not be appropriate for all readers. From my personal experience, I have not seen any problems with kids checking out offensive books. Most little kids are attracted to the children's section because of the colorful pages and simpler words.  There is a variety of materials available to the public that may be offensive to some, especially to their little children. As a parent, it is their responsibility to keep track of what their children are being shown. People cannot take materials off the shelves because it is only offensive to some. This would not be fair to those who enjoy these kinds of materials. If they do not want to buy it, then they should simply move on to another shelf or to a completely different store. It is their choice as the consumer on whether or not they want to buy into the many different types of books, music, movies, magazines, etc.

I believe that if you are at a library or movie store, or wherever there are books, movies, magazines, or CDs that you find offensive, they should most likely be taken off the shelf. Have you ever walked into a store and seen something inappropriate for little kids, feeling embarrassed yourself? I know I have at least once in my life. That's why I think it should be removed from the store or at least the shelves.  I always consider how my grandparents would feel if they knew what kind of music most teens are listening to today. There is so much terrible language and talk about violence and bad things that really isn't suitable for anyone to hear or discuss. Some people may have different opinions on this matter, and some may take it too seriously, but it's essential to remember that everyone has their own perspective.

Dear @CAPS1 paper, I do believe that there are valid points on both sides of the debate regarding whether certain books should be removed from library shelves. On one hand, it is important to consider the presence of underage children in libraries and the potential for certain books to be offensive to some individuals. However, libraries are meant to provide a diverse range of reading materials for the public, and censoring certain books could limit access to important perspectives and ideas. It is essential to strike a balance between protecting individuals from harmful content and upholding the principles of intellectual freedom and diversity. Ultimately, it is crucial for individuals to consider different viewpoints and respect the rights of others when it comes to the selection of books in libraries.

When it comes to censorship in libraries, there is a growing concern about the content that is available on shelves. Many believe that there are books, movies, music, and magazines with inappropriate language and imagery that should not be easily accessible to all library visitors, especially children. Some argue that these materials should be removed or restricted in some way to protect young audiences from potentially harmful content. On the other hand, there are those who believe in the freedom of expression and access to information, even if it means having controversial or explicit material in libraries.  It is important to find a balance between freedom of expression and protecting individuals, particularly children, from content that may not be suitable for them. Perhaps having a separate section or store for such materials could be a potential solution. This way, those who are interested in accessing these materials can do so, while others who prefer to avoid them can easily do that as well. Ultimately, the discussion on censorship in libraries is complex and nuanced, with differing opinions on what should be allowed on shelves. Finding a middle ground that respects both freedom of expression and individual preferences is key to addressing this ongoing issue.

Censorship in libraries, especially in schools, remains a contentious issue. The restriction of certain books due to their content, such as violence or language, deprives students of valuable educational resources. By limiting access to these materials, students are denied the opportunity to explore diverse perspectives and engage with challenging subject matter.  It is crucial to recognize that what may be deemed inappropriate for some individuals does not necessarily apply to everyone. Banning books based on subjective interpretations of what is deemed offensive only serves to hinder intellectual growth and critical thinking. Students should have the freedom to choose their reading materials, even if they may contain controversial themes.  Books have the power to inspire, provoke thought, and spark meaningful discussions. By censoring literature, we risk stifling creativity and limiting the potential for personal growth and empathy. Everyone deserves the right to access a wide range of reading materials that reflect the complexities of the world around them.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries, especially in educational settings, is a hindrance to intellectual freedom and personal development. It is essential to uphold the principles of free expression and allow individuals to make their own choices regarding what they read. By promoting open access to diverse literary works, we foster a culture of curiosity, critical thinking, and empathy. Let us embrace the power of literature to enlighten and enrich our lives without unnecessary restrictions.

I think certain materials should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive because the word is just saying 'OFFENSIVE', or those things should be placed where not everybody can get it, like the little kids or when your religion doesn't accept that kind of things. In @DATE1's world, there are numerous materials surrounding children that may not be suitable for their consumption. While many adults express concerns about the changes in the world compared to their own childhoods, it is essential to take action rather than simply complain. Adults can play a significant role in controlling the amount of inappropriate materials children are exposed to. It is common to find questionable content in stores, such as movies and music with negative themes like drugs and parties. These materials can have a detrimental impact on young minds and should be restricted from children's access as much as possible.   Although it may not be possible to completely remove all unsuitable materials from the shelves, efforts can be made to limit children's exposure to such content. By safeguarding children from harmful materials, we are nurturing a healthier and more positive future generation. There are many books, music, movies, and magazines that people find offensive. Some people even believe these things should be taken off the shelves. I do not believe that the books, music, movies, or magazines should be taken off the shelves completely. Not everyone finds these things offensive and they should not be taken off the shelves because a few people do not agree with them.  First, people have different views on what they find offensive. Not everyone will find the same things offensive or want the same books or song to be removed. With people always having different views it is difficult to take books, music, movies, or magazines off the shelves for everyone. Just because one person does not agree with what is being said in the movie or book does not mean that every single person wants that movie or book to be removed. If one person found my favorite book offensive I would not want it taken off the shelves completely.  Equally important, if every book, song, movie, and magazine that someone finds offensive is taken off the shelve there would not be many books, movies, songs, or magazines left. Author Katherine Paterson once said, 'But if I have the right to remove a book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' @CAPS1 is saying that if every single book that offends someone is taken off the shelves there would be no books for anyone to read. People find different things offensive and if everyone took these things off the shelves there would be none left for anyone.  Finally, if someone finds a book offensive they do not have to read it. When someone finds a book, movie, song, or magazine offensive they don't need to watch it or read it. Instead of taking it off the shelves the person could just not read it. Not everyone finds the same books offensive and taking them off the shelves could upset many people. When someone finds something offensive they could just avoid that instead of getting it removed and upsetting other people. If someone was offened by one of my favorite books, I would prefere if they just avoid reading it instead if taking it off the shelves so that I can not read it.  Some people find many books, songs, movies, and magazines offensive. They would like these things to be removed from the shelves permenatly. I, however, do not believe that these things should be removed. Taking these off the shelves could make some people happy, it could also upset even more. Not everyone finds the same things offensive and should not be taken off the shelves because a few people do not agree with them.

Imagine walking out of your home and you see right down the street a giant bonfire, right in the open. You see men walking into a library empty-handed and walk out carrying armfuls of books, magazines, movies, and other media. The men then toss them into the raging inferno, and you see them become incinerated, lost forever. This is what will happen if we let censorship of our libraries take place. We should not let censorship of our libraries take place since it violates a constitutional right, will gradually make our society more and more ignorant, and will let this nation slide from a democratic nation to one where the beliefs and ideals of the people are controlled by a small group of people.  Letting censorship of our libraries take place will violate a basic constitutional right, plain and simple. In the United States Constitution, it clearly says that there will be freedom of the press. By tossing out certain literary works, this right will be thrown to the side, and by violating one constitutional right, what will come next? Will our freedom of speech be negated, or our freedom to assemble? As citizens of the United States, we cannot let this happen to our great nation.  By allowing certain books and essays to be thrown out of our libraries, the people's knowledge base will eventually shrink down drastically. For example, take Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, a very sensitive subject among people of the Christian faith. If all of his works regarding that were to be thrown out, much information that was very valuable to biologists would be lost, and those biologists would not be able to improve upon the existing pool of information. If this were to take place, our civilization would experience a lessening intellect and an expanding ignorance regarding many fields of knowledge.  Picture Germany in the 1940s. Hitler's Nazi Party has taken power and is systematically destroying all materials they find to be subversive to the Nazi cause, only allowing materials that contained beliefs and ideals that they thought were correct to exist in libraries. This is exactly what we would be doing if we allowed censorship of our libraries to take place. The censoring of the libraries would be controlled by a relatively small group of people, which means that the censoring would be controlled by those same people's beliefs and ideals, and those same beliefs and ideals would thus be forced upon the people, shaping the beliefs and ideals of the masses to those select few.  In conclusion, letting censorship take place in our public libraries will dismantle the basic structure of our society by violating a constitutional right, making our society gradually become more and more ignorant, and letting the beliefs and ideals of our people rest in the hands of a select few. This is not what our founding fathers envisioned America to become, and they were right. Letting censorship exist in our public libraries is simply wrong.

Everyone has things that would offend them, whether they admit it or not. Books are known to do this to people. However, there are all different kinds of books, music, and all the other materials that could offend all different kinds of people. There are even books read in school classrooms that offend people. Reading is an important thing and whether or not the reader likes it, they will come across one that offends them. I believe we have the right to have those offending things because there are so many books who offend people, music and movies have censorship, and if they don't like it they should ignore it.  First of all, we have the right to have these kinds of books. Just like in life, there are certain things people don't like, but deal with it anyway. That's what this is. Even though there are the handful out there that don't like those certain books, those books are the ones that are well liked and become famous. To sum that all up, if we took away every book that one person didn't like, there would be only few left.  Secondly, music and movies have censorship. If they don't want it they don't have to listen to it or watch it. We all have the certain things we love and hate, we can't eliminate all of the hated things.  Last of all, in my opinion if they don't want it they don't have to have it. The music and movies are an option to people, they don't have to listen or watch something they think is a bad idea. It's all opinionated, there isn't a right or wrong to it. I know of people out there who don't have @CAPS1's or they don't listen to the radio, that's perfectly fine. They don't have to complain about because they don't pay any attention to it.  To wrap this all up, there are so many books out in the world that offend people, the music and movies have censorship, and if they can't stand it they don't have to deal with it. As I said, these books, magazines, music, etc. are very well liked by many of people, so why get rid of them for those few who get offended? And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.'

There I was, shuffling my way through the library, finding the perfect books to check out. It was then that I had stumbled upon a book that looked incredibly interesting. The cover page featured a depressed girl with the look of hope plastered on her face and the back included the summary of a book I wanted to get my hands on. The book, titled @CAPS1, was about a girl who went through some troubled times but found her way out of it. Stories, novels, magazines, or books on tape of any type find their way onto our library shelves, it is then our job to discover them. Whether literature includes stories of love and breakbreak, sorrow and depression, or the success of a sports team, it should all be allowed on our library shelves.  Opinion, everyone has one that conflicts with someone else's. Our world revolves around these different viewpoints and ideas, should our literature and music not reflect these opposing sides? Literature is an escape for many people, it is their way of experiencing the world and to live through the main character of whatever they are reading. If we remove books that @MONTH1 be offensive to one, we are taking away that opportunity for others. In my opinion, the removal of the potentially offensive material in our libraries, is sheltering our world.  Regardless of how hard we try, children and teenagers will one day be exposed to the offensive material we are attempting to remove from their lives. We should not attempt to hide what our actual world is like, rather allow them to experience it in a safe way, like reading or listening to music. If someone views material as offensive, it should be the parent's responsibility to regulate whether their child reads or listen to it or not. The removal of the potentially offensive material would not be any help.  In conclusion, offensive material should not be removed from our libraries, rather regulated through our parents or elders. The idea of regulating what is on our shelves is not the most effective. If any material has the potential of being offensive, it is not the library's role to regulate whether or not it is displayed to the public.

The censorship in a library should be kept the same as it is already. A few reasons explain why the censorship is alright as it is. Those reasons are that parents should be in charge of the books their children read, that not all people agree on censorship, and that libraries have books of different subjects that people like to read. The first reason is that parents should be in charge of what their children read. If the parents would just tell their children no to a certain book, then the child will not read it. If the parent does not want their child to go into a section then, the parents can just say keep away from that area. Although, sometimes the child may stray away from its parents, it is not very likely that the parent will not notice. That is why the parents should be in charge of what their children read. The second reason is that not all people agree on censorship. Certain people think that religion is important no matter what the book shows, but others would think parts of religious book (nudity, swears, etc...) is extremely inappropriate. Some people would say that books like mythology books are inappropriate and need to be censored, although others think these books are past culture and that they should remain in the libraries forever. Most children will look at these books and think that the books are too big to read, so they would not even look at them. Few people would agree on censorship, and a lot of people would disagree. The third reason is that libraries have different subjects than the inappropriate books. The people can look at a different book and completely ignore the others. It is not like a child will go up to the dirtiest book they can find and say I want to read that one. the child will probably want something that relates to a television show or a movie of some sort. The point being that a person can read other books than just inappropriate books. Library books should be kept the same because the parents should be in charge of what their children read, not all people agree on censorship, and libraries have different subjects that people want to read. The censorship should be fine according to some people other would disagree. The children probably would not look at the inappropriate book anyways, because they would not interest the child.

So you see a nice, old lady looking at one of many books through a library, she chucks it. You look at her, she looks at you, she walks away. Two, if you have a library card, you can check out books, movies, music, etc. Three, if you're walking down the road and 'gotta go,' you can stop right in and leave.  What I'm trying to say is that nothing should be removed from any shelf at any library. I think that if you take something off the shelf at a library, you are just taking away part of the heart. Let's say you have 3 libraries in your town, one library has one thing the other doesn't have. Someone riots and they get to take it off the shelf. You're never going to find that anywhere else unless you buy it online. And sometimes, that can get a little pricey, especially since you can get it free at a library.  But then again, I see where people are coming from to take certain materials off the shelves. Say you have a 2-year old kid, and he walks up to you carrying a sex love book. What can you say about that? Most parents just want to keep their kids in a safe, harmless environment. That's where they come in and say, 'I thought this was a library?!' Then that's where it goes bad.  After all that happens, people just accuse the librarians that they got these books, movies, and music that's just bad for a young kid. But it's not the librarians' fault, different people like different books, that's why a library has many choices when it comes to books.  That's when the question comes up, 'why don't we just have separate rooms, for separate books?' Yes, that sounds good and all, but who's gonna pay for it? Libraries get donated a lot of their stuff, they are profitable, but then again a non-profitable resource. Libraries have been around for ages, most of them started out small and now are big. That's when the library gets donations, looks through them, and sells the books they don't want or need. They make money off that, that's when they start making separate rooms.  It sounds crazy, but it wouldn't cause a riot to go on about people. Therefore, people are happy, librarians happy, and most of all you are happy. You can find the book you want or need easy as one, two, three. All you gotta do is go to that certain room, look for it, check it out and you got a nice book to be reading anytime. It sounds easier than looking it up, get the dewey decimal number, find the number.  All in all, we shouldn't remove anything from a library shelf because it may be the only one in your town, maybe the only one in your state, maybe through the whole country. You never know. All I gotta say is, it's better to keep a book, than to forget a book.

Maybe, to a certain extent, I do not believe that books should be removed from shelves. While some books and magazines may contain offensive content, there is also a great deal of informative material that can be valuable for learning and understanding different perspectives. It is important to consider that what may be offensive to one person may not be offensive to another, and removing all potentially offensive material could limit the opportunity for learning and growth. Additionally, music and other forms of media should not be censored or removed, as they provide enjoyment and relaxation for many people. It is essential to recognize the changing generations and evolving societal norms, while also preserving the freedom of expression and access to diverse viewpoints. In conclusion, while it is important to address offensive content and its impact on individuals, complete removal of books and media may not be the most effective solution, as it could hinder learning, creativity, and the expression of different voices.

In my opinion, all types of material should be allowed in libraries. If someone takes offense to a particular topic or section, they don't have to read it. Libraries should cater to a person's desires and interests to keep them engaged. Variety is key in attracting a diverse range of visitors. While there should be a line of respect in place, allowing for different viewpoints and genres ensures that there is something for everyone. People should have the freedom to choose what they want to read and explore. The library is a place for learning and discovery, and having a wide range of materials available only enhances the experience for all visitors.

I do not believe things should be removed from shelves in libraries if they offend someone. Just because it is offensive to one person doesn't mean it's offensive to all. If you are offended by something they display, there are ways that you can avoid seeing them. One thing you can do to avoid it is never go by or around the shelves displaying it, ask for help so you get whatever it is that you need, or try to search what you're looking for on the internet.  When I visit the library, I already know what I'm going to get, so I have never found anything offensive to me. If I did find something offensive to me, I would complain, and if they didn't do anything about it, I would just never go back. I would just research online or go to another library where I know they will meet my needs.  The libraries I go to always have sections separating the different age groups. The sections are split into children, teens, and adults. I've been to the library numerous times, and I have never heard anyone with a complaint about something being offensive. If the library had something that would offend me, I wouldn't know. Every time I go, I stay in one particular section for teens and look at magazines and books.  I feel that if people are offended by what they see on the shelves, they should just avoid or ignore it because everyone has their own opinion on what offends them and what doesn't. In the end, it's important to respect the diversity of perspectives and opinions that make up our society.

I think we should not take it off the shelf because what may be offensive to you may not be offensive to me. Something that is fun or beneficial to me may not be the same for you. If something is offensive to someone, they should simply walk away or choose not to pay attention to it. Everyone has their own perspectives and sensitivities, so it is important to consider that what may be acceptable to one person may not be to another. It's essential to respect each other's differences and make choices based on personal preferences without imposing them on others.

I believe the current way materials are censored and removed works, and should continue. While everyone may dislike a particular novel or book, libraries cannot remove every book a person dislikes, as Katherine Paterson said. When a book appears so controversial to the point where the majority of people disapprove of it, then the book usually is taken off of the shelves.  The possibility children will see the offensive material appears unlikely. Most public libraries do not put their offensive material near the children's books. At my local library, there is a section that has the more offensive or obscene books all in one place. To acquire these books you must have a parent's permission or be a certain age. It is very unlikely a child would ever see the materials in question.  Numerous people who find the materials offensive must also remember the time and place the story originated. Books like To Kill a Mockingbird have had racial slurs in it, but if one considers the time and place of the novel, these slurs were normal for the time. Someone cannot be frustrated with a novel written years ago because it has something offensive in it by today's standards.  While I believe, for the most part, libraries should not censor or remove materials, there should be some restrictions set in place to keep extremely harmful materials out of libraries. For instance, libraries should not have dirty magazines or movies on their shelves. If a high majority of people want a particular material banned, then it is hard to ignore them. When a book is so vulgar people begin to protest the book, there are questions as to whether the book should remain on library shelves. When a high percentage of people join that cause, then it should be banned.  Censoring or removing materials from libraries remains a hot topic today. I believe the current system in place to censor or remove books does its job, and that it should continue. If few people disapprove of a particular material, the book remains on most shelves uncensored. When a lot of people begin to protest that same material, it has a high probability of being banned. With this process, every book with a racial slur or questionable scene is not removed, while the ones that truly deserve it are removed. Therefore, the current approach to censorship and removal of materials in libraries is effective and should be maintained.

When considering which books should be banned or restricted in a library, it is important to take into account the content of the material. Books that contain explicit sexual content, graphic violence, racism, or sexism may be considered for removal or placement in a separate section for adult readers. However, it is crucial to ensure that the process of banning books is not arbitrary and involves input from a diverse group of stakeholders, including educators, parents, and librarians. By having a comprehensive discussion and evaluation of the reasons for banning a book, the community can ensure that censorship is done thoughtfully and with consideration for the diversity of readers' preferences and sensitivities.

Censorship in libraries is a topic that sparks various debates. Some argue that movies, magazines, and books should be available for all to access, including children, as it is essential for them to learn about the world around them. They believe that exposure to different content at a young age can better prepare individuals for the complexities of adulthood. While some may argue that certain materials are inappropriate for young audiences, others maintain that early exposure can lead to a more informed and educated society. Ultimately, the decision to allow access to a wide range of materials in libraries can have a significant impact on the knowledge and development of individuals, particularly the youth.

I believe that it is important not to remove materials such as books, movies, or music just because a few individuals do not like the content. Everyone has different preferences and what may be offensive to one person may be enjoyable to another. Instead of trying to censor everything, individuals should take responsibility for what they and their children are exposed to. Setting boundaries and having open discussions about media consumption is more effective than trying to ban certain materials. People should have the freedom to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to, without the fear of censorship. It is essential to respect diverse opinions and allow for a variety of content to be available to cater to different tastes and interests.

Censorship; the aspect of removing offensive materials from the public eye. Is this the right thing to do? Should society as a whole take away variety? Do you believe our generation or future generations should not get to experience and understand what the past generations have? I believe censorship is wrong in every aspect, but I also believe that materials that are offensive, or inappropriate for certain ages can be controlled.  Movie theaters, video stores, @ORGANIZATION1, and television all do it. They use ratings and age control for their viewers. Now control can be difficult, and @MONTH1 not always work if not handled correctly. To handle this situation before it arises, the library can use a system like restaurants or bars use; such as, checking identification before letting a book that is '@CAPS1' rated or above be checked out. Different sections in the library can be available to certain age groups. Now you @MONTH1 be thinking; doesn't this idea take away from the liberties that libraries give us? Well, you would rather have our children see violence and other inappropriate materials that they shouldn't? It would be just like the movie theater. You would not need to buy a ticket, but the control of content would be phenomenal compared to what it is. Would you want your six-year-old girl picking up an adult violence movie, sexual content movies, or even a @CAPS2 with cursing in it? Why should the library offer things for children that parents would frown upon?  I believe the library should be a place of learning and freedom, but the learning should be something age-appropriate. Our society is maturing too fast for young children, why should the library take part in that? Libraries located in schools do not even offer this material because they know that the majority of the readers for their library are students. This being said why should public libraries be okay with stocking this material?  Yes, media is everywhere. Movies, books, magazines, newspapers, music, and much more flash and sell more than they should. Media shows children things they shouldn't know about until they are young adults, but does this make it okay? Does it make is right for children to see and want all they want to? No, it does not. Fighting fire with fire only makes a larger fire. Why start our children out at a young age with violence, sex, and inappropriate material? Would you like to set your children up to fail? I know I wouldn't so why let our libraries hand out books, magazines, movies, and more to let our children thrive upon the culture they are stuck with? I do not think we should remove these books from our libraries because everyone has a different opinion, but I do believe that control needs to be put into place for our children's and other children's sakes. With that being said, censorship is overrated, but some of the material at the library is underrated, and that needs to be handled and controlled.  In conclusion, while censorship may be seen as limiting freedom of expression, there is a need for age-appropriate control in libraries to protect children from exposure to harmful or inappropriate content. It is important to strike a balance between freedom of access and responsible content management to ensure a positive and safe learning environment for all library users.

Everyone has a favorite book. And some of us can't put it down once we read the first sentence. Then days later, the library takes it down and states that it's offensive to many people that have read it. Why should multiple people lose a good read just because someone doesn't like what they see? We're all trying to accommodate to everyone and their needs just to please them. Whatever they ask is done because we don't want a big scene. A majority of people think, 'That book is offensive! Take it down! Disgusting!'. But why?   Everyone has a right to read what they want to read. No library should uphold to the needs of a minority about an 'offensive' book just because they say it's inappropriate. Who are we to judge what's good for everyone and what's not? Books are written for a reason, and that's to share the ideas of the author, not to corrupt society with their 'evil' and 'offensive' ideas that could potentially cause a child to rebel. That excuse is ridiculous. A parent should've taught their child to differentiate between right and wrong, and if they use the 'child will become a rebel if they read this!' excuse, then they're not confident in their child's capability, or the fact that they taught their child well.   Also, it's not just the readers getting angry, it's the author. How bad would someone feel if they spent a year or two on a fantastic book, just to have it banned from library after library? Probably angry or upset. Authors have the right to write whatever they want. If they wish to talk about dragons and princesses, so be it. If they want to discuss why we see a full moon when we do? Go right ahead. No one can stop great books from being made and they certainly shouldn't be able to stop people from reading it. If someone is offended by a book, then don't read it, simple as that.   Parents like to protect their children from harm's way and bring them up as fine citizens of society. By having this desire, the parents do every little thing to make sure their son or daughter doesn't see, hear, or read anything inappropriate or 'bad'. This is just ridiculous. Controlling a child's life will just cause them to rebel more and more as they get older. Let children have a choice in what book they read, or the movie they watch. Parents need to teach their children right from wrong, and in doing so, letting them see, hear, or read whatever they want should be no problem.   Without books, movies, and music, what would the world be like today? No one knows. Books are a great source of information, letting the author express themself as well. Movies are almost just as harmless, limits are needed, but overall? There should be no problem. Also, music allows the artist to bring out their side of creativity and emotion. Allowing that music, or movie, or book to be made, and then take it away is ridiculous. If it offends someone, then that person should just forget it, instead of taking it away from the people who love it and the person who made it.   In conclusion, the freedom to choose what to read, watch, or listen to is a fundamental right that should not be compromised. It is essential to respect the creative expression of authors, filmmakers, and musicians, and not let personal opinions dictate what others can access. Let individuals make their own choices and exercise their own judgment when it comes to consuming media, rather than imposing restrictions based on subjective views of offensiveness.

I don't believe in censorship when it comes to books and music. Just because one person finds something offensive doesn't mean it should be removed for everyone else. People have different opinions and what one person may find offensive, another may not. Music is often the target of censorship, but I think this is detrimental to the art form. It's an artist's way of expressing themselves, and if someone doesn't like it, they can simply choose not to listen. The same goes for books; they are a writer's expression and should be allowed to exist without censorship. It's important to respect different perspectives and allow for freedom of expression in all forms of art.

Why should they take them off the shelves? If you ask me, I think they should leave controversial materials up there. I do not think books should be censored from library shelves. Removing books that some people find offensive can actually help others see the errors in their ways and learn important life lessons. Libraries are places where individuals should have the freedom to choose any book they desire without facing any restrictions.
