Newspapers are interesting to read and might have little to none offensive remarks in them. Some might pertain to blacks or mexicans, something like that. Well I haven't read any like that yet but, I have heard somethings about it. In the newspapers there might be little comics or gags that would probably be more offensive than anything in the newspapers. I think that if you find something offensive then just ignore it and move on to something else instead of throwing a fit about it because that wouldn't do well at all.

There are so many things these days that people find offensive, in various forms of media such as magazines, books, movies, and the internet. Some individuals believe that they should have the right to remove these offensive materials from public access. One major concern for parents is the potential impact on their children if they were to come across such content. However, it is important for parents to monitor their children's exposure to these materials and have open discussions with them if they do encounter something inappropriate.  If everyone had the ability to remove content they found offensive, there would be little left for people to read, listen to, or watch. What one person finds enjoyable, another may find deeply offensive, leading to conflicts within communities. Furthermore, sheltering children from all controversial content could give them a false sense of the world being easy and problem-free. It is essential for children to learn about the complexities of the world through positive role models who can help them navigate media influences.  Allowing individuals to censor content based on personal offense could result in increased crime due to heightened anger, a lack of diverse media options, and confused children unsure of how to interpret the world around them. Instead of censoring, it is more effective to educate and guide individuals, especially children, on how to critically engage with media. By promoting understanding and critical thinking, we can create a more informed and responsible society.

At my point of view, I believe that if someone finds a particular material offensive, they should simply choose not to engage with it. It is unfair to restrict access to books, music, movies, magazines, or any other form of media just because one person finds it offensive. There are likely many others who would like to enjoy that material.   If something is offensive to multiple people, it should not be immediately banned. Instead, there should be a discussion or a vote to address the issue. It is important to consider the feelings and perspectives of everyone involved before making a decision that affects a larger group of people.   For example, if my family couldn't decide on a place to eat and one person didn't want pizza, we wouldn't go out to eat that night. It wouldn't be fair to make a decision based on the preferences of just one person when there are others to consider.   In conclusion, it is crucial to consider the broader impact before removing or restricting access to something just because one person finds it offensive. We must think about the rights and interests of everyone involved, and respect the efforts of creators who put their hard work into their craft.

The content of a library should be full of various material even if one may find certain materials offensive. Just because someone may think a material is offensive does that mean we just ignore the subject, forgetting it altogether? Some subjects may be awkward to talk about, read about, or even think about, but that doesn't mean we should ignore them.  One subject that may be awkward to read about is sexually transmitted diseases. You often see people walking through the library skimming through the aisles, once in a while opening a book to see what it's about, but when they come to the section on sexually transmitted diseases they just walk on by, too uncomfortable to be seen in the area. It's not a subject that people normally read for fun, but everyone should be aware of it. There are many subjects like this that everyone should be aware even if you think it doesn't affect you.  Another reason to keep all books in the library is to be informed of history. Some history may be gruesome and completely crazy, but we should be aware of those things and not forget about them. The Holocaust, for example, was a very dark period in history. Over six million people died because just one person didn't like what they believed in. It's sometimes hard to read about, but you should be aware of what happened in the past no matter how depressing it is. We should be aware to prevent another event like that from happening.  People's likes in music vary. There are so many different types and styles of music. Some music may be offensive to other people, but does that mean you should get rid of it at the library? The library should always have a large variety of different music. Often people would like to widen their music intellect, and the library is the perfect place to do that.  Everyone is different. We never all like the same thing. Taking materials from the library to avoid the subject doesn't stop someone from finding that information. If people wanted information and they couldn't find it at the library, they would most likely find another way to get that information. Having a variety in books, music, movies, and magazines makes the library a place to learn new things, no matter the subject. In conclusion, it is important to have a diverse range of materials in the library to ensure that individuals have the opportunity to learn and grow, even if they may find certain topics uncomfortable or offensive.

Your watching a movie on tv that you and your friend have seen in theatres. You both love the movie and just as it gets close to the best part, the tv skips over that part because people think that that scene is inappropriate. Censorship is good, but sometimes it is too strict when it comes to movies, music, and books.  Some of the movies that are popular will end up on tv for the viewers' entertainment, and some movies have scenes that are a little inappropriate. Even though it's not that offensive, the tv companies will cut that scene out of it. Also, if there is bad language in the movie, they will take that word out and replace it with another word that makes no sense with what the movie is trying to say. Censorship tends to ruin the movies that most people love. The tv companies even censor historical movies. If it's a historical movie, it shouldn't be censored because it takes away from the true story.  Music is another item that tends to get censored quite often. With music, if there is a bad word, the word is just skipped over or bleeped out which makes the song sound strange. Most songs are censored because parents don't want their children to listen to it. I don't think music should be censored just for little kids. If the parents don't want their children to hear those words, they shouldn't let their children listen to that kind of music.  Books tend to be censored and even banned at schools. Not too many children read books anymore so if they do decide to read a book, we should let them read what they want because reading helps the mind. Some schools banned books because of inappropriate language. That is unfair because some books are beautifully written, but children can't read them because of language. Also, some books are censored because they are too detailed when it comes to certain scenes dealing with sex and crime. Some books are just too good to be banned.  A lot of things seem to be censored in this world. We should have censorship, but it shouldn't be so strict when it comes to movies, music, and books. At the end of the day, censorship should aim to protect without overly restricting artistic expression and the freedom of choice for consumers.

The library is a valuable resource for individuals seeking a wide range of materials, from research papers to movies and books. While some may argue that certain materials are inappropriate for certain audiences, it is important to consider the educational value and personal choice involved. Censoring materials can limit access to important information and diverse perspectives. Instead of removing books or movies from library shelves, age-appropriate labels can be used to guide readers. Ultimately, individuals should have the freedom to choose what they read, allowing for personal growth and exploration.

There are thousands of books in libraries, some of which may be deemed inappropriate by certain individuals. However, all books serve a purpose in libraries, whether they are offensive or not. Books provide us with valuable knowledge about the past, help us expand our imagination through fiction, and ultimately make us more intelligent individuals.  Books that may be considered offensive, such as those discussing controversial topics, still have a purpose in educating us about historical events and preventing us from repeating past mistakes. Fiction books, on the other hand, play a crucial role in stimulating our creativity and empathy by allowing us to relate to the struggles of fictional characters.  Furthermore, all books contribute to our intellectual growth by offering a wealth of information on various subjects. Even books that some may find offensive can be essential in shaping the knowledge and skills of future professionals, such as doctors who need access to diverse perspectives to better understand their patients.  In conclusion, while opinions on what constitutes offensive material may vary, removing books from shelves simply because they are not suited for everyone is not the solution. Instead, we should embrace the diversity of literature and respect the freedom of individuals to choose what they want to read. By allowing all books to remain accessible in libraries, we ensure that everyone has the opportunity to learn and grow intellectually.

No, I do not believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. If you are reading, listening, or watching any of these things, then simply avoid the parts that offend you. It is your choice to engage with the content, so if something offends you, you can easily set it aside and move on. Removing such materials takes away the enjoyment and entertainment for those who do not find them offensive. It is important to consider the impact of censoring these forms of media on the freedom of expression and access to diverse perspectives. Let us preserve the variety of content available for all individuals to enjoy.

Libraries should not remove books simply because they are deemed offensive. While some may find certain books to be offensive, it is important to remember that everyone has different tastes and perspectives. What one person finds offensive, another may find enlightening or thought-provoking. It is not fair to censor literature based on individual opinions. Just as we have the freedom to choose what movies we watch or music we listen to, we should also have the freedom to choose what books we read. If a book is offensive to someone, they can simply choose not to read it rather than trying to have it removed for everyone else. It is important to respect the diversity of opinions and perspectives that exist in the world, and banning books is not the solution to addressing offensive content. Let books remain on library shelves for those who may find value in them, while allowing others to make their own choices about what they read.

I will be talking about, do think books, music, or even magazines should be removed from libraries if they are found offensive. In my opinion I don't think books, music, movies, or magazines should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive to some people. Because not all people have the same interests.  First of all I think things shouldn't be removed from library shelves because people don't like the items because they get offended. But the people who like the item say like an explicit movie they would probably buy it. But also the people who don't the explicit movie would get offended and would want it off the shelves.  Another example can be a book. What if a person didn't like what he/she read and gets offended. They would return the book and would not want to sell anymore and wouldn't mention it to a friend. But another person comes along and picks the same book and did like what he/she did read and that person would probably recommend it to a friend.  The same way goes for a magazine also. What if a person gets offended at an advertisement. A person likes it and returns it, then comes along another person who gets offended at it and doesn't like it it shouldn't stop selling for that particular person.  In conclusion I think things in the library shouldn't stop selling because one person gets offended at it. They shouldn't have looked at the item in the first place.

Books and magazines are valuable sources of information that provide insights into the past, present, and future. They offer a diverse range of content, including both positive and negative aspects of life. While some may argue against exposing children to certain topics, it is important to acknowledge that they will eventually encounter such information as they grow older. Schools play a crucial role in educating children about historical events, wars, and other important subjects that shape our world. Removing books from shelves would hinder access to valuable knowledge that authors have worked hard to share. It is essential to respect the effort and time put into creating these resources and to consider the implications of restricting access to information. Ultimately, books and magazines are essential tools for learning and understanding the world around us.

For as long as people can remember books have been banned for various reasons. Whether it be a time of war or a religious restriction, it is always viewed as a negative thing and therefore should be no different today. Though it may be a bit less extreme, books or content such as movies, music, or magazines should not be removed from library shelves based on someone else's opinion. It is a right to be able to obtain the information these materials offer. No material should ever be removed from a public library based on censorship.  Some may argue that certain material can be offensive to other groups of people, but who is it to judge how another feels. Material is written or made to show the feelings of the author and how they want their feelings or knowledge portrayed. The author is merely taking advantage of their freedom of speech. It is at the responsibility of the public to how they use the information they receive. It is still a piece of history and was recorded for a reason.  Religion is always a hot point when it comes to censorship, but is that not in our constitution. Freedom of religion includes how we interpret and study our religions. Most have holy books and writings. Many express their religion by means of music and culture. It is a right for the public to be able to access this material.  There are some rare situations when restrictions may need to be upheld but merely based on age. This however doesn't restrict the public, but offers parents the right to censor what information their children are able to get ahold of. An age limit on specific types of material could be added in the cases of sexual content, vulgar images, or disturbing content unsuitable for children. This way information is never censored completely.  It is never right to tell people what they can or cannot know. It is a part of the very structure of our country to allow all information to be shared freely. Censorship of these materials is not and never will be the answer. Although, age restrictions may be an answer for younger citizens these materials aren't taken away from the public. Whatever it may be called, book banning or censorship, it is a negative thing and should not be a part of our public library systems.

Should there be censorship in libraries? People think that there should be and some think it shouldn't matter. I think there shouldn't be because maybe some people like those books. I have three reasons why there shouldn't be censorship. My reasons are first people like certain books and should be able to get whatever they want. Second, the libraries should be able to put whatever they want on the shelves. Third, if you don't like what the books say then don't get the book.   Libraries have many books for you to choose from and you can pick which book you want to check out. Libraries don't need to censor their books because some people might want books like that. Everybody has their own preference on the kinds of books and music that they like. Censorship wouldn't allow them to get what they want which would make them mad. There are all kinds of genres of books and music around, some have more strong language in them than other genres. Some people like their music uncensored and should be able to get it. Libraries and entertainment stores are the ones who buy the books and music not you.   Libraries have the freedom to get whatever books they want and put them on shelves. If you don't like what certain books or music say then go get something you do like. There is no rule that says you have to get a certain kind of music. Some people like the music genre called rap which does have some strong language in it but it's your choice to listen to it. The stores just put the products on the shelf to make money not to get you angry about what the products say. There are sections on the shelves that say what genre they are.   People that want to say something about what the language is like in the book should not have checked it out. You have the right to ask what certain music, books, or movies are like, and movies have ratings on the case. Music and movies have ratings which tell you how strong the language is on the cases. People can not say to monitor that when it tells you everything that's in the movie or CD. The libraries and stores usually mark the sections on what genre they are. That can tell you where the uncensored parts are. You can stay away from those sections if you find them offensive.   The libraries should not have to censor their books and entertainment store should not need to censor all the music and movies. It's your choice what to get not theirs. People can stay away from those areas that they find offensive. Everybody should be able to get what they want even if it might offend others.

Have you ever watched a movie that had some scenes you didn't want your kids to watch with you? What are you supposed to do when this problem happens time and time again? Do you just tell your kids to close their eyes and cover their ears? Well, I honestly think that shouldn't ever have to happen to you.   I think that you as a parent or adult should be warned about certain behaviors during a movie that you do not approve your child of watching, even if it is with you. It's just flat out wrong, I would say. So, I say that we should get some kind of extra warning that these inappropriate behaviors are showing up in movies. Parents should be able to know what their kids are about to watch is okay for their age and whatnot.   So to wrap this all up nice and sweet, just make some kind of label that says that there might be things in the movies or whatever item such as books and magazines also, that there might be things that a parent will find inappropriate for a child to watch or read. If the people that make these products do this, it will be much easier for parents to do the right thing for their children.

I believe that libraries should stick to their traditional purpose of housing books rather than expanding to include movies and music. Introducing movies and music could potentially overshadow the importance of books and lead to a decline in reading habits. Books are a timeless and valuable form of expression that should be preserved in libraries. Movies and music have their place in theaters and stores, and introducing them into libraries may dilute the significance of literature. It is important to maintain the integrity of libraries as a place for books and literary works, without allowing other forms of media to overshadow their importance. Let's keep libraries focused on books, the cornerstone of knowledge and imagination.

Censorship is a topic that sparks debate on whether it is beneficial or harmful. One argument against censorship is that it can easily offend people, as individuals have varying levels of tolerance. While some may find humor in controversial content like political cartoons, others may feel hurt or upset by it. However, it is suggested that if something offends someone, they can simply choose not to engage with it.   On the other hand, there are instances where censorship may be necessary to prevent content from crossing a line. Some books and movies contain extremely offensive material that can be harmful or inappropriate for certain audiences. Establishing clear boundaries and regulations on what can be published or shared is essential to protect vulnerable individuals from being exposed to harmful content.  In conclusion, finding a balance between freedom of expression and protecting individuals from offensive or harmful material is crucial. Collaborative efforts to establish guidelines and standards for censorship can help ensure that content remains respectful and suitable for all audiences.

Books, movies, music, and other forms of entertainment play a significant role in our lives. While there may be concerns about certain content being inappropriate for certain age groups, banning them altogether is not the solution. It is important for individuals to be mindful of what they consume and for parents to monitor their children's exposure to various materials. Rather than imposing bans, we should focus on responsible consumption and supervision. Everyone has different preferences and sensitivities, so it is crucial to approach these forms of media with discretion. By being vigilant and making informed choices, we can enjoy a diverse range of content without the need for blanket bans. Let us embrace the variety of entertainment options available to us while exercising caution and respect for differing preferences.

Censorship in libraries is a topic that sparks debate, especially when it comes to children's exposure to explicit content in books. While some argue that censorship is necessary to protect young minds, others believe that it restricts access to valuable information and stifles learning opportunities.   It is important to consider the impact of censorship on children's education. By limiting the availability of certain books, students may struggle to find resources for school projects and research. This could hinder their academic growth and curiosity about different subjects.   On the other hand, parents have valid concerns about the influence of inappropriate content on their children. However, it is essential for parents to have open conversations with their kids about the books they choose to read and guide them towards age-appropriate material.   Furthermore, if authors start removing their books from libraries due to censorship, it sets a dangerous precedent that could lead to a lack of diverse reading options for all individuals. Books are a vital tool for learning and should be accessible to everyone, regardless of their content.  In conclusion, while censorship in libraries may have its place in certain circumstances, it is crucial to strike a balance between protecting young readers and preserving access to educational resources. Parents, educators, and librarians should work together to ensure that children have the opportunity to explore a wide range of literature while also being mindful of age-appropriate content.

NO, I do not think that books, music, magazines, and other forms of media should be removed from shelves if found offensive. These resources play a crucial role in our lives, offering a wide range of benefits.  Books, for example, help expand our knowledge and understanding of the world. They enhance vocabulary, improve focus, and stimulate critical thinking. When we encounter unfamiliar words or concepts, we are encouraged to explore and learn more, leading to personal growth and development.  Music serves as a powerful tool for relaxation and creativity. It can help us unwind after a long day and inspire us to express ourselves through various art forms like dance, singing, or painting. The soothing effects of music can provide much-needed stress relief and emotional support.  Magazines are valuable sources of information on a variety of topics, from recipes to fashion to current events. They offer practical guidance and inspiration, allowing us to explore new interests and make informed decisions. Whether seeking a new recipe or comparing prices on products, magazines provide a wealth of resources at our fingertips.  In conclusion, books, music, magazines, and other forms of media are essential in enriching our lives and expanding our horizons. Instead of censoring or removing offensive content, we should embrace the diversity of perspectives and ideas that these resources offer. Let us continue to explore, learn, and grow through the valuable resources available to us.

There are always going to be people who don't like certain books, music, movies, or other forms of media. However, this diversity in opinions is what makes our world interesting. It's important to remember that just because someone doesn't like a particular book, it doesn't mean that others won't enjoy it. People have different tastes and preferences, and that's perfectly okay.  While freedom of speech is important, there should still be a line that writers and creators should be mindful not to cross. It's essential to exercise judgment and sensitivity when discussing certain topics or sharing personal stories. Respect for others' feelings and experiences is crucial in creating a harmonious society.  Ultimately, it's essential to have open discussions and listen to different perspectives. Instead of getting upset over differing opinions, it's crucial to engage in constructive dialogue and learn from each other. Embracing diversity and respecting individual viewpoints can lead to a more inclusive and understanding community.

Censorship in libraries is a controversial topic that raises concerns about freedom of expression and the impact on authors. While censorship may seem like a way to protect children and sensitive audiences, it can lead to the removal of valuable literary works from shelves worldwide. Different individuals have varying thresholds for what they find offensive, making it difficult to establish universal guidelines for censorship. Instead of outright banning books, libraries could consider segregating potentially objectionable materials into separate sections. This would allow patrons to access a wide range of content while also addressing concerns about offensive material. Authors who have their works censored may experience financial losses and feelings of injustice, as they invest significant time and effort into their creations. Ultimately, censorship in libraries is a flawed approach that undermines the principles of intellectual freedom and diversity of thought. Libraries should strive to promote open access to information and ideas, rather than restricting access based on subjective criteria. In conclusion, censorship should not be enforced in libraries, as it stifles creativity, limits access to diverse perspectives, and infringes upon the rights of authors and readers alike.

Have you ever encountered someone with eccentric beliefs, sharing unique or unconventional theories? Each individual has their own perspective, and while it's acceptable to hold differing opinions, it's essential to seek understanding. I believe that while censorship in libraries serves a purpose, it's crucial for people to be open-minded, consider different viewpoints, and strive for mutual comprehension to foster better relationships.   Libraries contain a diverse range of materials, some of which are subject to censorship due to the expression of strong ideas and theories. Freedom of speech allows individuals to share their beliefs, but it's important to ensure that this expression does not harm others. Explicit content, such as movies and music, while regulated by rating systems, can sometimes lack consideration for others' perspectives.  Misinterpretation of others' ideas is a common issue, as people struggle to see things from different angles, leading to conflicts. By embracing a mindset of seeking understanding, conflicts arising from diverse beliefs could be minimized. Different perspectives can offer valuable insights and broaden one's awareness of various opinions.  Stubbornness can hinder the process of seeking understanding, as individuals rigidly adhere to their own beliefs without considering alternative viewpoints. Overcoming stubbornness can lead to increased empathy and awareness of others' feelings. When people are more open-minded, it becomes easier to navigate disagreements and build stronger relationships.  In conclusion, while censorship plays a role in society, the underlying reasons for censorship must be considered thoughtfully. A culture of seeking understanding would enable better discernment in censorship, addressing materials that may cause distress while allowing for the free exchange of ideas. By embracing different perspectives, being open to new viewpoints, and reducing stubbornness, individuals can coexist more harmoniously.

I understand how some people may get offended by certain content they come across in movies, books, or music. However, just because something offends one person doesn't mean it should be removed from public access for everyone else. Ratings and warnings are typically provided to inform consumers of potentially offensive content, allowing them to make informed decisions about what they choose to watch or read. It is important to respect individual preferences and opinions, but it is not fair to restrict access to certain media based on the views of a few. Ultimately, censorship should be approached with caution, and individuals should have the freedom to choose what they consume without interference from others.

I believe that certain materials such as books, music, movies, etc. should not be removed if they are found offensive. The library has different sections for different groups like the young or teen section, easy children or picture book section, and adult section. Each section caters to the specific needs and interests of its target audience. The library takes great care to ensure that the content in each section is appropriate for the intended age group. If someone finds something offensive, they can always seek assistance from the library staff. Overall, the library is organized in a way that allows people of all ages to find materials that they enjoy without encountering anything that they find objectionable. It is important to respect the diverse preferences and sensitivities of library patrons while providing a wide range of materials for everyone to enjoy.

When people think of libraries, they often imagine a quiet and dull place filled with books and strict librarians. However, libraries have evolved to offer much more than just books, now providing access to music, movies, magazines, and other forms of entertainment.   As a child, I didn't appreciate libraries because I found them boring. It wasn't until sixth grade that I discovered the library was actually a cool place with a variety of things to explore. Some traditional library-goers may not appreciate the changes, such as the introduction of music and movies, as they are used to the quiet atmosphere of the past.  In considering how to handle these differing opinions, it reminds me of the book "To Kill a Mockingbird," where old traditions clashed with new ideas, much like the situation in libraries today. Instead of banning or removing new additions, it may be more productive to have discussions and find a compromise. By creating designated sections for new ideas, we can accommodate all library visitors and ensure that everyone feels welcome and respected.

Everywhere one goes, something is being kept from them. It is either to keep them safe, pure, or happy. In the everyday world people who break the law are put into jails and prisons. Not only is it a punishment for them, but it is also to keep them away from other people. This is much like how our libraries are becoming. Books that have questionable content are being thrown out.  I do not believe that this should be done. Books are here to enlighten people and let them experience something they never would have been able to on their own. People should be able to choose what they read and if it offends them they can choose by themselves to stop reading that book. Many times I have learned new things from books that may not have been appropriate for my age, but it taught me a valuable lesson. For example, I read a book about a teenage girl engaging in sexual relations, she became pregnant and it ruined her life. From this, at the age of ten years old, I learned that I do not want that to happen to me, so I am abstaining from adult relations until I am married.  Of course the libraries should be separated into different categories such as: Children's, Young Adult, Adult, and Read at Your Own Risk. Also, the same with magazines and music. That way, a person could go to a specific section and know what to expect from there. This is much like the movie ratings, a mother can pick up a movie and see that it is rated PG and know that it is acceptable for her nine-year old to watch, except possibly save for a few curse words, but a child hears that in their everyday life anyways, whether the parent knows it or not.  In conclusion, I believe that literature should not be censored from the people. However, it should be categorized so a person could have an idea of what age group it would be most appropriate for. People have the right to choose what books they read and what they learn about. Everyone can learn a valuable lesson from any book, it just depends on how they interpret it.

I believe that children should not be sheltered from offensive materials, as they need to understand the complexities of the world they live in, both positive and negative. It is essential for them to learn about the good and the bad aspects of life at a young age, so they can make informed decisions as they grow older. While there should be age-appropriate limits in place, children should be exposed to a variety of information to develop a well-rounded understanding of the world. It is crucial for children to learn about the existence of bad people, the importance of making good choices, and the difference between reality and fiction. They should also be taught to critically analyze media messages and not succumb to peer pressure. By equipping children with the knowledge and skills to navigate challenging situations, they will be better prepared to make responsible decisions and handle the complexities of the world around them.

In @DATE1, there are many rap/hip-hop artists who sing about gangs, narcotics, alcohol, and using women for favors. This content is not suitable for young children, as they may end up learning inappropriate things at a young age. Parents play a crucial role in monitoring what their children are exposed to, including the music they listen to and the magazines they read. While it's important for children to understand the world around them, there is a limit to how much exposure is appropriate. Alternative genres like country music can offer a more peaceful and positive listening experience for kids. Additionally, movies and online content should be carefully monitored, as children can easily come across inappropriate material. Overall, it is essential for parents to be vigilant and mindful of the media their children consume to ensure they are not exposed to harmful content at a young age. Thank you for considering these viewpoints.

My views on censorship are clear - I do not believe in any form of censorship. Books, music, and movies should not be censored. It should be the responsibility of parents to decide what their children can and cannot read, watch, or listen to. Removing these materials from shelves is unfair to those who wish to access them, as well as to the creators of these works.  People should have the freedom to express themselves in any way they see fit, even if others may not agree with or enjoy what is being said. Ultimately, it is the right of the individual to share their thoughts and ideas without fear of censorship.

Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us'. Although I understand her message, I don't completely agree with it. I believe most things such as books, music, magazines, etc. should be censored in some cases.  One reason why I think there should be censorship is because of minors that might want to see things that may not be suitable for them. Children often mimic what they see, and not all adult content is appropriate for young eyes. That's why I believe that the media should be censored to protect children from negative influences.  Another reason for censorship is the prevalence of explicit content in today's media. Violence, disrespect, and profanity are often glorified, leading to a negative impact on society. By censoring these materials, we can promote a more positive and respectful environment for everyone.  In addition, censorship is necessary to maintain societal values and standards. Allowing inappropriate content to be easily accessible in public spaces like libraries can have a detrimental effect on our culture. By censoring materials, we can uphold decency and respect in our communities.  In conclusion, I believe that censorship is important in ensuring that our media promotes positive values and influences. By monitoring and restricting certain content, we can create a more wholesome and respectful society for all.

Censorship is a controversial topic, especially when it comes to materials found in libraries. Some people may find certain books, magazines, movies, or music offensive and believe they should be removed. However, removing these materials can also upset those who find them valuable for research or entertainment.   Historical readings, for example, may contain content that is considered inappropriate by today's standards, but they also provide valuable insights into the past. Similarly, modern music and media may have explicit content that some find offensive, but others enjoy and find relatable.   Ultimately, censorship in libraries can lead to a loss of valuable resources for those who appreciate and benefit from them. It is important to consider the diverse interests and perspectives of library patrons before making decisions about what materials should be available. Finding a balance between protecting individuals from offensive content and preserving access to diverse perspectives is crucial in maintaining the value and relevance of library collections.

From what I have observed in my life regarding censorship, I believe that materials should not be removed from shelves simply because they are deemed offensive. Libraries should keep such materials on the shelves but perhaps in a separate section to prevent easy access for those who may find them objectionable. It is unfortunate that people are easily offended by even the smallest things, making it difficult for others to enjoy certain content. In my opinion, censorship is ineffective as it often only serves to pique curiosity and make people more eager to seek out the censored material.   I adhere to the belief that censorship should not be enforced based on individual sensitivities. The saying "sticks and stones may break my bones but words will never hurt me" rings true to me, suggesting that individuals should learn to overlook things that offend them. Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, and one person's offense should not dictate what others can access. Additionally, censorship may inadvertently shelter individuals, making them ill-prepared for the realities of the world outside where not everything is censored.  In conclusion, I suggest that offensive materials be segregated in libraries and perhaps a rating system, similar to that used in video games, could be implemented to inform individuals of the content they may encounter. This way, those who are offended can avoid such materials while others can access them freely. This approach would ensure that everyone's preferences are considered and respected, promoting a balanced and fair environment for all.

Censorship in libraries should not be imposed on books, movies, music, magazines, etc. Authors put their time and effort into expressing their thoughts and ideas, which should not be censored. Everyone has the right to freedom of speech and to share their creations with the world. While some content may be offensive to some, it should not be removed from libraries as there will always be someone who finds value in it. Limiting access to certain materials would deprive people of the opportunity to learn and understand different perspectives. History, even if it includes controversial or offensive events, should not be censored as it serves as a reminder and a lesson for future generations. Overall, freedom of speech should be respected, and censorship should not dictate what materials are available in libraries.

I believe that censorship should not be allowed in libraries. Everyone has the right to free speech, and censoring material takes away that right. People go to libraries to seek knowledge, and censoring information can be harmful to learning and the progress of mankind. While minor adjustments can be made for inappropriate language or graphic material, completely blocking access to media is unnecessary. Libraries should be a place where people can freely access information and expand their understanding of the world. Censorship limits the capacity for learning and growth, which is detrimental to society as a whole. It is important to preserve the freedom of information in libraries to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to learn and grow.

To me, it is not right to remove music or books because people often express their feelings through them. People should be able to read or sing what they feel without the fear of it being taken away. It is important to respect the talents and passions of others, as taking away what they create can limit their ability to share their thoughts and emotions with the world. Instead of removing music or books, individuals who do not appreciate them can simply choose not to listen or read them and find something else that aligns with their preferences. Removing someone's creative work can have a negative impact on their sense of identity and self-expression, so it is crucial to allow them to share their art with others. In conclusion, it is essential to respect the creativity and individuality of artists and creators by not removing their work, but rather allowing them to express themselves freely.

Turn the other way  When I see a book that I don't particularly care for, I simply put it down. I really don't see the need to do away with all books that may be offensive to a single person or group of people. Any time I look through the library, I come across a few books that are slightly inappropriate. However, when I see these books, I don't make a big deal about it. I just put that book down and continue my search. I couldn't imagine how scarce our book selection would be if we were to rid the libraries of all books that people might find offensive.  Also, there are many people that find The Catcher in the Rye offensive. If we were to remove all controversial text from libraries, then we would have a hard time passing the word of literature to people who do not have access to such material.  Although I do not fully agree with the ideas of many theorists, I do not ask that their work be banned from public libraries. I may not like a particular author's book on evolution, but because of our freedom of speech, they have every right to write about their discoveries and beliefs.  As you can clearly see, I am by no means claiming to be open-minded to others' thoughts or beliefs. However, when it comes to literature and art, I think that a variety makes us unique. If everyone read the same books, listened to the same music, and watched the same movies, then we could have a very boring culture. That is certainly not the basis on which this great country was founded!

Everyone enjoys different forms of entertainment such as movies, music, and books, and should have the freedom to access and consume what interests them. Censoring certain materials in libraries can limit people's access to literature and information that they enjoy or need for research. People have diverse interests, and what one person finds entertaining or informative may not appeal to others. Therefore, libraries should cater to a wide range of preferences to ensure that everyone can find something they enjoy. Authors write to entertain and inform their readers, and it is important to respect the diversity of interests by providing a variety of materials for people to explore. By allowing individuals to access a range of content, libraries can better serve their community and promote intellectual freedom and cultural diversity.

When going to a library, one expects it to be a place of positive influence. However, there are instances where offensive and inappropriate material can be found, such as racist books, adult content, and music with explicit language. While some may argue that these materials serve educational or historical purposes, it is important to consider the impact they may have on individuals, especially children.  Parents may be concerned about their children accessing such material, and it raises the question of whether there should be age restrictions or censorship in place at libraries. By limiting access to certain books and music, or creating separate sections for adult content, libraries can better cater to the needs and preferences of their community members.  Ultimately, the decision to implement voting for library materials or introduce censorship measures should be carefully considered to ensure that libraries remain inclusive and welcoming spaces for all individuals. By addressing these concerns, libraries can attract more customers and continue to serve as valuable resources for the community.

The book "To Kill a Mockingbird" has been a controversial topic due to its offensive language and graphic content. While some praise the story, others find it inappropriate for high school students. The repetitive offensive language used by the author adds to the discomfort for some readers. Despite its awards and popularity, the offensive nature of the book raises questions about censorship in libraries. It is important to consider the impact of such material on readers and whether it should be available without restrictions. In conclusion, while "To Kill a Mockingbird" may have a compelling story, its offensive content warrants a closer examination of censorship in libraries.

I agree and disagree with the prompt. I think that it is good everyone is allowed to take any book off the shelf, listen to any music, watch all types of movies, or read any type of magazine. Then I think it isn't okay.   First, reason for agreeing is because some books, music, movies, magazines, and etc. may not be suitable for most young children. They may use profanity, show naked pictures, or talk about things that a child is not yet supposed to be exposed to at that age. Most music and movies these days use bad language or show people engaging in explicit activities. Also, adults may use these materials in a way that could cause many problems within the library. So, it is reasonable to agree that certain materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from the shelves if found offensive.  On the other hand, I believe that libraries should leave most of the books, movies, music, or magazines on the shelves for everyone to access. This allows children to be exposed to various content and learn about what is appropriate or inappropriate for their age. It provides them with an opportunity to understand the consequences of certain behaviors or actions if they are exposed to them at a young age. Having a designated section for potentially offensive materials could also be a good compromise.  In conclusion, there are valid points for both sides of the argument. While offensive materials should be handled appropriately, having a diverse range of content available in libraries can help individuals, especially children, learn and grow. Finding a balance between access and censorship is crucial for promoting a healthy and educational environment in libraries.

Hello, I am writing to you today about my concerns regarding censorship in libraries. Firstly, some of the music played in libraries can be quite graphic and inappropriate. Music should be meaningful and uplifting, rather than promoting violence and negativity. It would be beneficial to consider the impact of the music on library patrons.  Secondly, the selection of books in libraries should be carefully curated, especially when it comes to adult content. It may be helpful to have a designated section for adult material to ensure that younger readers are not exposed to inappropriate content.  Next, the magazines featured in libraries should also be age-appropriate. Displaying magazines with explicit content can be unsettling for some library visitors. Creating sections for different age groups could help in providing a more suitable reading environment.  Lastly, the movies available for checkout in libraries should be considered with caution, particularly concerning their suitability for younger audiences. Exposing children to graphic content at a young age can have negative effects on their development. Libraries should be mindful of the impact of the movies they make available to the public.  In conclusion, while everyone should have access to a library, it is essential to consider the impact of the materials available. Libraries should strive to provide a diverse selection of materials while ensuring that they are appropriate for their audience. Making thoughtful selections can help create a more positive and enriching library experience for all patrons.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf..' said by Katherine Paterson. Books are used to entertain and even teach readers in certain aspects of life. Not exactly all books are offensive but some are. Those who are, should be taken off the shelves, especially if it is in a school library. Children could take that offensive or violent book into action. Other children could show the book to other peers. And also, children can get very offended. Now should offensive books be taken off the shelves?  Children nowadays are being motivated a lot. Whether it's through television shows, video games, or even music. On the news, there have been reports about children being influenced to have a gun and hang themselves, etc. Books are meant to entertain readers in a good way and not teach them to become a violent person. Some readers who read such things can turn those words into action. Then the student could be in trouble. And people really wouldn't want that.  Children have a tendency of showing off to friends. If a student sees something offensive or violent in a book, there is a big chance that they will show it to their peers. Just because children think it's cool. Having one person read this could be a problem, now imagine having more than just one, a whole clique seeing this. It could end up in a huge problem, not only for the children and their parents, but also for the school. The children learning these new things from the book can cause the children to use everyday and make it popular. The school can have a bad image from the students. Passing on the information can become a conflict, and people certainly do not want that.  School is not only a teaching building, but also a social place. There are cliques in every school. Within each person, there is a different color, religion, style, and personalities. Children can be easily hurt. If books are being offensive, it can just easily hurt anyone reading that book. Once again, books are meant to entertain readers and not to hurt them. So why even have authors write something offensive in their books? Maybe authors feel the need to add interest in the book and suspense, but not all readers would take it easily. Hurting people isn't a fun thing to do, and people certainly do not want to do that.  So why have offensive books on shelves? These books can cause children to use it in action, to show it off to other peers, and to hurt them as well. Children nowadays have it hard on themselves, why make it harder. Books are meant to entertain readers, why not just do that. So yes, take the offensive books off and there will be no problems.

Yes, I do believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. The reason why I think some things should be removed is because some kids don't need to look at certain things. Parents don't always go with their children to the library and tell them what they can and can't get. At school libraries, they really don't have bad things; they only have school-appropriate things. But the public library has a lot of different things than a school library. Therefore, those are my reasons why I believe certain materials should be removed.

Censorship plays a crucial role in safeguarding the well-being of children in today's society. It is essential for parents to have the ability to regulate what their children are exposed to, whether it be in the form of TV shows, movies, books, or newspapers. Many forms of media contain violence that may not be suitable for young audiences, and it is important to shield them from such content.  Cartoons, for example, often depict violence as a means to resolve conflicts. While children may enjoy watching these shows, it is crucial for parents to explain that the actions portrayed are not acceptable in real life. Similarly, popular book series like Twilight contain violent themes that may not be appropriate for young readers. By monitoring what their children read, parents can ensure that they are not exposed to harmful content.  Furthermore, newspapers frequently report on violent events, which can be disturbing for children. It is essential for parents to limit their children's exposure to such news to prevent them from becoming desensitized to violence or feeling compelled to seek out dangerous situations.  Overall, censorship is necessary to protect the innocence and well-being of children. By monitoring and regulating what their children consume in terms of media, parents can help shape a safe and positive environment for their development.

Libraries should not remove offensive reading material just because some people find it offensive. What one person finds offensive may not be offensive to someone else. It is important to remember that offensive material exists everywhere and it is up to individuals to decide what they want to read. Removing offensive material from libraries sets a dangerous precedent of censorship and limits access to diverse perspectives and ideas. It is important to allow for freedom of expression and the opportunity for individuals to make their own choices about what they want to read. Ultimately, it is important to respect the diverse opinions and preferences of others, even if they may differ from our own.

Should books, music, etc; be removed from shelves if they are found offensive? Well, people have the right to choose what they want to read or listen to. While some may find certain content offensive, it is important to remember that everyone has different opinions and sensitivities. In a diverse society, it is impossible to cater to every individual's preferences. It is essential to respect freedom of expression and allow individuals to make their own choices. If something is offensive to you, it is best to simply avoid it rather than demand its removal. Life is full of challenges and obstacles, and learning to navigate through them is an essential part of personal growth. In the grand scheme of things, focusing on more significant issues and striving for a better world should take precedence over minor disagreements or discomfort. Embracing diversity and differing viewpoints can lead to a more inclusive and tolerant society. In conclusion, while offensive content may exist in various forms, it is crucial to uphold the principle of freedom of expression and encourage open-mindedness and understanding.

If I found a book that offended me, I would have to go and take it off the shelf because if I find a book offensive, I know that others would think the same. I agree that some books can be offensive to some and not to others, and it's really not fair for those who think that way. One reason that I would take it off the shelf would be to keep young children from reading it. Parents don't really want their children reading about violence and murder.  Most of what I would take off the shelf would have to be about people being racist against another person or people, people killing others, and engaging in sexual activities. People really shouldn't read things like that because it puts things in their heads and sometimes makes them think the same way as the writer. If children read books about violence and sexual actions, they could think that it's okay to do these things to other people and get into a lot of trouble with the law and their parents. Children really need to be kept away from these kinds of books until they are older and understand what's right and what's wrong. Some books have a lot of cursing in them, and a lot of children pick up on words and start using them more and more until it becomes a habit.  Even though some books are about real people, they should still be taken off the shelves. In some of these books, there is a lot of violence, and children should not be exposed to that kind of book. Books can sometimes be more bad than good. If everybody had their way and could take a book that offended them off the shelf whenever they wanted, then there would be no books left.

If people want to remove books, movies, music, magazines, and other forms of media because they find them offensive, they may do so to prevent negative influences on others. However, it is essential to consider the context in which these works were created and the intended audience. While some content may be deemed inappropriate by certain individuals, it is essential to recognize that censorship can limit access to valuable sources of information and entertainment. It is crucial for parents to be involved in guiding their children's media consumption and to have open discussions about the content they encounter. Ultimately, it is important to find a balance between protecting individuals from harmful material and preserving the freedom of expression that is fundamental to a diverse society.

Books should not be removed from shelves just because they are offensive to some people. Everyone should have the right to read any book they choose in a library. If a book is offensive but can help someone with problems, it should not be taken off the shelf. People may have different reasons for reading offensive books, and it is important to respect their choices. Offensive material should be moved to a separate area in the library rather than being completely removed. It is possible that those who find certain materials offensive may feel guilty about something, and their discomfort should not dictate what others can or cannot read. Ultimately, the decision to remove a book should be based on a consensus of many people finding it offensive, rather than just one individual's opinion.

The belief of certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from shelves if they are offensive, depends on the situation the material is relating to. If one wants to see these type of resources, then he/she must be mature enough to withstand it. It all depends on where the material is at in the library and what situation it's in. If it is in the children's area, I highly suggest that it should be removed from there, since it's clear that a child should not process this type of information. If it's in the teen section, then the person must be mature enough to take this sort of inappropriate matter or just leave it be. In the adult section however, there should be no argument of any sort because it is obvious that the person must be fully mature to take in this sort of material.  One example on why this sort of aspect on whether or not inappropriate material should be removed are the comic books called 'Tales' or 'The Organization'. These type of materials have some from inappropriate to disturbing events in the books, but have been distributed to the teen section. Now from ages 13 years of age usually spend their time there and would likely read this type of information. Some teens would be horrified of looking through these books and others would be fascinated by it. It varies through the people and what type of material they would like to read. It all depends on the situation where this material is distributed in.  Another example on whether or not inappropriate material should be taken out of the shelves is how movies are put in situations. There was once a time, a young lady around her early teens who wanted to check out a type of movie in which she have never saw before. So once she checked it out, she watched it with her parents and saw some uneasy sections during this movie. The person should have thought this through before jumping into the situation. If the person was mature enough to go through this matter, it would have been fine; but she was young still and so it made the matter worse.  Whether or not inappropriate material should be removed from shelves depends on how and where the material is distributed and so it shows that one person can change the difference in the situation.

Books, music, movies, magazines, and other forms of media have a significant impact on individuals, especially children. Parents are increasingly concerned about the content their children are exposed to, as they want to ensure that it is appropriate and does not have a negative influence. Violent, gory, or sexually explicit material can have detrimental effects on young minds, shaping their behavior, emotions, and overall outlook on life. It is essential to safeguard children from such harmful influences to promote their well-being and development. By being mindful of the media consumed by children, we can help create a safer and more positive environment for them to grow and thrive in.

Newspaper staff and/or whom it may concern, Reading material found in a library is very useful and informative to the world, there is no limit to what could be found on paper. Whether it be offensive or not, having limits to books will only create tension, affect the economy, and will lead to illegal activity, ironically enough, in which offensive books will be written and sold, completely undercover.  In today's world, it would be nearly impossible to pick up a book and factually state that it is not offensive. Almost everyone has some little issue with something in the world today, and because of that, original and unoffensive material are hard to come by. With the stripping of offensive material from libraries, authors will be devastated, not just emotionally, but will be out of a job and will have less income. Because of how virtually impossible it is to write a book that is not offensive, authors will become very frustrated, and most are very passionate about what they do. Also, because almost all reading material is offensive in some way, there will be little to no reading material on the shelves of the world or nation's libraries. This could potentially lead to violent protests that quickly tear down even the most successful of nations. However, physical devastation would not be the only toll paid for the stripping of offensive reading material from libraries.  Books cost money; to make books costs money, to buy books costs money. Paper companies would take a major nose-dive in the market, having almost no clientele. When a major division such as the paper industry falls, it will bring others down as well, and due to the nation's market complexity, almost all major companies rely on paper. This would ruin the economy. Some might say, 'it means that the people of the world will be much more green!' However, the past few centuries when economics and the environment are put on a scale, economics takes the cake by a mile. Obviously, this will do much more harm than good. The people of the world always have a priority. Also, the majority of the people don't enjoy having something taken that they have grown so fond of.  People, in general, want what they can't have. An obvious example would be illegal drugs; the drug market is extremely successful, but it's illegal. If people were to have these currently illegal drugs for their use, being completely legal, chances are that the success of drug marketing will plummet. The opposite situation for books: We have them now, but when they are taken, we will want them even more. People who read tend to be very passionate about literature and very intelligent. All it takes is one group to gain numbers, and have a very talented speaker persuade others to follow in a potentially violent revolt to be given back permission to write and publish alleged 'offensive' books. All other material found in libraries, such as music and movies, being taken away will have the same effects, give or take a few similarities or differences.  Avoiding such problems is easy, keep the books and all other material in a library on the shelves. It will only be problematic to take it all away, especially for being offensive, when there are very few books that the general population will find not offensive. If keeping the material in libraries means individuals will become offended for very different reasons, let it be organized chaos. This is how people work, and keeping the material on the shelves is how the people are pleased or motivated. Let's strive to maintain access to a diverse range of reading materials to preserve creativity, freedom of expression, and a thriving economy.
