Therefore, no book should be censored, no matter how inappropriate the material is.  Just as remembering the @CAPS2 has influenced mankind not to repeat past mistakes, keeping books of the most horrible content @MONTH1 save authors from repeating such dishonorable content.  In other words, if censorship removes the 'mistakes' of literature from library shelves, who is to say that an oblivious author will not repeat that 'mistake'.  By remembering these mistakes, mankind will be able to move forward in literature.  @CAPS1 books are not 'mistakes', they serve as reminders of the high-points in literature.  All literature, appropriate and inappropriate, is a piece of mankind's history that should not be kept a secret.     Finally, who is to judge what is a 'mistake' in literature?  A book on @CAPS3 @MONTH1 be inappropriate in the eyes of a @CAPS4, but that book @MONTH1 be sacred to a @CAPS5.  Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.  Furthermore, for any given book there is at least one person who disagrees with its message.  A library is built for the education of the public, not for the interests of one person.  If one is offended by a literary work, perhaps he should just move on and find a book more suited to his interests.  The decision on the appropriateness of a novel is up to the reader, not the government or library or activist group.     Censorship of material in libraries would strip authors of their chance to let their works be seen by others, keep records of the human race secret, and take away the privelage of the reader to decide what is appropriate.  Authors endure long hours of practice and writing in order to have their thoughts read, and such a motive should not be taken away from them.  Every book represents some aspect of human life and records it for future generations to avoid previous mistakes.  And these 'mistakes' are decided by the reader, a decision that censorship takes upon itself.  Instead of choosing what books are seen by the public, perhaps libraries should just create an adult-only section to house the 'controversial' books; as a result, mankind would stay educated and free, and children would remain innocent. -@ORGANIZATION2  Expanding on the idea that books serve as reminders of historical mistakes, censorship can hinder society's progress by suppressing valuable lessons from past literature. In essence, allowing unrestricted access to literature, even if deemed controversial, ensures a more informed and enlightened community. Letting individuals make their own choices regarding what they read promotes intellectual freedom and personal growth. In conclusion, the preservation of diverse literary works is essential for fostering a society that values creativity, critical thinking, and the exchange of ideas.

There are many different perspectives on censorship in our country. Different people have varying opinions on what should be censored, especially when it comes to materials in libraries that some may find offensive. While the intention is not to expose young children to inappropriate content, sometimes these materials end up in their hands. However, removing all offensive material from libraries would leave shelves empty and deprive adults of valuable knowledge and entertainment.  It is important to label all materials appropriately so that individuals can make informed decisions about what they consume. While some content may not be suitable for children, it does not mean it should be completely removed. Parents can monitor what their children access and make decisions based on what they find appropriate.  Instead of censoring all offensive material, libraries can explore alternative solutions such as keeping children's books in a separate area or implementing stricter guidelines for accessing certain materials. By finding a balance between protecting children and preserving access to information, libraries can continue to serve the public effectively without resorting to censorship. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is a complex issue with valid arguments on both sides, but it is possible to find solutions that benefit everyone without compromising individuals' rights to access diverse content.

@STATE1 @NUM1, @PERSON1, IN @CAPS1 Katherine Paterson,  I read your article in the newspaper yesterday about offensive books in the library. I agree with you on this article. Some of the books, music, movies, or magazines in public libraries are very offensive to me but they can be normal to other people. There can also be some books that are normal to me and can be offensive to other people. Everyone has their own views and ideas on everything. The people of @LOCATION1 have freedom of speech so it is true that every mouth has got something different to say.  There are some books or movies that children cannot read or watch but children still do because once the child is in the library he can read, watch, or listen to anything. You cannot depend on the librarian because there are other people in the library too. The librarian probably has other things to do like arranging the books or checking out the books or making a library card or helping someone find a book.  In my point of view, the library should have different sections for different kinds of movies, books, or magazines, and there should be a person assigned for every section. This way, children would not be able to go to older people's sections. If there are books that are found offensive by everyone, then people should write a letter to the president to help remove those books from the library.  Yours @NUM2.

Have you ever been in a situation where you couldn't read a book because someone else had bitter feelings towards it? Are you frustrated when you finally get a chance to read a book you've been waiting for, only to find it unavailable due to its content? This is a common occurrence at libraries, where books are sometimes removed because of complaints from a single individual. However, censorship of books can lead to the loss of important historical and cultural material. While some content may be offensive to certain individuals, it is essential for understanding the context and message of the work. Authors, filmmakers, and artists often draw on history to create meaningful and impactful pieces of art, and censoring these works can diminish their value. It is important to strike a balance between protecting sensitive audiences and preserving the integrity of artistic expression. Censorship should be reserved for content that is gratuitously offensive and lacks any redeeming value. By being mindful of the need for diverse perspectives and open dialogue, we can ensure that important works of literature and art remain accessible to all. Let us strive to uphold the principles of intellectual freedom and resist the urge to censor materials based on individual preferences.

I think that it is should be left alone the way it is because it put that way for a reason. They might not know the reason so thats why i think it should because the person might get mad if you mess it up just cause you dont like it the way it is because it is offensive to some people. Other reasons is because people are gonna home and watch it online or on tv so how is it gonna make a difference. It is not goiing to make one difference at all.

No, I believe all materials should be on the shelves at libraries. Because some people like stuff other people may find offensive. But you as parents should control what your kids are reading. If you find it offensive, tell them to pick out a new book, movie, or magazine. Some people like things from other cultures or religions, and it's important to have a variety of perspectives available. By creating separate sections for adult content and implementing age restrictions, libraries can cater to different preferences while still ensuring appropriate access for all readers. It's essential to embrace diversity and respect individual interests, even if they differ from our own. Ultimately, the freedom to choose what to read or watch should be preserved, with parents playing a key role in guiding their children's selections.

Everyone in the world has different opinions when it comes to censorship, especially in libraries. Some believe that inappropriate material should be kept away from children, while others argue that teens should have the freedom to access such content. Parents often play a role in deciding what their children can read, but some believe that kids should be able to choose their own books. Ultimately, the debate on censorship in libraries is ongoing, with varying perspectives on what is appropriate for different age groups. In the end, everyone has their own views on the matter, making it a complex issue to navigate.

Offensive books, music, movies, magazines, and other forms of media should not be allowed on library shelves as they can incite violence and crime among individuals, especially youth. For instance, a CD labeled as a "Black man's only CD" could spark conflict when a white individual picks it up, leading to potential altercations. Such instances can lead to unnecessary tension and aggression, ultimately contributing to a hostile environment. Therefore, it is essential to monitor and regulate the content available in libraries to promote a safe and harmonious community.

What should and shouldn't be censored in a library really is just a matter of opinion from the people using the library. If everyone were to remove what they didn't like from the shelves of a library, then much information would be less accessible to the general public. Although some people may be offended by certain forms of literature, this doesn't mean that the literature should be removed for everyone. A solution must be made to satisfy everyone.  Currently, some individuals are unhappy with certain books, music, movies, and magazines available at libraries. They believe that the information may be unsuitable for some viewers, especially children. While this is a valid reason to consider censorship, others disagree with restricting access to library materials, as it would limit information available to the public.  One proposed solution is to have parents fill out a form before allowing their children to get a library card. This form would list specific content they wish to prevent their children from accessing, such as explicit language, nudity, or violence. This information would be linked to the library card, and if a child tries to check out restricted material, the librarian would intervene.  Censorship can be important, but it should not limit access to information. Finding a balance between protecting sensitive viewers and preserving intellectual freedom is crucial. A tailored approach, like the one proposed, could help address concerns while maintaining a diverse and inclusive library collection. It is essential to explore solutions that accommodate various viewpoints and ensure that everyone can benefit from the resources available in a library.

In the library, it is essential to ensure that literature materials are age-appropriate for younger readers. This includes movies, magazines, and books that may contain content unsuitable for children and teens. Dividing the library into sections for adults, teens, and children helps in maintaining a safe and suitable environment for all visitors. Bright and colorful displays in the children's section attract young readers and keep them engaged with appropriate materials.  It is important to carefully curate the collection in each section to prevent younger readers from encountering inappropriate content. Movies, TV shows, and books that depict drug use, violence, or sexual content can have a negative influence on children and teens. By reorganizing and monitoring the library's collection, the risk of accidental exposure to unsuitable material can be minimized.  In conclusion, libraries play a crucial role in providing access to educational and entertaining materials for all age groups. By ensuring that the content is age-appropriate and suitable for each section, libraries can create a positive and enriching environment for all visitors.

There are many books out there that contain obscene or vulgar content, which may not be suitable for children to read. However, this does not mean that these books should be banned from library shelves. Authors carefully choose every word they write for a reason, whether it be to evoke certain emotions or to convey a particular message. While it is important to consider the age appropriateness of certain books, that does not justify removing them entirely.  Libraries often have sections designated for children, teens, and adults, which helps to differentiate the content and ensure that age-appropriate material is readily available. By implementing such systems, both sides of the debate can be satisfied without resorting to censorship. Banning books with offensive material could potentially lead to the removal of classic and award-winning titles, which would be a disservice to literature as a whole.  While it is important to be mindful of what children are exposed to, there are better ways to regulate access to certain books without outright banning them. No book should be censored solely based on its content. By creating age restrictions and organizing books by genre and intended audience, libraries can effectively manage the availability of potentially sensitive material. In conclusion, it is possible to address concerns about offensive material in books without resorting to censorship, ensuring that a diverse range of literature remains accessible to readers of all ages.

I feel that books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves just because someone finds them offensive. They only become offensive when people think they are. No one is forcing anyone to consume content they don't want to. Everyone has the choice to decide what they want to read or watch. What one person may find offensive, another may find interesting and exciting. It is important to respect everyone's right to access a variety of materials, even if individual preferences differ. There are a wide range of options available in libraries and stores, catering to diverse tastes and interests. Therefore, nothing should be taken off shelves simply because someone finds it offensive. It is essential to uphold the freedom of choice and diversity of content in our society.

I believe that there are many books in a library that should not be available to everybody that goes into a public library. Yes, there are some very offensive items in a library, such as a book about racism towards African Americans. No, that person who takes offense to those items does not have to be around them or even go into the library at all. The library is open to anyone and everyone.  Let's suppose you have a young child, and you take him/her to the public library with you. As you're looking for a book, the child reaches for the highest book that he/she can reach, pulls it off the shelf, and it lands on the floor open. You look down to see what happened and you see the book lying there with an inappropriate picture right in front of your child. That's your own fault, not the library's.  Although many times it's not the library's fault where certain books are placed, you should be more responsible and check out the area in which you are looking. I think there should be a select area for which the 'inappropriate material' should be kept. For a person to access the select area, they must show a membership type of identification and sign a waiver stating that the material they have checked out will cause no trouble or offense to anybody in their vicinity.  In conclusion, creating a separate section for potentially offensive material in libraries can help ensure that individuals are not inadvertently exposed to content that they may find inappropriate. This approach allows for freedom of access while also respecting the diverse sensitivities of library patrons.

Books should not be taken off the shelves just because they may offend someone. Libraries are meant to be inclusive spaces where individuals can access a wide range of information that aligns with their interests and preferences. Removing material that may offend some individuals could limit the learning opportunities for others. It is important to recognize that everyone has different tastes and perspectives, and what may be offensive to one person may not be to another. By maintaining a diverse collection of materials, libraries can continue to serve as valuable resources for individuals seeking knowledge and information. In the end, the primary purpose of libraries is to provide access to information for all, regardless of individual preferences or sensitivities.

Should certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., be removed from shelves if they are found offensive? I do not think that certain materials should be removed for many reasons. Many different people have many different thoughts on what's offensive and what isn't. Some people will find something funny that others may find nasty or inappropriate. If things deemed offensive were removed from shelves, there wouldn't be much left for people to choose from. Everyone has their own opinion, and while certain materials may not be suitable for young audiences, it should be up to the parents to regulate what their children are exposed to. Removing materials based on one person's opinion would limit the diversity of content available to the public. It's important to respect individual differences and allow people the freedom to make their own choices about what they consume.

I firmly believe that the removing of books, music, movies, etc., from a shelf just because someone finds it offensive will not solve the problem. A person can find many things in life offensive to their personal views, but they cannot just remove them. To remove books, music, movies, etc., from people who do not find them offensive could provoke chaos.  As Katherine Paterson stated 'And then we have no books left.' If everyone were to choose books, music, movies, etc., they felt were offensive and should not be placed in the library, the statement would probably be true. Besides the point, the library is sectioned off into different genres, so if you have a different view of a certain genre of books, movies, music, etc., skip over that section and go to the genre in which you prefer.  In other words, the things that offend one person may not offend another person. So to remove one particular thing would be unreasonable for the person who likes or finds interest in a particular subject. So instead of there being a problem with one person, there would be a problem with two unsatisfied people. Not saying that it is right, but the library has done particular things such as, separating the books for reasons like this.  According to Katherine Paterson, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' The library has a section for children only. Therefore, worries of problems like this have already been solved. The books, music, movies, etc., in the children's section are age-appropriate for a child. Books, music, movies, etc., are also sectioned off for teenagers and adults.  In conclusion, the removal of books, music, movies, etc., that are found offensive by others may not be found offensive by someone else. It is not like the library would purposely offend anyone by having the books, music, movies, etc., on the shelves. If you are mature enough to understand that and overlook something that may offend you, you would not be so offended. Also, if the library is sectioned off into different genres, you can easily bypass a particular genre you wish to avoid. Problems can be easily solved if they are dealt with in the correct manner.

I don't believe books with bad words should be removed from libraries altogether. What if that's all someone enjoys reading? Instead, books could be organized into different sections to ensure that children are not exposed to inappropriate content. Librarians could create sections for kids, teenagers, and adults, and implement age restrictions for checking out certain books. There are many ways to categorize books without completely removing them, as a book with some bad words doesn't necessarily make it a bad book.

Keep it on the Shelf! What types of things do you go to the library for? Some go for books and others go just to relax in a quiet environment. Yes, the library is mostly used for books and studying, but there are many other things that libraries contain. Movies, magazines, music, etc., are all found in a library. Now, say you had to listen to a specific song, read a certain book, or review an article in a certain magazine, and you can't find it at the library because they have been removed because they are found to be offensive. All people have different views on what is and isn't offensive. Everything like books, music, magazines, and movies should all have their place in a library, regardless of the material.  Books can be used for many things. Some read just for the enjoyment and others read because it is assigned to them or they need to research some things. Books give information and knowledge that some people need desperately. What if you can't find that book because someone said that its material is inappropriate? What are you supposed to do about your research paper now? If a book is needed it should be able to be found on the shelf in a library and not be taken out because of the content of its pages.  Music is a great way to clear your mind and relax. Some music found in libraries can be somewhat offensive to some people. What if the only place you can find your favorite music is at your public library? You walk in and they no longer have it because it is considered to be offensive. Now you can no longer listen to the sounds that calm you down or motivate you to get your day started. Music should remain in libraries because of the cultural and educational sounds that most cannot find at their local music store.  Magazines are another great form of reading material found in a library. Magazines are a great way to stay up to date with the latest fashions and great dessert recipes. Without magazines our world wouldn't be able to keep up with the things that advance in our world every day. Magazines show us the hottest trends, the gossip in the celebrity world, and some great facts from educational magazines. Without the magazines in the library we probably wouldn't know anything about our advancing world.  You can find movies anywhere, but some believe that you can only find the really good and old movies at the library. The library has educational movies for children that may not be available anywhere else. They also have old classic movies that aren't even around anymore. The library has many movies that you wouldn't be able to find in our advanced world today.  Libraries hold a lot of important books, movies, music, and magazines. Without most of that, regardless of the material, we probably wouldn't know as much as we know today. The library has always been a place where you go to find exactly what you want and you know that they will have it. Removing these things from the shelves can be taking some history right out of our lives. All of these resources should stay on the shelves regardless of their material.

Can literature, which is the basis of civilization, be censored? Can you take these ideas away from those who wish to think them? I think not, for it would be a futile endeavor to even attempt. To keep something as important as written word away from the culture of the people, would be one of the highest crimes against humanity and could not rightly be condoned, in my mind. Not only would this attempt be a futile (for the people know ways to extract information) it would be downright idiotic of the 'administration' to do so. I will concede that there are explicit materials out there that are not suitable for children or even adolescents, but that is where the parent should step in by setting guidelines and positive examples which their children feel the need to follow. Not feel that they 'have' to, but feel that they 'need' to. If parents cannot take control and decide what is appropriate for their children, then in my mind, they are not doing their first and foremost job as a parent that is to protect the child. Some may say that the censorship of culture is protecting the children, but I say that this is not so. I believe censorship is a lousy excuse so that parents and upper government officials have to do less work. If every piece of written, filmed, or recorded work, that was offensve only one person, was thrown out on that basis, there would be none. There has never been a piece of literature, film, or music that has not offended someone in some way, whether it be spiritually, ethnically, or morally. The fact is that people cannot exist without strife and misery, and whatever people can do to cause that strife and misery, they will. People find all sorts of ways to do it, whether it be war, discrimination, media, or just downright obstinance, they will find a way to offend their selected party. I personally am appalled at the aspect of censorship, for if a person cannot speak his mind, then is he more than a mindless homunculi? Created and controlled by the government surrounding him. Made their slave through ignorance. If in a society I cannot say what I need to say then I do not wish to live in that society, for it is nothing but a horrible image of civilization. In short I do not believe that libraries should be censored, rather that parents should pay more attention to their children and dependents. If a person is offended by a certain thing, then it is their absolute right to not take part in whatever it may be, but these afflicted peoples have absolutely NO right to say what I may or may not read! If this offends anyone, then I apologize, but at least you knew enough (through your education by media) to be offended and not just another mindless sheep.

In my opinion, offensive materials should be taken off of the shelves. Factors such as age, beliefs, and awareness of potentially offensive content all play a role in determining what is deemed inappropriate. It is crucial to protect younger individuals from harmful content and to respect different races and cultures by removing any offensive material. Additionally, labeling offensive content can help individuals make informed choices. Overall, removing offensive materials from circulation is essential to creating a more respectful and inclusive society.

Have you ever came across offensive material inside a library? Well some people have and they think there should be some type of censorship in libraries to protect the offended people. I do not agree with this idea because people should have the right to express their self through art, literature, and even music. After all the freedom of speech is written in our rights.  Many authors, artists, and musicians have the freedom to express themselves through their work. If they saw their own work in a library being censored it would be very offensive to them. I understand that the artist's material could be offensive to certain people but it is their work, a form of self-expression. They do not publish their work to offend people, they do it for themselves and for other people to enjoy it. An artist's work is a part of who they are. A censor would just put a negative aspect to the art and literature of the library.  Over many years most libraries have developed and arranged their media into a system called @CAPS1 @CAPS2. This system separates all books, magazines, music, and movies into their own genres. For instance, if you are looking for a mystery book, you would find it in the non-fiction section. This system helps people find exactly what they are looking for. If people are offended by a certain genre they do not have to come in contact with it. This system is a better way to find exactly what you want instead of coming across a book or movie that you would find offensive. Almost every library uses this system so they do not have to use a censor.  Everywhere we go someone somewhere is going to find something offensive. It is basically part of our human nature. It is truly impossible to make every single person happy with everything in the world. In a library, there will always be a book that someone disagrees with or someone will find it offensive. The author of that book and other people who enjoyed it do not need to be punished by having the book taken off the shelves. Just because the book offends one person does not mean it has to be taken off the shelf or have a censor. If every time that happened there would be no books left to read in our libraries. Most people would not even call that a library.  In the end, a book is a book, music is music and we are not going to create censors or take books off the shelves because it is offensive to people. Authors write what they want to write, musicians play what they want to play, and actors act how they want to act. After everything, it does not matter what is offensive to people, they will just have to deal with it. There is no reason for a censor in a library.

'Everyone has their own preferences and dislikes. It is true that everyone has their own unique tastes, especially when it comes to books. For example, I personally do not enjoy reading books about illegal substances, but I do not believe in censoring materials that some may find offensive. While some may find certain content disturbing, it does not mean that everyone shares the same sentiment.  In a recent school project, a classmate chose a book about illegal drugs for a presentation. While I found the topic uncomfortable, others found it intriguing. It just goes to show that what may be off-putting to one person can be fascinating to another.  Similarly, when doing research on the human body systems, my friend was disturbed by graphic images of blood, while I found them fascinating. We each have our own unique reactions to different materials, and that is perfectly normal.  It is important for people to acknowledge and respect that everyone has their own opinions and preferences. Instead of trying to censor or remove materials that some may find offensive, it is better to simply seek out alternative resources that align with individual interests. By recognizing and accepting our differences, we can coexist harmoniously in a diverse society.'

I believe that if something or someone offends you, you have the right to take a stand. You shouldn't have to deal with it. If something is offensive in your library, it has no right to be there. A library is supposed to be a helpful place. Who would want to sit back and watch a racist movie? Who would want to have a little kid watching something sexual in a movie? Magazines can even develop a lot of problems. Music can be straight offensive.  If a young adult or a child reads or watches a movie that is racist, it teaches them bad things. Racism is a very hurtful thing. What you see or read can really have an effect on you. You may not realize that it is wrong. It could have you saying hurtful things to a different race. If a person isn't racist and they see something that is, it could offend them. They may feel like they are 'cool'. They go out and say racist things. It makes them feel good. Later on they feel guilty. All because of a movie or book. If a movie is making fun of your race, it hurts. Being made fun of hurts. It is technically bullying. Bullying can lead to suicide. Who cares if someone is black or white? We are all the same deep down inside. Movies like this should be banned from public libraries.  Movies today can have pretty much anything they want in them. Sex, drugs, cursing, etc. Kids can get by with watching them without anyone saying anything. The librarian just swipes your card, then you have the movie. They may not know right from wrong. If they see someone doing drugs or having sex, they might think that it is cool. They may go out and do it. We do not need movies like this in our public library. We should make it a lot harder for kids to try to get movies like this. These movies can also offend us. Make us feel uncool. Make us feel like we have to go out and try it.  In magazines today, they make everyone look so perfect. These people can offend you. Young teenage girls or even boys are the ones mostly looking at magazines. If you see someone in a magazine, you begin to want to look like them. You see how skinny they are. They are tan. They have perfect skin. It's normal for someone to be jealous. We are only human. Sometimes these images get to us. We may starve ourselves to try to be skinny. That can be very dangerous to your health. These images knock our confidence down. In today's society, people strive for popularity. They want to look perfect. They want all the guys to stare. We use the girls in the magazine to help us know what we want to look like. You should love who you are and what you look like. You are unique. No one has to be skinny to be pretty. Magazines can be offensive.  In today's society music is horrible. Rap, country, or rock music. Some of the lyrics can really offend people. The words get in your head every time you hear the song. If you really take the time to look up lyrics to a song, you will realize that they will let you say anything. I can't name how many songs I know, just being a teenager, that make fun of something. For example, there is a song by the band XYZ. It is called 'I must be emo'. It makes fun of people who are unique in their own way. Some lines from the song are, 'I get depressed, I cut my wrists in every direction'. How can you make fun of someone who does self-harm? Depression and self-harm are a big thing in today's society. There is nothing funny about it. If someone who hurts themselves hears this, think of what could happen. It would really offend them! They could go and cut themselves even more. They could try suicide. In the song it also makes fun of gay people. It makes fun of the way 'emo' people look. 'I look like I am dead and dress like a homo', is another line from the song. I don't know about you but to me that would be terribly offensive! We need to get these types of songs out of our libraries.  We should have a say in what is in our public library. The library is meant to be a good place. Anyone can go there. We are all unique in our own ways. If something is offensive to you, you have the right to stand up for yourself. We need to make offensive books, movies, magazines, etc., harder to get a hold of.

Would you censor the Bible? I sure would not. The Bible is a very precious and religious part of our nation and history, but this is just a mere example. There are thousands of books, newspapers, articles, and media that play an important role in the history and the future of human beings. Common sense, also referred to as common knowledge, is something that we don't pick up out of nowhere. We absorb it through things we do, see, and read. For example, "The Giving Tree" is a book about a tree that meets a young boy and selflessly gives everything it has to make the boy happy. This story reflects that helping someone else is a key to life and that another's happiness is the true gift of life. Religion is often censored these days, but why? The Bible, for example, is just a book full of short stories that provide reminders of right and wrong, kindness and jealousy. It offers helpful advice, just like asking someone else for advice. While censorship can have its benefits, such as protecting children from adult content or maintaining national security, too much censorship can be harmful. Religious content and classic books that teach important life lessons should be preserved for future generations to come.

Shutting down libraries may be a drastic solution to the issue of inappropriate content in books, music, and movies, as mentioned in the original text. It is suggested that instead of completely closing libraries, creating separate sections for different age groups or genres could be a more practical approach. By segregating materials based on appropriateness, the risk of exposing children to unsuitable content can be minimized. Additionally, reeducating teenagers who may be influencing younger individuals with inappropriate language and behavior could help in promoting a more positive and respectful environment within libraries. Ultimately, it is important to consider alternative solutions before resorting to shutting down libraries entirely, as they serve as valuable resources for education and entertainment.

With the world's diverse cultures and beliefs, it is inevitable that some materials in libraries may be offensive to certain individuals. However, I believe that all types of content should be available in libraries to cater to a wide range of interests and perspectives. While some may find certain books or media offensive, it is important to remember that different works serve various purposes, such as entertainment, information, or persuasion. It is crucial for libraries to provide access to a variety of materials, even if they may not align with everyone's views. Additionally, individuals have the choice to avoid content that offends them and can request warnings or age restrictions on certain items. Ultimately, libraries play a vital role in providing knowledge and diverse perspectives to the public, and it is essential that they continue to offer a wide selection of materials for all individuals to explore and learn from.

As a place used to gain knowledge and wisdom, a library is a wonderful resource. Multiple varieties of books can be found at a local library from documentaries to science fiction or just fiction. The most amazing part of a library is the fact that one can choose what he or she reads. Yet if one man opposes the view in one book and believes a certain book should be removed from the library, then the freedom of choice is lost. The selection of reading should be open to every reader, and although some may disagree, heavy censorship of libraries is an unnecessary measure that constricts the ability to gain knowledge.  In today's society, many people differ in taste or genre. So much so, that at times it is hard to find a common ground in a large group setting. The library is a place where people should be able to enjoy their differences, reading different types of books spread across many shelves. Yet if one person dislikes a book, their opinion should not influence the removal of the book due to their preference. Author Katherine Paterson made a wise remark on the idea of censorship saying, 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-- that work I abhor-- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books.' If one person finds a work to be vulgar and believes it should be removed from the library, then what stops another person from removing a book that they dislike? If heavy censorship is allowed in libraries, then libraries will become diminished resources, only containing a few documents.  Still, censoring age-specific materials is necessary in libraries. Allowing a child to read or watch a movie or book that is inappropriate is an inexcusable action. Censoring books for children does not mean removal of said book though. Removing a book from the shelf of a library is just as wrong as allowing a child to read a book that is too mature for his or her age. Katherine Paterson stated, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But... then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' The censoring of books in a library cannot lead to the removal of books that have shaped our society and ideas, even if it is to protect a child. A medium must be found between true censorship and opinionated removal of books, due to one's beliefs. Doing so will not only help libraries but also society.  There are many different opinions in modern society, and due to the differences in beliefs and ideas, at times people will disagree. Yet it is important that people agree on allowing each other to have a choice. A very important choice that each individual makes on a daily basis is what to read. Libraries allow for people to make their choices and help to expand one's knowledge in the process. Literature, whether it is found in a library or at one's home, should never be cast out due to someone else's opinion. Censoring of libraries should be considered, but not at the expense of knowledge. Libraries should not be censored.

I believe that the idea of removing materials from the library is not a good one. Students rely on the library for important information for their reports and assignments. The library is a valuable resource for students to have access to a wide range of materials that can help them succeed in their classes. Additionally, the library can inspire students to explore new topics and expand their knowledge beyond the classroom. It is important to keep the library well-stocked with a variety of materials to support student learning and academic success. Ultimately, the library plays a crucial role in the education and development of students, and its resources should be preserved for the benefit of all.

It really doesn't matter to me because I only go to the library to get a book when my teacher at school makes me. A library should be able to put whatever they want out on a shelf because the library is divided up into sections for kids, young adults, and adults. If a person doesn't like what he or she sees on a shelf at a library, then they don't have to look at it or check it out. Just because one person doesn't like it doesn't mean someone else doesn't. Libraries don't make people look at or check out something they don't like, so why are people complaining about it? They are getting to check out books, movies, and music for free unless it becomes overdue. So people need to stop complaining about what the library has on their shelves.

In the @LOCATION1 @DATE1, there are numerous libraries that offer a wealth of information to the public. While this information opens up new opportunities for exploration and learning, there is also a concern about the potential negative impact of certain materials. Some content in libraries, such as books, movies, and other media, can be offensive or provocative, leading to harmful behaviors and attitudes in individuals. Therefore, the implementation of censorship in libraries is essential, especially in a diverse community like @LOCATION1.  The diverse population in @LOCATION1 means that what may not be offensive to one individual could be deeply offensive to another. Establishing censorship guidelines can help ensure that materials available in libraries are appropriate for the community. This can be achieved through creating separate sections for different age groups, providing knowledgeable assistance to help individuals navigate through the collection, and implementing screening processes for potentially harmful content.  Organizing libraries into sections based on the target audience allows for easier access to relevant materials while also preventing exposure to inappropriate content. For instance, having a children's section separate from adult materials can protect young readers from harmful or confusing information. Additionally, having knowledgeable staff available to assist patrons in finding suitable materials can further enhance the browsing experience and minimize the risk of encountering offensive content.  While censorship is important to maintain a safe and respectful library environment, it is also crucial to uphold the principle of freedom of speech. Individuals should have the right to access a wide range of materials, but measures should be in place to protect vulnerable groups, such as minors, from potentially harmful content. Ultimately, while censorship should be exercised within reason, everyone should have the freedom to choose what they read or view.  In conclusion, while libraries are invaluable sources of information and knowledge, the presence of offensive or provocative materials necessitates the need for censorship. By implementing appropriate guidelines and providing assistance to patrons, libraries can ensure a safe and enriching experience for all individuals in the community. Balancing freedom of speech with the responsibility to protect vulnerable populations is crucial in maintaining a harmonious and respectful library environment.

My opinion is that there should be some items being censored, but we don't want to punish everybody just by taking the books off of the shelf completely. If I was an adult, I would not want my child renting very graphic books, magazines, etc., but I wouldn't want to block his whole life. There can be different censorship on individual people too. An idea is to have a parent come in to decide what type of censorship you can put on a child by putting this on his or her library card.  The censorship would be a great way to help parents watch what their children are reading and watching. A good suggestion for this is what I just brought up, a personal censorship. This would keep the child from reading too graphic of novels for their age and it would not offense the parents. Also for the rated X magazines, movies, etc. I believe they shouldn't be taken off the shelf and just moved to a different area that is secluded.  The censorship on books can also be completely outrageous too. A lot of books have graphic parts in them but yet are also a great read and can have great morals to learn. Graphic parts of the books are like the graphic parts of our lives, it's going to happen no matter what and we can't get away from it. Let the child, teenager, or whoever it is read the book if they are mature enough to read this and don't take it off the shelf.  Another point to get across is the library is also censored a little bit too. The libraries are organized into sections by categories of books. Some books are categorized by the age level they are intended for. Once you get into the actual novels, it isn't much like this but for younger ages this is the case, which people can see it work as a censor in ways. When you become to the higher reading level, you are most likely going to be old and mature enough to pick what you think is right to read and what is not.  With all this being said, there really doesn't need much censorship in libraries. Unless you have the personal censorship on the younger ones. There is no need to punish the ones that did absolutely nothing wrong to the community and to others when all they want to do is to simply check out items at the library.

Everywhere a person goes, there is always a media source. Media can range from newspapers, to magazines, to the radio, and through the television. Media is used to inform citizens of occurring events and to provide entertainment. Many media materials contain photos, language, and etc. that can be considered offensive to citizens. Media materials should not be taken off the shelf if they are found offensive. In the United States, citizens have the freedom of speech. With censorship, authors, directors, singers and other producers are deprived of this right. If the government enforces the censorship law, people can not say what they want to or how they truly feel about a subject. Also with censorship, citizens are neglected of their right to watch and listen to what they choose to. Not everyone has the same opinion about what should and should not be blocked out of everyday media materials. Parents and certain groups have a huge effect on the production of censorship. Parents and these groups complain that books, television, and other media materials are offensive and otherwise 'harmful' to their child, and that they should be removed from the media sources. I believe that if a parent has a concern with what his/her child is viewing, then they should take matters into their own hands by not letting the child view this material instead of having it censored so the rest of the people can not watch it. Parents and certain groups should not have the rest of the world be neglected of their choice to view these certain programs and read certain things. Censorship can include anything from photos, to language, to news reports. People who believe that offensive material should be blocked out for young viewers and other people do not understand that at some point in a person's life they will encounter these materials. Sometimes, in order to understand a major world event, such as the death of Martin Luther King Jr., have to understand the violence and forces that were used. If this material is taken offensively, no citizen will truly understand the real story and background of world-wide events. Censorship effects everyone, from a small child to a grown adult. It can deprive people of certain knowledge and understanding of certain concepts. Censorship should not be allowed in the United States and other areas of the world due to the lack of a citizen's freedom of speech and the rights that we as citizens hold.

I believe that certain materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, and other things can be removed from the shelf. However, I think that @CAPS1 should be removed from the shelf when cleaning up. Other times, I don't believe they should be removed unless necessary. As a responsible individual, I always prioritize completing the chores assigned to me by my parents before engaging in other activities. While removing items from a shelf is not necessarily a bad thing, it should only be done when required, such as when the shelf is full and needs organizing. Overall, I believe in maintaining good behavior and being obedient, and I do not see the need to constantly remove things from a shelf unless it is necessary.

Should a library be able to remove a book or a movie from its shelves if someone happens to find it offensive? I believe that the answer to that question should be no. If a library decides to remove every offensive piece of literature or art in its possession, the shelves would be bare. Everyone has their own opinions, and what one person finds offensive, another may find beautiful. Offensive pieces of literature and art often evoke strong emotions and make people think. With the diverse society and culture today, someone is bound to be offended by something every day. Censorship is not the solution, as there is no way to avoid offending people entirely. Libraries should not waste their time on censorship, as someone will always find something that bothers them. Just because something is offensive to someone does not make it wrong, and depriving others of the chance to read or see it is not justified. Offensiveness is subjective, and libraries should maintain their collection without unnecessary censorship.

Everyone has their favorite music they listen to or their favorite book to read even if it does offend a certain group or type of people. People do still read or listen to it. And the people who write the books or write the lyrics for a song are just expressing themselves. I believe that anything offensive shouldn't be censored because it's a way that people can express themselves.  I listen to music all the time as long as I like the way it sounds. It doesn't really matter to me what the lyrics say and I'm pretty sure that goes for a lot of people. But there are some songs out there that people feel they can relate to so they actually listen to what the song is saying.  I don't really read a lot because I'm picky about the books that I do read. That's not the case for everyone though. A lot of people like to read because it makes them feel like the book takes them to a different world. It's an escape for them from everyday life. Which I can understand why someone would want to escape.  Movies are like books but you get a visual of what's going on. Which makes it more entertaining than a book. So more people would rather watch a movie. But the movies don't have all the details that the book has so the books are more fulfilling. And just because someone doesn't like a movie doesn't mean that there isn't someone out there who does because there is.  So my conclusion is that everyone is different they like different things and dislike different things. But just because someone doesn't like something doesn't mean that someone else won't like it. Like I said everyone is different. So why can't the materials they read or watch be different as well?

As a teenager, I am exploring ways to grow and express myself in life. I believe that materials like books, music, and movies should not be censored in libraries. While younger children should be shielded from violent content, high schoolers and older individuals should have the freedom to choose what they read or listen to. Censoring books and music limits our access to diverse perspectives and experiences. What may be offensive to some can be enlightening to others. It is essential for libraries to respect individual choice and not impose restrictions on content. In conclusion, censorship should be limited to materials that are deemed inappropriate for younger audiences, allowing older individuals to make their own decisions about the media they consume.

I believe that certain materials should not be removed from the shelves in a library. Libraries are meant to provide people with the varieties of media that they need. This action will pose three things: business loss, inconvenience, and a narrowing of people's book selections.  The first reason why libraries should not be censored is so they will not lose business. Just like any other industry, libraries need people to use their multimedia materials, such as books, magazines, music, etc. so they stay in business. The purpose many people go to the library is to get certain magazines, or movies, and so forth, and to get rid of certain movies and/or magazines is getting rid of certain customers. Another reason is the loss of business will lead to loss in customers, and if there are no customers to check out multimedia materials, the library will be closed down. No one wants their library to be closed, so libraries should not be censored.  Also, parents, instead of having an entire library censored, censor what children get from libraries. One way is to get the local libraries to participate in putting restrictions on the cards of young children. For example, if a thirteen year-old child wants to check-out a movie that is rated R they would not be able to. The restriction on their card could be to PG-13, or G movies. Another way is to have an adult monitor what the child gets from the library. For example, if a thirteen year-old child wants to get R movies, only allow them to get like one at a time. This will lower the risk of offending a parent or guardian.  Finally, there would be nothing left in the libraries. One reason is that out of all the books in the library, I'm sure at least one person is offended by each one. Does this mean that every library should close its doors? No, of course not, this just means that if something offends someone from their local library, stay away from it. Don't check out that book, movie, magazine, etc. A second reason is do not go to that library if the material in it is offensive to people's beliefs or religion. Libraries offer many things to help people in enriching their knowledge about a certain belief, so they should not be censored.  Sometimes what is considered offensive to one person, is essential to another. In every book of every library, there is something that people most likely think should be censored. But they must come to understand that those same books help people tremendously. Those same books transform lives, and are read to improve their understanding of something. So never will I think that the library should be censored.

Freedom to choose is a fundamental right that everyone should have, including the freedom to choose what type of clothes to wear and what books to read. Censorship in libraries should not be allowed because it restricts this freedom of choice. Instead of censoring books, there are alternative ways to prevent children from accessing inappropriate content, such as parental guidance and supervision. Adults, especially those over the age of eighteen, should have the autonomy to decide what they want to read or watch. Parents can play a crucial role in monitoring and guiding their children's reading choices. Additionally, offensive and inappropriate content exists in various forms beyond books, such as television shows and online content. It is essential to recognize that censorship in libraries is not the solution to protecting individuals from potentially offensive material. People should have the freedom to make their own choices and decisions regarding the content they engage with, without unnecessary restrictions. Ultimately, censorship should not dictate what individuals can or cannot access in libraries, as everyone deserves the right to exercise their freedom of choice.

These days, libraries offer a wide range of media beyond books, including music, movies, and magazines. Some may argue that certain materials should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. However, I believe that such censorship is unnecessary. Children will eventually come across these offensive materials in one way or another as they grow up. Removing them from libraries would only limit access to information and knowledge. As Katherine Paterson, the author, pointed out, if one person has the right to remove a book they find offensive, then everyone else would have the same right, leading to the removal of many more materials. This would defeat the purpose of libraries, which is to provide access to a wide range of information. In conclusion, offensive materials should not be removed from library shelves as children will inevitably encounter them as they mature, and censorship would only hinder access to knowledge.

Should certain materials on shelves that are offensive be removed from shelves? I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., that are offensive to people should not be removed from shelves. These materials are taken in perspective by all different kinds of people.  Offensive materials should not be taken off of shelves because something that is offensive to one person may not be offensive to another person. People take things differently than other people might. For example, a lady might find a book to be disturbing or offensive, while the man next to her can find that same book interesting and useful to him. Not one person is the same so not everybody will take offense to the same thing.  I also believe that if someone does not like the object that they are offended by then they do not have to look, purchase, or give attention to that object that is there on the shelf. He or she is not forced to buy, read, or watch what is offending them. The material that is offending that person is not purposely put there to offend them, it is there for people who are interested in it so that they can enjoy themselves in whatever it is that they might be doing.  Therefore, I do not think that materials that are offensive should be taken off of shelves. People have the right to things that they enjoy. A material should not be taken off of a shelf just because one person is offended by it. Different people have their own perspective of things and opinion of how things should be.

The thought that Katherine Paterson had in her quote is quite understandable. If we were to censor books then there would be nothing to read in libraries. If you really tried, in every book you could find something offensive. I somewhat agree with her; however, I do believe there should be rules on where books are located.  Books are meant to be read and taking them away would be horrible for every book-loving person in this world. There are some things about where the books are to be found in the library that is up for debate. Personally, I believe the children's books should be on the opposite side of the building from the adult books and other reading material. In doing this, you, for the most part, prevent the children from entering an area that is not age-appropriate.  Teenage reading material should be separate from both children's books and adult reading material. In this way, they are not around the material that is 'above their heads', so to speak. If this were done parents' minds could be put at rest for the time being. They would not have to worry about their child or teenager finding reading material that is inappropriate or offensive.  Books that some people find offensive should be categorized, such as 'Young Adult (YA)'. They should also be categorized as 'Fiction', 'Non-Fiction', or 'Other'. In doing this most times where someone would have been offended are prevented from happening. Although there will be times where people will still find those books, and may be offended, it is mandatory that we do our best to limit those times. All necessary precautions should be taken.  At the same time, we should not remove any books from the shelves that are offensive to some. In removing a book from a shelf we would be eliminating a piece of knowledge or even life-long lessons that are difficult to teach without experiencing them yourself. Books offer us as humans so much, from knowledge to entertainment to even a form of comfort. Books are important to everyone whether they realize it or not. We have much to learn from books and we have much to offer our future members of the human race through books.  I do support Katherine Paterson's belief in that removing books from libraries would destroy the purpose of having them around. At the same time, I believe there are ways to limit the times where people would be offended by something. Removing books would destroy countless years of knowledge, past thoughts, and past experiences. Books should never be removed from libraries just because they may be found inappropriate.

I don't believe that certain material should be taken out of our libraries. If they take the books that people get a learning expression off of then what does that leave us with. Everybody in life should have their own choices, we shouldn't limit them. It's all about making choices in life, people should get the right to read the books, magazines, etc. they want, without people looking down on them or thinking the material they receive is unnatural. What one person might think is not good to read, the next person might think the total opposite.  Music is a creative aspect in our world, just as every person you meet is not the same, so should music be. You can't have the same ideas when it comes to making your creative outlook on the music in your community, it's not going to turn out the same as everyone else's will. If that was the case, then the world would be one boring place to live in. I think that everyone has their own taste in music. If you're the right age and you're not hurting anybody, then what's the big problem in listening to the music that encourages you to become creative.  There are a lot of movies that some parents might think are not good for their kids to watch. I think that we shouldn't be so worried about what our kids are watching and more about what they are doing. I believe that every movie you watch has a secret point in it, in other words, the lesson learned in the story. Some solutions that happen in real life might be in a movie that's probably rated. I don't believe that we should focus on the rating of the movie, we should focus on the lesson the movie is teaching you.  The children in the world are going to have to make their own choices and find what they find interesting, so should we ban everything we think that's not. We need to let the children grow on their own and also learn on their own. We can't make somebody listen, read, or watch what we want them to.  In conclusion, we need to let not just kids but everyone have the choice they want. The world is changing every day, so we need to change our ideas with it.

When walking into the library and children are finding books, movies, and magazines they should not look at, it can be offensive. I believe that it is not the author's fault for the offensive language in their work. I can understand that parents can get upset if their child is reading a book they should not be looking at. My opinion is that students should be able to choose what they want to read, and if it is offensive to them, they should stop reading the book. Censorship in the library is to find books for everyone to read.  I think that they should not ban anything in the library because it can be used for something useful to the person. I find it hard to believe that libraries will remove every offensive book, movie, or music from shelves because the rating of the item can be horrible. I just don't think it should be a good idea for them to ban things from libraries if they need to use the information from the book. If it offends them, then they should not read the book and choose another book. Authors work too hard for writing their book and go through the publishing process.  My opinion is a no because I feel they should not remove items off shelves of the libraries because the content of the item is not appropriate for someone. My views can vary when I am older and have children of my own someday. But as of right now, I do not think they should remove items off shelves at libraries.

I do not believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. Parents play a crucial role in shaping the media consumption habits of their children, and they must take responsibility for what their children are exposed to. Blaming offensive content for negative influences on children overlooks the role of parental guidance and oversight. If parents are more mindful of the media their children consume, the impact of offensive materials can be mitigated. Ultimately, it is up to parents to make informed choices about what is appropriate for their children, rather than demanding the removal of offensive materials from public access.

I certainly don't believe books, magazines, etc.. should be taken off the shelves in libraries just because they're offensive to a certain amount of people. For one of the reasons are in the @CAPS1 @CAPS2 it states that you have the freedom of speech and when you write a book or an article in a magazine you are writing a story on whatever you want and if it is put on a shelf in the @CAPS1 place it should stay there. Also, just because it is offensive to one certain group or person doesn't give anybody the right to take something off the shelf in the library because the author is speaking what they want.   Also in magazines today there are many offensive things to certain people such as celebrities, sports stars, etc... but they don't go to the libraries and take them off the shelf. If you were one of those people that did take a book or magazine off the shelf I think you should ask other people what they think about that material, because some people @MONTH1 like it. Also if you keep taking all the books off the shelf what will we have to read and educate ourselves about today, and read stories that were told for generations? If you do see one of those reading materials and they are offensive to you just put it back up on the shelf; and act like you never picked it up.  In conclusion, it is important to respect the freedom of speech and the diverse viewpoints expressed in books and magazines. Removing materials from library shelves based on individual offense goes against the principles of intellectual freedom and limits access to valuable information and perspectives. It is essential to uphold the right to express varied opinions and allow readers to make their own choices about what they want to read.

I don't believe in censoring books or any form of media because everyone has different tastes and preferences. In my own experience, I was restricted from listening to the music I enjoyed by my foster parents who imposed their religious beliefs on me. This kind of strict control only leads to rebellion and stifles self-expression. All individuals should have the freedom to choose what they consume and express their own interests. It is important to respect people's preferences and allow them to be true to themselves without imposing restrictions. Everyone deserves the right to express themselves and enjoy what they like without judgment or interference.

One of the amendments in the Constitution of the United States is freedom of speech, which grants the right to express oneself as long as it does not infringe upon the rights of others. The issue of whether people should be allowed to censor books has been a contentious topic throughout history. Some argue that individuals should have the ability to censor materials they find offensive. However, if everyone had the power to censor books they disliked, there would be very few books left for people to enjoy. In our diverse society, literature has evolved to cater to various cultures, customs, and beliefs, allowing individuals to find works that resonate with them. Just as we are taught to accept and respect the differences of others in our daily lives, literature reflects this diversity. Despite ongoing debates, it is clear that differing opinions on book censorship will persist due to the uniqueness of individuals and their perspectives. In the end, it is essential to recognize and appreciate the diversity of thought and expression that enriches our society.

Censorship in libraries is a controversial topic with valid arguments on both sides. Some believe that censoring books limits freedom of choice and access to information, while others argue that certain materials may be inappropriate for certain age groups. It is essential for parents to monitor what their children are exposed to and make informed decisions about what they read or watch. Libraries can help by providing age recommendations for books and movies to guide parents in their choices. Ultimately, the responsibility lies with parents to ensure that their children are not exposed to offensive content. By working together, both libraries and parents can create a safe and enriching environment for young readers.

I think other materials in libraries such as music and art should stay active in public libraries or school libraries. They show symbolic meaning to the ever-changing world as we know it. People have different beliefs about anything, and it is essential to respect diverse opinions. It is crucial to remember the saying, ''if you don't have anything nice to say, then don't say anything at all.'' In my experience, access to a variety of reading materials in libraries has been essential for individuals to explore different perspectives and histories. Restricting certain materials can limit knowledge and understanding. It is vital to preserve history, even if it may be controversial or uncomfortable for some. I hope that this essay will encourage protesters to reconsider their stance and recognize the value of diversity in library collections. Let's continue to support access to a wide range of materials that contribute to a rich and informed society.

I believe that libraries should not censor their literature, as all media is a valuable source of knowledge waiting to be discovered. No individual or institution should have the authority to determine what is appropriate for the public to access. The right to choose what is suitable for oneself should rest with each person.   Throughout history, media in various forms such as books, music, movies, and magazines has served as a reservoir of information and lessons from the past. It reflects our triumphs and failures, guiding us towards a better future by reminding us of past mistakes. The vast array of media available today continues to offer valuable insights that we have yet to fully comprehend.  While some media may be deemed inappropriate by certain individuals, there is still much to be gained from it. What one person finds objectionable, another may find enlightening or informative. Those who are offended by certain content can simply choose to avoid it, rather than imposing restrictions on everyone else.  Media holds significant power and should not be subject to censorship. Its impact on society is profound, and attempting to conceal certain aspects of it only hinders our ability to learn and grow. We have only scratched the surface of what media can offer, and it would be a disservice to limit access to it. Let us embrace the diversity of media and the knowledge it brings, without imposing restrictions that inhibit our ability to explore and learn from it.

Do I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? No, it should not be removed. Katherine says, 'I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, that work I abhor.' First of all, she can have the right to do that but there are people who have a say in this. There are people who can read, listen, watch, and see what they like. Definitely, I really think that it should not be removed even though it doesn't have positive things.  Although it might offend some people, they have a choice whether they should see, watch, listen, and read it. Many people might agree with the author about what she thinks about this. Though, many people might go against it. One reason why I think that people should be allowed to see, watch, listen, and read whatever they would like to see, it's because it's their own choice. We make our own decisions whether people like it or not. Another reason would be because people would want to see the funny things that people invent that actually make the shows. Some people do not like to be bored of the same thing.  Katherine Paterson, the Author, is right in some ways. She wouldn't want her children to see things that are inappropriate. I have a daughter and I wouldn't want her to see things that are abhorrent. The last reason would be children should not be allowed to see inappropriate things until they are eighteen or older. These things can influence children very intensely.  Indeed, many people in this world are influenced by bad things. The author stated, 'then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else.' Right, she is meaning that we have a choice of what our children would like to see. For example, there is a magazine full of negative words and full of horrid stuff. Would you pull it out of the shelf for your child to not have a chance to see that? You should if you love your child even though it's your own choice. You would want the best for your child to not see, read, watch, and listen to things that are inappropriate.  In conclusion, this would be your choice. There will always be things in the world that you don't like. You cannot stop the terrible things from happening. In the libraries, there shouldn't be anything negative anyway because you never know what your child might be doing. Simply, teach your kid what is wrong and right. Finally, from what you experienced. Teach them the right things from the wrong things you learned so they wouldn't do the same mistake as you did.

I believe that all types of books should be available to all types of people. A library should never be intended for a certain group of readers. As far as I'm concerned, books are creativity in text-form. Creativity is a large part of life, and without it, we would all be the same. There is at least one book for every person in the world, and whether reading is a hobby or not does not matter, there is a book that will interest you.   It is not fair to everybody to take books off the shelves of a library due to 'offensive' content. With different personalities comes different writers. With different writers comes different books. With different books comes different readers. There are a lot of people out there who like to read. What are the people who like 'offensive' content going to do when these books are taken off the shelves?   Books are written for two reasons: allowing authors to express themselves and giving readers the chance to explore and relate to the imaginations of authors. I think that if a writer has the ability to put whatever he/she wants in a book, that book should be available to anyone and everyone.

In my opinion, I believe that books, music, movies, magazines, etc., are at the library for a reason. The reason being if we wanted to check out a movie and everywhere else was too expensive to get it, why wouldn't you just get it at the library if they had it. Most libraries that I've gone to have certain sections for adults and children. That means there would be appropriate things for little children to read in the section that they have been given. If children under age were to wander off into the adult section and saw something inappropriate, that would be their fault, not the library's.  If every time a child or someone under age took a book offensive, I believe that the libraries wouldn't have as much of books in their buildings that grown-ups would like to read. Of course, I'm not trying to say that there should be extremely inappropriate books wandering around in the library that small children should see. Adults have the right to have books that they would be interested in.  I believe that no material should be taken off the shelf just because one person found it offensive. If a person doesn't like the idea of the library not taking the material off, it's the person's personal problem. For example, there is this book called '@CAPS1' about a teenager who got into drugs and got pregnant at a young age. If somebody finds that offensive and asks for the book to be removed, then it's their loss.  If there were a book about how to murder somebody, then I would ask for that material to be taken off the shelf immediately. However, no library in this entire world would have that kind of stuff up, so why worry about it? In conclusion, that is my opinion on this matter.

Offensive material should not be removed from shelves. Books cover a wide range of topics, and everyone can be offended by something. If we start removing books that some find offensive, then there would be very few books left for people to read.   @PERSON1 faced a similar situation with his music lyrics in front of Congress, leading to the creation of the '@CAPS1' sticker for albums with offensive content. Censoring books would hide the thoughts, ideas, and meanings behind the author's writing.   Parents concerned about their children reading offensive material should engage in conversations about the book's context to address their worries. Children go through various stages of growth, learning from both positive and negative sources, and it is the responsibility of parents to guide them in distinguishing between truth and falsehood.   My grandmother once shared a memory of me learning to read from an adult magazine.
