That doesn't mean these books need to be taken out of the library. Children should be restricted from viewing the explicit materials though. Having a section in the library from which only adults can rent the items, would remove this problem. People under @NUM1 should also be restrained from looking through these materials. Having a childrens' section in the libray would also keep them away from adult materials. The library needs to make itself user friendly.   People who frequent the library often pick up a book, not knowing what it holds. When inappropriate material is inside a child might innocently read into or see something they are not supposed to. Parents should not have to worry about their kids seeing inappropriate pictures or text. They should feel safe letting their children look through all the books at the library. Library workers should also make sure the adult materials stay in the hands of adults. Allowing children and their parents to feel safe and welcome is an important part of the library.   Taking adult materials out of the library is not a good idea. It would lower its popularity. Everyone has different interests, and they want to research them at the library. The safety of children is also important. Making sure children cannot reach these materials is a concern. Having separate adult and children sections could solve this problem. Not allowing anyone under @NUM1 to check out explicit materials would also help. Keeping the library full of information but still safe for children is the ideal situation.

I believe that not all books should be banned, but some books should. For example, there are many good books that are banned because they may contain a little bit of cussing, but I believe that is acceptable since children are exposed to similar language through other mediums. However, books that promote hate against other races or religions should definitely be banned.  For instance, I once encountered a banned book called The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain. While this book may contain some controversial themes such as a rebellious protagonist and smoking, it is not as harmful as the negative portrayal of certain groups. On the other hand, a book discussing historical perspectives on slavery should be allowed as it provides insight into different beliefs of the time.  In conclusion, instead of banning books based on language or events that may not align with personal views, the focus should be on the message that the book is trying to convey. It is important to consider the impact and implications of the content rather than simply censoring based on personal preferences. By reevaluating the criteria for banning books, we can ensure a more open and diverse literary environment.

Whenever you go these days, you see violence in every store around the world. Children growing up in this environment are exposed to negative influences, and many thrive off the offensive materials that are readily available. I believe that offensive products should be restricted to stores for adults aged twenty-one and older to prevent young people from being exposed to harmful content. For example, magazines with inappropriate content should not be sold in bookstores, which are intended for books. It is important to protect young minds from being influenced by offensive material, as they may grow up thinking such behavior is acceptable.   As a child, I would often visit bookstores with my mom and pick up any book that caught my eye. However, my mom would sometimes take the book away if it was deemed offensive. In today's society, children are growing up too quickly and should be allowed to enjoy their childhood by reading age-appropriate books. While older students may not be as interested in reading, it is crucial to protect younger children in elementary school who are eager to learn.  Ultimately, the decision to publish offensive material often comes down to profit. Regardless of the content, companies and authors prioritize making money. However, it is essential to consider the impact these materials have on young, impressionable minds. By restricting access to offensive content and promoting age-appropriate reading materials, we can help shape a more positive and healthy environment for our children.

There are many different topics that could be offensive, it just depends on the person's own personal judgment. In my opinion, I do not believe that materials should be removed because not everyone has the same views or opinions. If someone comes from a different country or even a different religion, topics like abortion and racism are going to be viewed very differently. I think having a variety of topics will help expand different thoughts and make the readers of the material see things in a different way.  When I am older and if one of my elementary children were to bring home a book over abortion, I would be concerned. Honestly though, I do not believe schools would let inappropriate topics for younger children read books like that. It is a little bit different with a high school student though. Their maturity level is going to be mature enough to handle the material and I do not think it is right for schools to remove something that could actually help someone.  Libraries should be able to have a variety of different books. I am not saying, however, that they should have books on murder and saying it is alright, but books that will help expand the children's minds. It could even change their lives. Some books are a sensitive topic but who has the right to tell someone something they should believe? It would mean more to someone if they found their own way and beliefs than having people tell them what they should and should not do or believe in.  Racism, abortion, child abuse, unwinding your children, whatever the case may be, some people will support it and some will not. I think it is time for children around the world to discover for themselves what they truly believe in, and taking 'offensive' material from libraries is not going to help. My opinion on this topic is strongly advising to leave the material alone because for there to be a book about it, the author had to have had a reason to write it, and honestly, what is better for the future than a generation of children grounded in their own true beliefs.

Since the beginning of time, there has always been controversy surrounding media that some find offensive. Books, movies, and music have all faced scrutiny, leading to censorship in some cases. However, I believe that censorship in media is unnecessary. Instead of banning materials, they should be properly labeled or described to inform consumers of potentially offensive content. Everyone has different tastes and sensibilities, and it's important to allow for diverse expressions in media.   The Bible, for example, is a widely challenged book that continues to spark debates across different cultures and religions. Despite its controversial nature, it remains in print, highlighting the importance of free expression. By allowing for a variety of viewpoints and ideas in media, we encourage critical thinking and open dialogue among individuals.   While there are already measures in place such as parental advisories and content ratings, these should not limit access to different perspectives. Freedom of thought is a valuable asset that should be protected, as it allows for personal growth and understanding. Let media remain free so that people from all walks of life can explore new ideas and form their own opinions. Censorship may be prevalent, but it is up to individuals to challenge it and advocate for a more open and inclusive media landscape. In the end, embracing diverse viewpoints in media leads to a richer and more vibrant society.

Books, music, movies, and magazines in libraries should consist of appropriate material, but there can be value in having some offensive literature available for those who wish to learn from it. However, there should be an age limit for checking out such items to ensure they are accessed responsibly. It is important to maintain a balance when it comes to the content available in libraries. While some may find certain materials offensive, others may see them as valuable sources of information and education. By providing access to a range of materials, including those that some may deem offensive, libraries can serve as a place for learning and exploration. It is essential to have a designated section for offensive material and enforce age restrictions to ensure responsible consumption. Ultimately, the presence of offensive material in libraries can contribute to a well-rounded and enriching experience for patrons seeking diverse perspectives and knowledge.

I am not in agreement because young children should not be exposed to certain offensive books. However, I believe that books should not be removed or censored in the libraries. It is important to protect children from inappropriate content, but censoring books can be a slippery slope towards limiting freedom of expression. Instead of removing books, parents and caregivers can guide children towards age-appropriate reading materials and have open discussions about the content they encounter. By promoting critical thinking and responsible reading habits, we can empower children to navigate the literary world while respecting diverse perspectives and ideas. Ultimately, education and communication are key in shaping young minds and fostering a healthy relationship with literature.

I think that censorship in libraries should definitely be relevant. For example, requiring ID to check out adult books can help prevent children from accessing inappropriate material. Public libraries should adhere to state and city laws to ensure that adult content is not shown to children. In some libraries, manga and anime books contain graphic content that may not be suitable for younger audiences, despite being rated for ages 18 and up. Making changes to the library system to implement a censorship system can help protect children from accessing adult material. Ultimately, it is up to the individual libraries to decide if they want to make these changes.

I do not believe that materials in libraries should be censored. Parents should take responsibility for monitoring what their children are reading or listening to, rather than restricting access for everyone. Libraries cater to people of all ages and should not be limited to only children. Censoring library materials would alienate many adults and diminish the value of the library as a resource for the community. It is the role of parents to guide their children in making appropriate choices, rather than imposing restrictions on everyone. Libraries should continue to provide a wide range of materials for people of all ages, and parents should be proactive in teaching their children about what is acceptable for them to access.

Censoring books in libraries because a certain group of people finds them offensive is unfair. A diverse library should cater to people of different backgrounds. A compromise can be reached by regulating books with age limits based on content and maturity level. For example, books with mature content can be labeled and placed away from young readers' books. Censorship is not the solution, as it limits diversity in library materials. Just like movies have ratings, books can have age-appropriate labels to guide readers. People have the right to choose what they read, but age-appropriate labeling ensures that everyone can access a variety of materials. Ultimately, a balanced approach can allow for freedom of choice while considering the sensitivities of different readers.

I believe that some products should be removed from shelves, especially those that promote harmful behavior like drug and alcohol use. These products can influence young minds in a negative way and lead to serious consequences. Additionally, songs with inappropriate lyrics should not be played as they can influence children and lead to disciplinary issues. Magazines with explicit content should also be restricted to prevent children from accessing them. It is essential for parents to be mindful of what their children are exposed to and to ensure that inappropriate content is not easily accessible. Ultimately, the well-being and safety of individuals and families should take precedence over profit-driven motives in the marketplace.

Do you think books, music, movies, magazines, etc. that could be offensive should or should not be pulled off the shelves? I believe they shouldn't. All kinds of people buy books or movies and they all have different types they like. Companies that manufacture books, movies, music, and magazines would be losing out on money if people can't find something they like, and if they don't have the money to make whatever it is they make, then they will go out of business. Then you might be out of luck for what you are looking for. All kinds of people buy things that they like. How would you like it if your favorite candy was taken off the shelves because it offended people? Well, that's how they feel when that happens to them. What would be put in their places? Stores have to have something to fill the shelves. Would they put more candy to make the world fat? If you come across something you think is offensive, just don't pay attention to it. Others may like it like you like your favorite candy. We have a great number of other things you can pick from.

A curious child goes into the library for the first time to find a story to read. Yet, when she goes to the children's section, the book she wants is not allowed in this library because it is said to promote certain ideals to children. The child goes to her older sister for help to find a different book. The older sister is too busy looking for her own book. She had walked into the library looking to find answers to her questions over a liberal topic. She can't find the book she wants; the library has censored it.  Why would we censor libraries if we have the freedom of the press and the freedom of speech? It is not right to censor libraries because that is restricting what is allowed to be read, which is taking away part of our freedom. The press is allowed to print anything, and we the people read it. Will that be the next thing that is censored? A book is just like the newspaper; it is relaying a story to entertain the audience that is reading it.  By censoring libraries, that is taking away the freedom of speech. Writing is a way to express yourself. Authors share their expressions through writing, hoping they can touch someone else's life and be of some assistance. Whether the book helps its reader to escape a horrendous day or to answer the questions of a curious teenager. I use books daily to escape the stresses of life; the Harry Potter series gave me something to do and allowed me to use my imagination and mind. I could escape into another world and leave my chores behind me.  Some may say that offensive things should be censored. In our culture, the slightest thing can be called 'offensive' now. If we never learn about these 'offensive' things, how would we understand history? There will always be rude things that have been said, but we should be exposed to them so we can learn from it. By censoring these items, we will never learn, and neither will our children about other cultures, history, or liberal ideas.  Instead of censoring items, there is another solution. Make certain items restricted and red flagged. If certain items become restricted; it would mean that people over a certain age are allowed to read them. By doing this, a child's mind would not be polluted, but we could still be exposed to different ideas and learn from them. If there was a system to red flag an item, this would allow the reader to know that this item contains what could be considered offensive material so they do not have to expose themselves to it if they did not want to, but others could.  In conclusion, censoring libraries is a bad idea. It takes away our freedom of the press and speech. We are also making ourselves ignorant this way. If we put out a warning system, it is fair to everyone. The 'offensive' material can stay in the libraries but people will know ahead of time what they are being exposed to and what their children are too.

I believe that no source of knowledge should be removed from library shelves just because some people find it offensive. What one person finds offensive, another may find reasonable. Censoring books based on individual sensitivities limits access to diverse perspectives and important information. Even if a book contains racist or sexist content, it can still provide valuable insights and provoke critical thinking. Reading controversial books can be thought-provoking and lead to personal growth. Libraries should remain open spaces where people have the freedom to choose what they read. It is essential to preserve access to a wide range of literature, including books that may challenge or discomfort some readers. Ultimately, the decision to read a book should be left to the individual, not dictated by the opinions of a few.

I believe that things should not be taken off the shelves just because a few people are offended. While some individuals may find certain content offensive, there are others who appreciate it. Removing items based on the feelings of a minority can limit the choices available to the majority. It is important to consider the overall impact and necessity of removing something before taking action. Offensiveness is subjective, and individuals have the option to avoid what they find offensive. Therefore, removal should only occur when there is a valid reason, such as preventing harm or legal issues. It is essential to strike a balance between respecting individuals' feelings and maintaining freedom of expression.

I believe that books, music, movies, magazines, and other forms of entertainment are valuable tools that bring joy and learning to people of all ages. While some may find certain materials offensive, it is important to remember that there are plenty of other options to choose from. These materials are not meant to gather dust on a shelf but to be utilized for education and enjoyment.   Children, teenagers, and adults alike benefit from the knowledge and character development that can be gained from these sources. It is crucial to understand that everyone has the right to their own opinion, but attempting to censor or remove these tools from our communities sets a dangerous precedent. If we allow one form of censorship, it could lead to a slippery slope of restrictions on other forms of expression.   In the end, it is essential to embrace the diversity of opinions and perspectives that these materials offer. They have the power to enrich our lives and contribute to a more well-rounded and informed society. Let's not stifle creativity and learning by restricting access to the tools that have the potential to shape our world for the better.

I believe that materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves just because they are found offensive. Everyone has different tastes and preferences, and what may offend one person may be enjoyable to another. It is important to remember that these forms of entertainment are a reflection of reality, and removing them would limit freedom of speech and artistic expression. People should have the autonomy to choose what they want to engage with, and if something offends them, they can simply choose to avoid it. It is not fair to impose one's views on others and restrict access to creative works that may hold value or meaning for different individuals. Ultimately, it is important to respect diverse perspectives and allow for a variety of content to be available for those who appreciate it.

In this world, there are various materials that may not be suitable for individuals to consume, such as books, music, movies, etc. While some may argue that everyone has the right to choose what they read, watch, or listen to, I believe that certain materials are not appropriately rated for different age groups. Some materials should be restricted from minors, some from children, and some from the general population.  For instance, some movies may have excessive violence or explicit language, which may not be suitable for younger audiences. The current ratings may not accurately reflect the content, leading to exposure to inappropriate material. This can contribute to behavioral issues in children, as they may mimic what they see without understanding the consequences.  Parents should be vigilant about the content their children are exposed to and advocate for stricter regulations on offensive materials. By banning certain materials from minors, we can help protect them from negative influences and promote a healthier environment for their development.  Moreover, there are instances where materials are not suitable for any age group due to their offensive nature. Engaging with such content can have a detrimental impact on individuals, leading to desensitization to violence or inappropriate behavior. It is essential to recognize the harmful effects of such materials and take measures to restrict their access to the general public.  Ultimately, by being mindful of the content we consume and advocating for stricter regulations on offensive materials, we can create a safer and more positive environment for everyone. Banning certain materials from minors, children, and the general population is a necessary step towards fostering a society that upholds values of respect and decency.

A place filled with knowledge should provide access to a wide range of information, including news shaping the world today and historical content. Libraries offer a diverse collection of books, magazines, movies, and sometimes music, catering to various interests and learning needs. While libraries aim to educate and inform, it is essential to consider the presence of mature content and profanity in some materials.   Individuals, regardless of age, benefit from understanding past events and staying informed about current affairs to prevent historical mistakes from recurring and to make informed decisions. Libraries can provide signage or labels to indicate the content of specific sections, allowing visitors to choose their reading materials based on personal preferences. Ultimately, libraries should uphold the principle of providing unrestricted access to information, allowing individuals to expand their knowledge without censorship. The decision to visit a library and engage with its resources remains a personal choice, guided by the pursuit of knowledge and information.

I think that your parents should have to sign a piece of paper saying that it is okay or not okay for the person to go to that side of the library. It is up to the parents and the way their kids will handle it. On one side of the library, it would be more geared towards a more mature audience, with no pornographic material, of course, but content that wouldn't be considered appropriate for children. Kids fifteen and older would understand. They might also have to have an adult with them. On the other side of the library, it would be more of a children's area with child stories targeted for kids aged fourteen and younger. There would have to be someone at the dividing line checking the pass that says it's okay or not. It would be a little difficult but would satisfy both parties. It is up to the parent to decide if it is okay for their children to read certain content of language and description. The child must be at least fourteen in order to get a pass from the parent though. I definitely agree with Katherine Paterson; eventually, your kids will find out about all those things. I would rather have my kids learn from a book and ask me than find out on the streets where they could end up getting hurt or in trouble with the law, or even going to a party and ending up doing something that might harm them.

Do your rights end where mine begin? In such a diverse society, clashing opinions are unavoidable. Does that mean another human's rights should be abused because we don't agree with their practices, beliefs, or lifestyle? Everyone in this world is entitled to their own opinion. What is wrong to some people may be right to others. For example, one family may view their children using curse words as offensive while another may see no problem. Diversity in beliefs does not mean that it is acceptable to censor society from cursing, religion, or violence discussed in published works. These concepts exist in the world and censoring them will not make them disappear. It is understood that there is both bad and good in the world, and pulling materials from the shelves of libraries will not change that. Censoring books, magazines, music, and other media is denying someone the ability to see ideas from all points of view. Whether or not you prevent a young child from seeing all perspectives does not mean the bad and good do not exist. The saying 'one year older, one year wiser' can refer to the acknowledgment of different ideas and opinions. As a child grows, he will learn more about the materials that were censored. In some cases, such as in the classroom, your rights do end where mine begin. When it comes to learning about the beauty of diversity, everyone is able to choose what they pick from the shelf. The definition of 'offensive material' is simply a matter of opinion.

I do not think that certain materials such as books, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves. While some content may not be suitable for young children, it is important to allow access to a variety of materials for different age groups. Restricting access based on age appropriateness and obtaining parental permission for certain materials can be a better approach. This way, children can still explore a wide range of topics and interests while ensuring they are exposed to content that is suitable for their age. Removing these materials entirely could limit children's exposure to diverse perspectives and ideas found in literature and media. Therefore, it is important to strike a balance between providing access to a variety of materials and ensuring that children are exposed to age-appropriate content.

Do you believe that certain books, movies, or magazines should be taken off the shelf in a library due to censorship? There are many times when you hear a parent tell their child not to look at that magazine because they don't want them to see the vulgar things on the inside. I've heard parents tell their children not to ever watch that movie because it'll show things that they don't need to be seeing. Almost every day we're put in situations like these, not knowing whether we should pick up the magazine or just leave it on the shelf. In my opinion, I believe that libraries should remove anything vulgar from the shelves. Kids are encouraged to go to the library as much as possible, but not if there is vulgar things on the shelves.  Kids are told many times a week by their parents, teachers, and other adults to go the library. They can work on their homework, read a book, or do some studying for school. When they get distracted from finding the book they want with a book that has vulgar things in it, they're going to be curious. The main reason I disagree with having vulgar things on the shelves is because of young children. The last thing they need to be looking at is something that isn't appropriate for their age. It's hard for a child to turn down a movie or magazine they've never seen or looked at before.  In most libraries the adult section is separated from the children's section. This doesn't mean that a child can't overhear something that the adults are listening to or watching. The children's section is made for fairy tale stories and kid movies, but when the adult section has things going on over there that aren't the most appropriate then kids can overhear. If children and adults are going to be in the same library then I think they should make it completely impossible for children to veer over there and see what's new on that side of the library.  Another reason I think libraries should censor themselves more is because of teenagers in the community. After school hours, a lot of teenagers in our community enjoy going to the library. If this is such a good environment for teenagers to be then why are they able to download bad music off of the internet?  Some teenagers listen to bad music with cursing, vulgar language, and much more. Libraries should make it impossible for teenagers to do this. If they want to download bad music then they need to do it somewhere else where youngsters can't get ahold of any of it.  My last argument for this is a heads up for the parents. Parents should check out what stuff their kids are looking at when they go to the library. You might not think your child would look at something with vulgar things, but sometimes, they're curious. All children are and it's human nature to be curious. I, myself, would go with my child a few times just to see what's in the library and tell them not to take things off the shelves that look bad.  Some libraries can't completely fix everything. They can't take every bad or vulgar thing off of the shelves. In the quote it says, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.', I can think of books and magazines that I would never want any child to look at, especially at a young age. Libraries need to be more interested in taking vulgar things off the shelves so that younger children cannot get ahold of. It's one thing for a child to see a book or magazine that isn't necessarily appropriate, but in a library it's a completely different story.

There are certain books that no child should ever read, but in some libraries, they don't seem to mind what is on their shelves. They are more focused on the fact that a child is reading, regardless of the content. Even though there are designated kid sections in libraries, children can still easily access books with inappropriate language.   I recall my own experiences of finding books with curse words when I was younger, and how we found it amusing to read and repeat them. It was even common for teachers to read books with curse words to us, eliciting laughter from the students. However, if we were to use those words outside of the context of reading, we would be reprimanded.  While some may find it acceptable for books to contain curse words for older children, elementary school-aged kids should not be exposed to such language. These books are intended for adults, as some stories may benefit from the use of curse words to enhance the narrative. Despite my parents' disapproval of me bringing home books with inappropriate language, they understood that I would inevitably encounter such words as I grew older.  In conclusion, books containing curse words should not be readily available to young children. It is important to consider the appropriateness of the content being consumed by children to ensure their language development and moral values are not negatively impacted.

Billions of books are circulated among shelves daily, encompassing a wide range of genres and themes. Authors from all corners of the globe contribute their unique perspectives and stories, catering to diverse audiences. With the fundamental right to freedom of speech, writers have the liberty to explore endless narrative possibilities.  Libraries serve as vast repositories of knowledge and imagination, housing books of varying genres, styles, and covers. Categorizing books based on their content is crucial for organization, but the idea of censorship should not impede the availability of diverse literary works. Each reader has their own preferences, and restricting access to certain materials based on subjective judgments can hinder the enjoyment and intellectual growth of individuals.  While concerns about inappropriate content for young readers are valid, implementing a rating system similar to that of movies could offer a compromise. By creating designated sections for mature content, such as an @CAPS1 @NUM1 cubicle, libraries can provide a solution without resorting to outright censorship. Ultimately, parental guidance plays a crucial role in guiding young readers towards age-appropriate material.  Censorship, whether applied to books, music, or other forms of media, undermines the creative freedom of artists and limits the diversity of thought and expression. Rather than imposing restrictions on content, a more nuanced approach that considers individual preferences and the role of parental supervision is essential. Allowing for a variety of voices and perspectives to be heard enriches the literary landscape and fosters a culture of open-mindedness and critical thinking. In the realm of literature, as in all forms of art, diversity and freedom of expression should be upheld as paramount values.

Censorship, or the ability to control what is seen or heard, is a term that is taken very differently from one person to the next. Music, if it is found offensive or inappropriate, can be censored or even banned from listening. Some magazines that are found at grocery stores, libraries, and sometimes even airports, have censored covers on the front to visually censor the front page of the magazine. Movies are given ratings based on their level of explicit material, and when shown on basic cable, they sometimes can have either silenced words, or more appropriate words brought in to fit the dialogue in the movie. Books, although very rarely, have been banned from libraries and censored from the entire world. Some books have been previously censored, but became uncensored and brought back to libraries. In my opinion, censorship should not be based on a single person's view of the material, but rather on the viewpoint of the public. Growing up, my parents would watch carefully about what shows I watched, what music I listened to, or the types of magazines that I looked at.  When I was growing up, I loved to watch professional wrestling. I loved to watch big scary guys as tall as seven feet hitting each other with steel chairs, crashing each other into tables, or throwing each other off of twenty-foot steel cages. My brother and I used to have a favorite wrestler that we would root for every week, @PERSON1 @CAPS1 could frighten any other wrestler who stood in his way. My brother and I loved to watch @PERSON1 @CAPS1 compete every week for a chance at a world championship belt. As time passed, professional wrestling began to welcome in beautiful women into their business. These women would come out onto the ring with tight, shiny lingerie on as they became eye-candy for the men who watched professional wrestling. One day, I'm watching two girls fighting in a match when my mom walks in. She takes one look at the half-naked girls fighting each other and turns off the TV and declares that professional wrestling is too adult for me. Even though I was twelve at the time, I didn't want to get in an argument with my mom about how much I should be allowed to see. Censorship can be based on the ideas and viewpoints of the parents and guardians.  I was in grade school when I fell in love with the show, '@CAPS4 @CAPS5 @CAPS6.' @CAPS7 is a show about four boys who go on unintentional adventures to save their town. These four boys, who are all around eleven years old, use curse words that some adults would be afraid to use in everyday life. Their behavior is very controversial and the show itself has been forced to ban a few of their episodes for safety reasons. One problem with @CAPS7 show was that my dad loved @CAPS7 show as well, and tried to get my mom to like the show. When my mom saw the show, she immediately banned me from watching it because of its explicit content. Now that I am older, I am able to make my own decisions about what I watch, but as a kid, my parents decided what was appropriate for me.  I grew up listening to several different types of music. My brother listened to rap, alternative, and even songs that were in musicals because he was in show choir. My dad introduced me to classic rock, and my mom loved soft rock. Although I didn't necessarily like the music that my mom liked, I learned to love my dad's music and my brother's music. I loved to listen to music from artists like @ORGANIZATION4, @ORGANIZATION1, @LOCATION1, @ORGANIZATION3, @CAPS8, @CAPS9, and so on. My musical tastes branched out into a variety of different genres. One day, I'm walking in the hallway when I hear some music coming from the living room. I go to see what is playing because it sounds unfamiliar. My dad and my brother told me to go into another room and not listen to the music. The song was by a band named @ORGANIZATION2. Even though it might seem unfair, censorship, given by the parents and guardians, is very necessary.  Although some people might find a certain piece of material offensive, it doesn't mean that the entire world should be banned from the material itself. If that person wants to keep away from the material and keep their kids from seeing or listening to that material, they are able to do that. Censorship, given by the parents or guardians, is the best way to view censorship. Nothing should be banned from a library, music store, or any other place that sells these materials. Censorship is important, but the entire banning of a certain piece of material is unjust. Parents and guardians have the responsibility to monitor and decide what is appropriate for

Yes, there are many things today that face censorship, but that doesn't mean they should be removed from libraries. Instead of taking censored items out of the libraries, there are alternative solutions that can be considered. One option could be implementing restrictions, such as requiring individuals to be a certain age or have a parent or guardian present when accessing censored material. Another possibility is to create a designated room for censored items, located in a less prominent area of the library, with clear signage indicating the content within. By exploring these alternative solutions, we can ensure that censorship concerns are addressed without completely removing access to these materials for those who wish to engage with them. It is important to consider the diverse preferences and opinions of library patrons when determining how to handle censored items, rather than implementing a blanket removal policy that may limit access for all individuals.

If a woman were to walk into a library and throw a tantrum about the appropriateness of a book, it would not be appropriate to remove the book from the shelves. Everyone has their own opinions about what is offensive or inappropriate, and it is not fair to restrict access to certain materials based on individual preferences. Removing books from the library would limit the knowledge and information available to the public. It is important to respect the diversity of opinions and allow people to make their own choices about what they want to read. Keeping all books on the shelves ensures that everyone has access to a wide range of information and perspectives. Don't be selfish; keep the books on the library shelf.

Often we go to the library searching for a good book or magazine to read without actually knowing what books are available. In order to find a book that interests you, you have to explore by picking up the book and looking at the cover and reading its background. Sometimes we come across a book or magazine that is inappropriate for children, and wonder why that book is still on the shelf for anyone to pick up. I believe materials that are offensive to some people should be permitted from the public library.  To begin, the books selected to advertise on the shelves of a library are not restricted for a certain age level. Libraries are broken up into different sections on where to find a genre, but a young child may not be aware. I believe there are certain materials found in a library that should not be put out for the public. Perhaps you have a five year old child pick up a book about sex and drugs, this could lead the child to learn things they shouldn't know until they are older.  To continue, offensive books should not be put into libraries because they give that library a bad reputation. If someone were to come from out of town and the first thing they seen on the shelves of a library was a book with a naked body or drugs, they would immediately be taken back. Offensive types of books can include books you wouldn't want a first grader to see and also books about racial or religion. Certain people would take offense to a book that was against what they believed in. This could result in a huge confrontation.  Lastly, offensive books can include books about someone's opinion on a certain topic. If someone against the writer's opinion started to read the book, they would automatically be offended by what the writer was saying. There is never an agreement when two people have a different look on something.  To conclude, although some books are offensive to some people and not to others, we have to be aware of what could cause problems to certain people. I believe any book open about opinion, and books that would be 'x-rated' should not be kept in a public library. We could easily solve this problem by making a separate place to hold these books so people will not take offense to it.

Taking books, music, movies, and magazines that are considered offensive off the shelves is a controversial topic with varying opinions. Some argue that it is necessary to protect children and young teens from harmful content, while others believe in the freedom of expression and access to information. However, considering the impressionable nature of young minds, it may be best to restrict access to such materials for individuals under a certain age, such as @NUM1. By doing so, we can help ensure that children are not exposed to inappropriate content that could negatively influence their behavior and mindset. Ultimately, the decision to remove offensive materials from shelves can help create a safer and more responsible environment for young individuals to grow and develop.

I believe that all literature of any kind is useful even though it could be offensive. If society plans on taking something off the shelf because it offends a race or gender, then many life-lesson books, movies, magazines, music, etc., would be removed from the shelves. Things such as books or movies are there to take people to different worlds, to help them learn knowledge, to teach them lessons that the real world may not teach them. If materials are taken off the shelf in fear of offending someone, then not very many things will be left just like Katherine Paterson says in her quote. If certain literature were not around anymore then it definitely would not be the same as it is now. Literature is there for us, they teach us, and if one was taken away, it would start a riot.  Books are always there for us, when we are bored, lonely, or just want to escape reality. Imagine if you were not able to read your favorite book because it was no longer considered appropriate for society. If all books had to be appropriate for every age, it would take all the interesting out of everything. Whether it is a novel or a regular encyclopedia, all books would be dulled down to exceed the needs of our 'non-offending' society. Lots of music would lose its luster and magazines would not be able to gossip about the 'hottest new things.' Movies would get too boring to watch and many things in society would fall apart.  Books, documentaries, magazines, are there to help people learn, either if it's a lesson about what not to do while you're young, such as smoking, if books about smoking were taken away because it offended the part of society that chose to smoke then how would any of the teens today know not to start smoking? Novels are usually fiction, but the characters come to life to readers. They have problems just like people of the real world even though they may not be real themselves, so if one reads that book, the way that character handles the situation could help a real-life person decide on what they should do about their problem. Important history books or movies could be taken away because it 'offends' certain people to have students learn about slaves.  If one is taken from the shelf because of offending someone then more and more materials would be taken away from society. What good does that do anyone? It leaves many students uneducated about many things that they need to be educated about. It would disrupt the order in libraries if books were being removed because of appropriateness. If books were being judged on appropriateness then many authors would not be able to write the novels and literature that they do now. No good would come of removing anything from the shelves of libraries.  Books, movies, magazines, music, it is all too important to society, it keeps us company, it teaches us, it makes life easier at times when the world wants to kick you while you are down. If one person decided that a book was not appropriate then they can choose not to read it, but they should not decide to help remove that book from the shelves of libraries. They would start a landslide of trouble that would affect everyone in the community and maybe even across the globe. Information of any kind is a good thing no matter the content of it. So removing any sort of material from our libraries is a horrible idea.

The content in today's materials is not always suitable for young children. Information distributed in the media and other networks can be harmful for some young children to read or be surrounded by, including video games. By growing up in a violent environment, children observe and have a greater chance of becoming violent. The continuation of censorship in today's materials is a necessity for the well-being of children in today's society.  In video games, there are ratings that help explain what is suitable for each age throughout childhood and adolescence. Movies also have similar ratings, making it harder for younger children to see certain movies. Books and magazines are not as well protected, although they should be. Age and maturity play a huge role in determining whether a child should be allowed to read and be introduced to specific material. Violence is a major trend in video games today, and the influence it has on children can be unnecessary and eventually detrimental to their well-being.  The reason ratings should be enforced is that children absorb their environment and can become what they see. If they are introduced to violent behavior, they have a greater chance of becoming violent themselves. Libraries have sections for every age group and specific genres of books, fiction, and non-fiction. However, some explicit material in books and magazines should also be censored before being distributed on shelves and made available to young teenagers and children. As part of the community, libraries should take part in safeguarding the well-being of children and not expose them to inappropriate information prematurely.  In my own experience, I have witnessed children growing up too quickly when exposed to certain knowledge. Today's music, for example, often contains explicit content. While radios do a good job of editing songs and placing parental advisory warnings on CDs, this does not prevent children from accessing the material. Video games like Call of Duty, Fortnite, etc., are normalizing behaviors that are not safe or conducive for children.  By censoring certain materials, we can prevent the perpetuation of negative behavior among today's youth, ultimately contributing to a safer and healthier society for children to grow up in.

I do not believe that libraries carry the responsibility to censor reading materials. When a person enters a library, they immediately must infer that, because libraries are a place in which knowledge is accumulated, some of that information they find may not coincide with what they believe. If a person believes a book is offensive, they can just as easily put it down as they had picked it up.  Obviously, however, there are certain exceptions. Children's sections should be limited to those intended for younger readers. Putting mature content into a children's section hardly seems logical, just as much as putting children's books into the adult section.  In addition, author @PERSON1 once stated that if she was able to ban a book from a library, the same right would have to be given to all other patrons as well. Thus, leading to all the books in a library being unable to be read, the knowledge contained within them unknown.  There are, as with any ordinance, exceptions. For example, if a library is intended solely for the use of younger audiences, censorship should hardly be considered a crime. The exclusion of inappropriate items, such as promiscuous reading material, keeps children from formulating ideas about concepts they may not be able to fully understand.  With all these things considered, banning books from a library hardly seems to be the best course of action. A library should be a place of enlightenment where opposing ideas are presented, leaving the readers to formulate their own decisions about what they believe. Because books are like atoms. When two opposing types collide, a burst of energy is released.

A library is a place where people of all ages can access a wide range of materials for learning and entertainment. While libraries are essential for promoting reading skills and knowledge, it is important to consider the appropriateness of the materials available. Offensive content, such as explicit movies or books, should not be accessible to all library visitors, especially children. Parents should feel confident that their children can explore the library without encountering inappropriate content. However, materials related to religion or culture should not be censored, as they serve as valuable resources for education and understanding. Ultimately, libraries should be a safe and welcoming environment for everyone to enjoy and learn from.

The subject of censorship in libraries has been brought upon many times. Censorship is a rule prohibiting the view of a book, music, movies, magazines, etc. This censorship is because of its rating or the content in it is inappropriate for some viewers/readers. Of course, many people have their own opinions about this censorship in libraries, as do I.   I believe that censorship is a good idea in some cases. These cases being music, or movies. However, I don't believe censorship is a good idea in books. Children all over the world read books and as time goes on, our children are becoming more and more advanced and read on higher levels. This is where censorship comes into play. Libraries want to censor higher reading level books because these books include profanity, violence, sex, drugs, and any other aspect of adultery. I disagree with the censorship of these books because this is basically telling our children that they can't challenge themselves or they can't learn about certain things because of their age.   These books, in my opinion, can only help them. These books will help them learn about society, what's wrong and what's right, and will help them grow as they get older. The higher reading level books help them understand words better, and also help them learn about literature and past times.   When I was in middle school, I was not an advanced reader by any means, but I did like to read occasionally. One day, I went to the library in search of a challenging book. The book I found was a book called "To Kill a Mockingbird" by Harper Lee. This book was a fictional story taking place during the Great Depression. As I put in my pin number to check out the book at the front desk, the librarian informed me that I couldn't check out the book because it was a young adult book, meaning 'too advanced' for me. She said I needed parent consent before I was able to check it out.  That night, I asked my parents about it and asked if I could read it. They said yes, mostly because they were so thrilled that I even wanted to read a book so challenging. The next day I got a note from home informing the librarian that I could read the book. I was so thrilled when I was finally able to check out the book and read it.  From my experience with the library censorship, I think that the best route to take is that if there is a parent/guardian who is over 18, and they approve of the checking out of the book/magazine or whatever it may be, then the child or student is allowed to check out said book/magazine etc.  In conclusion, the censorship of books, magazines, etc. is an overall mediocre idea, with some exceptions. The rule of parent/guardian consent is the best route to take in my opinion. Of course, this subject will be argued for many years to come and many people will have their own opinions. Each side of the argument has valid points, but I think that it is imperative that we keep censorship out of books and keep our children learning and reading at their highest ability, no matter what the reading level is.

I don't understand why libraries would have to removed a book from the shelf just because it offends someone. Especially, when that person could just ignore the book and pay no attention to it. Is @CAPS1 Right?   Is @CAPS1 right to have censorship in libraries? This question could be answered in two very different opinions. Some people may want all censorship items out of public areas. On the other hand, there are people that like to read this type of material. This is a very opinionated topic.   In my opinion, libraries are places I go to find a book to read, research, listen to music, rent movies, or relax while looking at a magazine. Libraries are public areas and not everyone is going to agree. Everyone has their own favorite book or genre. I believe it is unjust to take away censorship in libraries because this may be one's favorite genre. Why do libraries need to limit their choice while no one else does? For example, many parents would love if all clothes stores would ban holes in jeans because they are too revealing. The stores don't. They do not ban holes in jeans because many teenage girls like holes in their jeans. American society is not going to ban capris just because I do not like them. There are different favorites, likes, dislikes, and opinions.   A great resolution for this disagreement is categorizing. By putting all of the censored books, movies, magazines, and music in one area, it will decrease arguments on this topic because all of the people that like censorship in libraries will be together in their area. Whereas the people that do not want censorship in libraries do not have to be around it. This is a quick and easy fix.   There is no reason to take away one's favorite genre because someone doesn't like it. If this is true then our world will have nothing because not everyone likes one certain thing. For instance, I do not like blue Aeropostale shirts. Pink is my favorite. My friend likes the blue shirts and hates the pink shirts. We both write to the manager to get rid of the shirt color we do not like. This is non-beneficial for either of us because now the one we do not like is gone but so is the one we do like. This is nonsense. There will be nothing left in the store. People in charge can easily sort material at a store or a library to make it fit the community's likings. Getting rid of material is not the answer. Categorizing is the fix that needs to be put into action immediately.   In conclusion, censorship in libraries should not be completely eliminated. Categorizing the material can help accommodate the preferences of all library visitors, allowing everyone to access the content they enjoy without infringing on the rights of others.

In our society today, there is a significant amount of exposure to materials that many adults did not have access to when they were children. Young children are exposed to drugs, alcohol, sex, and teen pregnancy through various forms of media, which can influence their perception of what is acceptable behavior. Censorship of materials, such as books, movies, and music, is essential to protect children from being exposed to inappropriate content.  One crucial reason for implementing censorship in libraries is the fact that children may not always know what type of book they are picking up. Despite most books being age-appropriate, there is still a risk of children choosing something unsuitable for their age. Censorship in libraries would create a safer environment for children to explore books without parents worrying about the content.  Another reason to support censorship in libraries is the existing practice in video stores, where materials are categorized based on content and age appropriateness. This system ensures that minors cannot access materials intended for adults without parental consent. Implementing a similar system in libraries would allow parents to have control over what their children are exposed to, promoting responsible viewing habits.  Moreover, early exposure to inappropriate materials can have a detrimental impact on children's development. The portrayal of risky behaviors like underage drinking and drug use in media can lead to harmful consequences, such as peer pressure and unsafe decision-making. Censorship in libraries can help limit children's exposure to such negative influences and promote a healthier upbringing.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries is crucial to protect children from being exposed to inappropriate content. By implementing measures to regulate access to certain materials, we can create a safer environment for children to explore literature and media. It is essential to prioritize the well-being and development of our youth by ensuring they are not exposed to harmful influences at a young age.

Library books should not be removed based on individual opinions of offensiveness. The decision to remove a book should be left to the librarian, who is knowledgeable about what is acceptable for the library. While some may find certain books offensive, others may find value in them. It is important to remember that the library is a place for knowledge and entertainment, and differing opinions should be respected. If there are concerns about the content of a book, it is best to have a calm conversation with the librarian rather than demanding its removal. Ultimately, the choice to keep or remove a book should be made by those who are informed and responsible for the library's collection.

To whom it may concern,  Censorship is an issue that has plagued our society for centuries. It is not only unnecessary but unconstitutional. As citizens, we have certain rights that are guaranteed by the documents that keep our society out of anarchy. If the right to pick what literature to read, watch, or listen to is taken away, where will that put our country? Censorship should by no means be allowed in our country today.  In the Constitution, the Bill of Rights, and the Declaration of Independence, we are given certain rights. Some of these rights, including freedom of speech and freedom of the press, have already been constricted. We may not have lost these rights, but they have definitely been limited. Why should the government be able to tell us what to read? If censorship is allowed, what is to come is frightening. If our government, which is supposed to be for the people, tells us what we can read and not read, what is going to stop them from telling us what to wear, drink, or even eat?  Censorship in libraries is one of our biggest issues. There are countless examples of why censorship of written literature should not be allowed. For instance, if a college student is writing a research paper about the effects of rape on a child, but the government sees rape as too graphic, what is this student to do? He or she should be given the right to use what materials are necessary to write a fully-informed paper. But by censoring our libraries and taking books out, the government is hindering the education of its country's youth.  Some literary classics are also being speculated against. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn has been known as a classic since it was written. It is used in classrooms everywhere around the country for education. But recently, the availability of the book has been questioned. Throughout the novel, the n-word is used, but never as an insult. During the time-period of its writing, this word was more common and had a much less severe meaning than it does in modern-day societies. But because time has changed its meaning, it is being removed from libraries and curriculums across the country. This is unlawful censorship. One of the greatest books of our time, a literary classic, is being removed from the lives of our youth because of racy language.  Censorship is not only taking place in written literature. Movies and music are also under the magnifying glass of censorship. Movies are rated for a reason, to give the viewers an age group for which the movie is appropriate. This is helpful to parents to be able to self-censor their children. But it is not up to the government to choose what a specific child is able to view. It is a parent's right to expose or not expose their child to whatever they see fit, not that of our country's lawmakers.  Music is one of the biggest parts of our society today. With the invention of iPods and other devices, music has become much more common and portable. Censorship is becoming more severe with the change of music style. The music styles of modern teenagers greatly differ from that of their grandparents. Almost nothing is seen as unacceptable by many of today's rappers, as displayed in their choice of lyrics. The music business is taking quite a beating for what has become the most popular. With the most common themes of sex, drugs, and money, it may seem offensive to some citizens, but others just shrug it off as a normalcy. So how can someone say, "No, you cannot listen to that"? This should not be allowed, yet it is.  How can one person or a group of people decide what is acceptable and what is not? They cannot. Censorship is morally wrong, as well as lawfully wrong. Taking the media from its citizens, such as books, movies, and music, is unconstitutional. What would our forefathers think of what censorship has become? Before you pull that unacceptable book off the shelf, remember the rights of our great country's citizens, and the rights of individuals like yourself.  Sincerely, [Your Name]

It is a prominent question of debate whether or not certain materials in libraries such as books, music, movies and magazines should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. Although there are materials that may be harmful to children, freedom of information is far more important than protection because censorship is unconstitutional, prevents readers from an impartial perspective, and in some cases hides pressing societal issues that are deemed improper by the censors. The United States Constitution states that freedom of speech, religion, and the press shall not be denied or abridged. In more general terms, the Constitution grants freedom of expression. Censorship is effectively unconstitutional as it prevents freedom of expression. Censors often ban particular books because of personal views of alleged 'immorality.' Without a clear and complete access to all information, how can one make any valid conclusion about anything? Many books are banned that address great problems of society. Censorship is a great problem. Although there are many works that are meaninglessly violent, brutal, and cruel, no book or any other material should be censored. In public libraries and schools, censorship is blatantly unconstitutional. Censorship prevents people from seeing the whole perspective, and censorship hinders societal change. Censorship must be denounced as a restriction on our intelligence and liberty.

Children are our future, and as such, censorship in public libraries is a significant concern. While I believe that most books should be allowed to remain on the shelves, there are certain extreme cases where censorship is necessary. Books that contain extremely racist content, for example, should be kept away from children to prevent them from being influenced negatively. One way to address this issue is by separating adult books from children's books in the library and placing more explicit material out of easy reach for young readers. These measures can help maintain a balance between freedom of expression and protecting children from harmful content. Ultimately, finding a middle ground in censorship is crucial to ensure that public libraries remain accessible and safe spaces for all individuals.

Books, music, movies, and magazines are all forms of expression that allow individuals to convey their thoughts and feelings. However, there is a concern that some content may be too graphic or inappropriate for certain audiences, especially children and individuals who are easily influenced by external factors. Therefore, censorship in libraries is deemed necessary to protect the minds of these vulnerable groups.  Children, in particular, are highly impressionable, and the material they are exposed to can greatly impact their behavior and mindset. Books and comic books with excessive violence or inappropriate themes can leave a lasting effect on young readers, shaping their perceptions and attitudes towards the world.  Similarly, music, movies, and magazines also play a significant role in influencing individuals, especially teenagers. Artists like @ORGANIZATION2 @PERSON1, known for their explicit lyrics about drugs, sex, money, and violence, can easily sway young listeners into emulating their behavior. This highlights the importance of regulating access to such content to prevent negative consequences on the audience.  The movie industry is also guilty of producing films that glamorize harmful behaviors, such as drug use and violence. While these movies may be entertaining for some, they can have a detrimental impact on individuals who are easily swayed by what they see on screen.  In conclusion, while freedom of expression is essential, it is equally important to consider the potential harm that certain content can have on vulnerable individuals. Censorship in libraries serves as a protective measure to safeguard the minds of children and those who are easily influenced by external factors. By carefully monitoring and regulating the material available to the public, we can create a safer and more responsible media environment for all.

I think that offensive books should be removed from shelves because they can have a negative impact on children who are still developing and learning. Children are like sponges and can easily absorb and remember information, so exposing them to offensive content can be harmful. It is important for children to have access to educational and appropriate books that can help them learn and grow in a positive way. Offensive books may not be suitable for young readers and can potentially teach them the wrong values. Therefore, it is best to prioritize the well-being and education of children by removing offensive books from shelves.

I think that books and magazines that contain explicit content should be removed from shelves if they are too inappropriate for young children. Material that deals with subjects like sex or violence should not be easily accessible to kids. Only age-appropriate content should be displayed on shelves for everyone to see. If certain materials are deemed too mature, they should be kept out of sight or restricted to adult-only sections. Ultimately, people will make their own choices, but it's important to consider the impact of exposing children to inappropriate content. Have a great day.

Katherine Paterson made a valid point in stating that some books are too offensive for some people to read, but that does not mean they should not be read. Time and time throughout someone's life we hear things that we do not like nor want to be bothered with, but it is good that we do. Libraries should have the right to open all types of books to their shelves and not have them be censored by the public, this is why.  We, as people of the world, have battled through hard times. War, racism, and extreme poverty or depression are just a few to recall. Having dealt with those issues we always tend to repeat them out of lack of knowledge. Slavery and civil rights movements were some of the world's lowest moments and they were also very gruesome. Recalling those memories is difficult but something that needs to be done; if books were to be censored then many young adults would not be educated and could repeat such horrible actions.  Pertaining to movies, music and magazines the same laws apply. Though not in the same way, many times these publications are written about current news or social aspects of life. Music is a form of expression and everyone has their own taste. Not having the option to choose from a variety of styles is wrong and unfair. Music can not only be an expression of feeling about love or anger but it can also teach life lessons. Some artists like to sing or rap about their life journey. This can educate others into knowing that if you do this then this is the result, good or bad. In a magazine they tend to lean towards more current topics such as politics, jobs, or young adults lifestyles. Movies apply to the same rights and topics. Each one is equally as important and if a group of citizens feel that it is not then who are they to make that call.  What gives a group of people the right to say this is inappropriate and that you should not read it? They do not have it. In the constitution it states that you have freedom of speech and that means you can express it any way you choose. By censoring what people read that is in a way taking away that author's right to speak. Now, that is unfair.  Though Katherine Paterson made a valid point in saying that some books are too offensive to read, she simply is not right. A library is supposed to be a place where people can find a book, music, movie, magazine of any genre and read it. If materials were censored then that is unfair to someone else who does want to read it. The bottom line is that you have free will and you have the power to choose whether or not you want to read something.

There are things in the world that are not meant for certain people to see. Things like rated R movies, mature books, alcohol, and explicit music are not suitable for children. While people have the right to view whatever they want, there should be age limits in place to restrict access to such content for minors. If a child wants to engage with mature material, it should be the responsibility of the parents to make that decision, not the storekeeper selling the products.  It is reasonable for a storekeeper to deny a child access to inappropriate material. For example, if a child is trying to purchase a movie with violent content, the storekeeper should have the right to refuse the sale. It is difficult for the storekeeper to gauge the maturity level of every child, and it is better to err on the side of caution when it comes to potentially harmful content. By enforcing age limits, we can prevent children from being exposed to content that could have negative effects on their behavior and decision-making.  Age limits are also crucial when it comes to substances like alcohol. Allowing underage individuals to purchase alcohol can lead to dangerous situations like drunk driving. Teenagers may not fully comprehend the consequences of their actions and could put themselves and others at risk. By implementing age restrictions, we can help prevent tragedies and protect young people from making harmful choices.  In conclusion, age limits are necessary for certain things to protect children and society as a whole. By restricting access to mature content and substances like alcohol, we can ensure that young people are shielded from potential harm and can make safer choices as they mature. It is the responsibility of parents and society to regulate what children can access to promote their well-being and safety.

What do you go to the library for? In earlier times libraries used to be the place where you went to study. They were no computers, and so you had to go look up your work in an educational book at the library. Is that truly what people are doing at the libraries now, or are people there to look at vulgar books, magazines, and movies? A library is meant to be the place where you can go to work in peace and have a helpful resource of educational books. But, now you can go to the library and be tempted to look at books you shouldn't be looking at. Instead you could be on the computer the whole time playing games of some sort. The possibilities are endless. People now could go to the library and check out a magazine, movie, or book on: pornography, drugs, alcohol, or worse. Is that really what you want your kid to accidentally pick up at the library? Personally, I myself witnessed a little kid pick up a porn magazine at the library, and his mom had to grab it very fast before he had the chance to look at the magazine. The library should not be used for this, and the threat of young kids accidentally looking at these materials should not be happening in the library. The music someone could listen is also very bad, and your child could listen to that. Then what if they want to keep listening to it? Yes, the world does have a huge impact on what is put into the library; because, drugs, sex, scandals, and alcohol seem to be what most teenagers are interested in at some point in their young life. But a library is a community building and there is no stopping someone from coming in and easily getting these vulgar things. The thoughts of the youth are completely swayed after they watch, read, or listen to this. And, this needs to be controlled. Women and children can find all of these materials offensive. These materials need to be censored more than what they are right now. Libraries should be a safe place where people can go to study or get a book, and not to be tempted to look at something they should not be looking at. Many people find this offensive. Yes, in the end libraries are a great place, but the people who do not use libraries for the right reasons are why these materials need to be censored at the libraries.

A library card is a valuable possession for a child, opening up a world of entertainment and knowledge. However, there is a risk of children accessing inappropriate material in libraries. To address this issue, libraries could consider creating a separate section for adult content, implementing a rating system similar to movies, and allowing viewers to leave comments on items. These measures would help protect library users from stumbling upon offensive material and ensure a positive experience for all visitors. Libraries should be a safe and enriching environment for everyone to enjoy without the worry of encountering inappropriate content.

I believe that it is possible for there to be books that have offensive words or actions in them, but unless they are directed towards the reader, or intentionally being used to offend someone then it is just a book. A lot of books, especially ones on history, use language and actions that were used during that time. They use them to show you and inform you on how things used to be and what it was like during the time. Not very often, or that I have ever seen, do the authors make a book to just to put someone down. I tend to see books just explaining things and using offensive words just to show how things were and to set a tone of the book.  Music on the other hand could be thought of as different. Many people could take music in the wrong way. A majority of offensive problems spawning from music come from the genre of rap. Rappers tend to express themselves throughly, and in doing that often times use very offensive language. I personally don't get botherd by the music, because they are usually refering to their own life and how things went with them. Music can also be on the good side too. When you get the calm and collective music, it tends to help people and can be used to help people relax. Therefore music can be either way, but it mostly goes about who the person is and how they react to what they listen to.  Then you have magazines. Personally I think they are the worst of all. Magazines tend to go one way or the other. They either put a person down and be completely negative towards them, or they are positive and say nothing but good about them. One big problem with magazines is that they write down what they hear and what they want to hear, not always knowing the full story. In that case they have a very high chance of being very offensive towards the person or group they are talking about. Magazines always have a positive, but where there is a positive they have a harsh negative thing to put in with it.  In these regaurds, I believe that there is nothing wrong with a library. There are always going to be negatives and positives, but libraries tend to stick with the positive side. Plus if a book looks like it might end up being offensive towards you, then there is no one that can tell you that you can't just put it down and stop reading it. With music, only get stuff that you like and if you are easily offended don't listen to that music. Libraries just give you the opportunity to possibly get something you could enjoy. There is no reason someone would not be able to refrain from going in and getting an offensive book. In saying this, it can go either way. I don't believe there is anything worng with libraries censorship as long as you can use your own good judgement.

Imagine your favorite book, song, and movie. The ones that you love to watch, listen to, or read a million times over. The ones that you keep on checking out from the library again and again because you love it so much. Now imagine it gone from the libraries. What happened to it? You think that it has been checked out, but later you find that it has been removed from the shelves because someone found it offensive. What can you do?  When you go to the library, you usually expect a huge selection of books and other materials to choose from. A library helps many people of all ages be able to choose whatever they are interested in. This is one reason why libraries are so popular among all people. If the libraries were to begin to remove items off of the shelves that they found offensive, many people would not be able to find all the items that they enjoyed anymore. I believe that everyone is entitled to their own opinions. Libraries should accommodate as many people as they are able. Removing material from the shelves may make some people happy, but it would also take away items that many people find enjoyable.  Libraries should not remove items from the shelves if they are found offensive. Doing this could result in less material for people of all ages.
