If you find something to be offensive, all that you have to do is not check the book or other material out. In Katherine Paterson's words, 'If I have the right to remove a book from the shelf- that work I abhor- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I believe that if items were to be removed from the shelves, there would be less for others to enjoy.  Taking materials off of the shelves would be unfair to all readers. Everyone has a favorite book or movie that they love to read or watch. If someone were to disagree with this, this would not only disable you from reading or watching what you love, but it also takes away from other readers who didn't have a chance to make their own opinions on the material.  Many people have different ideas on what they feel is offensive. While some may think that some books have subjects too racy for readers, others may not feel that this is the case. Take a popular children's book like "Charlotte's Web". To some, this may be one of the best books ever written. If someone disagreed with this and felt that it was too serious or offensive to young readers, many new readers would never know this book. They would have never had the chance to make their own opinions.  I feel that censorship in libraries is an extreme show of personal opinion. It is only natural to disagree with someone. You can always run into people that don't share the same feelings about certain types of music or movies. Eliminating material from the shelves would be unfair to people. If everyone were to take their least favorite book off of the shelves and replace it with one they like better, soon the libraries would be filled with items that would only reach out to a certain audience. Libraries are meant to fulfill everyone's desires and taste.  To conclude, taking items off the shelves because they are offensive to someone would not be fair. In fact, I believe that doing so would create more problems for people. If an item that someone was looking forward to checking out was no longer available due to censorship, many people may even decide that they don't want to go to the library anymore. What is great about the library is that you have a huge selection of items to choose from. If censorship were to take place, the library would no longer be a place to enjoy. Censoring material would be like telling a reader that their opinions were not as important as those of the people who found it offensive. I believe that if you find something so terribly offensive that you don't want it available to check out at the library, first think to yourself what you would do if the library didn't have your favorite things. Because after all, what you think is offensive may be the best thing in the world to someone else.

Everyone has books that they do not like or do not approve of. My view on censorship in a library is that if you don't like it then don't read it. I think they should have a children's section and an adult section in the library so you won't have to worry about the problem. If a child wants a book from the adult section then he or she would need to have a parent with them. That way the kid wouldn't bring home any books that their parent wouldn't approve of or allow them to read. If you are an adult and you don't like a book then simply just don't read it. Maybe other readers like the book and don't want it taken off the shelf. They wouldn't be able to say that they want it off the shelf because they don't want their children to see it because their children would need their permission to check out the book anyways. I think this way would be much easier for all readers to enjoy the library and they would not have to worry about picking out a book they don't like or their parents would not approve of.

I believe that offensive books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from libraries. Instead, they could be placed in a separate section to prevent easy access for those who may find them inappropriate. Removing these materials could hinder children from learning about the truth and limit their exposure to different perspectives. It is important for individuals to have the freedom to choose what they want to read, listen to, and watch, as long as it does not harm others. By keeping these materials available, individuals can make informed decisions and gain a better understanding of the world around them. It is essential to teach children about responsible consumption and critical thinking, rather than sheltering them from potentially controversial content. Overall, I believe that offensive materials should be retained in libraries to promote intellectual freedom and encourage open-mindedness.

Being a parent or responsible child means understanding that censorship is not something that can be completely avoided. It is a personal choice whether to engage with certain material or not, and there are ways to keep children away from inappropriate content without completely removing it from public access. Censorship can provide valuable information and expand one's mind, allowing individuals to make their own decisions about what they want to read or watch. It can also serve as an escape for some people and keep them interested in various topics. Ultimately, censorship should be viewed as a way to protect children while still allowing individuals to make their own choices about what they want to consume. It is important to strike a balance between protecting young minds and allowing for freedom of expression.

I do not believe that these types of books should be taken off of the shelves. Everybody has their likes and dislikes with music, books, movies, magazines, etc. If the reader does not like the book, then the reader will not continue reading the book. If the listener does not enjoy rap music, then they will stop listening and try to find a different kind of music. This topic is about personal opinion and choice. If it was me, then I would say yes to allowing censored materials. I like getting the full effect out of things. I wanna hear the rawness of a song or the anger of a character in a book. I don't want to read and see a bunch of little stars on a censored word. I want to see that word and feel its full effect.  I am actually reading the very controversial book 'To Kill a Mockingbird'. As you may know, the author of this book is named Harper Lee. Another thing you may know is the use of the 'N-word'. This is a very controversial book because Lee doesn't call colored people black or colored, she calls them the 'N-word' throughout most of the book. Most people now think this is very racist. But back in Lee's time it was very commonly said and used in her society. It wasn't racist back in that time, I mean it still was but it wasn't as controversial as it is today. Now critics and some readers don't agree with this term and think the book should not be held in libraries or read at all for that fact. I have to disagree though. I understand why she used the word, it was a common word in her time. If you take that word away from the book, you lose some history of the old south.  People have the freedom of speech to say whatever they want to say, whether that be in written form or verbally said. I honestly say some of these censored words. Most of the time these words are said when I am angry at myself or another person. People can't control what we say, so why should they be able to control what we write or sing? Just a thought. Saying that, on the other hand I can see why people don't want these censored words. Maybe they just don't want their little kid to say a censored word in class to the teacher or to another classmate. That's understandable, but you can't protect your kids from censored words. They are everywhere. From video games, to movies, and even most books now. You cannot control what other people do or say. It is their freedom to do whatever they want.  In conclusion, while some may argue for the removal of censored materials, it is important to consider the historical context and freedom of expression that comes with such works. Censorship can limit the full impact and authenticity of artistic expression, and ultimately, individuals should have the choice to engage with these materials based on their own preferences and beliefs.

I don't think that censorship in libraries is right, for many reasons. First, all books and content that a public library offers should be open to everyone in the community. Restricting access to certain materials limits the knowledge and information available to individuals seeking to learn and explore different perspectives. Second, what one person may find offensive or inappropriate, another may not, making it unfair to impose personal beliefs on what should be accessible to all. Lastly, authors have the right to express themselves freely in their works without fear of censorship, as it is essential for creativity and diverse storytelling. By allowing censorship in libraries, we risk hindering intellectual freedom and restricting the variety of voices and ideas available to the public. In conclusion, censorship in libraries undermines the principles of open access to information, diversity of thought, and freedom of expression, ultimately limiting the enrichment and growth of individuals and society as a whole.

No book should be taken off the shelves for any reason. Books are a vital part of daily life for many people, serving educational and entertainment purposes. People have diverse tastes and interests, and everyone should have the freedom to read without concerns about book removal. Books offer valuable insights, stories, and information that authors have worked hard to share with readers. While some books may be offensive to certain individuals, it is essential to respect the author's intent and the readers who appreciate their work. Removing books based on personal offense would limit access to diverse ideas and perspectives. Books play a crucial role in education and personal growth, and their availability should be preserved to enrich society. In conclusion, the importance of books in people's lives underscores the necessity of keeping them on shelves despite any potential disagreements or discomfort they may cause.

Libraries should censor some of the materials that they have available to the public, especially when it comes to offensive content that could be harmful to children. It is crucial to protect the youth from being exposed to inappropriate materials that could negatively influence them. By moving offensive materials to a designated adult section, libraries can ensure that children do not have access to content that is not suitable for their age group. While there may be instances where access to offensive materials is necessary, such cases can be handled individually. Overall, the priority should be to safeguard children from potentially harmful content and create a safe and appropriate environment for all library users.

@CAPS1 I believe that books, magazines, and other forms of literature should not be removed from shelves. These literary works play a crucial role in helping people read, concentrate, and learn about the past. Books provide us with valuable information, entertainment, and opportunities for personal growth. Removing them would deprive us of the chance to explore different worlds, perspectives, and ideas. Additionally, magazines offer valuable insights into our society and help us stay informed about current events. Therefore, it is essential to preserve these sources of knowledge and inspiration for future generations. Let us continue to cherish and celebrate the beauty and power of literature.

Although possibly offending some people, materials that are in libraries that could possibly be considered 'offensive' are actually good to keep around. If people who find the materials in libraries offensive are getting upset over the lack of censorship within the library itself, they should re-think the situation and consider that the 'offensive' materials that are left within libraries could be considered appropriate IF the viewer is ready to experience them. If a person does not want to be exposed to things in libraries that could be considered offensive, then they can altogether avoid these materials. If parents find the materials that are within libraries offensive, they should monitor their children while they are visiting their library. The materials that could be considered offensive may actually be good, educational media that a person could learn from. If censorship within libraries increases, 'then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Censorship in libraries should remain the same as it is now. Some books, movies, and any other number of things that can be found within libraries are being labeled as inappropriate. These materials can be educational, however, and should not be removed from libraries altogether just because some of the materials are found to be too crude, vulgar, or adult-like for younger ages. Parents should monitor their children while in a library as to not let them stumble upon something that they would not want them to see yet. If something is labeled as inappropriate for children to view by parents, then it is the parents responsibility to make sure their child does not stumble upon it. Much of what may be considered as inappropriate and needing censorship in libraries to this day may actually hold some educational value or meaning to it. There are books and movies that are based off of true stories that have taken place that could be announced by parents as 'not appropriate to be viewed by children'. However, this does not mean that libraries should have to remove the material from their shelves just because parents do not think or necessarily agree that it would be appropriate for their child to read or see. It is the parents responsibility to see that their child does not check out what they would consider inappropriate. Much of the things within libraries that might be considered inappropriate for children hold good educational value and should not have to be removed from the shelves of the library simply because parents find it not age appropriate for their children. Censorship in libraries should remain the same as it is now so that those who want to see or read the stories or movies can do so without having to buy them. If parents want to make a big deal out of how libraries hold materials that are not appropriate for their children, they can either altogether not go to a library or they can monitor their children closely if they bring them along on a library visit. I have found that when I visit my library, I look at it as a source of knowledge that has been pooled in one place, written and created by thousands of authors, all of which took time out of their own lives to create it. If we are going to remove these books or movies from libraries, I think it would be taking away the rights that people have to the materials that SHOULD be provided by a library. Censorship in libraries should remain the same as it is today so that people can enjoy all that should be within it, even if some of it is labeled as inappropriate by parents.

Imagine a world where nearly every other book is banned for some reason or another. That world is not a world I want to live in. I believe that censorship in libraries is wrong. For three reasons, really, the first being that people have the right to any information that they desire to have. The second, people do not have the power to take opportunities away from other people. The last point I will make is that no information is bad information.     Because we are in @LOCATION1, I asume that we are talking about censorship in @CAPS1 libraries. If that is the case, then I think that it is unconstituitional to ban any book, or censor any material. Censoring books is like putting a blind fold on whoever is reading the material; they don't see it for what it really is, or for what the intended purpose is.     If the prompt does happen to be including foreign countries, then I think humans do not have the right to influence what other people read. This is idealistic, yes, and in a perfect world, all countires would have equal rights for everyone, regardless of race or gender. I think that people should see everything the way it is. If something is offensive, it's offensive. It's the person's choice whether or not they read or listen.     That leads me to my last point, that no information can be bad information. Whether it is profane, or offensive in any way, there is always some kind of meaning behind it. From rappers like @PERSON2 and @CAPS2 @CAPS3, who I've found all of their songs have meaning, whether it's personal, or they are trying to send a message out to the people. There are books like @CAPS4 for @LOCATION2, by @ORGANIZATION1, which has recently been banned by some school libraries because of graphic scenes. The people who banned the book fail to realize that the book is not about those scenes. There is a much deeper message about guilt and grief, and redemption beneath it. Another, more famous book that was banned from school libraries is The @CAPS5 in the @CAPS6, by @PERSON1, which is a coming of age story about a boy.      In conclusion, I don not think it is right to ban books or music from libraries. No one has the right to.There is always meaning within. The way an author writes a story or a piece of music always has meaning; they made the conscious decision to write it that way for a reason. By banning books, they are taking people's chances to grow and expand.

Censorship is crucial in libraries to ensure that offensive material is not easily accessible to the public. While everyone is entitled to their own opinions, it is important to consider the diverse perspectives and sensitivities of individuals in society. If someone finds a certain book or movie offensive, they should address their concerns with the appropriate authorities rather than unilaterally demanding its removal. It is essential to respect freedom of speech while also taking into account the need to protect certain groups, especially children, from inappropriate content. Creating designated sections for adult material can help address these concerns and ensure that libraries remain welcoming and inclusive spaces for all individuals. Ultimately, the goal of censorship in libraries should be to strike a balance between freedom of expression and the need to maintain a respectful and safe environment for everyone.

A few months ago, I was at the local library searching for the perfect book. After an hour of searching, I decided on one. I was happy with my choice as I checked it out. However, as I anxiously started reading my book, I found language, drug abuse, and sexual content. As a teenager, I do not want or need to be exposed to any inappropriate material. No one should be exposed to that, and because of that experience, I believe that censorship in libraries is a must.  Due to sexual content, drug abuse, and vulgar language, one must be seventeen to purchase a ticket for a rated-R movie. I believe that since that is true for movies, it should also be true for books, magazines, and music. Inappropriate literature is not necessary for any age. The world exposes certain literature to children, and then is shocked when they see children in jails, gangs, and other horrible situations.  The world has set their standards too low, and the children of today's society are following after our footsteps. Author Katherine Paterson once said, "...if I have a right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right so does everyone else." This quote shows the impact that people have on generations to come.  Everyone has their own opinion, and this is mine. As a daily newspaper reader, I could not quiet my voice any longer. I had to step up and say something. I am part of a generation that is being affected greatly by the world in a negative way. The first step to changing that is to set the standards high. Protect the future generations and censor what children are allowed to be exposed to. Situations will become better when libraries choose to censor and remove offensive materials from shelves. If libraries censor materials, then next time I want to find the perfect book, I will.

Every individual has their own opinion on censorship. Some people believe that, in some instances, it is perfectly fine, but others disagree. I'm one person that thinks that, in some instances, things should be censored.  Schools have the right to censor what is put in their libraries for their students to read, especially magazines. Some of the magazines out there have articles in them that aren't appropriate for school hours or even in the school building. Schools may not want something inappropriate on their shelves where students can see it. Censorship is even more understandable in elementary schools. Younger students' libraries should be monitored even more carefully. Younger kids, such as elementary age, don't really know what they should and shouldn't read.  In public libraries, things are a little different. Parents can usually monitor what their kids check out. Most adults know to read the summary on the back of the book to know what is being checked out. If the summary is too vague, then they know to read a few pages inside the book.  A couple of times, I've gone to the public library and I checked out a book that I thought was a suspense. When I got home and began reading it, it turned out I was wrong. The book was a romance book that I didn't care to read. So, I returned the book to the library. Most of the time you can read the synopsis on the back of the book, but that doesn't always reveal too much about the book. So, the best thing you can do is read a couple of pages out of the book before you check it out.  Everyone has a right to their own opinion on censorship. I believe that in some instances things available to be checked out should be censored. In other instances, things should be left up to the adults and the parents to decide what they want to be allowed to be checked out.

If one person has a right to something, it would only be fair for others to have the same right. Just like how it wouldn't be fair to give some kids cookies and not others, everyone should have equal rights. If one person wants a book, and another person wants the same book, they should both have the right to it. It's important to treat everyone equally and give them the same opportunities. In situations like fights where some are involved and others are not, those who are actively participating should face consequences, while bystanders should not be unfairly punished. It's important to ensure that everyone is treated fairly and given the same rights and opportunities as others.

When I heard about the problems some libraries were having with censoring materials, I couldn't help but think about the importance of protecting children from inappropriate content. I believe that libraries should implement age-appropriate sections and guidelines to ensure that children are safe and exposed to suitable material. By creating designated areas for different age groups and enforcing strict rules, we can help parents feel more secure about their children's visits to the library. It is crucial to provide a safe and educational environment for children to learn and grow without being exposed to harmful content. Let's work together to create a positive and enriching experience for our children in libraries.

No, I do not believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves of libraries. Even if some content may be perceived as offensive to some individuals, such as war movies, they still serve a purpose in telling the stories of those who have fought and sacrificed. Every book in a library holds value for someone, whether it be for research, education, or personal interest.  However, I do believe that certain types of music, like rap, should not be allowed in libraries as they can promote negative behaviors and attitudes. Magazines on topics like racing, sports, or military can be beneficial, but those with harmful or inappropriate content should be kept out to protect the minds of library visitors.  In conclusion, while some materials may be controversial or challenging, it is important to preserve a wide range of content in libraries to cater to diverse interests and informational needs. It is crucial to strike a balance between freedom of expression and ensuring a safe and enriching environment for all patrons.

There are all kinds of books, movies, and even magazines out there. Most libraries have a huge selection for all types of readers or people who would like to watch a movie. They could even have stuff that the young minds should not read. Have you ever thought about what would happen if a little kid grabbed onto something that he/she was not supposed to read? When it comes to things like this, there is a huge range of topics. Some of them are not supposed to be looked at until an older age. Thats why I think there should be a certain section where only a certain amount of ages are allowed to go.     When it comes to books, there will always be some books that are not apporbiate for the young mind. They could include multiple things that could scar a kid for life. Some of the things that they might read are probably things that their parents would like to talk to them about later on in the future. Books are great for learning, dont get me wrong, but there are some that are more adult related. Now there are a ton of books that kids can read and parents won't need to worry about them reading.     Another way libraries can help is put the movies in a certain section. The library could make a section called 'family and kids'. This section would hold a perfect spot where parents wouldn't have to worry about their kids getting the wrong ideas from movies. In our library, we have this section. My grandma and I would always go there and find an incredible family movie to watch together. Finding a great family movie to watch is the best feeling ever.     Finally the last way a library could help is by making sure the child is old enough to check out a book or a movie. Clearly a child of @NUM1 shouldn't check out a movie that is rated @CAPS1, thats just wrong. Libraries should make sure the child is at the correct age to check out the movie. Thats why the movie companys rate movies, so they can give people heads up about whats good and bad about the movie. Also the libraries should make sure a kid is checking out the apporbiate type of magazine or book. The people that work there could look through it before and make sure its the right type of book they should read. There are an infinte amount of ways we can protect the minds of young ones.     I dont think libraries should banned books, magazines, movies, or even music. I think they should just make sure the kids are checking out what their allowed to read. Books are a great way to learn things, but they should be learning about the stuff that is sustable for their age. Libraries are there for us to learn and enjoy ourselves. I believe people would get upset if they would banned the stuff they love. They should just keep an eye out of what kids are looking at. Thank you for your time.

The last thing I would want my children seeing in a library is offensive material. A library is thought of as a learning zone, somewhere for people to learn about new things and expand their knowledge. If there are dirty magazines, movies on sexuality, offensive music, or inappropriate websites available to children, it completely defeats the purpose of having a safe learning environment. My opinion is that libraries should be used primarily for educational purposes. That means that there should be appropriate books and magazines that are also age-appropriate. Computers are also a great resource but can contain many offensive materials. My standpoint on this issue is that the computers in the library should be monitored. If someone wants to look up inappropriate images and websites, then they should do it on their own time, in the privacy of their own home. It should not be allowed in public where innocent children will be exposed to it. That isn't fair to the kids, and it isn't fair to the parents who have tried to protect them from that kind of suggestive material.  I'm sure that there are many people out there that would disagree with my proposal. However, those may be the type of people who aren't morally structured as I, or those who don't have kids to look out for. Or perhaps they just aren't as concerned about the issue. They will argue that there is really no severe need for the computers to be monitored, or that they have blocked websites. Yes, they may think that there is no real harm. But that may just be because that is the way they were raised, causing them to think in that same respect. With the magazines, some may argue that children will be exposed to suggestive material sometime, so why not now? But if everyone were to start thinking like this all morals would be forgotten.  In some cases, morality might not be the issue at all. In fact, religion might be the most important issue. A lot of people are religious, and their particular religion may be against looking at suggestive and 'unholy' material. Parents will not want to walk into a library with their children and find them staring at images that go against what they believe in. They will think of it as losing their child's innocence. Having these things out in the open and accessible to kids and teenagers could unintentionally send a message to them that indulging in sexual activities is acceptable when according to their religion it is not.  When I was a little girl, I remember going to the library often with my mother to pick out books for school. I distinctly remember seeing naughty magazines laying across a table as I was walking toward the children's section. My mother was appalled that they had those laying out in the open like that, and especially right next to where the children's books were. She complained to one of the librarians and asked that they please remove them. The librarian apologized and agreed that the placement of the magazines was a little out of line. Ever since then, my mom has been a little skeptical and dreads going to that library. I suppose that is why I am so involved in this issue and the reason for this informative article.  I did not write this to place blame on anyone or to judge people for their beliefs. On the contrary, the purpose of my writing this was to inform the general public of these issues and to explain my side of the argument. I don't see the reason for having these materials on hand at a library where almost anyone has access to them. I do not understand the need for them to be obtainable at a library, or if there is a need at all. I'm hoping that by reading this I have opened the eyes of some concerned parents out there, or have at least made them aware of the matter. Thank you for your time.  Sincerely, [Your Name]

How would you feel if someone confiscated a book from you simply because it contained offensive language or disturbing content? While there are certain books that may warrant censorship, banning them would mean excluding many great novels from the past that were considered acceptable in their time. If you feel the need to censor books, do so in your own personal library.  Personally, I am against the censorship of books. If an author chose to write a book a certain way, then it should be preserved in its original form. Censorship only serves to diminish the educational value of books and restrict the learning experience for students. While it may be necessary to censor a school book with explicit content, wholesale censorship of literature can have negative consequences.  There are numerous books that contain offensive language and controversial ideas, but these works were created to enlighten our society. By removing such books, we would be hindering our ability to learn and grow. Reading should be a stimulating and enriching experience, not hindered by unnecessary censorship.  In my own experience, I have read many excellent novels that may have contained some graphic details or offensive language. I do not believe that the presence of explicit content detracts from the overall value of a book. Those who advocate for censorship often do so for personal reasons rather than for the greater good, which is detrimental to both literature and culture.  When the Nazis burned books during World War II, they nearly eradicated an entire culture and body of literature. We must not allow the same fate to befall today's literature. Censoring books in public libraries would be a disservice to our culture and heritage. Libraries are meant to be accessible to all, and censorship should be reserved for individual preferences in personal libraries.  In conclusion, censorship should not be imposed in libraries as it stifles public access to literature. Books should be preserved in their original form, as they are a reflection of our society and history. Let us not be the arbiters of what is deemed appropriate for others to read, and let classic literature remain intact for future generations to appreciate and learn from.

I do not believe that items should be taken off the shelves just because some people find them inappropriate. Everyone has different tastes and preferences, so what may be offensive to one person might be enjoyable to another. It is important to remember that individuals have the right to choose what they want to watch or read, and it is not fair to impose restrictions based on personal opinions. Instead of removing such items altogether, they could be placed in a separate section to ensure that they are not easily accessible to children. Ultimately, it is up to each individual to decide what they want to engage with, and judgment should not be passed based on personal preferences. It is essential to respect diversity in tastes and preferences, as everyone is entitled to their own choices without being judged.

In my opinion, books that seem offensive to someone should be kept on the shelf. Meaning that people should be allowed to check them out in the library and read them even if some people think those books in particular are offensive, or come off as offensive. A person should be able to read an article without feeling like someone wrote that book, article, or magazine to be offensive. Yes, but at the same time it is up to you, the reader, to pick a book that does and will not make you feel uncomfortable. Do not pick a book to read that discriminates against football players if you are a football player, because most likely it is going to upset you, or make you uncomfortable. Well, say you want to read a book that discriminates against football players, and it does make you feel uncomfortable, do not take the book, and go complain to someone about how the book, or article makes you feel if you picked it out to begin with. If it makes you uncomfortable, put the book, or article down. No one is forcing you to read it or look at it. People should be allowed to read whatever type of books they would like, and about anything that interests them. Just because an article, or book is offensive to you, does not mean it is offensive to other people. If we were to take all the books, articles, magazines off the shelves of libraries, there would not be any books left for us to read because every book written offends at least one person. Movies are a whole other issue in itself. There are many types of movies, and within those types of movies are types of things people do in the movies to make it funny, scary, shocking, stupid, etc. If you do not cuss and say you go watch 'Scarface' you are going to find it offensive because every other word they say is a cuss word. If you do not like people jump out of strange places and scare the crap out of you, then you are not going to watch 'The Conjuring.' If people find movies offensive or not to their liking they usually go and try to make a big deal out of it, and sue the people who made the movie. You doing that is causing more trouble than it is actually worth. The same thing with movies as books, if we were to take all the movies out of movie stores, and just stores in general that were offensive to at least one person in any way, we would not have any movies left to watch because at the end of the day; there are tons of movies that would offend some people, and make them uncomfortable. In conclusion, if you find a movie, song, book, article, or magazine that is offensive to you, get over it. Keep that book or whatever it is out of your reach and in other people's, because at the end of the day no one is going to help you sue an author, producer, or music production company because something they wrote, directed, or sung offends you. In my opinion you should just read what interests you, watch what you like, and listen to the songs you usually listen to.

Should books, music, magazines, etc., be removed from shelves if they are found offensive? This question sparks a variety of opinions. In my experience, I have come across some questionable content in books, but I believe that others may still find value in them. Personally, I do not think that anything should be removed from shelves. While it is understandable that parents may want to shield their children from certain materials, I believe that it is important to let them know about the realities of the world. By censoring content, are we not essentially lying to our children? I believe that individuals should have the freedom to choose what they read, see, and listen to. We should not shield them from the harsh truths of the world, but instead, educate them about it. In conclusion, I stand by the belief that people should have the freedom to access a wide range of materials without censorship. It is essential to provide individuals, especially children, with the knowledge and understanding needed to navigate the complexities of the world.

Children should have the freedom to explore the world of literature in libraries without unnecessary restrictions. While it is understandable for parents to want to protect their children, it is important to remember that books and other forms of literature do not corrupt children. Rather, it is the environment and influences around them that play a significant role in their development. Libraries offer a diverse range of materials that can help children learn and grow in various ways. Therefore, it is crucial for parents to support their children's curiosity and encourage them to explore different genres of literature. Ultimately, libraries should not limit the availability of books and other materials that can enrich a child's learning experience.

Well, people should have the freedom to choose what they want, especially as adults. Children may not always make the best decisions, but it is important to respect individual choices. Taking away things that bring joy or satisfaction to someone wouldn't be fair. Everyone deserves the right to pursue their interests and preferences, as long as it doesn't harm others. Ultimately, respecting personal choices and preferences is essential in promoting individual autonomy and happiness in society.

Libraries are filled with millions of books that have the power to influence readers of all ages. While some books may contain adult themes or references that some deem inappropriate for certain age groups, it is important to consider the value of diverse perspectives and experiences in literature. Censoring books and restricting access to certain materials may limit the opportunities for readers to explore different ideas and viewpoints.  Books have the ability to inspire, provoke thought, and encourage empathy. They provide readers with a window into different worlds, perspectives, and experiences. By reading about historical events, personal struggles, or complex emotions, individuals can gain a deeper understanding of the world around them and develop their own critical thinking skills.  Young adults, in particular, benefit greatly from exposure to a wide range of literature. Reading allows them to explore their interests, expand their horizons, and develop their own unique voice. By limiting their access to certain books, we may be depriving them of valuable learning opportunities and stunting their intellectual growth.  Everyone, regardless of age or background, should have the freedom to choose what they read. By embracing a diverse range of literary works, we can foster a culture of creativity, curiosity, and open-mindedness. Instead of censoring books, we should encourage readers to engage with challenging material, think critically about what they read, and have open discussions about different perspectives.  In conclusion, censorship of books limits the richness and diversity of literature available to readers. It is important to uphold the freedom of expression and the right to access a wide range of ideas and viewpoints through books. By embracing the power of literature to inspire, educate, and provoke thought, we can create a more vibrant and intellectually stimulating society for all.

Materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. Instead, libraries should consider placing them in sections designated for specific age groups or in areas where adult content is located. It is important for libraries to cater to a diverse range of interests and preferences, while also ensuring that inappropriate material is not easily accessible to young children. By implementing age restrictions and organizing materials accordingly, libraries can maintain a balance between providing a variety of content and respecting community standards. It is essential to preserve the freedom of choice for library visitors, while also being mindful of potential sensitivities. Ultimately, libraries should strive to offer a welcoming environment where individuals can explore different forms of media without imposing unnecessary restrictions.

Censorship in libraries should not be allowed. People should have the choice to read or watch whatever they want to. Just because one person finds a book offensive doesn't mean that another person will also find it offensive. The library should let the community decide what they find offensive or not. Some parents may not want certain materials in the library because their children might come across them. If parents are concerned about what their children see, they should sit down with them and discuss why they should not read or watch that type of material. Parents should be able to help their children understand why they shouldn't engage with certain content instead of blaming the library for having it.  If certain books or movies are considered very offensive by the public, they could be placed in a special area marked with a sign indicating "@CAPS1 content" and only accessible to adults. This way, those who wish to access such material can do so, while preventing children from easily encountering it. By implementing age restrictions and segregating offensive material in a separate section of the library, both the freedom to access controversial content and the protection of children can be balanced. This solution addresses concerns regarding offensive material in libraries while still respecting individuals' right to choose their reading material.

I understand that some parents wouldn't want their kids reading a book about drugs or watching a movie about gangs, but libraries shouldn't have to remove them from their shelves. There is not one movie, book, or magazine where everyone will approve of it. Just because a couple of people find it offensive doesn't mean they should have the power to determine what materials libraries have or don't have on their shelves. One reason why I believe certain items shouldn't be removed from a library just because a couple of people find it offensive is because what Katherine Paterson said in her quote. She is saying if there was a book a couple of parents didn't want their kids to see and they were to complain and have the right to remove it from the libraries shelf. Then sooner or later, more and more parents will be coming in complaining about a different book, movie, or magazine every other day. Soon, there wouldn't be any books, movies, magazines in the library. Another reason why I believe we should have no say in what items libraries hold is this. As you know, there are many different cultural families living in the community. Some people say bibles should be allowed in libraries. Half the population agrees on that statement, the other half thinks that is ridiculous and they're thinking how they would even suggest doing such a thing. How would a library handle this situation? If we gave people the right to decide what was held in libraries, there would be constant conflicts and ultimately, no way to please everyone. My third and final reason why I think the public should have no say in this matter is that if libraries were forced to take items off their shelves just because a couple of people complain about certain books or movies, then why couldn't people do that at restaurants, movie rental businesses, or outlet stores with clothes they don't approve of? If it was to happen to one business, then it should happen to every business. The only person who should have the say in what they have in their store/library is the person who is paying for it  the owner. It's their responsibility to decide what is appropriate for their establishment, and the public should respect those choices. After reading all those opinions of mine, I would hope that you see where I'm coming from and understand that it just wouldn't be humane to censor materials based on the opinions of a few individuals. It's not our place to dictate what should or should not be available in libraries  we must trust in the discretion of the owners and respect their decisions.

Today, we live in a world where there are many different political, religious, and personal views, and with time, these views are only going to become more varied and widespread. Unfortunately, it is not always easy to cater to every single person's individual takes on the world. When it comes to libraries, it is even harder to have different books for all the different opinions that will not offend people with other opinions.  Let's take @LOCATION1 for example. There are many different races and people with different religions living here. This is a place that has already been through a @CAPS1 @CAPS2 and has fought against racism and slavery. Although these are things that our country has overcome, there are still going to be arguments and disagreements over these problems. When there are different opinions, there are always going to be different books out there about the same topic from multiple points of view. As the readers of these books we need to know what point of view this is coming from and not choose a book that goes against our personal beliefs. This is where the offensiveness comes from. We live with many different people and we need to understand that not everyone is going to have the same views on life that we do.  When I was in eighth grade, I was @CAPS6 @ORGANIZATION1 with some friends. One of them was pulling her eyes back (like someone would do if they were imitating an @CAPS3 person) because they were itchy. A very pregnant @CAPS3 @CAPS5 woman walked in and took offense to my friend's eye movements. She yelled @CAPS6 us and said, 'I would have thought your parents raised you better than that.' @CAPS6 first, we did not understand what this woman was talking about until we realized that our friend had been pulling her eyes back. This showed us that different people can take offense to different things because of their heritage.  There is nothing we can do about the expanding cultures in our country. We cannot change the views of certain people in order to match those of our own beliefs nor can we change the fact that all the different people are going to voice their opinions and view them as 'right'. However, we can change the way that we view these people. We need to understand that there is no 'right' when you are dealing with multiple opinions. @CAPS6 this point we need to embrace everyone else for who they are and what they believe because there is nothing we can do to change those beliefs.  So next time you pick up a book @CAPS6 the library, read the summary and check to see that the author agrees with you before you take the book home or there are going to be disagreements in your views. If you get a book and you don't agree with it or if you are offended by it, there is no one to be mad @CAPS6 but yourself for not checking to see the author's stance on the topic before you started reading it. Remember, understanding and respecting different perspectives is crucial in a world filled with diverse opinions and beliefs.

I strongly believe that books in libraries are meant to be read and for people to gain knowledge from. While some materials may not be suitable for children, it is the responsibility of parents to monitor what their children are exposed to. Libraries are divided into different sections for a reason, and parents should guide their children to appropriate materials. Censorship in libraries should not involve removing certain materials altogether, but rather restricting access to them for children. Everything in a library, from books to movies, serves an educational purpose and should be available for those interested. Parents should take an active role in monitoring their children's reading choices, rather than expecting libraries to remove materials that they find objectionable. In conclusion, libraries should not remove books, movies, magazines, or music based on individual preferences, but instead, parents should take responsibility for guiding their children's reading choices.

Offensive books containing content related to drugs, alcohol, or sex can be concerning for parents who do not want their children exposed to such material at a young age. While some adults may find these books informative or useful, they are not suitable for children or young teens. To address this issue, libraries could consider creating a separate section for adult-oriented material, ensuring that children do not have access to offensive content. By implementing measures to restrict access to inappropriate material, libraries can help protect the minds of young readers and provide a safer environment for all patrons.

I believe censorship is necessary. If all of the kids in the world grew up listening to hardcore gangster rap and watching porn, we would have shiftless and violent leaders tomorrow. It's important that we are held back somewhat by these offensive outlets so that we grow into mentally healthy adults. However, censorship can go too far. When it comes to removing an author's work from a public library altogether, we have crossed the line. With the rights given to us by our founding fathers, our rights given to us at birth, and the duty we have to express our opinion, it is a crime to remove the hard work of authors and artists from the shelves.   Of course, the first point of argument that comes to mind to defend my position is the fact that we are all given a legal right to express ourselves through the First Amendment of our Constitution. The writers of this Constitution were aware that freedom of creativity should not be held back from the people. That law still exists, and has been used many times to defend people arguing to keep their work, their words, and their ideas out in the world. As far as I know, taking any form of media, book, or entertainment away from the general public would be illegal. Still, even with this point made, some may not be convinced that we are allowed to say what we want.  A man by the name of John Lennon comes to my mind when asked about censorship in the media. Lennon was a musician, composer, writer, public speaker, and human rights activist. He spoke out against censorship, saying that it was a way to judge artists on their work when it wasn't even fully listened to. If someone as convincing and passionate as Lennon could feel that way, then everyone should see that the human race is given the right for their creation to be revealed. In some cases, it's necessary and needed for people to show their ideas to the public.  People like Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks, Gandhi, and the list goes on, were all avid believers in the rights of humans. Imagine if they had just said, 'I don't think people want to hear me so I'll just stop and let someone else take over for a little bit.' Do you think the world would be as amazing and integrated as a place? The point is, we never know how great and life-changing someone's point of view could be. Whether it's leading a civil rights movement, or attempting to bring peace to a world that needs it the most, censorship might be the one thing stopping people from seeing the most influential person they need.  In fact, we are all called to share our ideas. It's our duty to make sure people see the world not only from their view, but from the view of a poor homeless man, a single mother of five, a kid in elementary school, and a rebellious teenager. The world might not be ready for change, but it needs it.  Whose right is it to judge an artist's work? Some call it God, some call it the man, and others call it the government. It's hard getting your work acknowledged by someone, let alone a whole nation. However, that doesn't mean we are to just give up. Censorship in public places is a crime against the law, nature, and our unalienable rights, and it's our job to go out into the world to create a new one.

Censorship is a dangerous practice that can hinder the knowledge and awareness of a society. By withholding information, whether it be historical events, political corruption, or inappropriate content, individuals are deprived of understanding their past, present, and potential future. This ignorance can leave a society vulnerable and unprepared for what lies ahead.  If crucial information is censored, such as environmental warnings or political scandals, the consequences could be catastrophic. Without access to this knowledge, people may not be able to address pressing issues like climate change or governmental misconduct. In extreme cases, censorship can lead to brainwashing, as seen in dystopian literature where societies are kept in the dark about their own history.  While some information may be sensitive or distressing, it is essential for individuals to have access to a wide range of perspectives and historical events. Censorship in libraries, bookstores, and other media outlets should be prohibited to ensure that people have the opportunity to educate themselves and make informed decisions.  In conclusion, censorship has the potential to limit understanding, manipulate perceptions, and impede progress. It is crucial for a society to have unfettered access to information in order to learn from the past, navigate the present, and shape a more informed future.

Dear Katherine Paterson,  I believe that it is essential to uphold the principles of equality and freedom in our society. While there may be concerns about certain content in newspapers, magazines, or movies, I think that censorship is not the answer. Instead, implementing age restrictions and requiring identification for certain purchases can be a more effective solution.  By using ID verification, we can ensure that age-appropriate content is accessed by the right audience. This way, individuals can still have the freedom to choose what they want to consume, while also protecting young people from potentially harmful material. Therefore, I suggest that newspaper organizations continue their work but with stricter regulations on sales to maintain a balance between freedom of expression and responsible content distribution.  Sincerely, Zack

This writing is socially unacceptable! There are many books and media sources that include language, sexual tones, and other immoral things and ideas. However, culture does need to be obtained, although immorality on this earth is at an all-time high, we need to stop focusing on books that will always be on the shelves and turn our attention to people's hearts and morally right things.  When a person walks into a library, he or she can expect certain things, for example, the smell of the older books, the noise of a group of kids, and the librarian yelling to keep them quiet. What he or she would not expect is kids doing drugs and watching porn on the computers. This is not a book's fault or 'the evil computers' fault. This is the fault of an immoral world.  I myself have witnessed some evil things kids do in the school system, and it gets worse every day. There is good, but it certainly is not because they themselves are caring and loving about what they do on this planet. I can quote from many in my grade class that have told me 'The only thing that is wrong is telling someone they are'. This thought process is immoral. But who is going to tell them that, and what is the answer.  Jesus is the answer. In the Bible, it says, Jesus is the way, the truth, and the life. This is the truth. In the book of Romans, it says, God gave many people over to their sinful passions. God is the only good, and the only light comes from Him. The only man to live a perfect life was Jesus, and He was God in a human body. We as a planet need to turn to God, the only good thing, and try to be like Him because this world needs Him.  Only God can change a heart. We need to focus on Him, and once we do that, the way we think, write, and act will change, and we will not need to discuss this problem any longer.

I think that only if there is real offensive material should it be censored. It is wrong to make fun of or joke about people, especially when it comes to mocking disabilities. For example, the movie "The Ringer" portrays a man pretending to have a disability to compete in the Special Olympics and win money, which is highly inappropriate and offensive. It is important to consider the impact of such content and ensure that it is not promoted or normalized. Ultimately, decisions about what should be censored should be based on the level of offensiveness and harm that it may cause.

I believe that any kind of material, such as books, movies, magazines, etc., should be censored except for mature content like pornography, violent and horrid movies, and video games. However, age-appropriate restrictions should be in place to ensure that individuals are exposed to content suitable for their level of maturity. Maturity levels vary among different age groups, with some individuals developing maturity at a faster rate than others. It is essential for individuals to behave in a civilized manner and not engage in inappropriate behavior. Implementing age grouping systems for books and keeping adult content out of reach of children can help prevent them from encountering unsuitable material. Additionally, using safety locks on devices can further restrict access to mature content. By taking these precautions, we can help protect individuals, especially children, from being exposed to inappropriate or vulgar material.

Everyone has an opinion. That's what makes us unique and diverse. Some prefer certain forms of entertainment over others, just like some people may find certain materials offensive in a library. However, removing such materials would limit the variety and richness that libraries offer to the community. As Katherine Paterson wisely said, "And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us." If we start censoring based on personal preferences, we risk losing valuable resources that cater to different interests and perspectives. Libraries should remain inclusive spaces where individuals can explore a wide range of materials, even if they don't align with everyone's beliefs. Let's embrace the diversity of opinions and preferences that make libraries such vibrant places for learning and discovery.

Books in libraries should be available to everyone, and it should not be the job of any individual or group to decide what is appropriate or not. Parents and adults should focus on teaching children morals and values so that they can make informed decisions on their own. Censoring books in libraries could lead to a slippery slope of censorship in other areas, such as the internet, ultimately restricting freedom of speech. Offensive books can still provide valuable information and lessons, and individuals should have the right to choose what they read. Ultimately, people are responsible for their own choices, and it is not up to others to dictate what they can or cannot access.

Yes, I do believe that any book found offensive to any person should be removed from the bookshelf. One reason for this is that it could lead to others using the offensive material against the individual in a hurtful manner. Additionally, constantly being exposed to something that offends you can be emotionally taxing and create a negative environment. On the other hand, music may not have the same impact as books since it is something you hear rather than read. Overall, it is important to address offensive material to create a more inclusive and respectful environment for everyone.

Books are pieces of art, and authors are artists who use writing as a form of expression. In a society that values freedom of expression, it is important not to deny anyone that right. Removing books or any form of art from library shelves is not the solution, even if some may find certain content offensive. While parents may want to protect their children and keep them innocent, it is essential for children to grow up, explore, and learn about the world around them.  As the musician @PERSON2 once said, shielding children's eyes from the world may seem like a protective measure, but it also deprives them of the beauty and complexity that life has to offer. Deciding what is offensive is subjective, and everyone has different opinions. Censoring too much content would lead to a lack of diversity and creativity in the arts.  People have the right to express themselves through books, music, and other forms of art, and censorship takes away from the original intent of the creators. While individuals have the choice to avoid certain content, they should not impose their views on others. Art may evoke strong emotions, but ultimately, people are responsible for their own actions.  In conclusion, while there may be age restrictions or designated sections for more mature content, it is important to preserve the diversity of artistic expression. Limiting access to books or other forms of art based on personal preferences deprives individuals of the opportunity to explore new ideas and perspectives. Let each person choose what they consume, and do not take away the chance for someone else to discover something meaningful or transformative.

Books are part of history and should not be censored, as they provide valuable insights into the past. They serve as educational tools and offer lessons that can be learned from. While some books may contain content that is not suitable for younger audiences, it is important for individuals to be exposed to different perspectives and ideas. Teachers play a crucial role in selecting appropriate reading material for their students, ensuring that the content aligns with the educational goals of the classroom. Censoring books would limit access to important information and stifle intellectual freedom. It is essential for individuals to be able to make their own choices regarding what they read and to be responsible for their own consumption of media. Overall, censorship of books would be detrimental to the learning process and hinder the exploration of diverse viewpoints.

Removing books off of shelves in our public library? To me, that sounds crazy. It's diversity, some people love the down-to-earth literature, but some people can't handle it. Why take away something that only a few people disagree with?   I believe some of the best entertainment in libraries are the most offensive, but it is all fact. I mean, if this is such a problem there should be a certain section to find those things in. If people want to complain then they can get out of that section, because people like me will be in that section ready to learn about all these different varieties of entertainment. Whether if it's offensive or not. People may find some of it offensive, but I believe it makes that person stronger. It helps them realize how lucky they are that they're not being treated a certain way in the offensive book they're reading. It's just a piece of entertainment! If it offends you and you're not entertained, go find something that does!   Even though I hear of people reading offensive books I've never really seen one myself. I think some people just get offended too easily. That's where we should reason with them instead of giving into their demands. So what if they aren't taken off the shelves? Like I said, we can make a certain section for them type of things. If they aren't happy with the outcome, they will get over it.   Now that you read what I had to say, what do you think? Do you think we should remove certain entertainment off of library book shelves? Or should we just reason with the people who are offended? I hope what you read today helps keep books on the shelves and readers happy!

Should we have censorship in our libraries? This is a question that both sides can argue with credible facts. However, censorship is mostly defined as not allowing certain items or things to be seen or heard until a mature age. How can you tell when someone is of a mature age? Maturity lies behind one's ability to cope with various thoughts, ideas, actions, etc. Censorship should be allowed to an extent.  Censorship plays a big role in society today, shaping the content on television and in other media. While censorship has evolved over the years, it is still important to consider the impact of certain content on different age groups. Books should generally be accessible to children and adults of all ages, as literature can provide valuable knowledge and insights. Books can help expand the mind and facilitate learning.  When it comes to movies and magazines, some level of censorship may be necessary to protect the innocence of youth. Certain content, such as explicit sexual scenes, may not be suitable for young audiences. However, music should generally remain uncensored, as it is a form of expression that can be enjoyed by people of all ages.  Ultimately, censorship should be a personal choice, with adults determining what is appropriate for themselves and their families. While some forms of media may require censorship for certain age groups, it is important to allow individuals the freedom to explore and learn from a wide range of materials. In the end, everyone should have the right to choose what they read, watch, or listen to, as long as it contributes to their growth and understanding. Let's preserve the diversity of content in our libraries and trust individuals to make informed decisions about what they consume.

I don't believe that books, movies, and music should be removed because people should have the freedom to choose what they want to read, watch, and listen to. It is not up to others to dictate what content is acceptable for individuals to consume. People have the right to make their own decisions about what they find interesting or entertaining.  Individuals will naturally gravitate towards material that resonates with them, and they will determine what they want to expose themselves and their children to. It is not the responsibility of others to censor or restrict access to certain content based on personal preferences or beliefs. People are capable of making informed choices about what aligns with their values and interests.  In conclusion, people should be able to decide for themselves what they want to engage with in terms of books, movies, and music. It is a personal decision that should not be influenced or controlled by external factors. Everyone has the right to choose what they want to read, watch, and listen to without interference from others.

I feel that individuals should have the right to access a variety of materials from the library for personal information or research purposes. However, it is important to handle such materials maturely and ensure that inappropriate content is kept separate from general access to protect children and individuals who do not require such information. Creating designated areas or rooms for explicit content, with restricted access based on age and valid reasons for requesting such materials, can help prevent censorship while also safeguarding against unsuitable exposure. Ultimately, while freedom to access information is crucial, implementing certain guidelines and safeguards can ensure that the library remains a resourceful and responsible institution for all individuals.

Books should only be removed if they are found to be offensive to a certain degree. While some books may be meant for educational purposes and not intended to offend anyone, there are others that promote harmful ideas and stereotypes. It is important to strike a balance between allowing freedom of expression and protecting individuals from harmful content. Education is a key aspect of books, and many stories serve to inform and educate readers about important historical events and social issues. While censorship may be necessary in some cases to prevent the spread of harmful ideas, it is also important to consider the value that books can provide in educating and enlightening readers. Ultimately, the decision to remove books should be made carefully, considering the impact on society as a whole.
