One example from the book would be when they kill some of the children. Most people, like myself, do not agree with this idea. They think that it is wrong. Again some people may try to get this book banned, but it is still a wonderful literature.   As you may have seen in the media lately, many people are trying to get the book Adventures of Huckleberry Finn removed from schools. Some people have found the book as offensive because it repeatedly refers to Native Americans by a more profound word. The law has not passed yet and has remained in schools. The law hasn't passed because it does not affect everyone. Some people may not find this offensive. Therefore it was not removed.   Removing offensive books from libraries is the exact same thing. Some people may find the books offensive while others may not. Removing the books from everyone's reach would be appalling. The book may only be offensive to one race or religion. Why not simply put a warning label for that race or religion? That would take care of the problem by putting the decision of reading it and being offended in their hands. Possibly it isn't that the books are offensive to a race or religion, maybe it is to an age group. If that is the problem then the librarians can put those books in the appropriate age section.   I have given reasons from my own experiences, other readings, and my observations in the media. I only hope that you consider my ideas. Do not remove the books from the shelf only because it is offensive to one person. Simply put a warning label on the book after a few complaints. This would put the responsibility of being offended in their hands. Once again, I do not think that offensive materials should be removed from our libraries only censored to the people of whom it is offensive.

In @LOCATION1, the desire for censorship is strong among the diverse population to avoid being ostracized. While some censorship may be necessary, it can also be driven by a quest for attention. It becomes challenging to cater to the preferences of every group when multiple races seek censorship. This issue creates a cycle where one group's request for censorship may offend another, leading to a never-ending chain of demands.   However, when it comes to young children, censorship plays a crucial role in shaping their development. Exposing them to inappropriate content can influence their beliefs and values negatively, impacting their future. As individuals with varying perspectives, what one person perceives as wrong, another may view as acceptable. Criticizing someone's taste in movies or music ultimately questions their judgment, which is unfair.  In a world where interpretations vary widely, it is essential to acknowledge the diversity of opinions and exercise tolerance towards differing views. Without imposing excessive censorship, it is important to strike a balance that respects individual differences while safeguarding the well-being of the younger generation. Ultimately, fostering open-mindedness and understanding can help navigate the complexities surrounding censorship in a diverse society like @LOCATION1.

Books, music, movies, and magazines are all important sources of entertainment and education that should be accessible to everyone. While some people may find certain content offensive, it is not necessary to remove these materials from shelves or advertisements. Instead, there should be clear labeling or categorization to inform consumers about the content.  For example, radio stations play songs that touch on controversial topics like sex, drugs, and violence. While it may not be suitable for children, it is a reality that they will eventually come across these themes. Parents play a crucial role in monitoring and guiding their children's exposure to such content.  It is essential to recognize that everyone has different tastes and interests, and what may be offensive to one person may be enjoyable or thought-provoking to another. Therefore, censoring or removing materials based on individual sensitivities is not a practical solution.  In conclusion, rather than restricting access to certain forms of entertainment and study, it is more effective to provide appropriate information and guidance to help individuals make informed choices. This approach respects diversity of interests and opinions while also promoting responsible consumption of media.

I do not think libraries should have to censor the kinds of books, magazines, etc..., because people should have the right to read anything that they want. People do not necessarily like reading some things, but if it is important that they research something, or read a book for school then they need to have the resources available to them. Take the book, @CAPS1 in the @CAPS2, for example. In that book it describes kidnapping, and the rape of young girls. Certain classes would require you to read this book, even though no one would really want to read about that. Some people have different tastes in movies. Personally, I prefer horror movies (but not gory) because they get me thinking about what's going to happen next. Some people like the really graphic and gory movies, and maybe if the libraries started taking movies like this off the shelf, it would be harder for those people to find them. Certain people would find some things more offensive than other people. Who can say where it should stop? Movies that make fun or talk about religion would be offensive to the people in that religion, but people from other religions would be unaffected by it. Just imagine watching @CAPS3 and seeing someone talk about everything you believe in and joking around about it. It would really offend people, while other people couldn't care less. Basically, I think we have the right to read or watch whatever makes us happy, and if there is something out there that you do not want to see, you just have to ignore it and leave it alone. It should not be ruined for other people who would like to see it.

Censorship in media has a long history, dating back to the early days of @ORGANIZATION1. While some may argue that censorship limits freedom of expression, there are valid reasons for censoring certain types of content in libraries.  When it comes to books, it is important to consider the audience. Books that contain extremely offensive material should not be readily available to children. Libraries should exercise caution when selecting books to ensure that they are appropriate for their patrons.  Similarly, music with explicit lyrics or themes should be separated from children's music sections in libraries. Parents may not want their children exposed to inappropriate language or content at a young age, so it is important to keep such material in a designated area.  Movies, like music, can have a strong visual impact on viewers. Libraries should consider placing movies with explicit content in the adult section, where they are less likely to be accessed by children. Censoring inappropriate language or gestures in movies can help to protect younger audiences.  Magazines pose a unique challenge when it comes to censorship. While it may be difficult to censor magazines entirely, libraries can take steps to remove or cover up offensive content. Librarians should be vigilant in monitoring the materials available to patrons and be willing to address any concerns that arise.  Overall, censorship in libraries is necessary to ensure that all patrons can access materials that are appropriate for their age and sensibilities. By taking steps to restrict access to offensive content, libraries can create a safe and welcoming environment for all visitors.

Yes, I believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. Some people do not want to read about those things that they have less interest in. Materials like that can offend many people, so they should be removed from public shelves.  For example, someone may stumble upon a book containing inappropriate materials by accident. They could take it home and begin reading it, only to realize that the material offends them. This can be concerning and may hurt the reputation of the library that held the book, potentially leading to a loss of customers.  Another reason why inappropriate materials should not be publicly displayed is the impact on children. If a young child were to come across a book or magazine with offensive content, it could have a negative influence on them. Parents would understandably be upset and would likely advocate for the removal of such materials to protect their children.  Religion is also a factor to consider when deciding what materials should be available. Some religions may prohibit the consumption of inappropriate content, and unknowingly encountering such materials could deeply offend individuals. This could deter people from reading certain books or visiting establishments where such materials are available.  In conclusion, the presence of offensive materials can lead to people feeling offended and upset. This is why it is important to remove such materials from public shelves to prevent harm and maintain a respectful environment for all individuals.

As Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' As an author, she feels if she, and anyone else, has the right to take those uncensored books off the shelf, then there will be no books left. Depending on the person, some books may be offensive to some, but not all. I don't think that books should be able to be taken off the shelf by anyone because everyone's preference on books can be different. I believe that libraries should keep uncensored books in a certain section so children can easily be kept from seeing or reading inappropriate material at their age. And lastly, my own experience has led me to believe there should be a warning on certain books, saying not all the material could be appropriate.  People having the right to take any book off the shelf would be unfair for the people. The library is a quiet place, meant for people to come and read any type of book, do homework, study groups, and undergo research for practically any topic, and the number of books based on one person's opinion is unfair to everyone else who might enjoy that genre. Libraries and books were one of the main resources for researching before there was the internet and many people still prefer books to this day. I think the freedom of taking any book off the shelf would be endangering the process of learning and discovering.  To reduce the number of uncensored books being found by children or people who find them offensive, there should be a certain section in the library for just those books. That way, people who have an interest in those books can read them, but also they are kept away for those who don't want to read them. I think taking away any type of book is unfair to the people because everyone likes different genres of books, so having uncensored books in one section is fair to all. It would also be easier on parents knowing their children won't find books with material in them that they shouldn't be reading.  By disagreeing with the right to take any book off the shelf, I think each book with any uncensored material should be marked with some type of sticker on the binding, just as a warning. If one sees that sticker and knows they don't want books with that type of material, then they can easily return the book with no argument. I have had experience with trying to find a book for a school project, but later finding there was material in it that really wasn't appropriate for school. This made me have to find a new book for the project. I didn't want to completely take the book off the shelf and away from anyone else who wanted to read it, but a warning right then would have been easier in the situation.  In conclusion, I don't believe that certain materials should be taken off by just anyone. Taking away books would spark many disagreements because even though one person might find something offensive, doesn't mean every other person will. As mentioned before, putting the uncensored books in a different section and putting a sticker on the binding would give a clear warning to anyone not wanting to read uncensored books. I think every library needs to take into consideration the topics above to help people reduce the issue of people or children finding uncensored books in just any section.

I do not really read books. I think that offensive things should be taken off shelves because there could be a scene if they aren't. There are many people who will fight if they are truly offended, and it is not a pretty sight. Therefore, it is important for materials that may cause offense to be carefully considered and potentially removed from public consumption to avoid unnecessary conflicts.

I believe that as a library employee, it is important to ensure that the books available for young adults and children are appropriate and free from profanity, racism, and other inappropriate content. If a child were to bring home a book that was not suitable, it would be concerning and upsetting for parents. Therefore, I would conduct regular scans of all books in the library to ensure their appropriateness.  I also think that libraries should offer a wide range of inspiring books, cartoons, and baby books to cater to different age groups. It is essential to create a welcoming and safe environment for all library users, especially children. If a book is found to be inappropriate, I believe it should be removed from the shelves to protect young readers.  In addition, I suggest that libraries have dedicated rooms for different age groups, such as one for baby books and another for older children. This organization can make it easier for parents and children to find suitable reading materials. Overall, promoting a diverse and inspiring collection of books in libraries can encourage more people to read and enjoy the benefits of literature.

Censorship in libraries has always been a contentious issue, with individuals and governments having differing opinions on what should be deemed acceptable for public consumption. The power to censor materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines raises questions about who gets to decide what is deemed unacceptable. If one person has the right to censor something, then where does it end? Should the government have the authority to decide what we can and cannot read, listen to, or watch?  Literature and art are forms of expression that should not be censored, as they provide valuable insights into different perspectives and ideas. History has shown us that censorship can have negative effects on society and culture. For example, during the Nazi regime, many forms of artistic expression were banned, leading to a loss of creativity and innovation.  By allowing censorship, we run the risk of limiting our exposure to new and diverse ideas. It is important to protect our freedom to access a wide range of materials, as this is essential for intellectual growth and development. Ultimately, censorship stifles creativity and hinders progress. We must be vigilant in protecting our right to access information and ideas, as censorship can have far-reaching consequences for our society as a whole.

There has been a problem with censorship in libraries recently, with many items being removed due to being offensive. However, there are ways to handle offensive material without outright banning it. Warning labels can be used to alert parents and children to potentially offensive content, allowing parents to make informed decisions about what their children can access. Additionally, offensive material could be placed in a separate section of the library, where children would need parental supervision to access it. Ultimately, the decision of whether a child should be exposed to offensive material should be left to the parents, who can determine what is appropriate for their children. Censorship is not the solution; instead, providing information and restrictions can help manage potentially offensive material in libraries.

Everyone has their own opinions and arguments about books that may be offensive to some people. With a wide variety of genres available, it can be challenging to find the right book that interests us. Personally, I believe that books should not be removed from shelves, even if they offend someone.  Books cover a range of topics such as murders, romance, mysteries, and drugs, and they should be placed in separate sections within libraries. Removing books would infringe on individual freedom, as everyone has the right to access different types of literature.  While some may argue that certain books could negatively influence young children, it is the responsibility of adults to guide them and monitor their selections. Libraries offer a variety of materials, including movies and music, which should be organized into appropriate sections for different age groups.  It is important to recognize that people have diverse preferences, and what may offend one person may appeal to another. Restricting access to certain books due to individual sensitivities undermines the principles of freedom of choice and expression.  Libraries provide a tranquil environment that can have a positive impact on everyday life. Maintaining a wide selection of books without censorship allows individuals to explore various subjects and perspectives. Removing materials only restricts access for everyone.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries should be minimal to preserve individual freedoms. Rather than removing books, appropriate categorization and guidance for different age groups can ensure that everyone can access literature that interests them.

There are many arguments surrounding the censorship of offensive books and the impact they may have on children. Some believe that offensive material should be removed from shelves, while others argue that they should be available for those who wish to read them. Parents often blame offensive material for their children's inappropriate behavior, while others attribute it to poor parenting. It is evident that opinions on this topic vary greatly.  In my view, there are certain offensive materials that serve a purpose and should remain on shelves. These materials can educate children about the consequences of bad behavior and help them differentiate between right and wrong. On the other hand, materials that promote harmful behavior without justification should be removed as they can influence children negatively.  I believe that children should be exposed to offensive material that carries a meaningful message, such as raising awareness about past atrocities like slavery. These materials can help children develop empathy and a sense of social responsibility. However, materials that glorify violence or discrimination without a valid reason should not be accessible to children as they can lead to harmful consequences.  I have seen instances where individuals were influenced negatively by offensive material, leading them to engage in illegal activities. Conversely, there have been cases where individuals were positively impacted by books, prompting them to adopt better attitudes and behaviors. Personally, I have been influenced positively by reading materials that shed light on historical injustices, prompting me to treat others with kindness and respect.  In conclusion, the censorship of offensive materials should be approached with caution. While some materials can be educational and enlightening, others can have detrimental effects on individuals, especially children. It is important to discern between offensive materials that serve a purpose and those that are simply harmful, to ensure a positive impact on readers.

Removing books from the library because they are offensive is not a good idea. Instead of completely getting rid of these books, there should be age limits set for certain materials. By implementing age restrictions, we can protect children from inappropriate content while still preserving history and upholding freedom of speech. It is important to keep books accessible but ensure that they are only read by the appropriate audience. By doing so, we can maintain a balance between protecting young minds, preserving important historical accounts, and respecting the rights of authors to express themselves freely. Let's keep books available for those who can appreciate and understand their content, ensuring that valuable perspectives and stories are not lost.

Many people claim that certain books should be allowed on library shelves. They argue that these books, known as 'banned books,' can be offensive to some and should not be read. Librarians and public officials should not have the right to choose who reads certain books and who does not.  In the novel To Kill a Mockingbird, the author uses offensive language that is essential to the setting of the novel. The novel provides a valuable insight into the history of the time period. Censoring such books would limit our understanding of the past.  Similarly, the novel, Catcher in the Rye, includes curse words and sexual references that are necessary to portray the characters and their development. Censoring these elements would dilute the authenticity of the story.  It is not just literature that faces censorship, but also music, movies, magazines, and video games. While some content may not be suitable for young children, it is the responsibility of parents to monitor what their children consume. Shielding patrons from real-life occurrences like violence and prejudice does not benefit anyone.  In conclusion, authors should not be restricted in their use of language or descriptions. Libraries should offer a diverse range of materials, leaving it up to individuals to choose what aligns with their personal boundaries. Censorship should not be imposed by librarians or public officials. Freedom of expression and access to information are essential in a democratic society.

Works of literature, regardless of their content, should be housed in library shelves. However, if certain material is considered offensive or crude, it can be placed in a restricted section where access requires permission. Literature holds persuasive power, so it is important to control who can access certain content. Authors write with various motives, such as profit or sharing viewpoints, and they desire their work to be read. Removing books entirely from libraries would hinder this goal. Even if a topic is considered crude, it may still be necessary for educational or research purposes. By restricting access to such material, libraries can cater to those who genuinely need it while preventing unnecessary exposure. Destroying literature due to offense or discomfort is futile. Instead, creating designated areas within libraries for controversial material ensures that those interested or in need can access it while respecting the sensibilities of others. It is crucial to preserve diverse literary works and provide access to them in a controlled manner to uphold the value and importance of literature in society.

Everyone has their own opinion about certain things in life. Maybe its politics; it could be a sports team. Everyone has a right to their own opinion. As for reading materials, the opinions could be endless and even painful to hear.   Opinions of some books and media type materials are biased. People could often be offended by the materials that can be accessed through a public library. For instance, let's say a grandmother and her grandchild are at the public library. The grandchild picks up a self-help book and starts to read. Later the grandmother reads it and finds out it says everything opposite of what the grandchild was taught about life by herself and her parents. To the grandmother, @CAPS1 is offensive.   Through observation, I have noticed when a person picks up 'an offensive book' and reads a little of it, they tend to put it right back where they found it. It obviously isn't hard to do. So why should a book be taken out of a library when all you have to do is set it down and leave it? The same goes for music, movies, and magazines. If you don't like the music, don't listen to it. If you don't think it would be a 'nice' movie, don't go out and see it. If the magazine seems raunchy, don't buy it.   @PERSON1 said it well, that if we took all the offensive books off the shelf '...then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' @CAPS1 statement is as true as any statement could be. What would be left? Everyone has an opinion and likely someone will always find it offensive. Therefore offensive books and media should be allowed to stay on the shelves.   Whether or not you find a book, movie, music, or magazine that is offensive, why fret over it? It's just easier to move on and forget it. Ignorance isn't all bad. Ultimately, it's important to remember that everyone is entitled to their own opinions, and it's best to simply let offensive materials be and move on if they don't align with your views.

Taking books off the shelves will not change anything children are just going to a different place to find the book, such as a bookstore or other libraries if they like it. If I see a book that I know I'm not supposed to read but find it interesting, I would still get it because children naturally explore. Books are meant to be read and looked at, so if there are restrictions, age verification should be required.  It's important to understand that children are naturally curious and should be encouraged to read and explore different types of literature. While some books may not be suitable for certain age groups, completely restricting access may not be the best solution. Children need to be exposed to the world around them, and books are a great way to do that.  Music, books, and magazines can all have a significant impact on children. Music, in particular, can resonate with them in ways that adults may not understand. It's important for parents to guide their children towards appropriate content, but also allow them to explore and learn on their own. Overly restricting children may only lead them to seek out forbidden material behind their parents' backs.  In conclusion, while it's important for parents to monitor their children's reading material and media consumption, it's also important to allow them some freedom to explore and learn on their own. Books, music, and magazines can all play a valuable role in a child's development, and it's important to strike a balance between protection and freedom.

When you go to the library, you have a lot of choices when it comes to reading books, watching movies, or listening to music. However, some of these materials may contain offensive words or abusive language that is not appropriate for children. Students should have the right to remove any offensive material from the library if they are offended or uncomfortable. This includes books, music, and movies that may contain inappropriate content.  Books are a common item found in libraries, and some of them may contain offensive language or themes. If a student finds something in a book that is offensive to them, they should have the right to have it removed from the library shelves. Similarly, music in the library should also be monitored for inappropriate content, and any songs containing offensive language or themes should be removed.  Movies in the library may also contain scenes that are not suitable for children, such as violence or abusive language. It is important to check the ratings of movies before watching them to ensure that they are appropriate for the audience. Any movies that contain content that is not suitable for students should not be available in the library.  In conclusion, libraries are valuable resources for learning and entertainment, but it is important to ensure that the materials available are appropriate for all users. Students should have the right to remove any books, music, or movies that contain offensive language or themes, as these materials may not be suitable for a school environment.

Alot of people are offeneded by things that are uncenored.  Some peopole think they should be censored and others think it should not.  Its all a matter of opinion.  I dont think anything should be censored because it takes away from the freedom of speech.     With censorship one can not fully express there self or opinion.  that is way nothing should be censored.  Censorship limits the ability of individuals to express themselves freely. It restricts the flow of information and hinders the exchange of ideas. Without censorship, people can openly discuss various topics without fear of reprisal. This allows for a more open and democratic society where diverse viewpoints can be shared and debated. Ultimately, the freedom of speech should be upheld to ensure that everyone has the right to express themselves without unnecessary restrictions.

I strongly disagree with the idea of removing any materials from public shelves. Books, magazines, and other materials are based on the author's and musician's experiences and observations. With a population of readers in society, the removal of books based on content would have a negative impact. Writers pour their observations and personal experiences into their work, so why take that away because of differing opinions on wording or content? Movies and music also face scrutiny, with some believing that certain genres or songs should not be exposed to children. However, artists have a right to their own opinions and connections with their audience. Removing materials based on minor issues diminishes the work of the artist and restricts the freedom of expression. It is important to respect the artistic process and allow individuals to make their own choices regarding the materials they consume. The diversity of perspectives and experiences in literature, film, and music enriches society and should not be censored.

Where it all boils down, censorship plays a vital role in shaping our society. From music to books to television, the need to filter out inappropriate content is crucial for the well-being of individuals, especially the younger generation. While some may argue that censorship limits freedom of expression, it is necessary to protect the values and morals of our society. By censoring out vulgar language, explicit content, and harmful messages, we can create a better environment for everyone. Let us strive to uphold censorship in a way that promotes positivity and respect, paving the way for a brighter tomorrow.

Censorship is a contentious issue with valid arguments on both sides. While some advocate for leaving all content untouched, others believe that offensive material should be restricted. However, determining what is too graphic for students can be subjective. Historical texts, even if deemed offensive, are crucial for learning from the past and preventing its repetition. Similarly, entertainment genres like horror should not be censored as they serve a purpose in stimulating creativity and imagination.  By censoring books, individuals are denied their right to freedom of speech, inhibiting expression and stifling potential ideas that could shape the world. Books are valuable sources of knowledge and insight, with the power to educate and inspire readers. Removing certain books from libraries could result in missed opportunities for learning and growth, as well as depriving future generations of valuable lessons from the past.  All books, regardless of content, should be kept accessible to readers. Students have the choice to engage with material that interests them, and each book has the potential to offer unique perspectives and lessons. The preservation of diverse literature ensures a rich tapestry of ideas and experiences for individuals to explore and learn from. Ultimately, books play a vital role in expanding knowledge and fostering critical thinking skills that are essential for personal and societal development.

Libraries contain a wealth of knowledge and entertainment in the form of books, magazines, and movies. Censoring these materials would deprive the public of valuable information and perspectives. The government may have various reasons for wanting to censor books, such as concerns about racism, radical ideas, or inappropriate content for children. However, censoring books would limit people's access to diverse ideas and stifle intellectual growth. Parents may want to shield their children from certain content, but censorship should not dictate what the public can or cannot read. Allowing censorship in libraries could hinder societal progress and innovation, as it limits the exchange of ideas and perspectives. In a society where everyone is meant to be equal, censorship could prevent individuals from reaching their full potential and hinder overall progress. Censorship should be avoided in libraries to ensure that people have the freedom to explore different viewpoints and expand their knowledge.

There are many things out in the 'material' world that people take offense to. No matter what, there are always those people who have to be against whatever it is, whether it be a book or a song or a movie. But they do not have any idea what they are doing when they bring up their 'rights'. If they get to say that they are offended by the certain media product, not only do they announce that they have the right to try to have it banned, but they are giving the people who do not find offense in the material to dish out the same. If they can pull something off the shelves that they 'find offense to', then everyone has a right to. Another thing is that they claim to find offense to the song or book or movie, but if it bothers them that bad, they should just not listen/read/watch what it is that they are feeling offends them. It would be that simple, just switch radio stations, or pick up another book, or watch a different movie. Another thing that the 'offended' people can try is having an open mind. It would make everything far less dramatic.  People that say that they have offense to whatever the material may be usually use the phrase 'it's offensive and i don't want my kid to stumble across it.' They say that they have a right to take whatever the 'offensive material' is off the shelf and keep it from the public. They couldn't be more right and stupid at the same time! If they have a right to take a certain thing off the shelf, then the writer of the song/book/movie can claim that he has been offended by some song/book/movie that the first person likes. Then it's just a free-for-all for everyone one to start taking everything off the shelves, one by one. Everyone has the same rights, and if the first offended person uses them to bring something down, then the creator has the right to do the exact same thing. So the government shouldn't let things be taken off of shelves, because if they take one down, they might as well take everything else down with it.  So, if someone finds offense to a song they hear on the radio, and they feel that strongly as to they want it removed from radios and anywhere that plays music, then they need help. When they find that song THAT offensive, then there is only one simple solution: turn the freaking radio to something else! Seriously, if someone finds the song offensive, then why are they going to sit there and listen to the entire song? Or if they find a book offensive. Would I sit and read an entire book if I don't like the content? Umm, no. If someone is that offended by whatever the material is, then they need to just do something else, because it's pretty ridiculous to waste more time attempting to ban the song or the book that to just change the radio or find a different book. So if you're going to complain about the song or book being out there, just take your attention to something else, because every song, book, or movie out there has a right to be sold.  On a light note, they could just have an open mind so that the song, or the book, or the movie can still be sold. They can try and read through the book to see if there is a reason that the author has written it this way. If they are conflicted by a movie, they should just watch it and test it to see if they really need to have it pulled off the shelf. Or if they are listening to the song, listen to it all the way through, or maybe even twice. The artist who sang the song might have been expressing themselves in a very deep way, and if someone pulls their song off the radio or where it is played, then someone could be offending them in return. Having an open mind will let the so-called 'offended person' see a whole other light being shown on why the 'offensive material' was even created. Then everything can stay ON the shelves!  People have opinions, and that is one hundred percent okay. But sometimes people think that their opinions are the only opinions that matter. If some people get offended (or think they get offended) by something, they would try to remove whatever it was from the nation's stores. But if they just sit back and think about it, then it would be okay. If they have a right to remove anything from the shelves, so does everyone. If that one song really, really offends they, they should just change the radio station and forget about it. And if they have open minds as to why the things are still 'out there', then all the songs, and all the books, and all the movies will still be on the shelves for people to buy. I do not approve of removing anything from stores just because one person feels like if they don't like it, then

Controversy in the library arises when individuals are confronted with a vast array of books that may include some which are deemed offensive to certain readers. However, it is crucial for a public library to maintain a wide selection of books to cater to the diverse interests of its patrons. Removing books that offend a specific group of people would ultimately limit the choices available to others, as Katherine Paterson aptly pointed out, "And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us."  Public libraries serve as a place for individuals to freely choose their reading materials. While some may find certain books offensive, it is essential to remember that everyone has different tastes and preferences. By preserving a variety of books, libraries can ensure that there is something for everyone. People have the autonomy to select books that align with their beliefs and values, and they are not compelled to read anything that they find objectionable.  In essence, libraries should strive to offer a broad spectrum of books to cater to the diverse needs of their readers. It is not feasible nor fair to eliminate books simply because they may offend a small segment of the population. The beauty of a library lies in its ability to provide a space where individuals can explore different perspectives and ideas through the written word. Ultimately, the presence of potentially offensive books should not deter people from utilizing the library as a valuable resource for learning and intellectual growth.

Personally, I believe that items that are found offensive should be left on the bookshelves. People who find them offensive can simply choose not to engage with them and move on with their lives. In educational settings like libraries, it is important to have a wide range of materials available for students to access for their projects and research. Removing offensive materials would limit students' access to important information they may need. Additionally, offensive materials can be found elsewhere, such as on the internet, so censoring libraries would not solve the issue. Libraries should have the freedom to choose the materials they provide, as long as they are properly categorized to ensure appropriate access for different age groups. Overall, if someone finds a book, movie, or any other material offensive, they can simply avoid it and choose not to engage with it. Offensiveness is subjective, and what may be offensive to one person may not be to another. It is important to respect diverse perspectives and allow individuals to make their own choices regarding the materials they engage with.

Yes, I do think it is important to have a variety of books available in bookstores, as everyone has different preferences and interests. People enjoy reading different genres and topics, so having a diverse selection can cater to a wider audience. While it may be important to consider the content of books in children's bookstores, for general bookstores, having a mix of materials can attract a larger customer base. Ultimately, the most crucial aspect is that people are reading and learning, regardless of the type of material they choose. The availability of movies, magazines, and music in bookstores can also add to the overall experience and appeal to a broader range of customers. In the end, what matters most is that people have access to a variety of reading materials and resources that spark their interest and curiosity.

@CAPS2, I agree that offensive content in books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from shelves. It is important to consider the impact of media on individuals and how it can be hurtful or disrespectful. For example, portraying negative stereotypes about gender, sexual orientation, or disabilities can be very harmful and offensive to those who identify with these groups. Additionally, making fun of people who are less fortunate financially can also be hurtful and perpetuate harmful attitudes towards those in poverty. Overall, it is crucial to be mindful of the content we consume and ensure that it does not promote discrimination or hurt others. Removing offensive material from shelves is a step towards creating a more inclusive and respectful society.

Books, music, and movies are forms of art and entertainment that can help individuals understand the world around them. While some may argue that censoring these forms of media protects children from harmful content, it is essential to consider that exposure to different perspectives can help them navigate real-life situations better. By limiting access to these mediums, parents may unintentionally hinder their children's ability to develop critical thinking skills and empathy towards others. It is crucial to find a balance between protecting children and allowing them to explore different ideas and experiences through books, music, and movies. Ultimately, exposure to diverse forms of art can enhance a child's understanding of the world and prepare them for the challenges they may face in the future.

Nobody should believe that we have the choice to take books off the shelves of a library. America is a free country, and we can write whatever we want. Everyone has the freedom of speech, whether expressed through music, books, or movies. If you come across a book that seems offensive, simply put it back on the shelf and move on.   Offensive content is prevalent in various forms of media, from jokes to literature. However, it is essential to remember that these are often meant for entertainment and not to be taken seriously. For instance, if a book like "@CAPS1's your @CAPS2" is not to your liking, simply set it aside and find something more suitable to read.   Allowing individuals to remove offensive material from libraries would ultimately limit the diversity of available literature. In contrast, movies have ratings to guide viewers on content suitability. There are designated sections for mature audiences, ensuring that inappropriate material is not easily accessible to young viewers.   In essence, censoring reading material sets a dangerous precedent. It is akin to suppressing diverse perspectives and limiting intellectual freedom. Instead of removing offensive content, individuals can exercise their freedom by choosing what to read or watch. By respecting differing viewpoints, we can uphold the principles of free speech and intellectual exploration.

Censorship in libraries has become too strict, limiting access to important lessons about life for the next generation. Imagine going to a library as an adult and only being able to check out children's books, magazines, and music. This extreme scenario highlights the impact of censorship on knowledge and freedom. Without access to a wide range of materials, we risk losing valuable insights, creativity, and growth.  Censorship affects various forms of media, including music, magazines, and books. While some content may be deemed inappropriate for certain age groups, excessive censorship can hinder the exploration of diverse perspectives and ideas. For example, classic books like "The Catcher in the Rye" have been removed from libraries due to a few cuss words, depriving readers of important literary works.  In balancing the right to free speech with the need for censorship, it is crucial to consider age-appropriate restrictions. Adults should have access to uncensored materials, while teens may require some level of guidance on certain content. Children, on the other hand, may benefit from limited censorship to protect their innocence.  Ultimately, censorship should not restrict access to valuable information and artistic expression. By embracing a more open-minded approach to censorship in libraries, we can preserve knowledge, encourage critical thinking, and uphold our freedom of expression. Let us not let fear of controversial content overshadow the importance of intellectual freedom.

Yes, some materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., are offensive. Yet they shouldn't be removed from shelves. Reason number one is: some people find offensive, others don't. Offensive material will always be out in the world. And finally, if parents don't want their children reading offensive material, they should only ban their children from reading them and not the rest of the world. In following essay, I will explain thoroughly my reasons for an opinion as such. '@CAPS1 is one man's trash is another man's treasure.' This quote goes very well with the first reason: some people find offensive, others don't. People's views about everything could be significantly different. For example, a book about killing the could be offensive to someone with descent, meanwhile, a book filled with cursing could be offensive to a religious person. As you can see, 'offensive' is defined differently by different people. Offensive material will always be out in the world. Parents can't shelter their child from these things forever. At one point in their lives, children will learn offensive things and parents won't be able to do anything about that. Children have active minds that pick up on everything around them. If they learn from these offensive materials, then parents should teach them what is wrong and what is right. Finally, if parents don't want their children reading offensive material, they should only ban their children from reading them and not the rest of the world. This reason ties in perfectly with the first. Parents can't decide what the parents of other children should do. They can only do something about what their children are doing. Therefore, my belief on censorship in libraries is non-existent for the following reasons: some people find offensive, others don't, offensive material will always be out in the world, and if parents don't want their children reading offensive material, they should only ban their own children from reading them and not the rest of the world. Thus, there should be no censorship in libraries.

Should we censor the materials in libraries? Some people believe that some of the books, magazines, and music in libraries are too vulgar and obscene. This could be a major problem if people are allowed to say what is too obscene to be put in a library. Katherine Paterson makes a great point by saying that if everyone was allowed to take books, magazines, and music that they find inappropriate off the shelves, there would be nothing left for us.  Books have been around for centuries. They are passed on, shared, and enjoyed by people all over the world. Books contain important information, stories, and tales of people's past times. Therefore, I do not believe that certain books should be banned from libraries. By taking away books in libraries, you are taking away the author's freedom of speech. Also, technology is rapidly advancing, and sometime in the future, I think libraries will become extinct. With all of the new devices we have today, people can just get their books online.  Magazines are a great tool to advertise and talk about some major topics happening around the world. Magazines are a great thing to read when you want to catch up on news, sports, or just other miscellaneous topics. With that said, magazines can also be bad for public libraries due to some of the explicit content. This is a reason on why some people would want to get rid of magazines from libraries, but I don't think they should be banned. By getting rid of magazines, you take away company's freedom of press, which is a major issue. Referring to the previous paragraph, technology is growing, and it is very easy to just go and look at news, sports, and other topics on the internet. That is why I do not think magazines should be taken out of libraries.  My final discussion is music. Music has also been around for many centuries and it has done many things. Music is something everyone can relate to. No matter who you are, you probably have some favorite band, music artist, or genre of music that you prefer. By saying this, I do not think music should be taken out of libraries either. Taking away music is like taking away humans natural culture. We all enjoy it, but have different versions that we enjoy. Therefore, I do not think it would be wise to take away music from libraries.  In conclusion, libraries are nothing without all the history, stories, news, and music that is inside of it. Censoring the libraries would not be a good idea and it would most likely upset many people. It is true that with technology that libraries may eventually become extinct. Until that happens, I hope they do not censor their materials.

Most people have been debating on whether or not to stop giving out books, movies, music, magazines, and so on, if they are disturbing other people's lives and offending them to the point of infuriation, thus disturbing the peace. However, it is important to consider that individuals have the right to choose what they read and listen to, and should not be punished for enjoying material that others may find disturbing. It is unfair to restrict access to certain content simply because it may not be to everyone's liking. Ultimately, people should be free to make their own choices and should not be judged or penalized for their preferences. In the end, what may be unsettling to some can be empowering to others, and diversity in content allows for personal growth and individual expression.

Most movies, magazines, music, and books are considered offensive to at least one person in this world. These materials often fall victim to censorship and are challenged daily to be banned, especially books. Mothers and fathers do have the right to prohibit such materials, but they do not have the right to ban them from all the world's children. Whatever the reasoning should be censorship is wrong. It restricts the freedom of the writer, the freedom of the reader, and, as Katherine Paterson well put it, would result in 'no books left on the shelf for any of us.'   In addition to the right of the writer to express themselves freely, every person over the age of eighteen has the right to read anything they wish. They are no longer under the commands of their legal guardians and in no way are under the command of other children's parents. Parents who prefer their own children not to see or listen to certain materials have the right to censor the materials away from their children, but they should not impose these restrictions on others.   Censorship limits the growth and learning experiences of both the audience and the writer. If every piece of offensive material were to be banned, the world would be devoid of diverse perspectives and creativity. It is crucial to uphold the freedom of speech and press to ensure a society where individuals can freely express themselves and engage with a variety of ideas. In conclusion, censorship is detrimental to intellectual freedom and should be avoided to preserve the richness of literature and art in society.

The library is a valuable resource, but there are certain materials that should not be openly accessible to the public. Censorship is necessary to protect individuals from harmful or offensive content that may be found in libraries. It is important to consider the potential impact of allowing unrestricted access to certain materials, especially when it comes to protecting vulnerable populations such as children and the elderly. By implementing censorship measures, we can create a safer and more inclusive environment for all library patrons.

I say that they shouldn't take off books that are found offensive and here's why. Authors put effort into their work, and it's unfair to censor it based on one person's opinion. Additionally, a book might be valuable and engaging to many, despite being offensive to a few. Overall, removing books because of one person's offense limits freedom of expression and access to diverse perspectives.

All of the materials in a library should have to be checked out before anyone can take them out of the library. If materials are not checked out, it can cause confusion and inconvenience for both students and the librarian. Additionally, if materials are lost, the responsible party will have to pay for the item, and the availability of the material will be delayed for other students. Checking out materials from the library is essential for maintaining organization and accessibility for all library users.

Yes, I believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves of a library if they are deemed offensive. People should feel comfortable and safe when visiting a public library, and having potentially offensive material readily available can detract from that experience. This is especially important for children and seniors who may be more sensitive to such content. It is essential to maintain a respectful and inclusive environment in libraries by ensuring that the materials available are appropriate for all patrons. If someone finds a particular book or item offensive, they should have the ability to report it so that appropriate action can be taken. Ultimately, the goal is to create a welcoming and enriching space for all visitors to enjoy without encountering offensive or inappropriate material.

Books, Music, Movies, and Magazines have been censored to protect children, parents, and religious individuals from inappropriate content. Children's minds are impressionable and exposing them to violence, vulgar language, or inappropriate themes can have long-lasting effects. Parents have the right to control what their children are exposed to, whether it be in the car, at home, or in school. For individuals with strong religious beliefs, it is important to avoid content that goes against their values and beliefs. Censorship helps maintain a positive and respectful community environment, ensuring that individuals are not influenced in negative ways. It is crucial to promote a culture of respect and decency in all forms of media to shape a better future for society.

I believe that controversial books should be left on the shelves. People often take things too seriously, and what some find offensive, others may find interesting. It is important to remember that everyone has different perspectives and preferences. While some content may not be to everyone's liking, it is not fair to censor material based on individual sensitivities. Magazines are another source of controversy, often judging people based on superficial factors like appearance or personal relationships. It is crucial for individuals to focus on themselves rather than constantly comparing themselves to others. By prioritizing self-care and self-improvement, we can reduce unnecessary conflicts and negativity in society. Ultimately, allowing diverse perspectives and opinions to exist can lead to a more inclusive and understanding community.

Different books are meant for different people, and while there may be restrictions on certain materials in public, it is essential to stay informed about global events. Just as individuals have diverse preferences, creators develop content to cater to specific audiences, bringing joy and fulfillment to those who appreciate their work. In this ever-changing world, it is important to cherish what we have and find happiness in the present moment. Embracing diversity and seeking understanding can lead to a more enriched and fulfilling existence.

Do you really want your kids to see bad images or read inappropriate content? It is important to teach them what is right and wrong, good or bad, to help them develop a clear conscience. My parents also ensure that we are not exposed to inappropriate material on television by changing the channel or turning it off. It is essential to be mindful of what our children are exposed to and take steps to protect them from harmful influences.

To whom it may concern:  As time progresses in our ever-evolving world, the issue of censorship continues to be a topic of debate. Censorship often restricts content deemed 'offensive,' leading to limitations in what we can access. It appears that people nowadays are more easily offended, as media is now more censored than ever before. Personally, I am tired of having information withheld from me.  Most censorship in our country is governed by established programs, but I believe that individuals should have the right to choose what they want to see. Why should others dictate what is suitable for us to view? No one knows our preferences better than ourselves, so why shouldn't we have the freedom to decide?  If censorship does not govern our daily lives, why should it control the media we consume? People are bound to come across things they find unpleasant, but it ultimately depends on how they perceive it. Censorship infringes upon our rights as citizens to freely express ourselves. If something is not to our liking, we have the power to look away.  In conclusion, censorship in media should not be imposed on us without our consent. We should have the autonomy to choose what we want to see or hear, without external interference. Let us take control of our viewing experiences and exercise our right to free speech without unnecessary restrictions.

Should materials, such as books, music, movies, or magazines be removed from the shelves if they are offensive? I don't think so, because it might not be offensive to everybody, it would be breaking the law, and it's not fair to the artists that created them. Just because something is offensive to one person does not mean it is offensive to everyone. For example, some may find certain content offensive while others do not. It is all subjective. Removing offensive materials would also violate the freedom of speech for artists. They should have the right to create whatever they want without censorship. Therefore, it is not fair to remove materials simply because they may be offensive to some individuals. Ultimately, everyone has the right to express themselves freely through their art without fear of censorship.

Censorship is a method used to limit inappropriate content, commonly seen in movies, video games, and television. In today's modern world, it is essential to consider implementing censorship in libraries as well. Just like how precautionary measures are taken on televisions, computers, and phones, libraries should also have a system in place to prevent children from accessing inappropriate materials.  A mandatory block should be in place in libraries, categorizing books by age group to restrict certain materials from reaching children who are not mature enough. It is important to acknowledge that some materials are not suitable for younger children, as they can heavily influence their thoughts and actions. By censoring what children read, view, or listen to in libraries, we can prevent them from being exposed to content that may not be age-appropriate.  In conclusion, implementing censorship in libraries is crucial to ensure that children have access to suitable materials for their age. By categorizing books and restricting certain content, we can create a safer environment for children to explore and enjoy reading without the risk of encountering inappropriate material.

Your beliefs are varied and complex, encompassing the idea that offensive media should not be removed from public consumption. Ultimately, you emphasize the importance of personal responsibility in choosing what to engage with and respecting the beliefs of others, even if they differ from your own. In a world filled with diverse perspectives, it is essential to navigate these differences with understanding and tolerance.

limit access to certain information. It is important for individuals to have the freedom to choose what they want to read and educate themselves on. Librarys are filled with a variety of materials, including books on different subjects like history, science, and art. Libraries are essential places of learning, providing access to a wide range of materials for educational, cultural, and entertainment purposes. While some may argue for censorship of certain materials, it is important to recognize the value of diverse perspectives and information in a library setting. Libraries should strive to maintain an open access to information, ensuring that all individuals have the opportunity to learn and grow. Some people believe that certain materials in libraries should be removed due to their potentially offensive nature. However, it is important to consider that what one person finds offensive, another may not. Families have varying levels of tolerance for different forms of media, such as movies, music, and books. If someone were to remove @CAPS4 work off of the shelves of libraries, he would remove one of the most important pieces of @CAPS5 literature.  '@ORGANIZATION2' by @PERSON3 is a book that explores the life of a convict in prison. During his time at @LOCATION2, he discovers that he is a homosexual. He falls in love with a man named @PERSON5 and begins to have sexual relationships with @CAPS2 of the men in his cell. These relationships are described in detail. What would happen if everyone could remove the books they dislike? The answer would be a society that is unable to share ideas, concerns, and experiences. Media helps to enlighten, persuade, and educate people about important issues. While some works @MONTH1 have offensive language, they also have a deeper meaning. A society that censors its media risks losing valuable insights and perspectives, hindering intellectual growth and understanding. It is essential to preserve diverse voices and narratives, even if they may be uncomfortable or controversial, in order to foster a richer and more informed society.

To the newspaper edits,Should books, music, movies, magazines, and other reading materials, be removed if the materials are view to be offensive? I do not think that is a good idea. Reasons why is that just like what @PERSON1 an Author (in the last sentence) said if we remove books from shelfs there will be 'no more books for any of us to read'. Another reason why not to remove the reading materials is because it @MONTH1 make other reads feel like they are not alone. Like a true story about a break up, of a family or a relationship. Finally the last reason why not to remove the materials from the shelves is because if you remove the material from the shelf it is likely that the topic is still there. And if that could even happening which is unlikely that it would people can still talk. And there is nothing that can stop people from talking. 'you can lock a bird in a cage but it still wants to fly away' or 'you can tell a cat or a dog not to run away but when you turn away it is gone' this are examples of what I am trying to say, you can try to remove books, music, magazines, but the topic you don't like is still out there.  I understand that reading some materials @MONTH1 offend you but it's better to just turn your head around and move on.
