Censorship can have both positive and negative effects on society. While it may protect individuals from harmful or inappropriate content, it can also lead to a lack of transparency and control over information. People may feel restricted and frustrated when they are not allowed access to certain materials, leading to a sense of being kept in the dark by those in power. Ultimately, the decision to censor material should be carefully considered, weighing the potential benefits and drawbacks to ensure a balance between protection and freedom of information.

I somewhat agree with taking out books, music, movies, magazines, or any other material that could be offensive to someone, as it could contain racial content or inappropriate material for children. However, it ultimately depends on the individual's perspective and interests. While it may not be fair to remove certain books from libraries due to differing opinions on what is appropriate, caution should be exercised, especially when it comes to content that may be harmful to children. Parents and adults should review materials before allowing children access to them. In the end, it is up to individuals to decide what they find acceptable in the media they consume.

I believe that every person has the choice to not read a book or magazine, or even watch a movie, if they find it offensive. 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no book left on the shelf for any of us.' This quote from the author, Katherine Paterson, resonates with me. If everyone had the right to remove a book they disliked or found offensive, there would be limited choices for readers.   I do not believe that people should be able to remove books from shelves based on their personal preferences. Everyone has a different opinion or perspective about books, and having a diverse range of options is essential. People should have the opportunity to explore different genres, themes, and ideas, even if they may not align with their own beliefs. Removing books based on individual preferences would limit intellectual freedom and the exchange of diverse viewpoints. Therefore, it is important to uphold the principle of allowing a variety of books to remain accessible in public libraries for readers to choose from.

Offensive books, music, magazines, and movies should not be removed from library shelves. While some may find them inappropriate, they are essential for people who enjoy reading and entertainment. The internet poses a greater risk to corrupting minds than offensive material in libraries. People have different tastes, and offensive content can make books more interesting and engaging. It is important to preserve these materials for the enjoyment and enrichment of readers, despite the concerns of some individuals.

Books, movies, and magazines all offer unique forms of learning and entertainment. While some individuals may prefer one over the others, each has its own value in providing knowledge and insight. Books, with their in-depth exploration of topics, offer a detailed and thorough learning experience. Movies, on the other hand, present information in a visually stimulating way that can capture the viewer's attention and provide a different perspective. Magazines, with their concise articles, offer quick and easy access to information on a variety of subjects.  Music, though primarily seen as a form of entertainment, can also have educational value for some individuals. It can inspire, motivate, and evoke emotions that contribute to personal growth and development. While it may not provide the same level of detailed information as books or movies, music has the power to connect with people on an emotional level and enhance their overall well-being.  In conclusion, each form of media has its own unique benefits and can contribute to individual learning and personal growth in different ways. Rather than removing any form of media from shelves, it is important to recognize the value that each one brings and embrace the diverse ways in which they can enrich our lives.

I am a student from @CAPS1. I wanted to share that I have come across some interesting books in both my school's library and the public library. However, there have been complaints from friends and family members about the books available. Some have suggested removing books that are not to their liking, but I believe that taking books out would not be beneficial.  Firstly, my friends have expressed dissatisfaction with the selection of books in the school library. If books are removed based on individual preferences, it may discourage others from utilizing the library. Access to a variety of books is essential for students to excel in their studies and limiting this access could hinder their academic progress.  Additionally, a family member witnessed a young girl reading an inappropriate book at the public library. Rather than removing such books, they should be placed in a designated section not accessible to children. This way, the books can still be available for those who need them while ensuring that they are not accessed by the wrong audience.  Overall, books play a crucial role in education and should not be taken lightly. Instead of removing books, individuals can request the books they prefer to read. By keeping a diverse collection of books, more people will be encouraged to read and learn.  In conclusion, retaining books in libraries is essential as they hold valuable knowledge that can benefit readers of all ages. Books should be preserved and made accessible to those who seek information, and inappropriate materials should be stored appropriately. Removing books may limit opportunities for learning and exploration, so it is important to maintain a wide range of reading materials for everyone.

There are things in this world that are relative. Censorship is one of them. Relative means that one person has a different view than that of another. Censorship is when a person or organization in authority does not allow people to see things that they believe are inappropriate. One phrase that is very important to censorship is 'things that they believe.' What is inappropriate to one person could be deemed viewable to another. This should not be decided by one person or even one group that believes they know what is socially acceptable or politically correct. Censorship in libraries is not a good thing.  Imagine two individuals, Person 1 and Person 2, walking into a library. Person 1 believes in providing for his family and exercising his Second Amendment rights, while Person 2 is against killing animals and prefers not to know where her meat comes from. They come across a hunting magazine that depicts a successful hunt. Person 1 sees this as an opportunity to gain knowledge and improve his skills, while Person 2 finds it inappropriate. Should this magazine be censored because of Person 2's views? The choice should be left to the individual to decide what they want to read.  In another scenario, Person 1 is a science enthusiast while Person 2 prefers religious books. They encounter a book on evolution, with Person 1 finding it interesting and Person 2 dismissing it as untrue. Should this book be removed from the shelves because Person 2 disagrees with its content? No, the choice to read or ignore the book should be left to the individual.  Librarians, like everyone else, are entitled to their opinions. However, the materials in a library should not be chosen based on personal preferences but on the potential value they hold for the readers. Censorship restricts access to information that could be useful to someone.  In conclusion, censorship is a relative concept, and what one person finds inappropriate, another may find valuable. People should have the freedom to choose what they want to read or view without interference. Libraries should be places where all perspectives and ideas are available for those who seek them.

Certain materials found in libraries may not always be age-appropriate for young children. It is important to be mindful of the content that children are exposed to, as some books, music, movies, and magazines may contain themes that are not suitable for their age group. For example, music in today's society often includes explicit content related to sex, drugs, and violence, which can have a negative influence on young minds.  During a visit to a school library, I encountered a movie that I deemed inappropriate for students without parental verification. Exposure to content about sex and drugs at a young age can lead children to believe that such behaviors are acceptable, as they may emulate what they see or hear. It is crucial for libraries to ensure that materials on their shelves are suitable for all age groups, and librarians should take measures to monitor and restrict access to inappropriate content.  Books with covers depicting violence, guns, drugs, or sexual content can be enticing to children, making it challenging for them to resist reading such material. While school libraries typically maintain age-appropriate selections, public libraries cater to a broader audience, including adults, leading to a mix of content that may not be suitable for children. It is essential for libraries to exercise caution in curating their collections and implementing measures to prevent juveniles from accessing inappropriate materials.  In conclusion, libraries play a vital role in providing access to information and entertainment, but they must also prioritize the protection of young readers by monitoring the content available for their consumption. By implementing age restrictions and verifying parental consent for certain materials, libraries can create a safer and more conducive environment for children to explore and learn.

All things in the world are not strictly black and white. Every person is different, with varying ideas. So when some people are certain that a specific word or topic should be restricted, there will always be another person to say the exact opposite. Sometimes, what's found as 'vulgar' can only be introduced with the intent of education. Also, this ties in with something our country was founded on, which is freedom of speech, and the press. Magazines, music, books, and movies are mainly for entertainment. Everyone who reads or watches something will take it in differently, and it will have a varying effect. Let's say there is a 10-year-old girl who just had her first day of high school. While at lunch, she slipped and dropped her tray of food. Later that day while she's alone reading her favorite magazine, she's reading an article about embarrassing stories, where one girl accidentally walked into a boys' restroom. Some parents may deem this inappropriate, but it has made the young girl feel better about her situation. It's human to mess up and act crazy; we aren't perfect by nature. So when we see errors made into comedies and dramas by any form of media, it's human to realize that we aren't the only ones who undergo these events. To censor books and television would be like claiming nothing bad happens. Not to say that a novel written about brutal murder that contains sexual references should be given to a little kid, but it should not be pulled from the shelf altogether. The topic of censorship in schools is also a very sensitive one, especially with younger kids. As Katherine Paterson pointed out, if every parent had the right to remove a book that they thought was not suitable, then eventually there would be nothing left. Many parents are uneasy with the thought of their child being taught things like sexual education, but on the other hand, there are also the parents who appreciate it. They do so not because it saves them time, but because certain explicit topics - to an extent - can help someone mature if it's done in a controlled environment. Years ago, it was not uncommon to see censorship in the media. It could range from saying 'intercourse' to replace 'sex' or it could be something like extreme propaganda. There's a reason that our constitution protects freedom of speech. No matter how appalling someone may find a topic, it usually has some type of informative purpose. Otherwise, it probably wouldn't have gotten issued. Choosing what is and isn't offensive is a matter of opinion. As previously stated, no two humans are exactly the same, and their opinions won't be either. So this means that if one person out of a group is allowed to dispose of or censor whatever they find necessary, it must be recognized that some portion of the remaining people will be unsatisfied. This is usually where people will claim that the law protects their freedom of speech. In the end, the media is largely for entertainment. It provides numerous shows and articles, with a huge array of topics. This goes to show that if one should find something offensive, it doesn't mean they have to rip it off the shelves and complain; it simply means they have the opportunity to look elsewhere. Ultimately, the diversity of opinions and the freedom to express them are essential aspects of a democratic society.

There are various perspectives on censorship in our country, reflecting the diverse opinions held by different groups such as the old, young, parents, and children. While some may find certain materials in libraries offensive, it is important to acknowledge the varied viewpoints that exist. It is crucial for individuals to approach the issue with maturity and understanding. Censorship, although sometimes contentious, plays a role in maintaining order and protecting individuals, especially children, from inappropriate content. By upholding censorship in libraries, we can ensure that knowledge is accessible while also being mindful of what is suitable for different age groups. Ultimately, parents should take responsibility for guiding their children's exposure to certain materials in libraries. In conclusion, the presence of censorship in libraries serves as a balance between providing information and safeguarding individuals, making it a necessary aspect of our society.

I do not think that a random stranger should have the right to decide what books to allow in a public library. If they have a problem with certain material in certain books, they should bring it to the attention of the library. The author who wrote that book has the freedom of speech, and they are allowed to write anything that they would like to write. If somebody did not want their children looking at a book, or reading that book, then they should just tell their child to stay away from it, and if they raised their child properly, he or she should respect those boundaries that the parents have set.  However, I think there should be a line drawn about what is too graphic to be displayed at a public library. Some magazines that contain graphic material are very educational, such as National Geographic. On the other hand, I am not saying that we should be lining shelves with explicit magazines either. There is a difference between having books that educate children about other cultures, and those that educate them about sex and explicit material. It is the adult's job to protect their children from material such as that. But they can do it in another way, other than taking the book off the shelf.  Even if the book is filled with drugs or nudity, the concerned parent cannot just take actions into their own hands. The owner of the library is the adult that gets to decide what types of books or magazines he or she allows in the library, not the customers. I think that if you are offended by a certain book at a library, you should bring it to the attention of the owner, or simply go to a different library. If the owner refuses to remove the item from the shelf and the material offends you that much, you could go to court and plead your case to the judge. But you have no right to remove a book from a shelf that does not belong to you.

When picking a book, music, movie, and magazines from the library, it's always a hard decision because you may want to read more than one book at a time. Books that are considered offensive can be more interesting than plain boring books. So why would anybody remove books from the shelves for being offensive?  When children choose books from the library, it is important to ensure they are age-appropriate and educational. Separating books into adult and children's sections can help prevent young readers from accessing inappropriate content. Having a wide variety of books available encourages people to visit the library. Removing books could deter people from using the library altogether.  For individuals who cannot afford to purchase books, libraries serve as a valuable resource for borrowing materials. Removing books would limit access to information and learning opportunities for those who rely on the library.  While it may be acceptable to remove offensive materials for the sake of children's safety, a public vote should be considered before making such decisions. Instead of completely removing offensive books, creating an adult section in the library could be a more effective solution. This way, individuals who are of a certain age can access these materials while ensuring that children are not exposed to inappropriate content. Keeping offensive books accessible in a designated section can make it easier for patrons to find the content they are interested in without restricting access to diverse perspectives.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' Katherine Paterson. Katherine Paterson is an author who, like the quote from her, believes that some books should never reach the hands of children. Does everyone believe the same way, no. I am one of those few people who believe that no one should have the right to remove a book simply because they find the book offensive.  Your an old fashion woman who believes in old fashion ideals such as no cursing or violence. You, as this woman, pick up a book and read the first page, on this page you see cursing and decide to remove all books with violence or cursing from the library. The library soon becomes half empty because of one woman and her beliefs. Beliefs are a wonderful thing outside of reading and can make you who you want to be. Books do not, in my opinion, have beliefs. This is true for some books but a book where someone runs from danger or flies into the sky, those are not beliefs those are dreams and no one can crush dreams offensive or not.  I compare books to dreams simply for the fact that they are dreams, the dreams of the authors who wrote them and wanted to share that dream with the world. Telling a person they cannot publish their book simply because another person finds it offensive is telling the author your dream is offensive. If you do not want your child to share this book of dreams then do not let your child pick up the book. You are the parent of the child who picks up this book then you can protect it from the offensive danger it holds like you protect it from the dangers of strangers in the real world.  Authors do not always write for the sake of everyone. Authors do not write for one woman, one man, one child, authors write for those who share a similar dream. If you do not share the same dream as the author that is fine, no one is forcing you to share in their sometimes dark and sometimes amazing dreams. Authors write because they wish to write, to express themselves in ways only words and stories can. Do not shun a book because one thing in it offends you, a book is someone's dream.  In short, you would never crush your child's dreams. If your child wants to grow up and be a fireman you do not tell them that it is offensive to people so they can't. Why would you do something to someone else's dream who you have never met. Be a bigger person and allow that person to live their dream through a story. No matter the level of offense you do not have to pick up the book and read it. The number one way to not be offended by a book that may offend you is to never read the book to start with.

Certain offensive materials that are created solely to offend others should be removed from shelves everywhere. It is morally wrong to intentionally hurt or belittle others, and such actions can have detrimental effects on the mental health of individuals. Continuous exposure to offensive content can lead to feelings of depression and worthlessness, as seen in personal experiences where individuals have been targeted and bullied. Furthermore, the novelty of offensive materials will eventually wear off, and people will lose interest in supporting content that aims to offend. Ultimately, there is no benefit in spreading negativity and causing harm to others. It is crucial to promote kindness and respect in all forms of media and eliminate offensive materials from circulation to create a more positive and inclusive society.

In my personal opinion, I believe that books that some people find offensive should not be removed. Just because a book is deemed offensive by one person does not mean that everyone will feel the same way. Libraries cater to various age groups and grade levels, ensuring that inappropriate content is not accessed by the wrong audience. It is important to consider the diverse preferences and perspectives of individuals when it comes to literature. Removing a book simply because one person finds it offensive may deprive others of the opportunity to enjoy it. Therefore, I believe that books should not be removed based solely on personal opinions of offensiveness.

There are both good and bad books out there, with different people finding different books offensive or enjoyable. While reading can improve literacy skills, some books may not be suitable for certain audiences. It is important for parents to monitor what their children are reading to prevent them from being exposed to inappropriate content. Libraries typically have sections for children and adults to help with this, but it is ultimately up to individuals to ensure that potentially harmful material is kept out of reach of children. By being mindful of what books are accessible to children, we can help them develop positive reading habits and avoid exposure to unsuitable content.

Banning books in libraries due to controversial content is a topic of debate in society. While some argue for censorship to protect certain groups, others believe in the freedom to choose what to read. It is important to consider that individuals have the right to decide what they want to read without restrictions. Restricting access to books may prevent people from accessing valuable information or well-written stories. Instead of outright banning books, libraries could consider segregating them into separate sections based on content. This way, readers can still access a wide range of materials while ensuring age-appropriate content. Authors should also have a say in the availability of their books, as they invest time and effort in creating their work. It is essential to balance the concerns of the community with the rights of authors to express themselves through their writing. Ultimately, the decision to ban a book should be carefully considered, taking into account the impact on readers and the value of the content.

In my opinion, everyone should have the right to access a wide variety of books, magazines, movies, and music at the library. The public library serves as a valuable resource for individuals who may not have access to these materials otherwise, such as those without a computer at home. It is important for libraries to cater to the diverse interests and preferences of their patrons by offering a comprehensive collection of reading and viewing materials.  While some individuals may not appreciate certain books, movies, or magazines, it is crucial to respect the freedom of others to explore and enjoy these materials. Just because a particular item may not appeal to one person does not mean it should be removed from the shelves for others who may find it valuable. Each individual has the right to choose what they want to read or watch, and the library should strive to provide a wide range of options to accommodate varying tastes and interests.  Overall, I believe that libraries should continue to offer a diverse selection of books, magazines, movies, and music to meet the needs and preferences of their community. By doing so, libraries can fulfill their role as a valuable resource for information, entertainment, and education for people of all backgrounds and interests.

I think that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. People enjoy books with offensive language or content, people love to feel the energy or tone of the writer. I personally love offensive language; if everything was censored, it would feel like everything is dull and fake.   Instead of removing them, why not just move them to an adult section of the library? The adult section will warn kids and parents of what they are getting into. If parents do not want their children to be exposed to certain content, then they should not be in that area. Libraries are usually divided into sections, but if not, you can ask local libraries if they separate adult and children's books into different sections.   It is important to allow people the freedom to choose what they want to read or watch, even if it may be offensive to some. By segregating these materials into appropriate sections, individuals can still access them while also giving parents the ability to control what their children are exposed to. Censorship should not be the answer; instead, let people make their own choices while also providing guidance and warnings where necessary.

Censorship in the arts is a complex issue, as what may be offensive to some may not be to others. The line between artistic expression and censorship is often blurred, leading to controversy. In the music industry, there have been concerns about the impact of explicit content on teenagers, as they may glamorize harmful behaviors. However, in literature and art, censorship can stifle the expression of thoughts and emotions, limiting the freedom of artists to convey their message. While societal norms and perceptions change over time, the subjective nature of what is considered offensive remains a challenge. Despite efforts by parents to shield children from certain content, censorship alone cannot eradicate real-world problems. Ultimately, while censorship may seem like a quick fix, it merely masks underlying issues without addressing them effectively.

Although it is a new day and age where demand is high for electronic books, hardback and paperback books are not obsolete quite yet. Many people still enjoy the old tradition of visiting libraries and embarking on a quest for the perfect book. Additionally, with the current economic situation, opting for physical books is a more cost-effective choice. However, some individuals may not find everything they desire at their local library due to censorship.  It is true that many libraries censor materials that they deem inappropriate for children. While some adults and teens may seek more mature content, it should not be readily available for young audiences. Parents, who are loyal library customers along with their children, prefer to shield their young ones from explicit materials. If libraries were to lose young families as patrons, a significant portion of their clientele would be lost.  Therefore, when seeking material that may not be suitable for children, it is advisable to consider alternative options such as purchasing from a bookstore. This ensures that children can remain in a safe and innocent environment without being exposed to content that is not age-appropriate. By making conscious choices about the content available in libraries, we can uphold a positive and welcoming space for all patrons.

No, just because a book or song or magazine article or movie is offensive does not mean that we should have the right to take it off the shelves. Sure we have a right to remove that book but there are a lot things that are going to offend people. Just because someone comes across an offensive book at the library doesn't mean that they should have to go through so much work to get it removed off the shelf. Its not worth the trouble for just a book that you could just simply look past and look at other books. If it was possible for anyone to just take a book off a shelf because they thought it was offensive we would have a lot of empty book stores. Because face it people can and will be offended easily if something they believe, like religion, is being made fun of in a book that they had read about. We all get offended but just move on from it and find something different. We are not forced to read that book or listen to that song or look at the magazine. We have a choice and the choice can be to move on and read or look at something different, more positive, or go through the process to get it removed and taken off the shelf. You never know someone else might think that maybe that article in that magazine was beneficial or relating. So it should not be up to one person, but if a whole community has a problem with a book then I can see removing it can be an option.

I think that some books in the library some people might take offensive. But some of those books have a meaning behind it.            I think theres one book out there that alot of people love to read, and that is "Huckleberry Finn". The book uses the 'N' word alot and many people take that offensive, but why? There was a big arguement about alot of book companies changing the word in the book to "slave" or "person".             From my perspective I think it should stay the same. Why change that now? Many english teachers use that book because it talks about a white boy named Huck saving Jim. Its not being used in a bad why at all just using the terms of how they did back in the olden days. The book is strong and shows readers a strong aspect in life.             Yes you shouldn't go around saying that word, but also not change it now, after its been out for along time to the public. The book would not bring the same meaning as it would if it is  being changed.

Katherine Paterson wrote about the true impact of censoring what is put in a library. In the quote she mentions how if what every single person finds offensive is removed, eventually nothing is left. The question of, 'Should library content be censored?' is a largely debated question. There is a simple answer to this question. It should not be censored. Views on what should be censored and why, vary based on type of person and their background. As Katherine Paterson said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-that work I abhor-then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' @PERSON2 made the observation that most people would not think far enough to realize. The most logical thing is to not censor what works are put into libraries. As was previously stated, once every person pulls what they deem should not be on shelves, the library will be but a building without books. To keep children from getting into certain types of literature, movies, and music, libraries could have a section set off within the adult section for these works. Many public libraries do not even have these types of items that would be so highly disputed for the simple fact that if the library does not even carry it, they do not have to worry about issues. These public institutions are working for the best of the visitors, and if there are works needing to be kept from the childrens' section, there is no doubt that this would be taken care of appropriately. The topic of censorship is a very touchy subject to start with. This goes back to the debate of what exactly should be censored. The problem with what is 'explicit,' is that there is no black and white line. Does a book become inappropriate because a teen girl becomes pregnant within the pages? In some eyes, the fact that a teenager got inpregnated within a book makes it inappropriate, but critics will argue that this is life and to shield the world from reality makes us all blind. Proper instillation of morals and values on the homefront will help young citizens make intelligent choices, but expecting the world to censor itself for each individual is something that would never be possible. Censorship in libraries is a touchy subject, but like Katherine Paterson said, if every person in the world removed what they thought inappropriate, there would be no books left. This truth being stated, censorship in libraries should be stopped before every book is gone. As the world turns, life cannot be stopped because bad or inappropriate things exist. It can only be learned that yes, these things @MONTH1 exist, but by using better judgement the whole world can get along just fine without trying to remove everything 'bad.'

I agree that individuals should have the freedom to read, listen to, or view whatever material they choose without censorship. It is unfair for schools or any institution to dictate what we can or cannot access. In a country like America, where freedom of expression is a fundamental right, we should be able to make our own choices regarding the content we consume. If something is offensive to one person, it may not be to another, so individuals should have the autonomy to decide for themselves. Censoring material because of the preferences of a few is unjust and goes against the principles of freedom and diversity. We should stand together against censorship and advocate for the right to access a variety of viewpoints and ideas. Let us fight for our freedom to choose what we read, listen to, and view.

I believe that no books should be censored or taken away from public libraries. Everyone, regardless of age, should have the right to access information and content that interests them. If certain materials contain explicit content, it should be the responsibility of individuals, especially parents, to monitor what they or their children are exposed to. Libraries should have the freedom to curate their collections based on their own discretion, and if certain materials are deemed inappropriate, they can be restricted from certain age groups. Overall, censorship in libraries should be minimal to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to explore a wide range of ideas and perspectives.

If I found a book that I thought was inappropriate for others to read, I would ask the librarian to check into it to see what she thinks about the book(s). If she believed they were offensive, then she could remove the book(s) without any questions being asked. If she was unsure about a book, she could take a vote or tally on that book to decide if it needed to be removed. In my opinion, offensive content in a book could include inappropriate pictures or language, especially if it is racist or contains foul language.   When it comes to offensive movies, I would suggest that they be moved to a section where only mature adults or teenagers can access them. Movies with inappropriate content can have a negative influence on young viewers, leading them to mimic dangerous behaviors depicted in the film. Parents also play a crucial role in monitoring what their children watch to prevent them from being exposed to harmful content.   Music is another form of media that can contain offensive subjects, such as violence and explicit sexual content. Some songs glorify drug use and violence, which can have a detrimental impact on listeners, especially young people. Artists should be more mindful of the messages they convey in their music, considering the potential influence it may have on their audience.   Overall, while everyone is entitled to their own opinion, certain content should not be readily available for children and adolescents. It is important to consider the impact that media consumption can have on individuals, especially the younger generation. Efforts should be made to regulate offensive content in books, movies, and music to create a safer and more positive media environment for all.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-- that work I abhor--then you also have exactly yhe same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us,' states Katherine Paterson. Books and movies all over the world are being censored and removed from libraries, day after day, due to their explicit content. I believe that books, movies, and magazines should not be removed from the shelf, and that they are there for a genuine purpose. Explicit objects should not be censored because a human being should have a judgement of their own, children's parents have a right to exclude the material from the child's life, and some material can be useful in life and someone @MONTH1 learn from @CAPS3.      Children everywhere are being influenced by books, magazines, movies, and even songs. Some people argue that these harmful materials are affecting how kids behave and act. I, however, believe that a child should have superb morals and values to know right from wrong. For example, if a child happens to see a pornography magazine lingering on a shelf of their local grocerey store, they should know that no matter how temping @CAPS3 @MONTH1 be, that buying that pornography magazine would be wrong. From birth, parents are constantly teaching their children what is right and what is wrong. They attempt to teach their children the basics: that drugs, alcohol, and smoking will corrupt their health. @CAPS3 doesn't matter if a child sees someone doing drugs in a movie or hears a song about a teenager getting drunk. They should not be influenced by this because by using their logic, they should infer that what is being read or listened to isn't always the right thing to do.     Everyday, children's parents have the right to exclude harmful material from a child's life. After all, they are a superior figure in the child's life, and the child will always look up to them to lead the way. At most local theaters now, you have to be seventeen to see a rated '@CAPS1' movie. I believe that profanity has both positive and negative aspects. On one hand, profanity adds flavor and emotion to books, music, and movies, often conveying feelings of anger. It can also influence behavior, affecting the way people speak and act. However, it is essential to consider the impact of profanity on children. Young minds are impressionable, and exposure to profanity at a young age can have detrimental effects on their development. Therefore, it is important to restrict access to profanity for children, such as by ensuring age-appropriate content in books, movies, and music. While profanity can be a powerful tool in entertainment, it is crucial to be mindful of its potential consequences and make responsible choices regarding its consumption. By being aware of the effects of profanity and taking steps to limit its exposure to children, we can create a more positive and respectful environment for all.

All materials in a library are for the public, as public libraries exist to serve the community. Children are often accompanied by adults in libraries, seeking age-appropriate books and activities. If a library patron finds a book offensive, it is likely intentional, as library materials are available for anyone to access.   Children may be curious in libraries, knowing that adult content is also present. It is the responsibility of parents or guardians to monitor their children's library use and guide them to appropriate materials. While some may not mind their children encountering certain content, others may have different preferences.   Libraries organize materials in a way that segregates adult and inappropriate content from children's areas. It is up to individuals to choose what they want to read or view in a library setting. Offensive material can also extend to content that may be offensive to different races or cultures, emphasizing the need for awareness and respect.   In conclusion, libraries provide a range of materials for the public, and it is essential for individuals to be mindful of what they access. Parents should supervise their children in libraries to ensure they stay within appropriate areas. Ultimately, it is the responsibility of individuals to select materials that align with their preferences and values while respecting the diversity of content available in a library setting.

In our society, many people and places are quick to take offense to certain things. However, I believe that libraries and bookstores should not remove items from their shelves simply because they may be deemed offensive. Everyone has the right to choose what they read, watch, or listen to, and it is important to allow individuals to make their own decisions about what they find offensive. If a particular book or movie is causing such a strong negative reaction, then perhaps it should not have been created in the first place.   Music, in particular, is a form of expression, and I do not believe it should be censored when sold in stores. If the content is too explicit for certain individuals, they have the option to simply not listen to it. It is not necessary to censor material just because it may contain offensive language or themes. Ultimately, if something offends you, it is best to avoid it rather than demand its removal from public spaces. Everyone has different tastes and sensitivities, and it is important to respect individual autonomy in choosing what media to consume.

When it comes to my idea of having censorship in libraries around the world, I believe that there are cases when certain books, music, movies, magazines, and other materials should not be available to the public. Throughout my years in school, I have come across numerous instances where I felt that the content of certain materials was inappropriate for individuals of all ages.  I have encountered books that contain explicit content such as drugs, sex, and other mature themes that I believe should not be accessible to young children or teenagers. Additionally, I have seen offensive behavior portrayed in books that were marketed towards a younger audience, leading me to question the appropriateness of the content being offered in libraries.  Moreover, I have found that offensive and inappropriate material can also be present in magazines, movies, and music. While the instances of offensive music in libraries may be less common, I have witnessed cases where certain music was deemed offensive and inappropriate for listeners of all ages.  As teenagers grow older, I believe that they should be able to understand the importance of maturity and appropriate behavior. Exposure to offensive and inappropriate material can have a negative impact on their development and behavior, leading to undesirable outcomes. Therefore, it is crucial for parents, teachers, and librarians to carefully evaluate the materials they recommend to children and teenagers.  In conclusion, it is essential for libraries to reevaluate the types of materials they offer to the public to ensure that they are appropriate for all ages. By taking steps to limit the availability of offensive and inappropriate content, we can help shape the minds of the youth in a positive way and contribute to a more peaceful and respectful society.

I believe that everyone has the right to their own opinion. If a parent does not approve of something, they should communicate that to their child and guide them accordingly. This principle extends to various aspects of life, such as hunting or personal preferences in music, movies, and books. By expressing our opinions honestly, we can create a better understanding and avoid conflicts. For instance, my father taught me the importance of hunting for food, except for coyotes, which are considered pests in our area. Parents can influence their children by living according to the values they teach. If parents do not want their children exposed to certain content, such as rated movies, they can take measures to restrict access. Ultimately, open communication and consistency in behavior can help shape the values and choices of the younger generation.

Censorship in libraries is a contentious issue, especially when it comes to determining what is appropriate for children. Factors such as racism, cultural beliefs, and religious beliefs all play a role in this debate. Racist comments and materials have no place in a child's reading material, as they can perpetuate harmful stereotypes and attitudes. Similarly, materials that disparage or disrespect certain cultural or religious beliefs should not be accessible to children. Children should be exposed to diverse perspectives and beliefs in a respectful and educational manner. Creating separate sections in libraries for materials that may be deemed inappropriate for children can help ensure that young readers are exposed to age-appropriate and enriching content. Ultimately, it is important for libraries to carefully consider the materials they make available to children, taking into account the potential impact on their developing minds and attitudes.

Every single person has their own beliefs and disbeliefs when it comes to books, music, or anything in life. What may be a bad and vulgar book in our opinion may not be bad in others' opinionated views. Everyone will have their own views about a book, music, movies, or magazines. That's why censorship is good in a public place like a library. Does that mean we're saying that you can't like what you want to like, listen to what you want to listen to, or watch what you want to watch in your own home? No, by censoring all that in public places like libraries or video stores, you're helping to prevent potential issues and concerns that could arise in the future.   On the other hand, censoring movies, music, books, and magazines in a library could also be a negative thing. Not everyone is going to like the same things or be interested in all the same movies or books. At the same time, we can't censor everything that someone doesn't like. Removing something because one parent has a complaint about their child watching or reading a book they found too 'vulgar' gives that right to any parent who complains about their child doing the same. It's not the library's responsibility to monitor every child or ensure they only watch or read what their parents approve of. Children will do what they want to do.   Censoring and removing items from library shelves doesn't prevent children from watching movies they shouldn't see or reading books they shouldn't read. Censoring libraries is similar to censoring words in movies; it doesn't stop children from hearing or learning vulgar language. Children today hear more vulgar words in school than they do in movies and television.   The concept of what is offensive varies from person to person. Everyone has their own opinion on what's offensive and what's not. We all have the freedom to look at what we want and listen to the music we choose. Taking items off library shelves because one person finds them offensive restricts the rights of other citizens. Censoring some things, like sex scenes in movies or vulgar language in music, is acceptable in my opinion. However, removing books because of personal preferences regarding the writing style, author, or language used is crossing a line. Books help children learn and imagine, and by restricting access to certain books, we may hinder a child's development.  Censorship has both positive and negative aspects. It can either hinder or aid a child's growth and development. While censoring some content is necessary, not everything with vulgar language or themes should be censored. Children need exposure to different perspectives in order to grow and navigate the complexities of the world. Ultimately, a balanced approach to censorship is essential to support both freedom of expression and responsible content consumption.

This is along the lines of personal thought. Some people can be happy with things, while others disagree. Unless it's racist or sexist, no one has any right at all to say something can't belong. If someone doesn't like a book, then walk away from it; don't ponder at why it's there, someone else may want it. So I don't like this topic personally, but I am okay with writing about it. It's not a choice just like it really shouldn't even be a choice for people to say what belongs where, unless it is rightfully owned by the individual. I know there are many things I don't like, but I don't try and get things moved and banned. It's there; people want to read it. Plus, the person who wrote or made the object would be shot down in sadness or rejection.   Along the lines of insulting a race and/or being sexist, if that is being done in the book it should be stopped and disposed of. People have the right to say they are not happy with that, but if they just don't like the topic but others do, then they need to move on and not make a big deal out of it. Now, if the title clearly states what the book is about, then walk away; don't pay attention to it. People may use it for research or something in the future. Now, some people may be self-centered and just want what they need so they cause a huge uproar or fight over stupid little things. That's the people that always got things handed to them, which I imagine is why this topic came up.   So, that is my thoughts and beliefs about the topic of Censorship. It doesn't matter where, in school or at a library; it is there because someone is/was interested in the item. I know this is my thoughts and beliefs; people may completely think what I wrote is stupid, some may think it's smart. It's just the culture you grew up in and the state of mind you are in at that current time and place.

I do not think that there is a need to remove offensive materials from libraries. Some people may find these things offensive, but I think that others will be greatly offended if they remove these things. Take rap music for example. There are many people that think that the lyrics of those songs are just terrible and offensive. Other people think that rap music is amazing. I do not think rap is very good at all, but I would not go to the extent of saying that rap songs should not be played on the radio, and that the albums should not be sold in stores. The same thing could be said for these materials in the library. Some may find them offensive but others greatly appreciate it.  Some people may be interested in these topics. Just like some people may be interested in fantasy or comedy. It would not be fair for libraries to remove these materials from the library, and deny the people that do like them the right to rent these materials.  Another factor is the maturity of the reader. If the person who is reading a book or viewing movies that may be offensive is viewing them for clear interest then there is no problem with it. But if the reader is not reading for interest, then there is a problem there. It all depends on the maturity that people have when they enter a library. The materials in libraries are there to give everyone a chance to find something that interests them. Just because someone else may find those materials offensive is no reason to take them off the shelf.  I can see why some parents may be upset that their kids may see some of the things in the library that may not be appropriate, but all the libraries that I have been to have had a special area for kids' materials. If the parents were worried about their kids seeing some of the questionable materials they could bring the kid to that area.  I don't think that these materials that may seem offensive to some people should be removed from libraries. Everyone is going to be offended by something and it is not fair to deprive others of those materials even if it is offensive to some.

Censorship in libraries should not be allowed as libraries are meant to provide a diverse range of books for people to explore and enjoy. The selection of books in a library is the responsibility of the owner, who aims to cater to various tastes and preferences. If a reader finds a book offensive, they should address their concerns with the library owner rather than simply discarding the book. Books are meant to be shared and discussed, allowing individuals to express their opinions and engage in dialogue with others. By allowing freedom of expression in libraries, we can foster a more vibrant and intellectually stimulating community where diverse viewpoints are respected and valued. In conclusion, censorship in libraries hinders the exchange of ideas and limits the opportunity for individuals to explore different perspectives, making it essential to uphold the principles of intellectual freedom in these institutions.

I changed the name of the organization in this story that I heard from my grandparents because I could not remember the real one. This is not really happening at the organization I think. To the people at the organization I would like to tell you and your readers that there is something wrong with the organization. Nothing really all too serious I guess. It seems the librarians there are censoring tons of books and other materials. One of which I really need for a homework assignment on the movie. They say that they are censoring what I need for the assignment because it is too bloody and scary for some of the other readers. They said that they have already blocked all the inappropriate sites as well. I do not have internet at home so you can see how well that is going to go at school. That way no kid will have nightmares anymore. I also threw in the idea of separating all the books and movies by age group like child, teen, older teen. To this they said alright but they were going to keep the classic books and movies.  The organization said they will try my idea and see if it works but I would have to volunteer at the organization and go through all the stuff that has been censored over the years. To this I said okay, but after I saw how big the censor list was, it was like a nightmare - over a hundred pages of books at least. I was too scared to see how long the other lists were. So seeing that it was too big for me to handle alone, I got most of the other volunteers to help me. Then put up posters at the school I go to, to see if anyone else would be willing to help me.  So far there has not been much progress in the lists so I would like to ask that if there are any readers out there reading this article. I could sure use your help because these are some really long lists. I thank you all for reading this article, if you are not able to help then see if there is anyone else you know that would be willing to help too, thank you.

I think that if there are offensive books, music, magazines, etc then they should be put in a section of their own, or the librarians should have them kept up and if someone needs/wants them then they would have to go to the front dest in order to get them. I think also, if a young child or teenager can't see, read, or hear those types of things than they should not be in there period. This segregation can help protect individuals from being exposed to materials that they may find offensive or inappropriate, while still allowing access to those who choose to seek them out. By implementing these measures, libraries can cater to the diverse needs and preferences of their patrons in a responsible and considerate manner.

Censorship in Libraries and Schools  Have you ever read or seen a book that you thought was not appropriate? Did you want to ban the book from the library you got it from? Well many people have experienced this and many of them have wanted to have more censorship in libraries but we cannot always do this. Maybe that book that you just put down, deeming it inappropriate for all to read it, is someone else's favorite book. You never know but maybe someone might think your favorite book is not appropriate. There are many different people in the world and they all have different opinions. So instead of banning them how about libraries and schools just censor them.  Censoring seems like a no-brainer but a lot of people do not think about it. We cannot just close our eyes to all the inappropriate books out there but we can at least censor them. Censoring them could be as simple as just putting a tag on them or making a different section for just those kinds of books. The tags should be clearly marked so that people can see it and know what to expect from the book.  People do not have to get rid of some books completely but they need to recognize that young children could pick it up and start reading it without knowing that it is not very appropriate for them. Parents do have the right to check and monitor what their child is reading. Although if you just get rid of the book completely, people are also getting rid of other people's freedom of speech. No one has the right to determine what books are not appropriate and what books are, so no one should have the right to just have certain books just removed from the shelves.  Instead of banning the books or complaining about them, people could try a rating system for books. When you buy movies a lot of times people check the rating on the movie to see if it would be appropriate for their child or even for themselves. This is what we could do with books too and maybe there will not be as many problems with books. It sounds simple enough but people need to take action and start to do something about it.  You may not be able to make everyone happy but at least people can be more informed about the books they are reading. If everyone can help out in the effort to make our libraries and school more censored than all the libraries would be a lot happier places full of adventure.

Offensive materials in libraries can vary from books, music, movies, and magazines, but what may be offensive to some may not be offensive to others. It is important not to remove these materials from library shelves simply because a few individuals find them offensive, as there will always be someone who enjoys them. People have different preferences and what one person finds offensive, another may find enjoyable. Therefore, all materials should be available to the public in libraries, allowing individuals the freedom to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to. Censorship in libraries restricts access to information and limits people's choices. It is essential to uphold the right to access a variety of materials, even if some may find them offensive. Everyone should have the opportunity to explore different perspectives and ideas through reading, watching, and listening to a wide range of content. Ultimately, individuals should have the freedom to decide for themselves what they find offensive and what they want to engage with, without others imposing their views on them.

Todays world is filled with racism and criticism. Anything we do is either right or wrong, no in-between. Offensive comments and images can be found everywhere, from restaurants to shopping centers. The media often amplifies events, making them appear worse than they actually are, which can be offensive to certain individuals.  When it comes to choosing books, movies, or music, everyone has different preferences. What one person finds offensive, another may not. It is important to remember that individuals have the freedom to express themselves through their art, whether it be writing, singing, or creating visuals.  In a society that values freedom of speech, it is crucial to respect the diverse range of opinions and perspectives. Libraries and stores should not remove items simply because they are deemed offensive by some. Instead, individuals have the autonomy to select what they consume based on their own values and beliefs.  While offensive content related to race, culture, appearance, or other sensitive topics may exist, it is ultimately up to each individual to choose what they engage with. It is essential to rise above negativity and focus on what brings us together rather than what tears us apart.  In conclusion, the presence of offensive material in books, music, and magazines should not warrant their removal from shelves. Everyone has the right to choose what they read, listen to, and view, and it is important to embrace this diversity of perspectives in a free and open society.

I think that if the books, music, magazines, or movies in a library are not offensive, then they have the right to be placed on the shelves. It is important to cater to a diverse range of interests and preferences, allowing individuals to access a variety of materials that suit their tastes. By offering a selection of different media, libraries can engage a wider audience and promote a love for learning and exploration. However, if any material is found to be offensive or inappropriate, it should be removed to ensure a safe and respectful environment for all users. Ultimately, the presence of non-offensive books, music, magazines, and movies in a library can enrich the experience for patrons and contribute to a more inclusive and welcoming space for everyone.

Books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not be removed from shelves just because they are deemed offensive or because children may have access to them and potentially repeat what they have encountered. These materials should remain available because they offer valuable lessons on what to do and what not to do, as well as insights into history, whether it be our own or that of another country. While it is true that some content in libraries may not be suitable for children, restricting access does not guarantee they will not seek it out. Some individuals are drawn to this so-called offensive material and can benefit from the knowledge it provides. Research has shown that some people are better equipped to navigate real-world challenges when exposed to the realities of violence rather than shielded from them. Without access to these resources, children may remain uninformed about the world around them, leaving them ill-prepared to handle dangerous situations or make informed decisions. Therefore, it is imperative that offensive content remains in libraries to ensure a well-rounded understanding of the world and its complexities.

I think that everyone has the right to hate or abhor certain works but only the author of the work has the right to take it off of the shelf. The reason that just anyone can not take a work off the shelf is if the one person hates the work but everyone else likes it then imagine how the people who like the work must feel when they hear it was destroyed.  Can you think of how the author of any work would feel if thousands of their works were being destroyed without any thought to others? I can and I feel horrible just thinking about it so I believe that is the reason that only the creator of anything should make the decision if their work should be saved or destroyed.  With these reasons that I have shared with you please consider how everyone feels before you destroy anything if it is a book, movie, song, or even a child's dreams think about how they would feel if anything of theirs was destroyed.

Dear reader,  Do you believe that certain books, magazines, movies, and music should be removed from the shelves of libraries if they are found offensive? This is a question that many people are grappling with today. Some parents argue for their removal, while others believe they should remain.   As a citizen, I understand the concerns of parents who want offensive materials removed from libraries. However, if we start removing everything that someone finds offensive, there may not be much left on the shelves. It's important to remember that what one person finds offensive, another may not.   If we start censoring materials based on individual opinions, we risk emptying out libraries altogether. As the quote by @PERSON1 highlights, if we start removing books we find offensive, then others have the same right to do so, and soon there may be nothing left for anyone to read.   In the end, we must learn to coexist with materials that we may find offensive and find ways to navigate around them. Trying to remove everything offensive will only lead to a loss of access to diverse perspectives and ideas. It's essential to respect differing opinions and find ways to make libraries inclusive for all.  Sincerely, @PERSON2

I believe that censorship in libraries can be a good thing, but can go too far. Removing movies and magazines that contain pointless offensive material from the shelves could be a good thing. If those are removed I do not think that people would care that much. Removing those small things, however, could grow into a bigger problem. It has to be decided how far is too far when removing objects from the shelves.   It all starts with a bad magazine that has a bad picture of a movie star doing something offensive with text surrounding it being pointlessly judgemental. A parent sees his or her kid reading this at the library and they do not believe it is appropriate so they complain and the magazine is taken off the shelf. Then a movie arises that is offensive and it is taken off the shelf. Pretty soon everyone is coming in with minor complaints about many different things and almost everything has someone who wants it banned.   Even if there was a set limit on what qualifies as able to be banned people would still complain until what they want happens. If the government has all these complaints they might just shut down the libraries to avoid looking over every 'offensive' piece of literature, film, or artwork. The original purpose being to block out offensive material ends with the realization that everything is offensive to somebody. Even what might be considered a great piece of work by most could be considered an abomination by some.   In the end a library should not be given the right to censor anything. The things that should be censored are a very small percentage and it is not worth the risk. Books that are offensive to some serve as inspiration to others. Libraries were made to give people the chance to be inspired. The library should not have the right to take inspiration away from the reader's hand.

I believe that offensive books should be taken off the shelf. Some books are offensive and inappropriate, and the librarian could remove them to ensure that children do not have access to them. Movies rated 'R' and above should also be removed from libraries, as well as anything with an 'A' rating. This practice extended to movies, magazines, and music as well, ensuring that only appropriate material was available to the public. Libraries should adopt similar measures to protect the mental health of their patrons, especially children.  In conclusion, it is essential for libraries to prioritize the well-being of their visitors by removing offensive and inappropriate content from their shelves. Dear Newspaper,  As a student at @ORGANIZATION1, I frequent libraries and have noticed some concerning issues regarding the presence of censored materials.
