Everyone has a preference in works of literature, such as books, magazines, movies or music. Different types of these works of literature are significant to each person. If everyone had the right to completely remove one piece of work that displeases them, then no works would remain. Therefore, I believe no materials such as books, music, movies and magazines should be removed from public libraries or other public places. Everyone has unique ideas, necesities and preferences.   A few years ago, I had a classmate who had different ideas from a myriad of people on religious persecution. He hated the idea of mixing people of different religions into one place. He wrote a paper containing all of his ideas on how the world should function in terms of religion. He tried to publish it, but did not succeed because his work was considered offensive. Even though I disagree with his ideas, I do not think his work should have been rejected. There could have been people in the world who did agree with his thoughts and would have been interested to read them. There could even have been ideas in his paper that could've helped countries solve various problems. I believe it is unfair that his paper was rejected.   People have different necesities based on what they have to accomplish. For example, I was reading a book last @DATE1 about a girl who was doing a project on racism. She went to the library to search for a book about apartheid in @LOCATION1 but couldn't find anything. She asked a librarian if there were any, but the librarian told her that books such as those were considered offensive in that local library and she would have to search elsewhere. I believe that it is unjust because the girl @MONTH1 not have had anywhere else to go to get the information about her project. She should've had the right to access the information that she needed for the project to prevent her from failing.   Another reason that no books should be removed is simply because everyone has unique preferences. In the world, there are books that certain people would enjoy more than others. Literature should be abled to be used for the purpose of entertainment and convenience. If I were to go to a library now, I would find many selections that correspond to my ideal novel or magazine. Every person should have that right. If people start removing materials that are offensive to them, then nothing on the shelves would remain and not one person would have the right to have access to the materials they desire.   In this world, diversity exists everywhere. People have and always will want, need and desire different things. Works of literature are just one of them. If people begin to eliminate offensive materials based on everyone's frustration or displeasures, then no books will remain on the public shelves. Therefore, materials such as books, music, movies and magazines should never be removed from public places. These things are necessities to the world.

I THINK THAT IF A BOOK IS FOUND OFFENSIVE THEN YOU SHOULDN'T READ IT. CAUSE WHAT IF SOMEONE ELSE LIKES THE BOOK, THEY HAVE THE RIGHT TO READ THAT BOOK. MAYBE IT'S AN INSPIRATION TO THEM, MAYBE IT WILL DRIVE THEM TO ACCOMPLISH SOMETHING THEY WANT IN THEIR LIFE. WHEN SOMEONE WALKS INTO A LIBRARY NO ONE CAN TELL THEM WHAT TO GET THEY MAKE THAT DECISION THEMSELVES, SO WHEN A BOOK OFFENDS YOU MAYBE YOU SHOULD WRITE TO THE AUTHOR AND TALK TO HIM/HER. ABOUT THEIR BOOK. THINGS YOU COULD ACCOMPLISH BY WRITING THE AUTHOR IS A LETTER IN THE MAIL STATING THAT HE OR SHE IS SORRY FOR HURTING YOU WITH THEIR BOOK, ANOTHER IS MAYBE A VISIT FROM THE AUTHOR IN PERSON TO TELL YOU THAT HE OR SHE IS SORRY FOR THE PAIN THAT HE OR SHE BOOK BROUGHT YOU. THAT'S WHAT I THINK. ALSO, NO, I DON'T THINK THAT THE BOOK/BOOKS SHOULD BE TAKEN OFF THE SHELVES BECAUSE MAYBE JUST MAYBE IT WILL MOTIVATE SOMEONE ELSE INSTEAD OF PUTTING THEM DOWN. THE END.

Some materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. This is important because such items can potentially offend individuals based on their race, religion, gender, or other personal characteristics. For example, rap music that focuses on controversial topics like race can be offensive to some listeners. Additionally, exposure to critical content in books or movies can negatively impact children's perceptions of others. Furthermore, content that ridicules individuals based on their sexual orientation or body image can be hurtful and should be removed. Overall, it is crucial to consider the potential harm that offensive materials can cause and take appropriate actions to remove them from circulation.

In conclusion, libraries should not have the right to take books and movies off the shelves if they find them offensive. People have different preferences and what may be offensive to one person may not be to another. It is important to respect individual choices and allow for a diverse range of materials to be available for all to enjoy. Let the readers and viewers decide for themselves what they want to engage with, rather than imposing restrictions based on the opinions of a few. Ultimately, a library should be a place for exploration, learning, and freedom of choice.

When you walk into the heavenly sanctuary that is our library, you have opened yourself up to a vast wealth of knowledge that is available to you at the click of a mouse, the push of a button, or the turn of a page. There are those of a select few, however, who are under the paradigm that not all of this information is for all eyes. They feel it should be locked away, as if it were some eyesore. Allow me to address this view with retaliation and distaste on a number of levels in the following document.   I am a musician. Music is my passion. My creative gears are forever turning. Often I look to other artists' works for inspiration, and the one place to get that music is, you guessed it, the library. How disappointed am I when I find that the music I want has been removed for being explicit. It was not the lyrics or foul message I sought, but the beautiful melodies and harmonies therein! It does not do well to isolate media without first seeing the good that lies in it and the strong feelings it has to convey.   We must not discard the world's greatest novel because of racial discrepancies or wizardry. We should not throw away a moving song because of its lyrics, nor trash a movie after only reading the title without giving it a chance. How fair is this? Even now, there may be those who refuse to read a newspaper because of disagreements with one individual editor. That is no fair judgement in my opinion.  I implore you, as a public, as people of sound mind and stout hearts, to reconsider the censorship of works that have a clear and true message and were created for the benefit of humankind. All things have a story to tell. We must absorb and interpret rather than reject or ignore what we find undesirable. By doing so, we gain new knowledge and understanding, whether it be of a new culture or a new perspective. Everything must be taken with a grain of salt.  Let us watch something we find immoral and then take the time to understand why it is immoral, for it is these things that define us. If we do not see what is or is not right, who is to say what is truly ethical? We need material of substance in our libraries for our exposure and for our fathoming of new knowledge in our modern world. Let us keep our minds open and embrace the diversity of ideas and perspectives that the world has to offer.

No, materials should not be removed from libraries. Books, movies, and music all serve as valuable ways to support different perspectives and ideas. Movies provide a visual way to understand concepts, music conveys messages that can be impactful, and books offer in-depth insights into various topics. Removing these materials would limit people's ability to learn, explore, and broaden their understanding of the world. It is important to give these materials a chance and not judge them too quickly, as they can provide valuable insights and perspectives that may not be easily accessible through other means. Ultimately, these materials play a crucial role in expanding knowledge and promoting understanding, and should be preserved in libraries for the benefit of all.

When you think of a book, you may consider happy kids' books or mysterious dark books, but what about offensive books? Many forms of media today are not always uplifting or intriguing. When choosing a movie, you want to be entertained, not disappointed halfway through. It can be frustrating to pick something that looks promising, only to find it unsuitable for your family. Offensive books, movies, music, and magazines should be removed from shelves if they do not bring joy or positivity. People deserve to feel good when engaging with media. If something is hurtful or offensive, it should not be readily available. It is important to speak up and take action to ensure that only content that uplifts and inspires is promoted. Let's strive for a world where we prioritize the well-being and happiness of all individuals.

There should not be censorship on the books in the library. Just think of how many great pieces of literature are out there that no one would be able to get their hands on because they didn't meet certain standards. People would miss out on reading some of their favorite books. Would you really want to take that away from the people? If my argument did not change your mind, you could at least consider putting censored books behind the counter. This way, people can still access them if they choose to. Let's ensure that everyone has the opportunity to explore a wide range of literature without restrictions.

I do not believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from shelves at a library if they could be found offensive. It is good to be unique, and no matter how inappropriate a subject might be, it is still factual and helpful in learning. If anything they should just put a label on the cover of the book that says something along the lines of 'adult content.' History repeats itself, and this quote reminds me of periods in history where we need to learn from our mistakes, no matter how bad the subjects are, such as the Holocaust, and the Civil Rights Movement in the deep south.  What about the Holocaust, when six million Jews were killed because they were Jewish. People may find these books offensive but that doesn't mean the Holocaust never happened. There are many offensive and controversial pictures and stories about events that happened during the Holocaust. Even though this is a very depressing and horrific subject, it is still good for our society to learn about what happened. Other categories need to be read because it can help individuals to understand right from wrong and help prevent them from making big mistakes in the future.  The Civil Rights Movement started from the 1950s all the way until the late 1960s. The Civil Rights Movement took a toll on everyone in the United States, but some people couldn't handle it as well as others. In the south, most white Americans treated African Americans as dirt. They didn't let them in their schools, in their clubs or churches, they were rude towards them, and most horrific of all, they lynched them. There were a set of laws called the 'Jim Crow laws,' which pretty much was a list of rules to treat African Americans as unfairly as possible. If a kid were to pick up a book or magazine with pictures of lynchings in them, they would remember it their whole life, and if that one picture truly bothered them, their whole life growing up, they would realize that what white Americans did to African Americans was unethical.  Some books and magazines in libraries are really explicit, but we can't shelter our society their whole lives. Parents need to sit down with their children when they have questions and discuss the truth with them. What are parents going to do when their children go to school and hear other children talk about subjects such as sex? Children could get the wrong idea about sex or not know exactly what it is because their parents never actually sat down and explained to them what sex is. I am not saying to go let your three-year-old look at pictures of people having sex by any means, but when children get to a certain age, their parents need to step up and talk to them about uncomfortable subjects such as puberty, sex, and babies.  It is time parents stop hiding the truth from their children, or hovering over their shoulders like helicopters. If children don't learn the truth about the real world and about how many evil and manipulative people there are in the world, when they go to college they won't be able to stand for themselves. If children don't learn about history and what all has been done, it is kind of like we are treating the books like the Jews and the African Americans were treated. Just because these books are different than others we will just get rid of them, just like how we tried to kill off all the Jews and African Americans because they were different. And it is wrong and inhuman.

Censorship in libraries is when a librarian has the right to remove certain materials, such as books, movies, music, magazines, etc., from the shelves of a library if the item is inappropriate. I believe that libraries should not have censorship. It should be up to the parents to ensure that their children have access to appropriate materials. In libraries where there is a mixture of adults and children, censorship would lead to conflicts and limit access to a variety of materials. Therefore, I believe that censorship is unnecessary in libraries.

I know that some people find some books offensive, mean, cruel, or racist, but most of the time, people write because it's what they feel or what people want to read. Books are a privilege, and we should be able to use that privilege. People need to learn that it's okay that books are sometimes a little harsh. The world is not the most friendly place ever, and books can help convey that with less hurt than experiencing it firsthand.  I believe that all books should be left on the shelves because just because it's offensive to someone doesn't mean it should be taken off. For every book, someone will find something offensive because of something. If the cause is offense, then all books should be gone. If someone took the time to go out and write a book and make sure that everything about it is correct, then why should we stop them from letting people read it? They have a right to write, and we have a right to read, and no one should take that right away.  If someone wrote a book on the Holocaust, people are very offended by that, but they don't try to get rid of it. So why should any other book be different just because it's not about a big event like that? It just seems absurd that people go to such lengths to get rid of a book just because they are offended by it. They just need to suck it up and move on. If they don't like it, then don't read it. Someone who wants to can, so do not take that away from the people that want to read it.  I remember a time when someone wanted to read a book in our library, and they said, "Oh, you can't read that because it was found to be too offensive." It made me appalled that they would decide how someone else feels about a book. It makes me angry that they get to decide how someone else feels about a book. We do have books here that are kept behind the librarian's desk if they are too offensive, and I'm okay with that because at least they have it for people to read if they really wanted to.  Let's consider another aspect heremoney. The book that you want so badly gone from a library was most likely paid for by you, the taxpayer. So you and many others paid for this book, and now you want to waste that money. It's insane that you would want to waste that money after it's been paid for. People need to realize the bigger picture, not just themselves but others. In them taking down a book because they were offended, it offends me. This offends me a lot because now you ruined something that did not need to be taken down.  This is how I feel about this subject. I am upset that people would go to such lengths to ban a book from a library. If you wrote a book and people did this to you, how would you feel? I know you would feel terrible that someone would do this to your hard work. People need to calm down and think before acting impulsively. Stand back, and think, "will this really affect me if I get this book taken off the shelf?" It also makes me mad that the library bought the book and now it's gone, so did the money just go to waste because the book is gone. This is how I feel about getting rid of books.

Censorship in libraries is a subject with an unclear answer. Some believe it is in their right to get rid of books, music, and movies with what they believe is 'offensive' material. Others think library censorship is wrong, that people should have access to whatever material they please. Censorship is simply a way of preventing knowledge from those who wish to learn more about worlds outside their own. In society, there are no limits. The human imagination can create beautiful works of literary art and music, but it can also create material not suitable for every age group. Library censorship is a way to keep this 'unsuitable' material away from young and curious eyes. However, what may be unacceptable for children to view may be perfectly fine for a mature adult. Censorship is purely opinion. If a person is a strict believer that God created the world in seven days, they might find it offensive to see a book or a movie that supports the theory of evolution. If a parent does not want their child to watch certain content, they would rather their children not see it on the shelves. Writing is a form of self-expression, a method by which to convey feelings and thoughts and share them with others. It is also a way to teach and to inform others about the past. But if what is written is not shared, how can one form their own opinions and thoughts when they are not exposed to the opinions of those outside their community? Parents are possibly some of the biggest advocates of library censorship. Not wanting their children to be exposed to explicit or graphic material is understandable. But just because they do not want their child to see a movie about devil worship or the Nazi era does not mean the parent has the right to prevent all others from seeing it. In conclusion, one can say library censorship is a matter of opinion. Citizens have a right to read, listen to, or watch whatever material they please. Granted, it is acceptable for parents to shield their children from certain subjects, but it is unacceptable for those same parents to prevent others in the community from learning. Freedom to express one's opinions in the form of literature means nothing if that literature cannot be shared with others. As Katherine Paterson once said, '... And then we have no bookes left of the shelf for any of us.'

Why do we have books out there that are viewed as offensive? If they are inappropriate, why do we keep putting those books, magazines, movies, and music out there in the world? The reason is that people in our society have outgrown the more wholesome entertainment options of the past, such as cartoons like Tom and Jerry, Looney Tunes, and Scooby-Doo, which used to teach valuable lessons. Nowadays, the media landscape is filled with inappropriate content that focuses on violence, sex, and other negative themes without providing any educational value for children.  While we cannot completely eliminate offensive material from circulation, we can take steps to restrict access to it. By placing offensive books and magazines in restricted areas of libraries, implementing parental controls on television, and monitoring the music our children listen to, we can help shield them from harmful content. It is important for parents and caregivers to be vigilant and proactive in protecting children from inappropriate media influences.  In conclusion, while offensive material will always exist in our society, we can work towards minimizing its impact on our children by taking practical steps to restrict access and promote more positive forms of entertainment. By staying informed and engaged, we can create a safer and healthier media environment for the next generation.

Libraries are meant to be a place where people can relax and enjoy reading, but sometimes, the content available can be offensive and inappropriate for certain audiences. It is important for individuals to speak up and address any offensive material they come across in libraries. Books, movies, music, and magazines that contain explicit content should be censored or removed from shelves to protect children and sensitive individuals from exposure to inappropriate material. Censorship plays a crucial role in ensuring that libraries remain a safe and welcoming space for everyone. It is essential for people to take a stand against offensive content and advocate for a more respectful and considerate library environment. In a society where harmful and explicit material is readily available, it is crucial to prioritize the well-being and development of our youth by promoting appropriate and educational content in libraries.

I believe that if people find certain books, music, or magazines offensive in a library, they should simply choose to avoid those particular items rather than advocating for their removal. Libraries should have the freedom to curate their collections based on the diverse interests of their patrons. If individuals do not like what is available at one library, they can easily seek out another library that better aligns with their preferences. It is important to consider the varying tastes of library visitors and not impose personal views on what should or should not be available for others to enjoy. Ultimately, it is unnecessary to create conflict over the contents of a library when there are plenty of alternative options to explore. Everyone should have the opportunity to access the materials they enjoy without infringing on the choices of others.

I don't believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. Instead, there should be age restrictions and parental consent in place to regulate what children can access. By implementing a rating system similar to movies and requiring parental approval for minors, we can help ensure that inappropriate content is not easily accessible to young individuals. This approach can potentially reduce negative behaviors and influences on children, leading to a safer and more responsible environment for all. Ultimately, maintaining these materials on shelves for mature audiences while controlling access for minors can help promote responsible consumption and protect young individuals from harmful content.

Today in the media, there are many things that can be found offensive, such as movies, books, songs, and magazines. However, it is important to remember that everything that is put into the media serves a purpose. Whether it is to convey a message, spark a discussion, or evoke emotions, there is intention behind the content that is created.  When individuals find something in the media offensive, the solution is simple: they can choose to avoid it. By not subjecting themselves to content that they find offensive, they can protect their own sensibilities without restricting others' access to that content. Just because something is offensive to one person does not mean it should be censored for everyone else.  Whether it is a controversial movie, a provocative book, or a polarizing song, each piece of media has the potential to resonate with different audiences in different ways. By allowing a diverse range of content to exist in the media, we create space for dialogue, reflection, and artistic expression. It is through this diversity that we can learn from each other, challenge our perspectives, and grow as a society.  In conclusion, the presence of offensive content in the media should not be cause for censorship. Instead, individuals have the power to choose what they consume and what they engage with. By respecting the diversity of perspectives and voices in the media, we can foster a more inclusive and enriching cultural landscape for all.

Certain books, magazines, music, and movies should not be displayed on the shelves of a library, as they may contain offensive or inappropriate content for children. Libraries must take steps to address this issue by implementing better supervision and control over certain sections. One way to do this is by ensuring that children do not wander off from their parents' side, allowing parents to monitor and regulate what their children are exposed to. Additionally, libraries can put up signs in prominent locations to warn visitors about potentially offensive material and the need for parental guidance beyond a certain point. By being more aware of the impact of their collections on the public, libraries can prevent incidents where individuals are offended by certain materials. It is crucial for libraries to consider the perspectives of various groups and take proactive measures to avoid exposing visitors to content that may be upsetting or objectionable. By implementing these strategies, libraries can create a more welcoming and inclusive environment for all patrons.

Offensive content in magazines should be removed from shelves for various reasons. Firstly, it may be offensive to important figures such as the president or the governor, which can cause unnecessary controversy. If individuals find the content offensive, they should speak up to address the issue and advocate for change. It is puzzling why offensive material is allowed in magazines, as it can easily be avoided to prevent offending readers. While movies may contain fictional content, offensive material in books may have a purpose that readers need to understand. For instance, questioning the birthplace of a president, like in the case of Barack Obama, should be based on facts rather than unfounded rumors. In such situations, it is important to address the issue and move on from unwarranted controversies.

What if someone found your favorite book offensive? Inappropriate materials do need to be kept from young minds of children. On the other hand, you cannot shield people from things they should know or already know. Everyone has different things that they think are offensive, so one person might think a book is so bad it should be recalled from the shelves but another person may see no problem with it. Children need to be protected from materials that may hurt them in some way. Children do what they see and hear, so they are liable to try and copy harmful things they read. Bad influences can even come from magazines with famous celebrities being caught breaking the law or doing bad things, and young minds see that as 'cool' and may try to follow that example. Children and young people see and hear a lot worse things at home, on television, and even at school than in some books. Children need to be protected, but you can't baby-proof life. They will be introduced to plenty of bad influences in their lifetime, but it should be the parent's job to teach their kids to say no and stay away from bad things. Kids can learn much worse things from something at the library by just sitting at home. Libraries are places for use by the public, and the public covers a wide range of different kinds of people, so someone will always find something bothersome with something or another. People have different views, beliefs, and religions, and books on these topics might be offensive to some but not to others. Like the quote by Katherine Paterson said, if we take off the shelves every book or material that someone finds offensive, there will be no books in the libraries at all. Yes, there are books that are not always very presentable to a certain group of people, but they should have the right to be read if there is someone who wants to read them. It is not the library's job to be prejudiced against certain books because someone doesn't agree with them. Books should have a wide variety like the people who are reading them. Additionally, children are protected from books if they have learned morals that allow them to make mature choices.

I believe that any book or movie in the library is there for a good reason. The world is full of things that can both hurt and uplift a person. While there may be content that is not suitable for children, it is important to understand that exposure to various aspects of life is inevitable as they grow older. Parents may have different comfort levels regarding what their children are exposed to, but it is essential to remember that books and movies are a reflection of real life. They provide valuable insights into the world and help children understand the complexities of life. It is crucial to strike a balance between protecting children from harmful content and allowing them to learn and grow through exposure to diverse perspectives. Ultimately, books and movies should not be removed from libraries just because they depict aspects of life that may be uncomfortable for some, as they play a vital role in shaping a child's understanding of the world.

Debates are a main part of our society today. Everyone has an opinion on how things should be in the world, and no one is necessarily right. Books that show how other cultures behave, that to the people being described in the book may seem offensive, are important because we as people need to absorb as much as we can about other cultures. Our businesses are in other countries, many people living in different locations speak multiple languages, and people have the right to read things that may in fact be offensive to a race of people.  Businesses thrive in other countries. A lot of our countries income is from our factories and companies in other countries. Japan is a place where much business happens for the technology industry. If we, as Americans, can't learn about the Japanese, how can we learn their business methods and way of life? To the Japanese, these books may be offensive, but to us they are learning tools describing Japanese culture.  Being bilingual is a trend that millions of people adhere to. High schools require that we learn some foreign language, even if it is only the basics. The schools do this so that we can go to other countries in the work force. Learning about their language and habits comes from books. The Mexican population might not like the way we depict them in our stories, but this is necessary to learn about them.  In the United States, there are all kinds of freedoms that we as Americans use freely. Freedom of speech says that we can say whatever we want when we live in the United States. Books are not excluded from this rule. I'm sure that other countries have offensive books about us. It's a common theme around the globe.  Businesses thrive in foreign countries, so we must be able to read some books about them, even if they seem offensive. Learning new things is something that every school teaches and there should be no limit to what we can learn. If a book has vulgar language and sexual scenes, it should be taken out of the children's section of the library, not banned completely. This is the same case with other populations of people. They cannot take offense to what we have to say, because worse has been said about them than what we can possibly put in a book. Learning is a necessary tool in our society and nothing should be restricted.

Books are essential to our society, holding a wealth of knowledge and playing a significant role in shaping our understanding of the world. While some may find certain content in books offensive, it is important to recognize the value of preserving diverse perspectives and ideas. Removing books that may be deemed offensive by some individuals would limit access to important information and stifle intellectual growth. It is crucial to maintain a wide range of books on shelves, allowing readers to explore different viewpoints and expand their understanding of the world. By keeping books accessible, we ensure that future generations have the opportunity to learn and grow from the knowledge and experiences shared within the pages of these valuable literary works.Books are a treasure trove of wisdom and insight, and it is imperative that we continue to embrace the diversity of perspectives they offer, even if some may find certain content challenging or controversial. Let us cherish the power of books to educate, inspire, and enlighten, and uphold the importance of preserving our literary heritage for generations to come.

In today's society, children are exposed to a plethora of inappropriate content through various mediums such as books, movies, music, and magazines. With the lack of parental guidance and supervision, it is crucial for libraries to take responsibility in filtering out inappropriate materials. One effective solution is to implement age limits on books, where librarians or national book associations can determine the suitability of content for certain age groups. Additionally, promoting the availability of educational and morally upright books can help steer children towards positive learning experiences.  When it comes to music and movies, it is essential for libraries to remove any content that is not suitable for children. By adhering to established ratings and guidelines, libraries can prevent children from being exposed to harmful language and scenes. Magazines also play a role in shaping young minds, and strict regulations should be in place to ensure that inappropriate content is not accessible to children.  As societal standards evolve, it is imperative to uphold strict restrictions on what children are exposed to in libraries. Parents may not always be fully aware or involved in monitoring their children's media consumption, making it crucial for libraries to take a proactive stance in curating appropriate materials. By setting clear boundaries and removing content that is not suitable for young audiences, libraries can contribute to the healthy development and well-being of children in today's world.

This is going to be an essay about if people finding something offensive in a library or in music that it should be censored. It is also about if you think it should be taken off the shelves because some people find it offensive. The way I look or my own opinion is that they should censor most things from libraries and music, but not get rid of it because one person finds it offensive. If you think about it, those uncensored material like books that some people find offensive might be a fit book for someone else to what they can relate to as they were growing up.  On the other hand, they should be more careful about it so when younger kids listen to the radio or are reading a book they don't get the wrong ideas. We should censor things but only with an extent and not go overboard with it. In the long run, it might help with a more clean and safe population because we are censoring things to where people don't hear bad and only hear the good in life. You never know you could make a big difference by doing that.   The reason I wouldn't go out and censor everything is because you can't stop everyone from doing it. You can always give it a try but that's one of the main reasons why I wouldn't try and get rid of it cause a certain person might find it offensive. I can understand if you took it off their shelf that someone found offensive but only move it to where no one will find it offensive.  I'm not saying it's wrong to do that but I think it could and probably would make a lot of people angry. But hey, what can I say what has the government done that we don't like or can't do anything about it. And that's all I have to say about that.

Books, movies, magazines, music, etc., make up a significant part of our entertainment system today, available in local libraries that offer a wide range of material. While some content may be deemed offensive or inappropriate for certain audiences, it is not necessary to ban such materials altogether. Instead, a more effective approach would be to create a separate section within the library for these specific materials. By doing so, individuals who wish to access this content can do so while ensuring that it is not readily available to those who may find it objectionable. This method allows for a balance between providing access to a variety of materials and respecting the preferences and sensitivities of library patrons. Ultimately, segregating offensive or inappropriate materials in their own section within the library is a practical solution that benefits all individuals seeking different types of entertainment resources.

I believe that certain materials should not be removed from the shelves due to censorship. Different sections in the library should be offered to cater to different age groups - kids, teenagers, and adults. Each section should provide content suitable for that particular demographic, allowing individuals to make their own choices based on their preferences and level of maturity. Censorship should not be imposed as it limits the variety of materials available and hinders intellectual growth. The library is a place where people should have the freedom to explore different perspectives and ideas. By maintaining a diverse collection of books, movies, and music, the library can better serve the needs and interests of its patrons. In conclusion, censorship should not dictate the content available in libraries, and individuals should have the autonomy to select materials that align with their personal preferences and beliefs.

I personally believe that materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves just because they are found offensive. The concept of offensiveness is subjective and can vary from person to person. What may be offensive to one individual may not be offensive to another. It is important to remember that we have the freedom of speech and press, and everyone has the right to express themselves through their work.  Censoring materials in libraries would limit people's access to information and entertainment. Libraries are meant to be places where individuals can explore a wide range of ideas and perspectives. By allowing a diverse selection of materials on the shelves, libraries can cater to the varied interests and preferences of their patrons.  It is crucial to respect the rights of individuals to choose what they want to read, listen to, or watch. Just because something may be offensive to some, does not mean it should be censored for everyone. People have the autonomy to decide for themselves what they find acceptable or objectionable.  In conclusion, censorship of materials in libraries would only restrict people's freedom and hinder their ability to explore different viewpoints. It is essential to uphold the principles of free speech and allow individuals to make their own choices regarding the content they engage with. Let us embrace diversity and inclusivity in libraries, rather than imposing restrictions based on subjective notions of offensiveness.

We all hope that one day our children will not pick up a book or a magazine they're not supposed to read. Children don't know any better, but should everything be censored just because there are children everywhere? I believe that we should be able to have uncensored books on the shelves. If everything was censored, we would have very limited options for reading and watching. Everyone should have the freedom to choose what they want to watch or read without censorship. Censorship in libraries is not necessary. While some materials may be offensive to some, it is a part of life, and individuals can choose not to engage with such content. Children today are exposed to more than they should know, such as cursing, and censoring materials in libraries will not prevent them from encountering such content elsewhere. Libraries should not have to censor materials based on isolated incidents. If I had the authority, I would uphold the right for libraries to have uncensored materials available. It is essential to preserve freedom of choice and access to diverse content in libraries.

Libraries offer a wide range of material for people to enjoy, from books to movies. While some believe in the need for censorship to protect certain individuals, such as children, from inappropriate content, it can also limit the freedom of others to explore diverse topics and perspectives. Everyone has different tastes and sensitivities, and what may be offensive to one person might be enlightening or thought-provoking to another. By allowing individuals to choose their own reading material, without censorship, everyone can find enjoyment in reading what truly interests them. This freedom of choice not only enhances the reading experience but also promotes a diverse and inclusive literary culture for all.

The author argues against the practice of removing books with inappropriate content from schools, believing that children can benefit from a variety of reading materials. While parents and educators may prefer educational books, children often gravitate towards books with pictures or interesting stories. By allowing children access to a range of books, they can develop a love for reading and expand their knowledge in different subjects. Ultimately, keeping a diverse selection of books available can help foster a love for reading and learning in children.

I do not think that materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. People have different views and beliefs on certain topics, influenced by religion, culture, and sexuality. What may be offensive to one person could be informative and enlightening to another. Removing offensive materials sets a dangerous precedent, as everyone has their own perspectives and sensitivities. It is important to respect diverse opinions and allow individuals to make their own choices about what they consume. Censorship limits access to knowledge and stifles freedom of expression, which are fundamental principles in a democratic society. Instead of banning offensive materials, individuals can simply choose not to engage with them if they find them objectionable. Ultimately, the availability of a wide range of materials enriches our understanding of the world and encourages critical thinking. Letting people make their own decisions about what they read, watch, or listen to is essential for promoting intellectual freedom and fostering a culture of open dialogue and debate.

Yes, we should keep books, music, movies, and magazines on the shelves. Magazines and music serve important purposes, such as helping with concentration and providing valuable information for schoolwork. It is essential to have access to these resources in our daily lives. Taking away books or any other forms of media that contribute positively to our lives should not be a decision made by someone else. We must advocate for our right to access these materials that enrich our lives and help us learn and grow. Let's continue to fight for the preservation of books, music, movies, and magazines in our society.

I do believe that books, magazines, music, and movies should be taken off the shelf if a person wants to engage with them. These forms of entertainment are meant to be experienced, whether through reading, listening, or watching. Books and magazines offer knowledge, entertainment, and inspiration, while music and movies provide a way to relax, learn, and be inspired. By actively using these resources, we can expand our horizons, learn new things, and be entertained in different ways. Therefore, it is important to take these items off the shelf and make the most of what they have to offer. So, let's not just let them sit there but instead, pick them up, enjoy them, and discover the amazing things they have to offer.

People have different ideas of what can be offensive to them, whether it's books, movies, or music. It's important to respect others' opinions and not discriminate against them for their choices. Books can provide valuable insights and learning experiences, even if they touch on sensitive topics. Similarly, movies can help us understand different perspectives and historical events, even if they are difficult to watch. Music is a form of expression, and artists should be allowed to share their feelings, even if it includes controversial content. It's essential to keep an open mind and be willing to learn from various sources, even if they may be offensive to some. Respect for differing opinions and the freedom to explore different viewpoints are crucial in promoting understanding and growth.
